name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027 and own resources (2018/2714 (RBS).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on 2 May, the Commission tabled its long—awaited proposals for the future Multiannual Financial Framework. They represent one of the most important files we will work on in the coming months. The file is considered a top priority by this Presidency, working in close cooperation with the future Austrian and Romanian Presidencies.  As agreed in February, once all the sectoral proposals are available, the European Council will return to the issue of the MFF and the timeline for the negotiation. This discussion will take place at the June European Council meeting. In the meantime, the Presidency started working at full speed on the MFF package. After a first political discussion at the level of Ministers on 14 May, experts now meet every week to review the proposals in detail. But work doesn’t stop in the Council. We are all very much aware that cooperation with Parliament will be essential to concluding this file in a timely manner.  For this reason, as soon as we receive the proposals from the Commission, my Prime Minister wrote to President Tajani to establish proper ways of communication. As you can see from the letter of Prime Minister Borissov, the Presidency and future presidencies are committed to keeping Parliament informed about the progress in the Council and to regular exchange of views between the two institutions. This will be key to making sure that we understand each other’s expectations and constraints. In that spirit, we have already met twice with Parliament’s negotiating team. It was very important for us to get the process off to a good start. We look forward to more frank and fruitful exchanges with your representatives in June on the margins of the next General Affairs Council. Before I conclude, I would like to add a word on the substance of the MFF debate. The discussion will seem to be about money, but in fact it will be about shared priorities. Behind the figures, the debate will be about our policy choices and where we expect the European Union to act in the next seven years. It is already clear that we will have to find the right balance between the new priorities and the traditional policies. The policy choices will determine the structure, the size and the resources of the next financial framework. The Presidency is fully committed to giving a dynamic start to the examination and the discussion of the proposals.  Expectations are high for this Multiannual Financial Framework. This is about the future of Europe. But challenges are equally high, and let us not forget the need to achieve unanimity in the Council. The first step will be to understand what the Commission proposals really mean. For that, we need clear information from the Commission. I gather that there were questions in Parliament about the figures presented by the Commission. We had similar questions, and I am confident that today Commissioner Oettinger will provide us with further information on it.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. Having drafted our proposal for the next decade's budget on 2 May, starting today until 14 June, we will finalise the wealth of sectoral implementing rules in the College and then forward it to you. This means that I can confirm today that we will have all the sectoral regulatory proposals on the table of your House and the Council on 14 June. Today, for example, the cohesion policy package and, later this week, the major agricultural policy package will be called for final consultation in the Commission. Since 2 May — taking the priorities, priorities, programmes and equipment with money — there has been a wealth of criticism. One says that the 1.114 frame is too small — others say: it is far too high. Some say that cuts in agriculture and cohesion are far too small — others say that cuts are unacceptable. We have proposed doubling Erasmus+. Some say: a tripling would be indicated. We are increasing research projects and digital innovation projects by up to 50% — some say that is far too little. I have also looked at the resonance in many Member States. I would like to ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to help me — because I need unanimity in the Council at the end of the day — and also where the Commission's proposal is considered too high on commitments of 1.14% in the dimension — Sweden, Denmark, perhaps Finland, the Netherlands, Austria. Because these are partly the countries in which your constituencies are. Only if we succeed together in achieving autonomy in the Council will the whole thing have a chance. The Commission's proposal is 1.14%. To put it ahead, I actually think both are moderate. Here I say very clearly: our European citizens generate EUR 100 through handwork, mental work and investment. Of this, we deduce €50 from them through levies, taxes, fees and contributions — that is the government ratio on the European average. Of the EUR 50, EUR 1 currently arrives in Europe and EUR 49 will remain in Paris, Warsaw, Berlin, Rome, Stuttgart, Linz, in rural areas and in social systems. That is why I say that the fabric of the European level — the European level, the national level, the regional level, the local level, the social level — does not go beyond. Nevertheless, we have to realise that — I am quite sure — we have no chance in the Council at 1.3. Secondly, with your March report, you called for a lot of what is included in our draft: new priorities, defence, migration, border management, increased investment in research, innovation, Erasmus+. This is exactly what we have achieved with our proposal. But they say no cuts in the CAP and cohesion. I tell you quite frankly: if a large net contributor — if the UK's large economy — leaves, then it's a game changer. You cannot pretend to keep all the programmes the same, tackle new tasks and want to add more investment to some new priorities. That is why we believe that moderate cuts, without damaging the programmes, are necessary in cohesion and in agriculture, the two largest programmes. I am convinced that everything else is lagged from realism. Now, over the past few weeks, we have had an intensive exchange on how to get these figures. First of all, the absolute numbers are indisputable. The annual proposed investments are set in euros and cents for the financial years 2014 to 2020 and for the next MFF — without any dispute. Dispute can arise if you want to evaluate cuts as a percentage. What does our calculation look like? We took the MFF 2014 to 2020, and we deducted from each programme what goes to the UK during these years — research projects with Oxford, Cambridge and London, second pillar: CAP for rural areas, direct payments for farmers in the UK; cohesion programmes or even the European Social Fund for regions in the United Kingdom. And so we came to a virtual EU-27 budgetary framework for 2014 to 2020, as farmers in Austria, Poland and Germany cannot expect to get more from the money that has gone to the UK so far to come to them. We have not cut for some programs. We didn't cut Galileo. After all, the investment in satellites for navigation technologies is the same for 27 countries as for 28 countries. Galileo will be more expensive, but it will remain important — so no cut here. Then we compared the last year in this MFR-2020 — and the first year in the next MFF. Because this is what our partners feel and people feel. What do we pay the farmer in 2020 for direct payments per hectare? And what can you pay the year after? And here — in 2020 and then in 2021 — we are coming to cuts in agricultural policy of exactly —4.6%. Since the proposal, if adopted this week, provides for slightly stronger cuts in the second pillar and lower cuts in the first pillar of direct payments, but proposes a little more flexibility for our Member States between the two pillars, we will see cuts of exactly -3.9% in direct payments in 2021. Cohesion is now about the implementing rules that are being discussed by the Commission today. There is a so-called Berlin model, which dates from 1999. This has been updated and modernised each time in the three MFF consultations. We're holding on to that. We wanted to ensure that cohesion policy is not too big winners and too many losers. But one thing can be said: the new Member States, in particular, have used cohesion policy correctly in 2005 to date, have significantly increased their GDP per capita, are coming up to the average. Countries such as Slovakia, the Baltic countries or Poland are getting less money in our MFF proposal for cohesion policy because they have become more competitive because they have grown economically. Others who have been in stagnation longer in recent years, such as Italy, are getting more money. We need a formula for this whole that still bears the idea of solidarity and the strengthening of the weak. I firmly believe that the new Member States will exceed the GDP per capita of the European average in the course of the next MFF — and indirectly can also become so-called net contributors. Cohesion policy has thus shown its success, I believe. They suggest that we abolish the discounts — we do that, but in stages. Even if colleagues in this House who are Members from the Netherlands would be frightened by cancelling the reimbursement of customs duties and discounts from now on tomorrow. This brings me to the final point. Member States' payments increase by more than 30% in nominal form. Why? If you set up a budget for 2019 and compare it to 2018, you have growth rates of 2%, 3% — no one cares. But if you compare the first year of the current MFF 2014 with the last year of the next year — 2027 — you will have 14 years of increase in research salaries, increase the cost of steel for gas pipelines, increase in construction costs for civil engineering, roads, railways and buildings, increase salaries for commissioners and deputies. Therefore, the disadvantage of a seven-year budgetary framework is that the figures are automatically significantly higher in nominal terms, not in real terms. Seven years means seven years of inflation. Makes 11% — 12% nominal increase without real increase in purchasing power. Seven years of GNI increase is +16%. This automatically brings us to a nominal increase of 27 — 28% in the next MFF at the current MFF, without any real increase in purchasing power. This means that +27% is automatically a prerequisite if Europe's budgetary framework is not to lose its relevance. Then comes the Brexit gap, which we want to close half by cuts in the CAP and cohesion areas and halfway through slightly higher payments. This is the third reason for a higher MFF. The fourth reason is the elimination of discounts, which is added for some Member States. And the fifth reason is new tasks. We propose to invest more than 13 billion in defence, to allocate far more for migration, and to increase Frontex to 10 000 employees for border management and control. And all of these reasons — an increase in BNE inflation, no more rebates, the Brexit gap and new challenges — mean that the next budgetary framework will rise nominally — not real — by at least 30% for Member States, and even more than 40% for some. So far a few words of clarification. I am grateful to the House for your work — rapporteurs and other Members of the Committee on Budgets, in all the committees — to address the issue. I want to tell you that farmers and research, mayors and regions, as well as our partners in development aid, want clarity as soon as possible. That is why I will continue to maintain the ambitious timetable from now until Easter next year, when this Parliament completes its work. With the goodwill of Parliament — it is there — and in the European Council, we have a chance to show in March next year that the British are leaving, and yet Europe is showing its will to act and its ability to act on a highly complex issue. I would ask you to help to show this sign of good governance, of European capacity for action, using the example of the multiannual financial framework from now until March next year.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! The debate on the multiannual financial framework is one of the key debates on the future of the European Union for Parliament. When discussing the longstanding financial perspective, we ask ourselves, which scenario of President Juncker do you want to implement with your proposal? That's the question we ask ourselves today when we wonder not about the numbers, but wonder about what's behind those numbers. Are we facing a widening of priorities at the moment, or are we facing a change in priorities, essentially a change in the priorities of the European Union? At the moment we look at the numbers that come to us, it is clearly apparent that there is a change in priorities, that some of the priorities are being replaced by other priorities. Little of that, there is a change in policies. What we will see today will probably show that there is no reduction in cohesion policy, but there is also a change in cohesion policy, as Commissioner Crețu confirmed yesterday. This is just a different policy. We therefore expect a serious debate from the Council on what Union we expect, what policies are to rely on in the future, not just as much money in the budget, only what European policy is to rely on in the future and how we will carry out some of our tasks. I would like to say at the end, Commissioner, you are calling for our rational behaviour. We uphold one three as a basis for conversation. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ashley FOX
text: blue-card question. – Would Mr Olbrycht agree with me that allowing the United Kingdom to continue to participate in the Galileo system after Brexit not only improves the security of all 28, but will also allow the EU to make better use of its resources in the next financial framework? And seeing that Mr Farage is in his seat, can I ask colleagues here not to be provoked. I suspect that he has come here to annoy and provoke you and to damage the interests of the United Kingdom.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — We recognise that it is in the interests of the European Union to establish as convenient conditions as possible for cooperation with the UK as long as possible, of course, the mutual backlog is very precisely settled. Whereas, when it comes to the future, any solution based on good cooperation will benefit us all. This also applies to Galileo.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Dear colleagues, We've been behind the time for a while. I would therefore ask for your understanding that if someone does not keep the speaking time, I will not allow a blue card for the speaker concerned.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the European institutions cannot adopt a budget for the future which we will cut in cohesion and convergence. This is just unacceptable, and we need to take into account the situation we have. Of course we need to address the challenges, but we need absolutely to keep a budget which reduces social inequalities and keeps the opportunity to invest in the future. This should happen for the European Union as a whole, but also for the eurozone. And let me make a special call on the European Commission, which is adopting in two days, finally, something to equip the eurozone with fiscal capacity. You need to be bold, because the eurozone has been suffering with deep divergences for many years. Look to the situation we now have in Italy. We are on the brink of a disaster – an economic, social, political disaster. Some call for leaving the eurozone in order to leave austerity. They are wrong. Others are calling to accept to stay in the eurozone, as it deals with austerity. They are also wrong. The solution we need to have is to reform the eurozone to make it a space where people can invest in the future and have again confidence in the future, and we Social Democrats have a full plan for this, and will be criticising all those who are opposing this necessary reform. So the Commission has this opportunity. We need to have a fiscal capacity able to support investment in the future, to support upward economic and social convergence and to protect people from shocks. This is the moment to send this message, because we cannot play with fire.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! After your speech today, you can note that there is really little left from the optimism with which you presented the draft financial framework for 2021-27. Firstly, because very nervously the increase in the burden was reacted by net payers, I will not be naming prime ministers of countries that have taken a decidedly voice on this issue. In turn, the constraints on expenditure in cohesion policy and in the common agricultural policy have been very badly received in the newly adopted countries into the European Union. If this information is confirmed and all points to the fact that these cuts to Central and Eastern European countries in cohesion policy will be higher than 20%, clearly such a constructed budget will not be able to be adopted. I will just remind you that the original idea of the contributions of wealthy countries to the Cohesion Fund was access to the markets of the newly adopted countries. With this access, these countries have received improbable benefits, these benefits continue so far. Consequently, the proposed constraints on cohesion policy are unsimilar to this original idea. Finally, I will point out inequality in agriculture. This inequality must be leveled, otherwise agriculture of Central and Eastern European countries will be able to consider that it is discriminated against and that is incompatible with the treaties

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to say that, in our view, the Commission proposal is a serious basis for negotiation. But I cannot hide before you and this House that the debates in my group have been sharp and even difficult, both in terms of the overall rate of increase in appropriations and the cuts proposed in cohesion policy and the CAP. Some firmly support the cuts you advocate, others radically oppose it. Clearly, there will be a complex and difficult debate. I am convinced that the final outcome will depend not only on the amount that will be spent on these policies but, fundamentally, on the quality of the new arrangements that will be put in place. Having said that, all members of my group are determined to find the right path for the future of the Union. It is not yesterday's Europe that must be maintained, it is the Europe of tomorrow that must be built. It is in this spirit that we strongly support the doubling, or even tripling, of appropriations for an Erasmus extended to apprentices, the doubling of support programmes for SMEs, the increase of more than 50% in appropriations for research and innovation, the increase to an unparalleled level of appropriations for the management of external borders — a common border is managed jointly — the creation of new financial means to support investments and, finally — you will not be surprised by the co-rapporteur — own resources. We support the Commission's proposal to introduce a package of own resources, the only way, with the effective implementation of the principle of European added value, to reduce the contributions of national budgets to the financing of the Union and thus increase the legitimacy and autonomy of the European Union.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the time was right to come forward with an ambitious budget proposal. Economic recovery, although uneven, is there as are growing challenges and new priorities. The urgent need to counter euroscepticism by showing that the EU matters and delivers is there and even some of the most influential Member States said that they were ready to put more money into the budget to fill, and even go beyond, the Brexit hole.  Instead of that, and with the exception of some limited improvements, we have a budget proposal that cuts spending in crucial EU policies and falls short of ambition both in volume and in content. I ask myself: where is the road map and what is the framework for this budget? What is the rationale behind the numbers? If we want the European Union to be the frontrunner in implementing the UN Sustainable Development Goals, why is there no clear commitment to that end in the MFF proposal? If we want the EU to lead the energy transition and the fight against climate change, why don’t we set priorities and have spending goals that are more ambitious? If we actually agree that the EU should be an instrument to fight against growing social inequalities, why then reduce the European Social Fund by 6% and have more spending in military research, but less in social justice? I don’t think that these are the right priorities.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it must be very good news for the European Commission that the Brexit hole is nowhere near as bad as you thought it was going to be. The EUR 40 billion that Ms May has agreed to pay over the course of the next few years must help and, of course, as we speak she is desperately scrambling to get us back into a whole series of EU programmes in your next budgetary period and, no doubt, will pay more for that. Perhaps what is even better news, Commissioner, is that the Prime Minister now wants a two-year extension of the transition phase. I can only assume that, if that effectively means full membership for a further two years, that EUR 40 billion would now become EUR 60 billion. I would like your confirmation that extended transition will mean a bigger bill. But perhaps the reality is that Brexit is not the biggest problem that the European Union now faces. Italy, of course, has been mentioned, and they are net contributors to this budget; they pay in about EUR 4 billion every single year. There are signs that in Italy, voters are tiring of paying that money. They question what the euro has done to their economy, they feel they are a victim of the European Union’s immigration policies and, as a result of all this, they voted in a new government, only to find that bullying and hectoring from the European Commission has been listened to by the Italian President. In the last 48 hours their democracy has been traduced. In the past, you managed to bully the Danes, you bullied the Irish, you bullied the Greeks into submission. I suspect with Italy today you have now bitten off more than you can chew. Bring on more elections and bigger eurosceptic victories. (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Lara COMI
text: Question 'blue card'. — Honourable colleague, I thank you for your speech, but perhaps there have been some dystonias you have not received well in your country. Do you know that both the 5 Star Movement and the League defined that they did not want to exit the euro and not want to get out of Europe? So to be pro-European forces and ready to change Europe as we want it to change all of us, but staying inside?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – It was said a few years ago that I was the European Union’s worst nightmare because I wanted Britain to leave the European Union. I suspect that actually two Italian political parties that want to stay inside the European Union but want to change immigration rules and their ability to control their own budget are actually an even bigger problem for a centralised Europe, and as history goes on, once the British have left, you’ll think, ‘gosh, they were really easy compared to this Italian Government’.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the message that the European Commission sends to citizens with this proposal, in my view, is a dangerous message, it is the evidence of a drift undemocratic of the European institutions. And that risks being an even stronger message in relation to what happened over the weekend in Italy, where a minister was rejected for his ideas of change in Europe. Connecting European budget funds to decisions in Brussels, to Brussels diktats, is a truly dangerous message. Heading II Cohesion and Values, the Structural Reform Fund, other funds that must be linked to compliance with policies or crazy reforms proposed by Brussels, are not the correct message. The failure to respond to the needs of citizens that the European Union has must not result in blackmail. The answer that the Union must give is a concrete response in its policies, it cannot blackmail the citizens. I hope that the next Italian government will reject the proposal on the multiannual financial framework. (The speaker agrees to answer a question 'blue card' (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: blue-card question. – I am afraid that you are representing the wrong choice for Italy, because you are suggesting that in the end, Italy should follow the Brexit example. We really believe that it is possible to change the eurozone for the better. So what are your plans for this?

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Answer to a question “blue card”. — The first thing I hope the next Italian government will do is to reject this proposed multiannual financial framework, where more money is being asked from citizens Italy, which is a net contributor to the European Union budget, and where these funds are conditional on compliance with Brussels diktats. For example, as I said in my speech, heading II “Cohesion and Values”: connecting the disbursement of funds to respect the diktats in Brussels is a folly that risks an undemocratic drift of institutions. This I hope will be first step of the next government. (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, in 1976 ABBA released its famous song Money, Money, Money, with its lyrics ‘it must be funny living in a rich man's world’. Well Mr Oettinger you and the European Union must have adopted ABBA’s song as the new EU anthem, as the UK leaves the EU instead of cutting the budget you increase it by 192 billion to 1.135 trillion. It is this lack of economic sense that will bring down the EU and the euro. Instead of dealing with 25% of EU poverty and social funds, you increase an EU army budget. Instead of closing the borders in 2014, you increase now the cost of immigration and asylum to Europe by 392%. The EU's problem is that you think there is a magic money tree – there isn't. If you don't spend less maybe the EU and other countries within the EU will adopt another song by ABBA – SOS – or like the UK, Hasta Mañana. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you Mr Woolfe for answering my question. Would you agree with me that now the Italian President is taking his orders from the European Union and Italy is a vassal state of the European Union, would you not say it's high time the Italians – and the two parties who are now hoping to take government – that it's high time they went for Italian exit as we are? What do you think sir?

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you Mr Coburn. The Italian people spoke for themselves when they decided to vote for the Five Star Movement and Lega Nord. They made a choice of a democracy to have their own government make their decisions for them. Any institution outside of Italy that infringes their own democratic rights are wrong, but it is up to the Italian people to make the choice of what they want, and they should listen to their own government, not the President acting on others’ behalves. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! I would comment on the entirety of the proposal based on my own experience, but I have to limit myself to the income issue Good thing the attempt to reform own resources has been made. The European Parliament consistently encourages this, knowing that corporate memory in the Commission is not very encouraging in view of previous experience. They also enjoy the positive signals coming from Vienna. For the most depends on the Austrian Presidency, and chances are that the negotiations will also include income issues. The proposal is more modest than we expected. The new own funds are supposed to deliver 12% of income and the membership contribution will decrease by that much. Of course, excitement arouses the very basket of candidates for these Among them is one that is supposed to deliver just 2% of total income, a proportion of ETS income. I would like to signal that perhaps it is not worth opening a serious front for those 2%, because for several countries they may be without a chance when it comes to own resources. Nor are the forward-looking candidates mentioned in previous versions of your documents, i.e. FTT and the taxation of the digital economy. In contrast, my surprise is raised by such early signalling of corrections for five countries and a reduction in membership dues, because usually such matters are left for the last, hot night of negotiations. I wish you the best of luck! (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the “blue card” procedure. — Dear colleague, I appreciate your intervention, but I would like to ask you something. The Commissioner presented that the Commission's proposal is to cut funds from the cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy and the European Social Fund. (President interrupted speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Grapini! That's not the game. Interim questions or questions should be addressed to the respective speaker. If you wish to put any questions to the Commissioner, that is a different format. We have the procedure of spontaneous interventions.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure. — The question was whether you agree that the right thing was done by cutting off the three funds, which, in my opinion, hold the European Union together. The Cohesion Fund is needed, the common agricultural policy is needed. Is it normal to cut off from these funds? That was the question.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — The position of the European Parliament is different in this matter, namely the traditional divisions of cohesion and agriculture cannot be cut in favour of the new challenges of the European Union, and we will defend this position in difficult negotiations.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, after a rapid assessment of the proposal for the new financial framework on 2 May, today we have the opportunity to discuss its content much more in-depth and I would like to make a few comments. First of all, I think this proposal is missing a story, a strategy. What do we want to achieve with this financial framework? What is the message we want to send to Europeans? And above all, how are we going to respond to the challenges and ensure that we are going to fulfil our commitments? I remember Mr Juncker in the last debate saying that the wind was already blowing in favour of the European Union and that it had to be exploited. And after seeing this proposal, another phrase is coming to my mind that “There is no favorable wind if you do not know where it is going.” And we don't have to invent any direction. We have the sustainable development goals, seventeen goals common to the whole planet. And I would like the proposal for a financial framework to have reflected this strategy. Because how are we going to promote responsible production or combat desertification if we reduce agricultural funds by 16%? Or how are we going to reduce inequalities if we reduce cohesion funds by 12%? Or how are we going to end poverty or promote decent work if we reduce the European Social Fund? Or how are we going to achieve equality if we do not have budgets that tell us what the impact of our policies is on the promotion of gender equality or on the empowerment of women and girls? There is none of this in this proposal. I believe that they have limited themselves to balancing the Brexit accounts with some reinforcement in Erasmus and innovation, introducing security as a new priority and cutting the pillars of European policies. We already know that there is reluctance on the part of certain governments. We already know that, in addition to will, resources are needed, and that is why we have made a revolutionary proposal for the European Union's revenues: let companies pay more, let speculators pay and make countries pay for their wealth. In the state of the Union debate, Juncker remembered Kohl and Delors, and said that Europe is moving forward when it exhibits its audacity, and I don't... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, how much will the European Union spend over the coming years and where will these pennies go? The European Commission's proposal has come on the table and the question is: does it deserve a compliment or are you being praised? Let us be honest, when it comes to the penny, the European Union still does not have a good reputation. And that is actually because Europe does not dare to make choices. The differences between East and West, between North and South, these differences are not settled, which are bought off. Cleaning up doesn't seem to be possible either. Yes, there are new and important priorities in the European Union: stopping migration, for example, and security. Let us start funding these new priorities effectively — even heavily financed — but in a sensible way, by removing outdated priorities first, by really shifting resources within the European budget. But no, the European Union does not dare to make a strong choice either. There is one choice that Europe dares to make, and that is to ask for more money from its citizens and even introduce new European taxes. Colleagues, that's not how it works. If Europe fails to prove its added value, people will only become more critical. I would therefore like to conclude by calling on the European Commission, to Mr Oettinger. Tomorrow, Wednesday, you will present a statement on the use of European accession aid in Turkey. Make that statement a real statement. Turn that European accession crane towards Erdogan. Only then will you really deserve praise and strengthen the support for the European Union. (The speaker answered a blue card question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card issue. — You had a bit of a cynical attitude towards this EMF. But there was one spot of light in it when you said that you had to be able to fund new priorities. I would ask you, what do you think are the things that need to be directed to more resources?

name: Sander LOONES
text: 'Blue Card' answer. — (NL) In all fairness, I find it a little sad that we still have to ask that question. If it is not yet clear what the citizens of Europe want, when will it be clear? Of course, we must close our borders, we must invest more in our security, we must ensure that there is a growth-friendly climate and we should spend much less time on energy, the environment and all other dossiers. I hear debates about all sorts of things that Europe should not be working on. We must concentrate on those issues where European cooperation can really make a difference.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome your commitment and energy, and assure you that we will do everything to accompany you and give Europe a budget that will enable it to meet the challenges of globalisation. But we are committed until 2027... Do we think that with a budget of 1.08% or 1.30% of GDP, we will achieve our goals? Today we are faced with major challenges posed by globalization. When it comes to migration, how to dry up migratory sources? We have challenges in the field of security, defence, climate protection, cyber attack prevention, digital economy. How come there is no European giant in the digital sector? One could also mention space policy. In these circumstances, we will not be able to continue to ask for more money from the Member States. Is it not time, Commissioner, to see that, in certain areas, expenditure at national level is no longer effective and will only be effective if it is now committed at European level? Can we foresee that if tomorrow we raise the budget to 2 or 3% of European gross domestic product, it will not be an increase in European public expenditure, because we will cease to incur certain expenditure at national level and commit them jointly at European level? We will therefore not increase European public expenditure, we will have greater efficiency and you will have the argument for demonstrating European added value. Yes, Commissioner, we need a Europe that prepares our future, a Europe that protects us, a budget that is consistent with our ambitions and our vision. (He agreed to answer a question “blue card” (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure for the 'blue card'. Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Arthuis, because I believe he has put it well in a nutshell: it is about European added value. One of the issues is, of course, unemployment in Europe. I believe that the programmes that combat unemployment will be the focus here. Mr Arthuis, do you believe that these programmes should be significantly strengthened in the future, such as the COSME programme, which gives small and medium-sized enterprises in particular the opportunity to create new jobs here?

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: answer 'blue card'. — (FR) Mr Rübig, the euro area cannot be limited to a single monetary policy with the addition of national policies. We need more coherence and we need more resources for the competitiveness of businesses, especially SMEs. I would also like Europe to have an ambition for vocational training for young people. We have a problem of youth unemployment in Europe: on average, one in four young people is unemployed, but in some countries they are almost one in two young people. So, yes, I would like a programme for vocational training and apprenticeship to be developed and that Erasmus be multiplied by three times so that apprentices also have access to long mobility.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. The European Parliament has called for a 30% increase in the budget, while the Commission has requested 11%. This is not an end in itself, we did it because we know that we have greater tasks ahead of us. Members have just mentioned a great deal: climate policy, the fight against unemployment, in particular youth unemployment, internal and external security, more for education, social inclusion and the stabilisation of Africa, so that not so many people have to get on their way. So we are facing great challenges. That's why we need more money, not because we're in love with a higher budget. The key thing in the European Council now will be: will you be able to recognise the common European interest in all national interests? Otherwise, there will be no ambitious MFF, and we absolutely need it if we are to play a responsible role in the global world of the 21st century as the European Union. That's why we need the digital tax. Right now, after the Zuckerberg consultation, it has become clear that we need to regulate the digital monopolies appropriately, and that is also with the digital tax.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: — Mr President, for Europe, this budget is only setting the course for austerity. He sacrificed France's interest, since France will continue to pay the British rebate until 2025. Amazing! And she will continue to pay the discount on the discount granted to other countries, including Germany. It's an injustice! And nothing can justify this injustice, especially since France is committed to an increase in the European budget. The bill, for France, is heavy. It is all the more severe as subsidies are foreseen at the level of the CAP and cohesion policy, which will hit French farmers and the French regions hard. So you can make up this budget any way you want, this budget is bad for Europe, it is bad for France.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we had been allowed to express in Italy a Minister of Finance who, in fact, shortly before being removed by the President of the Republic in Italy, who did not wanted to appoint him, this candidate of ours would have proposed to the European Commission and the European Council of extremely pro-European instruments, such as tax transfers or eurobonds, to try and really stabilize the eurozone, and not these paltry instruments put there by this Commission proposal, or 30 billion that the Member States will have to put in order to have a little help in return, with own money itself, in exchange for very burdensome structural reforms in terms of wage devaluation, in terms of unpopularity, what the citizens did not ask for. Our minister would have also asked that there had been protection, perhaps, even for small farmers by not reducing the funds for agriculture and also not reducing the cohesion which is still fundamental to especially help depressed areas of the eurozone. You have given up a great opportunity to change the EU and, with the next election, probably in Italy the eurozone will be... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Today, when we debate the multiannual financial framework, we also have to ask ourselves how the European institutions are meeting this financial challenge. In my view, the key would be for a corresponding redimensioning, which means that, on the one hand, we are going to halve the Commission. With 28 and 27 Commissioners, they wonder what such bloated administration can make an efficient difference. And take a look at the guidelines here: from shower heads, tractor seats to different levels of browning in French fries — we're on the wrong path. In my view, a redimensioning would also be good for the European Parliament. Now that the British are not just going to save the British seats here, but even add them, this is the wrong way. Here too, we could go towards halving and thus strengthen the efficiency of this House and the parliamentary discourse accordingly. It is also bad in this development to centralise the budget to continue with the payment of pre-accession aid to Turkey and thus to take a wrong path. I hope that the European Union's financial policy will go in the right direction for the coming years.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the European Parliament wants a Europe cohesive from a territorial and social point of view, a united Europe and a European Union that is competitive, secure and supportive. And this word has to be translated into concrete actions. We cannot say that cohesion policy works well and has increased gross domestic product in a number of countries, and even helps all the other Member States, and then we will cut off that cohesion policy and, more seriously, we cut off those who need it most, cut off the poorest. I believe that the 45% cut in the cohesion fund, which is allocated to Member States with less than 90% of gross national income per capita, is unacceptable. What works well must continue: cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy and, in particular, rural development. A cut also of 25% is incomprehensible. No one will be able to explain to voters, for example, that the poorest Member States will have higher cuts than the richer Member States. We need solidarity to be a de facto solidarity. The added value of the budget is more than proven: in the European Union budget, 94% is investment and only 6% are current expenditure, or rather administration and operating expenditure.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Since there has just been a little misunderstanding, let me explain this again: if I take someone's word because he speaks too long, I will not give an opportunity for a blue card. Nor will I allow blue cards within the same faction. That is why Mrs Thomas is speaking next.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Council for reminding us that the multiannual financial framework is not only a matter of money, but first of all the backbone of the future of the Union. The resolution on which we are going to vote is the reaffirmation of Parliament's demands on the means necessary to meet our future challenges and therefore finance the Union's future programme. It also recalls our intention to negotiate the next multiannual financial framework right now. Finally, it recalls the MFF's unwavering link with own resources because, indeed, money does not grow on trees. I start with a warning: there is no time to waste. But I regret the play of fooling the Commission in presenting its proposal: figures presented in their best light abusively, hidden cuts, elements of language, which are certainly sharpened, but which have not deceived anyone. Let us be serious and responsible, compare what is comparable and validate one method, one, with inflation and without the UK. Faced with Parliament's redemonstrations, the Commission has decided to publish calculations with the real figures. What are they? Less 15% for the CAP, minus 10% for cohesion — the first investment policy — minus 27% for the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, minus 6% for the European Social Fund — a priority — and up to minus 45% for the Cohesion Fund. Your real proposal is therefore at 1.08%, which is a share of the European budget in the Union's GDP which, compared to the current situation, is less than 1.13% in the EU27. And of course, solidarity policies sacrificed. I conclude by summarizing Parliament's resolution: on the one hand, who does not see the new challenges facing the European Union? Ecological transition, investment, migration, unemployment, defence, security. Commissioner, let us not lie to the Europeans that Europe will be able to provide solutions without increasing the European budget. Europe is dying of this hypocrisy and this makes the bed of nationalisms. Parliament is clear: let us invest in European ambition. As for own resources, we recognise that the Commission's proposal is in the right direction despite, finally, a sickly shyness. We ask the Council once again: it is time to start negotiations so that we... (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: — Mr President, the Commission is proposing a more sustainable budget and an increase in the level of climate finance. Parliament would be even more ambitious in this regard. The next budget period must be in line with the Paris Climate Agreement and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Not only on paper, but also in practice. Farmers are important contributors to the EU's climate and environmental policy. This is why cutting funding for agriculture is very problematic. As demands and pressures increase, funding for agriculture cannot be cut and will also lead to the inability to implement the EU climate agreement. There is no support for a big increase in the EU budget. I consider the level of funding of 1.3% presented by Parliament to be completely unrealistic. It does not reflect the goals of the public.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, the proposal for a multiannual financial framework does not reveal anything new to us, unfortunately. It is the same European Union moving away at a faster speed from real needs. Increasing the level of expenditure by 0.08% will be insufficient. It will be unable to compensate for inequalities, reverse deindustrialization or promote the energy transition and production model. But as if that were not enough, you also cut in common agricultural policy. The common agricultural policy needs reform, not a 15% cut as you propose. A reform to reach farmers, not just landowners and agribusiness. So that it finally reaches food sovereignty. However, 17 220 million more for what you are calling security and defense. And you can call it whatever you want, but these funds are only going to criminalize migration and oversize the military industry to end the overproduction of weapons exported to conflict areas like Yemen. The Commission is devoting the European budget to armaments. That's illegal and they do not care and the Council... (The Chairman withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: — Mr President, the new budget of the European Union must not become a whip intended to whip independent, independent members of the Community. That is the case, and not otherwise, I appreciate the proposal to link the support of the European Union with respect to the principles of the so-called rule of law, invented by the euro bureaucrats. This is the first. Secondly, support for agriculture and regional policy cannot be reduced. I believe that the budget must provide the same payments for all farmers. Thirdly, the European Union must finance the closure of the Ignalina nuclear power plant by 100%, which was the contract before the closure of the nuclear power plant. Fourthly, no new taxes in the formation of the European Union budget. The people of the Member States of the Community cannot be further impoverished, at their expense, more broader migrant resettlement programmes and war industry tycoons.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Over seven years will be worth a trillion euros. You therefore believe that you have been solving the political problems into which you — the Commission in particular — have manoeuvred this European Union. The donor countries are fighting back, apart from Germany. They are thrilled to be able to transfer even more money to Europe, to Brussels. Eastern Europeans and southern Europeans — we heard this today — are asking for even more money, even more cohesion policy. And with the so-called liberals, you then completely turn over. Mr. Arthuis shot down the bird today. Liberal has recently been asking for even more state money for all the problems of the world. Mr Arthuis, it was once liberal to leave solutions to the economy, leave it to the people and not believe that the state can solve everything better. You will be problematic as in Italy, where you prevented an Economy Minister who was once a minister in the 1990s... (The President withdrew the speaker.)

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, any entity that wants to develop wants to have a budget for the future period higher than the budget of the past period. The same rule should apply to the European Union. You can reduce the budget to policies you no longer need, but you cannot, for years, praise certain policies, such as cohesion or transport, and then come up and propose a smaller budget, especially when these policies are very needed. I believe that, given the discussions you have presented to us and what is happening with the Member States is real, you have two possibilities: either apply the European Parliament proposal, with 1.3%, which I think is a decent proposal, or bring successful policies to the level, at least, of the this financial year and cut off from the new proposals, the new policies that the Member States have to support themselves.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am obliged to devote the first part of my speech to defending the honour of Italy and the honour of our President Mattarella, who has been attacked in this House in this House. way decomposed by colleagues, above all, of the League and the 5 Star Movement. We have to tell the truth to this House about what happened, because President Mattarella has avoided, in recent weeks and in recent days, avoiding the establishment of an anti-European government which is to hidden he wanted to take Italy out of the euro and out of Europe, without having told anything in the election campaign and without writing it in the electoral programme. Commissioner, if Italy had had that government, this financial framework, which must be corrected, we would have dreamed of it, we would not have had a single lira. The colleagues who have spoken before me, colleagues speaking in Italy about the multiannual financial framework, etc., have not read anything you are writing. I believe that this is very correct and I agree with my colleagues who have spoken before me about the need to step up cohesion policy and agriculture. But the reform you proposed — our colleagues should know — that would bring Italy to Italy and will bring Italy more 6% of the cohesion funds for the policies you are establishing, as reported from the “Financial Times”. I had to say to this House, because we cannot hear the words that have been heard, because we are very close to the head of state.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: — Mr President, there is a virtue in the coherence of this budget, that of austerity: less 15% for the CAP, minus 10% for social cohesion and, at the same time, priority to Frontex and defence. Of course, at a constant budget, it is difficult to cover all the challenges. Consequently, at the same time, there is another lasting breach: the abandonment of a draft financial transaction tax which, at least, would bring €60 billion a year. Same for the introduction of a real carbon tax, even though the “unprogressive” US president does not hesitate to protect his country's economy. An English proverb says that a small bird is happy with a small nest. Well, Mr President, ours is small, very small.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The Commission's draft budget is a slap in the face of European taxpayers. The EU loses a net contributor with the UK, which accounts for about 14% of the current EU budget. This drastic loss on the revenue side does not seem to interest the majority here. Rather than cutting the EU budget by at least the amount that the British will no longer finance, you are even calling for an increase in the budget by almost 18% compared to the current multiannual financial framework. The already far too fat EU is fattening while taxpayers are on a diet. This is brazen fiscal scraptocracy without any sense of proportion, it is also a European harakiri. You still have no idea what your policy is doing: you are strengthening centrifugal forces with your megalomania. The British will soon be gone, Italy will reject this budget, and you just won't learn anything about it.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: — Mr President, President Jacques Chirac said so on the environmental emergency: 'Our house is burning and we look elsewhere! '. This applies to our budget, since the Commission is proposing buckets of water to extinguish a brazier, when we need a fire hose. Of course, there have been increases and a significant effort on innovation support policies, digital technology, Community policies such as Erasmus, border protection and defence, and that is all the better. These are major expectations of our fellow citizens to which Europe must be able to provide answers. But Brexit was an opportunity to trigger a real “budget big-bang”, and the mountain gives birth with a mouse. Parliament was calling for an increase of 1.3% in gross national income, but we know very well that after the Member States' planes, we will come to the present situation. So when we talk about the added value of the European Union, I want to talk to you about health policy. This is always the adjustment variable in our budget. Therefore, when we see that this health program is again drowned among other topics, such as the integration of migrants, this is unacceptable. (The President withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Minister Panayotova. Members have already dealt sufficiently with the question of how clear or unclear the figures that the Commission has presented to us have been. In my short speech, I would like to focus on the communication from the Council. Minister Panayotova! With all the pleasure of seeing an ex-colleague here on the Council's benches — the communication that the Council is working, I can only say with some irony: thank you for this information. Where are the conflict lines in the Council? I would be interested to know how the Council enviours the financing of the next MFF if, after its meetings, it legitimately notifies us for new achievements by the EU. What are the Council's proposals on how to make the money for this? What is the position of the Member States on the European Commission's own resources proposal? This is also an important issue that concerns us. Finally, what is the Council's position on the committed timetable presented by the Commission and Parliament? Minister, this is the place of European public opinion. You will see this debate that this Parliament is struggling with the issues of the future. We hear from you: the Council is working. I would be delighted if the Council would be more involved in this debate than with this information.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council. Thank you. This is a difficult morning, I think, because it is not about the budget, not about the prospects of the EU, but everyone here is cooking their soup like this: there is an election campaign in Italy, and the anti-Europeans talk about what they always talk about. I wondered what the Commission and the Council are taking home from this debate, and I would like to come back to a few things. On the one hand, I think the MFF proposal is remarkable because it includes new tasks. We manage to really change old tasks, but not dramatically change them, and allow new tasks to open the door. I think that is remarkable, and I would like to thank you very much for that. I think it is great that Parliament's old call for the integration of the Development Fund has finally been met. And I think it is great that the Commission has presented a draft regulation on the protection of the EU budget against rule of law problems in the Member States. This is a milestone that really drives us forward. And unfortunately, unfortunately, no one has underlined this yet. I believe that we have good materials on the table and can do something with it.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, there is no doubt that the Multiannual Financial Framework will determine the future of Europe and of the European Union. It's about what we have a clear vision. We want a stronger, more social, more secure Europe, a better Europe. In order to achieve this, we must first and foremost strengthen the employment of our young people. It is a shame for a modern Europe to have young people unemployed. We cannot and must not abandon the countryside and our farmers. We need to strengthen the Social Cohesion Fund even more and not weaken it. We can't abandon defense and security. We welcome and strongly support the strengthening of defence and security, because at last the European Union must ensure the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Member States. We want small countries such as Cyprus and Malta to be supported and supported. But, Commissioner, the European Union is not just an economic union. It is based on principles and values and countries that violate principles and values, such as Turkey, cannot be financed under the Multiannual Financial Framework. I believe that it is time, Mr Oettinger, to freeze the funds in the 2019 budget and, if Turkey does not comply with principles and values, to freeze the funds of the Multiannual Financial Framework for Turkey as well.

name: Albert DESS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. I was certainly the first agricultural politician in this House to offer, in a letter to the President of the European Union, to forgo a few billion agricultural money if the EU's agricultural policy is seriously debureaucratised. Unfortunately, the proposal has not been taken up. During this parliamentary term, too, the bureaucratic burden on our rural families has increased dramatically. With regard to the share of agriculture in the EU budget, I would like to make one thing clear: if all public money in Europe, like agriculture, such as agriculture, were cleared through Brussels, then the share of agriculture would be 1% — 1% of public money for over 10 million rural families, which would account for 40 million jobs are responsible in Europe and provide half a billion people with enough food every day is a negligible proportion. Dear Günther, I'm asking you to treat agriculture here fairly, and I'm sure you will.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: — Mr President, Mr Commissioner Europe competes in the global market. And so it is quite right that the next multiannual budget provides for a significant increase in European funding for science. Because, of course, we are able to compete not with cheap labor, but with good, expensive, valuable inventions. But there is a challenge! Currently, from all science funds, Eastern European countries receive a total of only about 3%. 3%! 97% go to wealthy Europe. Colleagues, Eastern European countries are poorer than Western European countries, but their scientists are no less knowledgeable. So investing more money for science also has to change this achgany so that Eastern European scientists can work at home so they're not forced to go to some wealthier country. Let's correct this mistake by giving more money to science!

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, one of the criticisms in our countries is that Europe is too bureaucratic and too rigid, so it is important that we are able to illustrate what EU funds do for people every day. Take migration and asylum. We are dealing with an issue that has, in many quarters, been hijacked by a populist narrative. We have to be proactive – throwing money alone will not solve anything. We need to see real political will to move forward – but funds are needed. The tripling in budget is an important sign that we stand ready to address this challenge. It will help to both manage our borders, with an additional 10 000 border guards, and respond to those in need of protection. More flexibility means being able to respond effectively to unpredictable geopolitical realities. This was badly needed. On regionality, we have to make sure no citizens are left behind. I am referring specifically to islands like Gozo, where economic growth has not matched Malta’s. This cannot be ignored when it comes to EU funds. And finally on Erasmus. Doubling the funds is good, but it’s still not enough for our flagship programme that shapes hearts, minds and futures of young Europeans. Let’s be bold and reaffirm our European ideas – and there’s no better place to do that and start than from Erasmus.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that there are some positive things, but of course we are focusing on what is not working. I would like to emphasise strongly that we are against reducing the funds allocated to the CAP, and we also have doubts about the basis of the Commission's calculation. That is why we wait to read the content of the sectoral regulations to understand, but there is no doubt that the cuts will be much higher than you said today. I don't dwell — some colleagues have already said — you get to much higher figures. But speaking, for example, of own resources too, I would like to point out the Commission's inconsistency. It will be recalled that during the negotiation on the revision of the ETS directive, the Commission strongly opposed the use of these funds for indirect cost compensation, which would have given a little bit of breath to some countries, taking away internal dumping that is unacceptable! Here, and now these funds can be used for completely different things, for budgeting and not for decarbonization. That doesn't seem consistent to me.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - Madam President! Common agricultural policy is not just for farmers. Consumers benefit from it too — all of us. Thanks to the CAP, there's cheaper food. Its quality and availability is ensured. They also benefit entrepreneurs, suppliers of the means of production, as well as service providers. CAP is rural jobs. Agriculture creates renewable energy sources. It provides raw materials for industry. Finally, agriculture is food. Food is food and food is health. Agriculture also has an environmental and climate dimension. So it can be said that this is an agri-environmental-food policy. So the funds allocated to the CAP serve a number of purposes. On the other hand, you have to remember the lack of young farmers and the aging of the countryside. How could it be proposed to reduce the CAP budget by up to 15% in this situation? The share of the CAP in the entire budget is expected to decrease from the current 37% to 28% at the end of the period 2021 to 2027. I have said this repeatedly and will repeat once again: agricultural incomes are at 50% of those of other professional groups and are half-funded by EU funds. International trade agreements are mostly unfavorable to current agriculture. So what is the prospect for farmers? What do we tell them? We are very surprised that many of them vote for Europe and support populists. What will we say to farmers during the campaign to the European Parliament?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Madam President, because I am the last speaker, I will allow myself to make such a sweet dot for these performances. In the introduction, I want to highlight both your performance and the proposal for a multiannual financial framework, it seems to me that it is fairly balanced. There's a rather greater degree of flexibility, though I personally would imagine far greater so that we can respond flexibly to any problems that may occur within those seven years. The multi-year framework is also fairly close to reality, and that I think is important as well. The European Union should play a greater role in security, stability, protection of external borders, digitization, but also not forget traditional policies. The last comment I'd like to have relates to control. Commissioner, really, from the beginning of the financial framework, there is a need to emphasize greater control and a greater emphasis on European taxpayers' money being used effectively.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: — Madam President, the new financial framework is better than it is, and this shows that good work is being done. However, we must not compare the European Union with its past but on the basis of its needs and the modern world. The major challenges remain unanswered and the strong in the European Union, particularly Merkel and Macron, must do something to improve the strategy. Otherwise, with the new financial framework we will continue to lose in economic and digital competition with the US and China. We will not be able to deal with the consequences of Brexit, the great Italian crisis, the difficulties of understanding with Poland and Hungary, the continuing great difficulties in Greece. In my view, we have to be ambitious, because small improvements no longer provide solutions.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, when the Commission came to Parliament on 2 May, it announced with a great fanfare that funds for Horizon Europe would be increased by 50% and that the funds for Erasmus would be doubled. These are programmes that the UK Government has indicated that it may well wish to participate in in the future, and therefore I welcome those increases – if they are indeed increases. Because the problem we have here is that an independent analysis of those figures by the Parliament has suggested that the figures presented by the Commission are not in fact the case, and I don’t think we’ve had any kind of response to that yet. Now I regard this as very serious, because when you come to a parliament, you need to be confident that the figures you’re presenting are accurate, and there are only two reasons why they wouldn’t be – one is mendacity (it’s deliberate) and one is incompetence, and we need to know which is which, because we deserve better than that.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Respected Chair, the budget hole created by the departure of the United Kingdom puts the Union in a position of having to evaluate past policies, redistribute funds and set the right priorities. In doing so, of course, care should be taken of the future development and stability of the Union. The future of this community is not flamboyant unless we reduce the differences between the most developed members and those behind. Unfortunately, the new multi-year financial framework is failing precisely in this segment because it takes away funds from the cohesion policy that is crucial for uniform development. Projects financed by cohesion funds represent real added value, they are something tangible and real that citizens associate with the European Union. Centralisation and fragmentation of cohesion policy would therefore undoubtedly have a negative impact on the Union's reputation for citizens, which the Commission must take care of.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, the world around us is changing, and that is why it is good that the European Union is investing in new priorities, such as monitoring external borders, attacking or mitigating climate change, ensuring greater security, cybersecurity. But, as is the case with any budget, you have to make choices when it comes to drafting them. So if you need more money for something, you need to cut back somewhere else. I think it is very important that we take a critical look at the old priorities, which are going to reform, so that we can make money available to reinvest in the new priorities. What I also think is important is that we look at how the money is spent and whether it actually produces results. I think it is a really missed opportunity that this European Parliament resolution completely ignores these two aspects. The cuts proposed by the European Commission are being reversed. Everything should be left as far as possible, and there is simply a demand for extra money. That may be the easiest way, but that is not my policy, and I will not support it.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuilim an-bhuartha mar gheall ar an tslí chun tosaigh atá léirithe ag an gCoimisiún don Aontas Eorpach leis an togra don chéad bhuiséad fadtéarmach eile. Tá tosaíochtaí an Choimisiúin soiléir. Ciorruithe dosna cláir le torthaí sóisialta - an Ciste Comhtháthaithe agus maoiniú i dtaobh forbairt tuaithe, mar shampla; agus méaduithe ar chláir mhíleata agus athchóirithe struchtúracha. Cuireann an buiséad fad-téarmach seo béim ar bhagairtí seachtracha agus molann sé caiteachas míleata gan fasach roimhe seo. Bogadh a chuirfidh deireadh le neodracht na mBallstát ar nós Éire, agus a chuirfidh ceann de phrionsabail bunaithe an Aontais Eorpaigh bunoscionn. Tá an Eoraip faoi bhagairt, áfach. Tá an Eoraip faoi bhagairt ón éagothroime atá ag ardú, ó sheirbhísí sóisialta tearcmhaoinithe, ó dhífhostaíocht, ó éigeandálaí daonnúla, agus gan amhras, ó athrú aeráide. Go bunúsach, a Choimisinéir, is aistriú níos faide ó Eoraip atá bunaithe go sóisialta, a chuireann síocháin agus slándáil eacnamaíochta chun cinn, atá le feiscint insan mbuiséad fadtéarmach seo. Is é fís an Choimisiúin don Eoraip ná Eoraip ina mbeidh níos lú maoinithe dhírigh, agus níos mó ionstraimí airgeadais. Níos lú tacaíochta, níos lú dlúthpháirtíochta, agus níos mó dár n-airgead caite ar ábhair mhíleata. Mínigh é seo dár bhfeirmeoirí, a Choimisinéir.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Madam President, European funding is necessary to further strengthen economic, territorial and social cohesion between Member States and between regions. It is also essential for our agriculture. I understand, of course, the difficulties of Brexit. I know that there are also new needs — borders, immigration, defense. I am concerned, however, that cohesion and farmers may be harmed now, when populism and euroscepticism rise. I would particularly like to highlight the problem of demographic decline, that is, low birth rate and population ageing. We must also face this very serious challenge from the European Union. Throughout Europe, the fertility rate is already below 2% per woman, which does not ensure generational relay. In Galicia — in Spain — for example, it is a very serious problem. Therefore, when setting the criteria for the allocation of funds between regions, I believe that the criterion of regional GDP per capita should be complemented by others, such as demographic decline. Also with the unemployment. And it seems clear to me that the regions most affected by the crisis need to be given special attention.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: — Madam President, under the pretext of filling the economic gap created by Great Britain's withdrawal from the European Union, the new Multiannual Financial Framework provides for major cuts and cuts in key areas such as the Common Agricultural Policy and social benefits. The economic life of Europeans will therefore be negatively affected. In this sense, it is inconceivable to cut the Greeks, who are suffering from the austerity measures imposed on them, and to provide for an investment of 13 billion in defence in order to deal with a non-existent, an imaginary enemy, who is supposedly our threatens. It is also unthinkable to increase the funds to deal with migration, from which the Greeks have again suffered more than any other people in Europe, rather than entrust the Greek armed forces with the mission to protect the borders of the country, which is and borders of the European Union, from the uncontrolled influx of illegal immigrants. Finally, it is unacceptable for Turkey to be financed, a country which has such provocative and unacceptable behaviour towards the European Union and violates every concept of international law.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the data from the forthcoming post-2020 multiannual financial framework, which the Commission officially released on 18 May, show clear discrepancies with respect to ads. The announced increases for several European Union programmes are actually significantly lower, while cuts for other programmes are higher than those originally presented. Just to give two examples: the common agricultural policy and cohesion policies would be cut by 15 and 10% respectively, negatively impacting the nature itself and the objectives of these policies. Also disappointing is the proposed level of global funding, lower in real terms than the level of the current MFF, and this despite the introduction of as many as three sources of own resources, for which The times and ways should be clarified. The post 2020 MFF must be able to really respond to the needs and expectations of European citizens, and this Parliament will have to work hard to achieve the necessary level of funding key Union policies, first of all CAP and cohesion policies.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! We have received very apparent logic from the Commission. Well, if we have less money because the UK is leaving, then first of all new spending should not be triggered, even more so that it is unnecessary spending. We want a stronger, greater security for Europe, we want stronger defense. Instead of the fiction of the Common Defence Policy, please remind three quarters of our countries, which are allied in NATO, of the implementation of 2 percent expenditures on national security policy within our Atlantic solidarity. Your country of these two percent does not implement. We want the safe borders of Europe. Let us at least give political support to Hungary, Croatia, Bulgaria and Slovenia, which defend Europe's borders. Meanwhile, these states are under attack. And what do you want to do? Increase employment in the Agency. It just begs the question, will its purpose be to protect our borders or to keep an eye out that they are not protected?

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Dear Chair, we can all agree that with the UK's exit from the EU, the budget must be smaller and cuts are necessary. However, the problem is that in this budget proposal we cut certain policies on the one hand and significantly strengthen the other. We cannot completely destroy the Cohesion Fund, and especially not the Rural Development Fund in conditions of complete decay of the village. Reductions of 45% and 25% are by no means acceptable and we are thus destroying the targets and positive effects of these funds. On the other hand, programs for which all countries compete, and the most developed and least developed, and of course most of the funds go to the most developed ones, because they have better and more competitive projects. What's our goal really? Is our goal to increase differences and strengthen divisions and differences instead of togetherness and strengthening unity? These should by no means be budget messages. I know it has been difficult in these conditions to put him together, but the messages have to be different.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, I will not resort to populism, because we believe that our common future is indeed the historic challenge of our time. Tackling climate change, helping agriculture and much more are positive. The convergence of the real economy is the criterion of our success or failure. However, as young people leave the European region looking for work in other Member States within continental Europe, as Turkey continues to enjoy European funds while violating the Copenhagen political criteria — and I could say a lot more of that — unfortunately, you will not convince that this Multiannual Financial Framework is our common priorities. It's not just what we say and do, it's what we don't do. We agreed on the three pillars for the European Banking Union, they became the two and the third to bring fair competition and strengthen the South.

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would also like to thank the colleagues involved in the negotiations. As an Italian I am concerned because the instability of government does not allow us to participate incisively and decisively in these negotiations. I am also concerned about the reduction of the CAP, so I think and hope that we can find some totally useful and necessary compensation for our farmers with direct funding.
