Very well, surely, the increase for innovation, for small and medium-sized enterprises and also for Erasmus, because it is certainly important for the new generation. You see, sometimes there is a countersense, they say — some Italian colleagues say — that the European budget is not good, that cohesion funds are not good, but you see, I say to these colleagues that maybe Italy has to spend all the money the EU gives. Because for now, on many cohesion and structural funds, we spend only 60% of what Europe offers us. And then, before criticizing, it may be agreed that Italy should spend it, and surely variations will have to be made on the subject of agriculture.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, I have always regretted that the European Union is playing a little bit on budgetary and fiscal matters. The fact that these issues generally require unanimity in the Council is undoubtedly one of the major shortcomings of our European organisation because, in good democracy, Parliament should act on these issues, since it is the representative of the peoples. The consequence of the predominance of the European Parliament would naturally be the establishment of own resources independent of the goodwill of the States. These own resources are possible. A European taxation that would tackle financial transactions, carbon adjustment at borders, GAFAs and, of course, tax evasion would not affect the portfolio of European citizens and would not shake on 1%, 1.3%, an x-percentage. Perhaps I am dreaming... If only we took the initiative to make the pockets of illegal passengers in the digital economy, we would take a big step towards a Europe of trust for citizens.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — (DE) Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. Together with my staff, I have included your speeches, your expectations, your suggestions. We will evaluate them over the next few days and they will certainly be a complementary basis for the Commission's position and the work of the Commission. There has been praise from very few Members for our proposal — thank you very much for that. There has been criticism by many from all directions — from all directions. And when I analyse this criticism, I come to the conclusion: in the middle of the criticism is the Commission's proposal that the Commission's proposal is in the middle of your critical speeches, disappointments, expectations or statements that it is unfair. If I were to imagine now that 26 other ministers of finance or Europe would sit here and have their say, then — I say — the picture would be even more colorful. The criticism would be even more diverse, and again the Commission's proposal would be at the centre of all critical expectations. I will briefly turn to the rule of law. Ladies and gentlemen, we as the Commission, in all programmes, investments and incentives, are committed to keeping an eye on the interests of our citizens and taxpayers and to prevent fraud, infidelity and corruption in the budget — through OLAF, through EPPO, through our own controls, through close cooperation with the Committee on Budgetary Control and with the European Court of Auditors. And if then there can be a dispute and you have to reclaim funds because of incorrect settlements or fraud or because a project has been misdescribed, then one is dependent on the independence of the courts, on an independent third party. And if this should not be respected in Member States or regions, if the independence of the judiciary from legislation or government is not ensured, then we would have a lack of confidence in fair decisions. That is why the rule of law is inextricably linked to a European budget and the aim of preventing corruption, fraud and infidelity to European taxpayers' money. That is why we are advertising the proposal for conditionality in the rule of law. Secondly, some of your speeches emerged what is much more emphasised in the Council: I want my money back — the issue of so-called net contributors. This may have been a comprehensible policy budget at a time in previous budgetary frameworks, when agriculture and cohesion accounted for more than 80% of all expenditure, where the return of funds to farmers, rural areas, structural programmes, regions, municipalities could be relatively clearly traced. With our proposal, however, cohesion and agriculture account for just under 60% of the budget framework. Tasks such as border management, such as development aid, such as migration, such as research, are collectively larger than agriculture or cohesion alone. But if I operate border guards in Bulgaria, Greece, Italy, Spain, Malta and Cyprus, no money will go back to Paris and Berlin. But external border management is in the common European interest. If I strengthen development aid to Africa by financing human dignity to people in need in Turkey, no penny will go back, but I believe we have taken into account our Christian commitments, human dignity and perhaps also the number of people who come to us through smugglers or even alone want to diminish. That is why this so-called net payer bill is increasingly fake. I therefore firmly reject them. Or if a research project is taking place for Philips, Siemens or Bosch, and they have their research center in Budapest, and not in Amsterdam or in Munich or Stuttgart — is this money a return to Hungary, Germany, the Netherlands? It is no longer possible for these global players to show whether the money for research returns to the Member State where the company has its registered office. It often goes to other locations within the European Union. Thirdly, we focused on only proposing programs to support projects only finance to spend money only when there is added value. For example, defense. We do not want more military, we want to use the taxpayer's money more efficiently for our external security. We can show that some tenders for a gun, a tank, a drone to maintain our external security are better European than 27 times in individual silos. This means that the billions we are proposing in the European budget can reduce the burden on national budgets. So the proposal is: give us a euro from your budget, we put together the 27 amounts, write down together, have economies of scale, save in the interests of the taxpayer. It is not about more military, it is about more efficient investment in defence at European level. Then, on the question of ambition raised by Mr Arthuis, not 1.3%, 1.14%, but 2% or 3%, which was also supported by Mrs Grossetête, Mr Rübig and Mrs Trüpel. I'm not far from this. Just in concrete terms, Mr Arthuis: France was the toughest representative of cuts in the budget discussions for 2018, it was France that fought for every euro and every million cuts. My request is therefore: let us not only talk about an ambitious budget in Strasbourg, let us fight for the corresponding revenue within the limits of our limited possibilities in Paris and Berlin. This also applies to Mr Rübig and the ÖVP-led government in Austria. What I dislike is that you perform strongly here and either do not perceive your authority or have no authority at home. I am addressing the German Government. A new departure for Europe, co-formulated by Martin Schulz. I very much welcome that. But my friend Olaf Scholz says publicly: “Germany does not give more than 1.0 of GNI.” And to deal with this in Berlin, as a Social Democrat, as a member of the SPD, as an S&D member, I consider it imperative. In part, we distinguish worlds between this House and our authority in Berlin, Paris or Vienna, in the capitals of the European Union. Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial asked me: what are the guidelines of the draft budget? Finally, I would like to mention four: economic strength and competitiveness. Secondly, when you are economically strong, it is about solidarity. Because the one who is economically strong can also share, must also share, must show solidarity with weaker people in Europe, with weaker Member States and citizens. Thirdly, it is about sustainability and, fourthly, it is about internal and external security. Economic strength and competitiveness, solidarity, sustainability and security are for me four guidelines which I believe does justice to this draft. That is why I am very interested in a critical but intensive consultation with all of you in the next few weeks.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr Arthuis, we will let Mrs Panayotova conclude. There is no blue card on the Commissioners' interventions.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for your remarks and comments. I have taken good note of them. I have received three questions from my former respected colleague, Mr Geier, and I will try to be very brief. He had three questions concerning the communication with Parliament and the Council concerning the system of own resources and also the timeline regarding the forthcoming negotiations. As I already said during my intervention, I can assure you that the Bulgarian Presidency, as well as the future Presidencies, are committed to regular and frank talks with Parliament. The Bulgarian, Austrian and Romanian Presidencies have a clear mandate to meet and brief the representatives of Parliament before and after each session of the General Affairs Council (GAC) when the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) is discussed, in line with the Treaty provisions. We have already had such meetings on 14 May, before the start of the General Affairs Council (GAC) meeting at high political level, and afterwards with a follow-up meeting at ambassador level on 22 May. Furthermore, when the Multiannual Financial Framework is on the agenda of the European Council, the President of the European Parliament also will be given the opportunity to contribute to the discussion by addressing the Heads of State or Government at the beginning of their meeting, as is actually the case generally. After each meeting of the European Council, its President will present a report also for your kind attention. Concerning the question about the system of own resources, I have to say that the discussions in the Council’s Working Party are beginning today, so you will understand that the work at technical level is just beginning. It would therefore be premature from the side of the Presidency to express itself on this issue. Concerning the timeline, I have to underline that the leaders discussed the calendar of negotiations at their informal meeting in February. They decided that we would advance as fast as possible with this file, but it was also clear from the discussion that the possibility of an early agreement was very much dependent on the proposals put forward. They will return to the issue of timing once again, at the earliest in June. In this context, the Presidency has started work immediately on the Commission proposal so as to advance work as much as possible, and the next Presidencies are committed to working intensively as well. I think that I have succeeded in responding to the three questions and, in conclusion, I have to say that in the weeks and months to come we will have a lot to talk about. It won’t be easy, it won’t be simple but I trust that we share the same objective – that of a good agreement that delivers the best result for our citizens.  The Council looks forward to working with you in the spirit of mutual, sincere cooperation for a timely adoption of the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr Arthuis, I will give you the floor for 30 seconds but, please, we do not resume the debate.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: — Madam President, thank you very much. Commissioner, let us not be mistaken. I am aware that at times there may be a gap between words and deeds. For my part, I try to put them at the same level. Forgive me, but with 1.08%, we are still in a budget of misery and the beautiful speeches of our Heads of State and Government do not fit with such a budget. I am not proposing to increase public expenditure, I am simply saying that some expenditure incurred at national level is no longer effective and that, therefore, the urgency is to transfer appropriations from the national budget to the European budget in order to achieve full efficiency and demonstrate what European added value can be. Otherwise... (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I cut off your microphone, sir. I indicated that the debate is not being resumed. You intervened on the merits, so I stop there. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, May 30, 2018. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - We need to focus on social affairs as much as possible, because only in this way we will be able to contribute to tackling youth unemployment. Combating child poverty and income inequality as effectively as possible. The European Parliament is calling on the Commission and the Council to create a European Child Guarantee since 2014, which provides free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and proper nutrition services for every child. The European Child Guarantee would be a means to ensure that all children have equal opportunities from an early age, and no child would need often such vital things as safe homes, proper nutrition, guaranteed health and education. In order to be able to reduce child poverty, we need to mobilise the EU budget for that purpose and decide that that money should only be allocated to children and no other priorities. Europe and the Member States must realise that investing in children is the most important investment in the future of all of us. At the moment, we have different instruments, which, among other things, can also be used to reduce child poverty in the Member States, but they are not harmonised and mostly money from the funds is still allocated to other areas, and there is simply no money left for investing in children. The new budget must therefore provide for funding to combat child poverty. Secondly, in order to effectively support young people who are looking for a job and want to gain a foothold in the labour market, the European Youth Guarantee budget needs to be significantly increased after 2020.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - In its current form, the European Commission's proposal for EU funds beyond 2020 is unacceptable. It would not increase, but reduce, the EU budget, despite the fact that many Member States, including Hungary, have indicated that they are ready to increase their contributions. Regional development and the resources of the common agricultural policy cannot be allowed to harm the Commission's ideas, and we must protect the interests of Hungarian farmers, businesses and citizens. The Hungarian regions and the Hungarian companies have demonstrated in recent years that they have used the available resources well and successfully. Outstanding growth indicators, steadily improving fiscal situation, decreasing unemployment and increasing employment all show that since 2010 the Hungarian regions have been on the path of economic development. Hungary has succeeded in recovering from the consequences of the misguided economic policies of former socialist governments. It is unacceptable that now the European Commission's proposal would penalise these successful, well-performing regions with EU standards by diverting resources from them. EU development money is not charity. Hungarian regions are entitled to these resources on the basis of objective criteria. Now the European Commission would associate subjective, so-called rule of law criteria with the call of EU funds. In recent years, Hungary has consistently demonstrated that it meets European values in all respects, whatever indicator is being examined, we are at the forefront of the Union. At the same time, no EU institution should be allowed to see development resources as a means of political pressure.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — (PT) This proposal for a Multiannual Financial Framework assumes as strategic elements the guidelines that underpin unequal, unfair and asymmetric development between the different countries in the European Union. The guidelines which instead of the promised convergence have only brought divergence. Time and life have shown that European Union funds have never compensated (nor could they compensate) for the destruction of the productive systems of the periphery, losses of sovereignty, the asymmetric impact of the single market, the euro and common policies. Nevertheless, what the European Commission is now proposing is to cut the instruments that are supposed to mitigate the divergence. Cut in cohesion policy. It should be noted that even if it stayed as it is, it would not be enough - as it is in plain sight! Cut into national envelopes of countries with greatest difficulties. Cutting agriculture and fishing. But they increase military spending. The funds for the repressive and security apparatus are increasing. They increase the appropriations for programmes which are mainly used by the major powers. Everything is tailored to their interests, demonstrating the true nature of the European Union. Unacceptable.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. — The European Commission presented its proposal for a post-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) on 2 May. The binding of EU aid to the rule of law is fiction, since the introduction of these subjective criteria would be contrary to the EU Treaties, the objective of creating an instrument with extortion potential is clearly behind this proposal. The EU's plans to transfer EUR 37 billion from the new EU Member States are also unacceptable. The alignment of the Central European and Baltic Member States with the Western Member States is far from complete. This will merely result in the European Commission to further fire the east-west tensions in the EU. These are the sources for Central and Eastern Europe after we have opened our own markets to Western companies that have made huge profits in our countries. Instead, the right approach would be to increase the resources of those Member States which protect the Schengen external borders and thus the security of the entire Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. - Commissioner, you have presented to us the Commission's position on the new multiannual financial framework, which is in major conflict with the position of the majority of the European Parliament! You have nonchalantly told us that you have done the right thing by cutting funds from the cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy and the European Social Fund! How to do the right thing when the three funds are the pillars of EU development, competitiveness and unity? You said that there was not enough money for Britain leaving, but you did not talk about new measures to bring money to the budget from enormous tax evasion, from huge losses from cross-border VAT evasion, from non-taxation of profits taken out in untaxed areas! We need subsidies for farmers! There are still smaller subsidies in the east than in the west, and we need to equalize them! We need cohesion funds because we still have regional disparities in quality of life! Find sources, Commissioner, do not cut off the funds that keep Europe united!

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - As we can see from the data published, Hungary may lose up to 24% less EU funds in the 2021-2027 budget cycle. I agree that the oligarchs of the Orbán government are not financed with EU money, but I do not think that Hungarian citizens should be punished for corruption and fraud applied by Fidesz. I completely reject the reduction of EU funds allocated to Hungary and should instead be prevented from theft. A good way to do that would be to make a decision by EU bodies to allocate the EU money owed to the country instead of the Orbán government. This would be good for the country, for the Hungarian people, for businesses and for the European Union. Currently, only a small proportion of EU funding reaches the Hungarian citizens, as the Orbán government is stealing it. If the reduction of EU funds will be applied, Hungarian citizens will be able to obtain even less money, which will make it worse for Hungary. It is no coincidence that the Orbán Government did not join the European Public Prosecutor's Office, as it knows precisely that after accession, a significant part of Fidesz's moonyard would be imprisoned for fraudulent public procurement. If subsidies were distributed by the EU in the future, there would be no possibility of deceiving public funds. My party, the Democratic Coalition, will submit this proposal in writing, and I respectfully ask you to consider it.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. — The proposal of the EU Committee on the Budget until 2027 is objectively insufficient. In order to finance only the initiatives on which the Member States have committed to in the European Council, and to respond to the concrete needs of our fellow citizens, it would serve approximately 3% of EU GDP, 20% more than proposed by the committee. There are also interesting elements in the proposal, starting with new own resources, in line with the position adopted by the Committee on Economic Affairs in the opinion of which I was rapporteur, and then integrated by the Committee on Budgets. It is also certainly a good choice to propose increases for programmes more in view of the Community budget: almost doubled the funds for Erasmus+; at least EUR 200 million more for Creative Europe; more total of 90 billion for research in the new Horizon Europe programme; a European programme to mobilise some 600 billion in investment; and two budgetary instruments to strengthen the Eurozone. Positive choices, although less ambitious than this Parliament has hoped... “even if (something) moves”. It will be our commitment to seek a compromise between this House and the Member States to respond effectively to the challenges ahead.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. — I am very concerned about how the European Commission has approached the proposal for the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2021-2027 and its communication. I believe that, even with new objectives and priorities, the European Union should not abandon the principle of solidarity, which is also enshrined in the founding Treaties. I find it unfortunate that a body that has the welfare of all Europeans in the credo will propose a plan that will show that is not at all as positive as it originally presented it. According to an analysis by the European Parliament Research Service, it is clear that the notified increase in resources for key programmes is actually lower and the cuts are higher. I am disappointed that the European Commission did not try to stick to the guidelines passed by Parliament a few months ago, which went not one but a few steps further in ambition. As far as the expenditure side is concerned, the Commission has not managed to produce a sufficiently good document. We all know which way the amounts will be pushed by the Member States when they are negotiated. Up it will certainly not and it will be to the harm of all students who would like to study abroad, all mothers who would like to reintegrate in the labour market, all scientists who in vain trying to get finance for his research, and many others. I positively assess the abolition of rebates and the proposal of new budgetary resources.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: in writing. — When we talk about the new EU budget, we should first talk about the priorities we want to set. For us social democrats, this is obvious: investment in the future, in youth employment and in research must take priority over industrial agricultural production. The money for the future challenges is to be collected from the corporations. We therefore need to increase own resources through an emissions trading system, the EU corporate tax, a European plastic tax, and also through taxation of the digital economy and financial transactions. While many Member States cross themselves from the outset, European finance ministries are sforging billions of tax revenues by acting reluctantly against legal tax tricks by large corporations. If we were to finally close the tax escape routes, the European budget would be financed with ease.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, many Members of the European Parliament and politicians from the Member States continue to underestimate the effect of Britain's exit from the European Union and insist on increasing the EU budget. Now, we need to reach a compromise on budget figures 2021-2027 as soon as possible. Without this compromise, we will not be able to have effective negotiations on draft regulations on the various European programmes, including those for cohesion and the common agricultural policy. We must accept the reality of the loss of the second largest net contributor to the EU budget and find the compromise needed to go through the first step: the level of the budget 2012-2027. We need flexibility and pragmatism in approaches.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. – Despite the financial impact of Brexit, we must ensure the same level of financing for the CAP after 2021. The cuts proposed in the new MFF is jeopardising the future of food and farming in the EU, while both the agricultural policy (CAP) and the cohesion policy are supposed to be reduced significantly. We are still in time to avoid major damage, to focus on solidarity and progressive financial investments, and to be able to implement new and integrated solutions, such as the Smart Villages. The CAP needs a smart investment approach and technological innovation to create new business models, based on end—users and digital farming technology. These actions can ensure generational renewal, training and skills development and environmental benefits. Contrary to the first pillar, which is entirely financed by the EU, the second pillar programmes are co—financed by EU funds and by Member States. We should avoid renationalising the CAP, while we should improve the own resources. I call on the Commission to strengthen the second pillar of the CAP and interconnect it with the other funds for the rural areas. Let’s be conscious that choices taken in the coming months will shape the Union for decades to come.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – The Financial Times is spreading panic that Poland and other Eastern European countries are being stripped of their funds to finance the Mediterranean fiesta. The people who believe this should read the documents released by the Commission and the documents this Parliament has produced. And for the ones who sit in the Plenary of the European Parliament and still believe it, I would suggest reading the documents twice and getting their homework done before the ‘bell’ rings. This is not the time for cultivating the art of madness or illiteracy, but it is rather a time to understand the sense of ownership in every policy we undertake. Therefore, I urge my colleagues to heavily engage in getting the Multiannual Financial Framework post—2020 adopted during the mandate of this Parliament.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. — Following the conclusions presented by EC v. The MFF for 2021-2027 and the EU's own resources system are at the threshold of key negotiations over the immediate future of the Union. The next financial framework must reflect a clear and positive vision for the future of the Union and respond to the needs, concerns and expectations of European citizens. Moreover, the decision on the MFF will undeniably need to provide the Union with the funding necessary to meet its most important challenges and to implement its policy priorities over the next seven-year period. In this context, I consider it fundamental to uphold the EP's hard position on the necessary level of funding for key EU policy strategies to enable them to achieve their objectives. In particular, I emphasise the call for Cohesion Policy funding in the EU-27 to be maintained at least at the level as in the 2014-2020 budget in real numbers, while respecting the overall structure of these policy strategies and increasing the current three times the budget of the Erasmus+ programme, doubling the special funding for SMEs and tackling youth unemployment. I stress with all my power that the next MFF must build on the Union's well-established policies, whose aim should be to promote peace, democracy and security, as well as long-term and sustainable economic growth, research and innovation, and to ensure high quality employment and strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — (PT) The proposal submitted by the European Commission (EC) on 2 May 2018 on the Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027 is far from the realistic and weighted ambition expressed in the resolution adopted by the European Parliament on 17 March. The resolution we are debating today is a strong warning from the direct representatives of European citizens to the institutions. At the political time in which the European Union (EU) is experiencing, with positive economic indicators and worrying political signals, it is crucial that the multiannual financial framework translates a mobilising and proximity vision capable of fostering convergence, strengthening cohesion and increasing competitiveness in markets global. The lack of consistency in the way in which some of the priorities and financial allocations contained in the EC proposal have been presented also causes serious damage to the credibility of the financial year. The EC proposal may be the embryo of a new stage in the consolidation of the European project, but for this the robustness of the approach, the safeguarding of European values and adequate financial allocation must be ensured. It is still possible to reach a good port, but it is necessary to correct trajectories and options. I hope that this debate and the resolution that will come out of it will contribute to this.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Élisabeth Morin-Chartier and Agnes Jongerius, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 96/71/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 December 1996 on the posting of workers as part of the provision of services (COM (2016) 0128 - C8-0114/2016 - 2016/0070 (COD)) (A8-0319/2017). I will be obliged to take an oratory precaution for this debate. At noon, we have the speech of the President of the Republic of Guinea, Mr. Alpha Condé, followed by the votes at 12.30 p.m. I am therefore obliged to concentrate on the debate, without accepting blue cards and with a series of very short requests speeches, so that we respect our schedule.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Representative of the Council, I am going to tell you frankly that this moment I dreamed of it ardently and intensely. To come to the conclusion of this work that was so difficult, it was for me for a long time, for twenty-seven months, a dream. It was an impossible mission and, together, we made it possible. At least that is what I want us to do today. We wanted to put in place a very clear political line: for equal work, equal pay, in the same place of work. Finally, it is this equality between European citizens, this European justice that we wanted to achieve. It is the result of unprecedented collaboration between the Commission, the Council and Parliament. I would like to greet my co-rapporteur, my friend, Agnes Jongerius. We worked together, hand in hand, and sometimes squeezing our teeth to get there. We wanted this agreement! However, this determination has been accompanied by a method of listening, dialogue and respect for each other's positions, because I know how many different positions exist in the spans of this Chamber. There are the positions of the political groups, there are the different positions of the Member States, but between us here, and that is the role of the European Parliament, we must be able to reach consensus, find a way of agreement, and we have respected all shadow rapporteurs to achieve this. We were leaving from afar, from a fracture, downright. East-West fracture. Is that what we wanted? We were starting from a divide of eleven Member States which refused to reopen the revision of this directive. Were we going to stay with our arms and do nothing? No, we had to give a new scope to the free movement of services, to put an end to all the speeches that, little or less, want both of us to retreat into a national space. It was necessary to build a balance. This is what we have done here in the European Parliament, by proposing to the Council and, always with your presence, Commissioner, as with the presence of Minister Rousinova, who has always been extremely committed, as with the Estonian Presidency which preceded you, this profound commitment, because we wanted, for the citizens of Estonia. Europeans, emerge from an unhealthy situation politically, economically unhealthy and socially unhealthy. Social dumping is not our goal, unfair competition between companies is not our goal. Our goal is to strengthen a social Europe, a healthy, strong economic Europe with fundamental values. That is what we came to in this agreement. It is this agreement that you will have to support earlier. Anyway, I wanted to say thank you to the stakeholders and I don't forget any of our team members, dear Agnes. We know all the first names: François, Yann, Lara, Alena... I say thank you to them.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, after 27 months of hard work we are here today to vote on the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, and therefore we are voting on a very important value for Europe, that all workers deserve equal treatment and that there are no first and second class workers in Europe anymore. Up to this day, we see colleagues on construction sites, in agriculture, in shipyards, and many more sectors, being turned into competitors, not because they want to be, but because some are less expensive for their employers than others. With this new posting directive this will change. We will put an end to both the undercutting of wages and the inhumane situations we sometimes see when it comes to lodging, and we can put an end to unfair competition between those companies that play by the rules and those who bend the rules to their own benefit.  Therefore, I am grateful for the courage and the political will of so many, because otherwise we would not have ended up here today.  First of all, I want to mention Commissioner Thyssen. I think she feels in her bones that the situation that workers are currently facing is unfair. Secondly, I would like to thank all ministers of the Member States who really aimed at reaching a fair compromise during the concluding negotiations under the Bulgarian Presidency, and if you allow me, I would like to single out my colleague and former Dutch Social Affairs Minister Lodewijk Asscher.  But without the good cooperation of Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, without the shadow rapporteurs, without the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, without all the MEPs involved, and of course without all the staff, we would not have made these steps towards a fairer European labour market. It is only together that we can curb the race to the bottom when it comes to wages, working conditions and social security systems. Undercutting wages and unfair competition leads to resentment from citizens, and this has to stop. I think the revision is beneficial not only to all European workers and to all honest companies, but it is also good for the European project as a whole. The freedom of movement of workers should become a right of workers again, and with this new directive we accomplish this. Workers’ rights are explicitly protected. So instead of being competitors, colleagues can become colleagues again when today we vote in favour. We can ensure a fairer labour market and we can turn the slogan ‘Equal pay for equal work at the same workplace’ into reality. With this step I think we are also taking a big leap towards a social Europe, to which we are committed under the social pillar. Today it is up to us to put an end to the exploitation of posted workers and to ensure equal pay for equal work at the same workplace for all.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, the importance of this agreement cannot be underestimated. The revision of the Posting of Workers Directive goes to the heart of the internal market. The European project has been built around the internal market, which is the European Union’s major achievement. But the internal market is not only about goods and services but also about Europe’s work force. In order for the European project to be successful, the internal market has to be fair and also perceived as fair by our citizens. Fairness means equal rules for workers when moving across borders and fair competition between companies. Following the commitments made by President Juncker to this House, we came in March 2016 with a proposal implementing the principle of equal pay for equal work at the same place. I would like today to pay tribute to the two co-rapporteurs, Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and Agnes Jongerius. With their clear understanding of the challenges, their determination and their spirit of compromise, they made it possible to reach an agreement with the Council on our proposal. Also, thanks to the shadows and to the Employment Committee, its Chair and staff. The text you adopt today is a substantive improvement of the rules set out in the 1996 Directive, both for posted workers and for companies. Posted workers will be guaranteed equal pay for equal work carried out at the same place. Companies will benefit from a level playing field that will stop a race to the bottom on working conditions. The revised Directive will tackle fraud and abuses. I will be very clear: this Directive is indeed protecting workers’ rights, but it does so without introducing any discrimination of cross-border service providers. The Directive ensures that undertakings provide services in another Member State under the same conditions as imposed by that state on its own nationals. To dissipate all doubts, I tell you that this Directive is not protectionist; its aim is to preserve fairness on the internal market, in order to preserve our citizens’ confidence in the internal market. That is why the importance of this Directive should not be underestimated. We need it to prevent Member States from having recourse to protectionist measures that would undermine our internal market and, finally, our welfare. This is the reason why in the Council this text has gained support from a large majority of Member States across Europe, from east to west and from north to south. For the same reason, I count on this House to vote in favour of this Directive with a large majority and to demonstrate to European citizens that the Union’s legislative institutions can overcome political differences to effectively make decisions that matter to them.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. — Madam President. Commissioner Thyssen, it is very clear today that all your statements on the common market and the removal of barriers are Sunday speeches. When it comes to your own interests, forget that you want to be great Europeans. “Equal pay for the same work” sounds fair, but in reality you are overriding the most important market factor — the price. Moreover, they directly and deliberately disadvantage service providers from Eastern European countries because they have to bear the same wage as well as the posting costs. They must not be part of the wage, as stated in Article 3 (7). I ask you: how are the Eastern European service providers to compete with Western European service providers?

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. — (FR) Madam President, this agreement, which has been negotiated for 27 months, is a very good agreement and marks a fundamental first step in the elimination of inequalities, on the one hand, and, on the other, in the fight against intra-Community relocations. That is why I would like to thank the two rapporteurs in particular and to welcome the work done by the Commission and the Council. I would like to say a second thing: this agreement is not only social, it is also a way of defusing a minimum the protests of the extremists who have relied on this argument to try to curb the construction of Europe. Finally, one last thing: amendments have been tabled. I call on my fellow Members to vote against these amendments so that this first step, which is extremely important, is not unforced and that we can begin an application that is really interesting and useful for the Union. Thank you for this work.

name: David CASA
text: f'isem il-group PPE. — Grazzi Sinjura President, anki jiena rrid nibda billi nesprimi s-sodisfazzjon tiegihei gall-eżitu tan-negozjati li tmexxew minn Elisabeth Morin-Chartier u minn Agnes Jongerius. name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner. Today is one of the most important days of this term. It's a fun decision we're going to make, something that's going to mean very much to our ability to stay together in the first place. We shall vote on decisive steps in the labour market and therefore also whether our ability not to conflict apart but do something together. We shall vote on whether we accept social dumping and competition with poor conditions in the labour market, A and B teams, East and West, or whether to compete with high quality and equal pay for equal work in the same place, regardless of where we are in the EU. This proposal is a crucial step in the fight against social dumping. Salary should now be set according to the host country's national law or practice. The right to strike has been strengthened. This directive is extremely crucial for the future of the EU.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, first, I really want to thank both rapporteurs for their inclusive and constructive work on this file. I may not have agreed with them, but both the rapporteurs conducted negotiations in a spirit of really good cooperation and I want to acknowledge that here today.  My Group felt that we should wait until the Enforcement Directive was fully implemented before bringing further legislation. Nevertheless, we have tried to be constructive, and our priorities have been clear: we must avoid dividing Europe between east and west, we must strike a good balance between the freedom to provide services across the EU and the protection of workers, and we must avoid creating legal ambiguity and uncertainty. Unfortunately, the trilogue agreement has failed in these areas. Even all references to Rome I, the law applicable to contractual obligations, have been removed, so we are in danger of undermining the competitive position of companies, especially SMEs, providing services in EU Member States other than their own. Some provisions in the final text exceed the scope of the Directive and cause legal uncertainty, so the European Conservatives and Reformists (ECR) Group has tabled an amendment to try and bring some clarity to businesses who are lawfully trying to provide a cross-border service. I fear that by making lawful postings very difficult, this proposal may cause the unintended consequence of increasing undeclared work and bogus self-employment and other illegal practices, so the ECR Group cannot support the final agreement.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. — Madam President, the revision of the Directive on the posting of workers has opened a theme that has been kept under wraps in Europe for a long time, namely the sensitive issue of wage disparities the levels of the Member States. The popular slogan “equal pay for equal work in the same place,” which made the directive visible across the states, was suddenly, from day to day, to straighten everything out. Does anyone really think that by this procedure we will miraculously solve any problems in the labour market? I don't think so. For over two years now, we have been discussing whether a truck driver or a construction worker sent abroad will have a wage such or poppy. But wages are not at the heart of the problem at all. This is about the future of Europe and its values. It's a debate about what kind of Europe we actually want. I now ask you: Do we want to maintain the free movement of people, goods and services in Europe? Or do we want to allow Europe to become a protective market where it will only be possible to move in one way? The new rules will severely restrict cross-border service delivery and undermine one of the fundamental values of the European Union. My stance certainly doesn't mean that I don't want to indulge our workers with a better wage, and that I defend the unfair practices of companies. Precisely the opposite. But try, at least for a moment, to look at the real situation in the labour market through the eyes of those who are real job creators. What do they really need? Are these other regulations that will tie their hands even more? Or simple and effective solutions that will simply be applied in practice? We must, after all, take into account the economic possibilities and consider the impact of our decisions on all, that is, businesses, on employers that are the backbone of the European labour market. Particularly in the transport sector, the situation is really critical and I am sincerely sorry that some colleagues very quickly forgot about the promise about setting the specific rules of transport on which we are in of the trialogue clearly agreed. From the beginning, my aim as shadow rapporteur of this report was to achieve the necessary balance between maintaining free movement of services and protecting the rights of workers. Unfortunately, that didn't happen. For these reasons, I personally cannot support the directive. To vote for the directive is to me to vote against one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is built.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear citizens of the European Union. Before assessing the outcome of the trilogue negotiations, we should put ourselves in the position of workers in the EU. Imagine that you have been training for years, imagine doing a good job, but your salary is stagnating. But you need more money because your rent has become more expensive. Imagine then sitting with your boss in the salary negotiation, and he says to you: I won't pay you any more wages, and in case of doubt, I'll just get posted workers, they'll do that down for a third. Or imagine working on a construction site, you did the same training as your colleagues, you work as hard as those, but still you get a third less pay. That can't be true! So we wonder that there is creaking in the European Union? We are therefore surprised that the most voted for Brexit in the UK, particularly in the regions where the negative effects of globalisation are most felt are felt? We have made the use of workers far too easy in recent years. We have made it far too easy for the right to stirred up hatred and resentment. And, damn it, it is our duty as legislators in the European Union to finally put a stop to this! That is why we need good and fair minimum standards, and this result is a breakthrough in this area. It gives the European Union a more social face, and that is so bitterly needed — not only for posted workers, but for all workers in the European Union. We need a European social labour market. And today we are taking an important step precisely in this direction.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: on behalf of the Gue/NGL Group. — Madam President, First of all, I would like to say thank you to colleagues. Thank you for a good collaboration. Thank you to the rapporteurs for inclusive cooperation. We've never really agreed or we've disagreed on many things, but we've respected each other, we've listened to each other and we've negotiated, so thank you for that. Let me start by saying quite clearly: does the new directive solve the issue of social dumping? No. Does the new directive ensure equal pay for equal work in the same workplace? No, neither does it. We have to be completely honest with the citizens. A labour market where workers and employers negotiate agreements voluntarily on the one hand, and on the other, a single market where employers move workers around and use pay as a competitive element — the two things fit together really badly. That is why it is a question of whether you want to support the single market, or you want to support workers and solidarity and equality. The new directive is still based on the internal market and freedom of movement, which is why we do not get far enough. However, there are also good elements of the directive: we have some of the worst timelines removed from the old directive, we will have better opportunities to create equal pay, we will have better opportunities for trade unions and for Member States to fight for a level playing field for all workers. That freedom to workers, that freedom to the unions, that I really hope they will seize now, because there are so many consequences of social dumping.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, to date, there have been too many crafters in Europe who were circumventing the rules on workers posted to another Member State to trample on their fundamental rights. For too many people, what was supposed to be a beautiful professional and training experience abroad turned into a nightmare, with wages utterly inadequate to the new costs of living. Enough now! Finally, after two years of close negotiations we are reaching a revision of the balanced and ambitious directive, able to ensure fairer wages and social protection, the protection of our small and medium-sized enterprises from unfair competition. We will be able to assure workers the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place. The salary will be established on a case-by-case basis by category agreements or national laws. Seconded work can last up to a maximum of 18 months: the rules of the country in which the service takes place will automatically apply after this period. Our work — and I thank our colleagues — has made it possible to make a clear step forward in protecting the rights of European workers.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, what about the revision of the posted workers directive aimed at reducing east-west social dumping, a dumping that you have instituted, both right and left, within your European Union? 516,000 workers posted to France in 2017, 516,000 fewer jobs for the French. There are some good initiatives that we support: equal pay and pay or, even, supervision of duration. But, unfortunately, you are complicit in this unfair competition: there is no specific provision on the hourly rate — posted workers will therefore be paid on the basis of 35 hours, even if they make 60 hours. There is no provision on subcontracting and temporary employment who recruit all over the world, like those Ecuadorians engaged in Spain to work in France. Similarly, there is no provision on the liability of contracting companies in the event of fraud. However, these frauds are numerous, not to mention the problems of cascading detachment. Finally, this reform could be described as deceptive, because differences in social security taxes are still not taken into account, as is the transport sector. Posted workers from Eastern countries will always be cheaper than our national workers. We proposed the following: the same salaries and social charges for all, from day one, which seems to us simpler and fairer. For all these reasons, we will abstain.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: — Madam President, the report on posted workers claims that it improves their position. Of course, the European Union has not taken on labour rights. If he were interested in them, the only way would be to apply the most favourable arrangement to posted persons without conditions. But the Union is concerned only with freedom of establishment, the despicable 'Bolkestain Directive', the mobility of workers with a uniform intensity of exploitation of locals and posted workers, and the widespread downward squeeze of wages and royalties. The Union, with a supposedly social face, simply chooses sides in competition with companies, the bourgeois classes, the strongest or the less powerful states. Who will lead the race for competitiveness with even cheaper workers? These improvements in the situation of seconded workers are left to employers and contractors, they are literally drowning in the widespread abolition of labour rights, collective agreements, the right to social security and strike in all Member States. Locals and posted workers in a joint struggle to claim collective agreements, salaries, insurance and rights based on their modern needs.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, I want a fair European labour market. A labour market where people who cross borders are not exploited, but get what they are entitled to. A labour market where rogue companies who abuse freedom of movement through false constructions and letterbox firms are actually tackling. And a labour market where we put an end to unfair competition and repression. We need two things for this: strict, fair rules and good enforcement. In the area of these strict, fair rules, we are taking a very important step today, because for the first time we are clearly laying down in legislation that the provision of a service is always temporary and always short-lived, that collective agreements apply to all employees and that revolving door posting is unacceptable. There is still a lot of work to be done, but the legislation we are adopting here today is a very good step towards a genuine, fair European labour market.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: — Madam President, the concrete progress is here: full application of collective agreements, payment of a thirteenth month when it exists, payment of premiums, pay increases in the event of overtime. Better yet — and it was very important — the costs of transportation, accommodation, catering, will be borne by the company and not withdrawn from workers' remuneration. We owe this to Agnes Jongerius and Élisabeth Morin-Chartier, whom I welcome for the progress that has been achieved. However, will this be enough to put an end to social dumping? Nobody says so, and today we can see that there are great risks to the transport sector, which states have decided to put aside in the debate on social dumping. Regulation is also lacunary, as we know, particularly with regard to subcontracting. So what to do at European level to defend workers, their rights and harmonise social rights? We must take responsibility, support these advances and vote for what is being presented today, and continue to fight to ensure that we can do even better for European workers in the future.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President! Intra-European migration is far greater than was assumed in all forecasts. Labour migration has put considerable pressure on labour markets. The Swiss initiative against mass immigration or Brexit was a direct reaction by citizens to migration that was perceived as too high. The purpose of this Posting of Workers Directive is to curb labour migration. It is dishonest because it does not address the central problem, but instead creates an excess of regulations and regulations that are not practical for companies. Some parts even contradict existing laws: the Rome I regulation, which is an existing law, is simply opposed to another law. Other parts seek to extend the EU's competences to social concerns, in contrast to Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. This is where the attempt is being made to build European law on the political declaration of intent — the pillar of social rights. This law provides for further over-regulation from Brussels.

name: Karima DELLI
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, social Europe is on the way. The Posted Workers Directive now protects these workers, who were most often vulnerable workers far from home, subject to sometimes unworthy accommodation and wage conditions. It's over. From now on, at the same place of work, the remuneration will be equal between a posted worker and a local worker and accommodation will be taken into account. This directive will also address the risks of social dumping, thanks to better tools to combat fraud and abuse. Nevertheless, this new legislation is a blow to the transport sector. I would point out that road hauliers have been excluded from this directive and their fate is now subject to another specific legislation. We take a huge risk: that of treating drivers as under-employees, with less rights, less income and therefore less protection. That is why, as chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism in the European Parliament, I believe that we must correct this unacceptable misconduct by restoring good working conditions for the employees of road hauliers.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Madam President! There is a dispute here between governments over which of these governments have the right to impose contract terms on workers and employers. Let me settle this dispute. None of the governments have such a right. Contracts between employees and employers are only a matter between them and no governments, no gentlemen in suits, just because they are sitting in blue seats in this room, they have no right to interfere with contracts between unknown persons. You wipe your mouth with the good of the workers, but you have no right to do so because the posted staff didn't ask you to do it. Quite the contrary — they just want to compete at the price. Because what are workers from Poland in France supposed to compete? No one will hire them because they speak French better, just because they're cheaper. Why would someone bring a worker from one country to another to work more expensive or at the same price? That's why I take away your right to speak up on behalf of these employees.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! There are no more bad solutions spoiling Europe's internal market from the revision of the Labour-Delegation Directive. Across Europe especially today there is a lack of hands for work. Hence, workers are delegated to countries where the local market lacks skilled workers, or local people are not interested in a given type of work, and we reduce delegation to 12 months, charging companies with all forms of collective bargaining, we destroy the internal market. The revision was intended to eliminate rogue companies using so-called social dumping. There are no solutions in the document. In the revision, we have chaos, a multum of bureaucracy, which we will charge all delegating companies whether Germany, France, Poland, the Netherlands, Belgium or Bulgaria. It is from these countries that small and medium-sized companies will collapse under the bureaucracy imposed on them. I will add, honest companies, because on company covers (letterbox companies) we have not found solutions, these will continue to flourish. Only a clear right the market will respect. Do Europeans really have to bear the cost of one politician's ideas? Do we have to be prisoners of populism?

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, fellow Members, this directive has sparked a lot of debate, generating political and geographical cleavage, rightly so. In my opinion, the mission of this dossier to protect the rights of mobile citizens in the European Union is extremely important. However, I wish we were more ambitious. We need effective solutions to real problems that affect these citizens. I would mention here the fight against mailbox firms, but also the change in the practices of multinational companies, especially in the old Member States, which choose methods of moving profits from the Member States where this profit was obtained to those of origin. Let us fight together to equalise living standards and, implicitly, wages across the European Union! Citizens of Eastern or Southern Europe must be paid at the same level as those in the rest of Europe, according to the principle of equal pay at equal work, no matter where we are in the European Union. And here, my colleague who left should know that in Romania a worker who does the same work, who has adequate training, just like the one in the West, is paid at 30 to 40% of what the other is paid.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President! Analysing holistically, the revision of the Labour-Posting Directive seems to confirm the view that the European Union is a kind of club named after Charles Darwin. In this pseudo-theability, he wins bigger and stronger. And while the original provisions of the directive were somewhat softened, the final result still reads as a blow to the entrepreneurship of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, particularly Poland, which has the largest transport fleet in Europe and a fairly large group of delegated workers. It certainly doesn't serve European integration and the competitiveness of the European economy. Consequently, it could lead to the collapse of the micro- and small enterprises of this industry and to lower the competitiveness of the entire Our European project is based on the principles of the common market, freedom of service, freedom of movement for workers, not on principles of protectionism from stronger states. So the stronger in the European Union have not agreed to a twenty-four-month period of long-term posting, fighting against social dumping, which has not even been defined. And so on, and so on.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — The Madam President, therefore, the purpose of this Directive is to ensure more fairness in the labour market for posted workers. Because the exploitation of workers and the shortening of labour rights within the single European market is absolutely unacceptable. However, alas, this is a fact and a cruel reality. And that is why I welcome this Directive, which, at least, by — if I may say so - minimum standards, minimum conditions governs that principle equal pay for equal work. What may worry about, however, is whether this directive will really come to light in practice and whether realisation really will occur. That is why, in addition to this, the purpose of the directive - better justice in the labour market - we also need strict oversight. And, of course, the persecution of those harmful practices and fraudulent practices that put workers in such an unenviable position. Let's remember only those pictures of posted workers, who then naturally stay in impossible conditions. And if violations aren't sanctioned, we won't achieve much.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President! The trilogue compromise contains very ambitious proposals. On the positive side, both wage dumping and social dumping are almost impossible. Germany is one of the countries most poent. Our companies are hardly suspected of dumping. In revising the deployment as the heart of the internal market, we in the EP had set a balanced solution. Firstly, we requested that posting should be possible for 24 months. Now only 12 months are committed, with an extension of 6 months. Secondly, instead of a longer transitional period — so that actors can prepare well — changes are to be implemented in two years' time. And thirdly, the consequences of short business trips are unclear. Practitioners denounce legal uncertainty and increased bureaucracy, the identification of different reporting obligations, the compilation of detailed documents for each posted person. I would have liked short business trips to be completely excluded, so I shall abstain.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. After more than two years, we are now on the home straight. Equal pay for equal work in the same place is a good start to further alignment of living conditions in Europe. The recast leads to greater legal certainty and respects not only tariff standards, but also people in particular. It protects posted workers, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises, against wage dumping and unfair competition. And, dear Thomas Mann, a business trip — every practitioner knows this, every works council in Germany — is not a posting and will never be a posting. Incidentally, I believe that the Commission has already informed you. The old law was so knitted that business trips are not postings, and the new one remains just as knitted. Liberals and conservatives have a duty today to join us in standing up for a new, social Europe. We want a social internal market that no longer looks exclusively at the economy, but on people.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! I believe that the amendment of the Directive will adversely affect the principles underlying the functioning of the internal market, above all the freedom to provide services. The revised text of the Directive does not guarantee a proper balance between the protection of workers' rights and the freedom to provide services. Instead of being a tool to protect workers, it will actually become a tool to protect the economies of wealthier member states from more competitive businesses, mainly from Central and Eastern Europe, but also from Portugal, Spain. It is particularly surprised that such changes are particularly in favour of those Member States who are keen to use European rhetoric on a daily basis. Here, too, we've heard a lot about social dumping (social dumping), but we're really seeing everyone what division it is, this directive instead of linking divides Europe, divides Central and Eastern Europe from Western countries, and we see a defence of interests rather than protecting workers.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, we are updating the Displaced Workers Directive, a directive dating back to 1996, with the aim of better protecting this type of workers — which must be remembered that there are more than two million in Europe — and to prevent unfair competition, because in some way we recognize that it had become a mechanism for abuse and exploitation and which could sometimes distort the labor market as a whole. Behind this update, of this new rule, there is a long work on the part of the European institutions as a whole, and there is also a lot of work and a lot of pressure from the Socialist Group, which has pushed in this direction. After today we will be closer to a Europe that protects workers, come from where they come, and to a Europe where workers have the same salary, the same social protection and are covered by the same collective agreement in the same place. A Europe that protects its workers more and demands legitimacy from its citizens.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, I would like to send a message this morning from this Chamber to progressive politicians and progressive people in the United Kingdom. It might have seemed over the last decade that the pace of progressive reform here was slow. Well, the response to Brexit here is that it’s speeding up and it’s deepening. This is progressive reform. This is tackling precisely the kind of undercutting of local workers by foreign workers that many people in Britain would like to have seen long ago. It’s tackling the exploitation of those foreign workers too. Progressive legislation, which we in the UK will not benefit from, partly because of Brexit and partly because our labour market is not structured in a way that would enable us to take advantage of these reforms anyway. The answer in both cases is the same, and it’s the only answer – labour government.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President! Equal pay for equal work in the same place — this is a milestone for a social Europe. Why? Groups, windy companies are deprived of their business base, which is based on the exploitation of employees, on unfair competition, and wage dumping. The Hungarian harvester finally no longer has to work for the pimperage of three euros in Burgenland, Austria. Next, we in the European Parliament must ensure that truck drivers also remain covered by the Posting of Workers Directive that it is not possible for truck drivers to commute through Europe for weeks to a wage of two euros. Europe will be social or it will not be. We can make a significant step and a significant contribution to this today. Turning now to the Austrian Government, I expect more from that at the Presidency when it gets it. This government has now adopted a social dumping attack, which is cynical, which is not social and against a posting of rights directive, which we hope to adopt today.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, I cannot emphasise enough how important this revision is. Congratulations to the rapporteurs. It is no secret that the Posting of Workers Directive has led to a great deal of frustration for both employers and employees. Indeed, this legislation is, for many, the symbol of a Union that worked in the wrong way. Revision was therefore more than necessary. The most important thing is that the issue of the temporality of the secondment is finally addressed. Twelve months with a possible extension to eighteen months: not short, but at least clear. But that's not all. The foreign worker is now entitled, in addition to wages, to the allowances to which a domestic worker is entitled. This is not just the case for the construction sector, but for all sectors. With that decision, we ensure that domestic workers are less likely to be priced out of the market and that foreign workers are no longer exploited. The revision of the Posting of Workers Directive has literally cost blood, sweat and tears. As a fellow countryman and party member, this may seem to me a bit easy, but I think that no one can deny that Commissioner Thyssen has put down a fearful piece. It is a courageous piece of work that ensures less fraud, fairer work and a fairer Europe.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, the lack of fair rules and enforcement protecting workers from wage undercutting exploitation has given unscrupulous employers a dividend for too long, and it was used to great effect by the Leave campaign in June 2016. Today’s reform of the rules on the posting of workers is a crucial step in addressing the legitimate concerns that many have, by ensuring that equal pay for equal work in the same workplace is guaranteed in law for the first time. While the Tories have tried to undermine these improved workers’ rights at every stage, Labour MEPs have been pressing for them for a long time to ensure that the single market is fairer for workers, especially in the construction sector. And now my call is to the UK Government to stop dragging its feet and to ensure that these rules are implemented as quickly as possible, to ensure that British workers and their foreign co-workers can benefit from a fairer single market as colleagues and not as competitors.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the Posting of Workers Directive in the context of the provision of services has been used in substance to legalise social dumping. We are currently required throughout the European Union to have equal pay for equal work, equality, the application of collective agreements, no exceptions, and also payment of the same allowances and the application of collective labour agreements. This must be the basic principle that applies throughout the European Union. The trick of having posted workers who are paid not on the basis of wages in the country where they work but on the basis of the remuneration in their country of origin must be stopped. Because it does not help the development of society or the development of the economy and, of course, leads to unfair competition and, at the same time, to huge social dumping. In my view, the same conditions should apply to all workers and this unacceptable directive on alleged posting of workers should be abolished altogether.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Madam President, the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, which is flagged as a major social flag, is, on the contrary, a good demonstration of how the enhancement of labour and social rights is not part of the Commission's priorities, not least of the majority in the European Parliament. We reject the view negotiated between the Council and Parliament, which, in practice, allows for a period of endless secondment according to the needs of the employer. Let us be clear: anyone who is working in another country for two years or more is not deployed, they are emigrated. The proposal removes responsibility for the enforcement of labour rights from companies. The explicit non-application of the principle of equal pay for equal work entails the non-guarantee of the principle of equal pay; it explicitly opens the door to the use of temporary employment companies which, we know well, remain on the basis of low wages and precarious working conditions, i.e. seek to maintain and secure a mobile army of cheap labour from countries such as Portugal that feed the profits of large European transnational companies.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members of the European Parliament for their interventions. Dear Members of Parliament, I started my intervention by highlighting the importance that this text has for workers, for companies and, ultimately, for European citizens. Once adopted by this House and the Council, this text will ensure fair labour mobility and, together with the Enforcement Directive, will contribute to strengthening the cross-border provision of services. I told you that this Directive is necessary to preserve the internal market. This is not about needless administrative burden for companies. Nothing in the revised rules requires companies to change their treatment of business trips. It is about ensuring equal pay for work carried out when companies provide a service cross-border, so that posted workers are paid according to the same rules as local workers and companies benefit from a level playing field. Dear Members of Parliament, labour mobility is a good thing. Free movement is the right that European citizens cherish most, but it must be organised. The internal market cannot be a jungle but needs clear, fair and enforceable rules. Today you have the chance to allow us to take an important step further in this direction. Please do not miss the chance. Citizens expect us to act.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, as you said right now, Commissioner, yes, citizens are waiting for us, yes, citizens are watching us this morning. It is the vote of each of us that will be read by each of our fellow citizens. I know there are a lot of rumors circulating, I know that pressure has been exerted, but a vote is to be clear in one's mind and conscience about his political objectives. That's what I ask each of you here. Our political objective is Europe, to bring Europe closer to our fellow citizens, to kill the worm that is in fruit, with the exploitation of this work detached by the populists against Europe, that is what will be at the heart of the campaign of the European elections in 2019, that is what I ask you to have in full consciousness, this morning, when you are going to vote. We have no right to be wrong. Parliament can show that it is big, that it helps to move Europe forward. That is what is on our table this morning.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, I think it is right to stress once again that the free movement of workers is also a workers' right. Employees have the right to look for an economic future if they cannot find it directly in their own environment. But employees also have the right to be treated equally and not exploited. Employees have the right to be able to work in companies that do want to comply with the rules of the game. And if I welcome this proposal now, it is partly because, at the beginning of the proposal, we stipulate that the rules also serve to protect workers. It is about the free market and also about the protection of workers. I believe that we have tried to take all the different interests into account and put forward a balanced proposal. There are people who said in the debate that there are even more problems in the labour market. Yes, that's true, there are more problems in the labour market. But there are also other proposals that are being discussed here in Parliament. I would like to mention the coordination of social security. I would mention the European Labour Authority. Let me mention the discussion about the employment contract. We still have a lot on our plate until the next election. But first things first, let us now send out an important signal with this vote: equal pay for equal work in the same workplace. Europe has no first-class and second-class workers. Everyone deserves equal treatment.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me just regret that two such important debates, with so many requests to speak, were grouped in such a short morning. I regret that because we could have taken many other interventions. The debate is closed. The vote will take place this Tuesday at 12.30 p.m. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. — The report on the Posting of Workers in the Service Provision Directive proposes an amendment to the existing 1996 Directive in the spirit of more favourably equating the wages of those workers with those employed countries. Polish companies currently delegate approximately 500 thousand of their employees, mainly from the construction industry, to complete numerous tasks, with their existing earnings far removed from those offered to local workers. The idea is for them to be treated no worse than locals and not to be exploited by both the posting and host party as a result of their hiring at the lowest hourly rates. Poland has already introduced the same principle for workers from Ukraine, i.e. the principle of equality between them in rights and obligations with Polish workers. Undoubtedly, the introduction of new regulations on delegated workers will return some of the many half million people of citizens to a country where they are guilty of quickly finding a fair job for a similar wage as in the country. After all, our country has a severe lack of professionals in the internal labour market, and this should cause a gradual equalisation of the wage for the same work. I support new EU regulations which are mainly beneficial for the workers.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - I consider the proposed EU regulation for posted workers to be restrictive and discriminatory mainly against small and medium-sized enterprises.
