The expected monitoring of individual countries' legal order and collective agreements is a particularly serious burden. I did not vote in favour of the directive because instead of at least the freight and passenger transport workers and entrepreneurs were exempted (this was the original compromise), it foresees a separate legislation which is expected to reduce the competitiveness of domestic carriers by the same means in the west.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. — I consider that this Directive is not an unambiguous step to be assessed. Although the directive contains reasonable rules that state that, for example, an employer cannot charge travel and subsistence expenses on an employee's salary while he is posted to another EU country, the requirement of assimilation of wages to local wages will in fact limit” the competitiveness of new European companies in the “old” Europe. As a result, such a well-meant administrative step with the aim of creating fairer pay actually looks like attempts by individual countries to protect their providers and employees. It practically limits the free market for labor force. For example, a company from Latvia that has won the competition in Germany because it has been able to offer a better price, also due to lower labour costs and high quality, will no longer be able to do this because this company will have to pay German level remuneration with Latvian income and profit in Latvia. These are two completely different categories, as a result of which this company from Latvia will no longer be able to compete in Germany.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: in writing. — The proposal for a directive on seconded workers is necessary and valuable in its efforts to promote equal treatment of seconded workers and workers in the country of destination and to protect seconded workers from fraud and exploitation more effectively. Strengthening the rights of seconded workers is important: the number of seconded workers in the EU has increased considerably in recent years. Better regulation is not only in the interest of workers but also in the interests of corporations. Regulation ensures a more even competitive situation between companies. Strengthening the principle of equal pay is an important step forward. The knowledgeable workforce must be paid decent compensation and the rights of workers should not be raced down.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The directive, by which we agreed to introduce equal pay for equal work in the same place, has been prepared for a long time and has brought a variety of views and discussions. Under this legislation, workers temporarily seconded to another EU Member State should also receive equal remuneration for the same work. I mean, like the domestic workers in the state. The costs of travel, subsistence and accommodation should also be borne by the employer to the posted worker and should not be deducted from their salaries. Broadcasting should not last more than twelve months, with a possible extension of another six months. After that date, if a staff member remains in that Member State, he will be subject to all the provisions of the labour law of the host country. I think that the concerns that foreign employers will no longer be interested in posting workers are unfounded because the advanced Member States are already suffering from a labour shortage and there will always be a demand for workers from other Member States. I consider the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place correct and supported it.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before my welcome address to the President of Guinea, I must inform you of what happened in Liège, Belgium. A man killed two Belgian policemen and a Belgian citizen. The man was shot dead by the police. We do not know whether this is a terrorist attack or not, but we are alongside the Kingdom of Belgium, alongside the Belgian citizens, alongside the families of these two Belgian police officers and this Belgian citizen killed this morning in Liège. I also thank the President of Guinea for expressing his condolences on this attack. We do not know the reason for the shooting, we do not know whether the perpetrator is a terrorist or not, but unfortunately, again, in Europe and Belgium, we have had deaths due to incomprehensible violence.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we have the pleasure of receiving today, in this Chamber, the President of the Republic of Guinea, Mr Alpha Condé. You are, Mr President, the third African leader to address this House within a year. Your visit is part of a framework of bringing together and strengthening our partnership with, on the one hand, the African Union and its member states on the other. First of all, I would like to commend the extraordinary work you have done in your country over the last few years: the emergence of “the worst health crisis in the modern world”, as defined by WHO in reference to Ebola, democratic consolidation and human rights, including the abolition of the death penalty, economic development, with a growth rate of over 6%, making Guinea one of the most dynamic economies on the African continent. However, many challenges remain: the fight against corruption, the lack of infrastructure, the improvement of the business climate, youth unemployment, which drives many Guineans to emigrate to Europe. The European Union has a role to play here, because insecurity, climate change, unemployment and migration are common challenges. We must therefore give ourselves the means of our ambitions. That is why we are advocating for economic diplomacy, for more private sector investment. In the next multiannual financial framework, the European Parliament is asking for more funds in order to have a real plan for Africa, a new 'Marshall Plan'. This should contribute to economic diversification and the creation of a manufacturing base to enable the absorption of newcomers into the labour market. We therefore support a real national development plan in this direction. I would also like to thank you for the outstanding work you have done at the head of the African Union. Important and concrete successes marked your presidency: Morocco's return to the African Union, the impetus for the creation of an African free trade zone, an indispensable pillar for the integration of the continent, and the organization of the Abidjan Summit, which marked a decisive turning point in our relations. Mr President, we look forward to having you here.

name: Alpha Condé
text: President of the Republic of Guinea. — Excellencies, Mr President of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great pleasure for me to address you this day. At the outset, I would like to express my gratitude for your honour in welcoming me on an official visit to your prestigious institution, where I came for the first time to receive the passport of freedoms. Over the years and investments of the European Union, your Assembly has established itself as a legislative body capable of effectively responding to the legitimate concerns of European citizens and contributing to the search for solutions to the challenges facing the world. In this regard, I am pleased to express our gratitude for your continued support for the efforts of developing countries, including strengthening the rule of law, good governance, as well as in combating irregular migration and climate change. Excellencies, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, since my accession to the supreme judiciary of my country in December 2010, Guinea has strengthened its democratic process, notably through the establishment of the regalian institutions such as the National Assembly, the Constitutional Court , the Court of Auditors, the Supreme Council of the Judiciary, the Economic and Social Council and the High Communication Authority. These institutions, now fully operational, operate independently and with strict respect for democratic principles and values. We have also established a constant political dialogue, with the participation of all political parties, civil society, administration and development partners. This climate of dialogue has greatly contributed to the calming of the socio-political space and to the construction of peace and stability. All this contributes to the preservation of Guinea's many democratic achievements in recent years. We also maintain a permanent relationship with the European Union, in accordance with Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement, to which my country is a party. For example, the second session of the framework for consultation held in Conakry in March 2017 addressed issues related to the preservation of democracy, the fight against corruption and impunity, migration and official development assistance that the European Union provides to our country. We welcome this framework for exchanges between our country and the European Union, which promotes mutual understanding in our political, economic and social cooperation. It facilitates the definition of common priorities and principles and strengthens the links between the various areas of cooperation enshrined in the Cotonou Agreement. Excellencies, Mr President, Members, ladies and gentlemen, during my tenure at the head of the African Union in 2017, our continental organization has worked to address challenges ranging from issues of peace and security on the continent, to institutional reform and financing of the organization, with a view to ensuring that the African Union was in 2017. strengthen our credibility and dignity in dealing with international problems. The ongoing reform should allow us, in the long term, to make our organization more efficient, to promote and consolidate our financial autonomy, whether for the functioning of the institution or for the financing of projects and programmes included in the 10-year plan for the implementation of Agenda 2063. I remain convinced that Africa is stronger when it speaks with one voice. I have therefore appointed Champion Heads of State to serve as spokespersons for our Union on all specific issues of continental concern. Furthermore, African integration, which is at the heart of our Union's Agenda 2063, has taken on an irreversible momentum with the launch of the single air transport market in Africa and, more recently, the launch of the agreement establishing the African Continental Free Trade Area. Indeed, in the long term, we want to build a stable, peaceful and secure Africa, composed of states with inclusive, efficient and competitive economies on the global market and whose growth benefits all citizens. We want to make Africa an emerging continent, with a single market with efficient structures while avoiding competition between its states. To do this, we necessarily want to invest substantially in infrastructure, particularly in the transport, telecommunications and energy sectors, in order to accelerate the transformation of our economies. That is why we launched the African Renewable Energy Initiative at COP21 in 2015, with the objective of providing our continent with 300 gigawatts of energy generation capacity by 2030 and significantly increasing the use of renewable energy. I would like to thank the European Union for the valuable support it continues to give us in making this initiative a reality, which I have the honour to coordinate on behalf of Africa and of which I chair the Governing Body. Excellencies, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is a strategic partner for Africa, not only because of its geographical proximity to our continent, but also because of its security, economic and humanitarian cooperation with Africa. The close cooperation between the African Union and the European Union deserve to be emphasized. The third African Union-European Union Summit, held in Abidjan in November 2017, under my co-chairmanship, on the theme “Investing in Youth for Accelerated Inclusive Growth and Sustainable Development”, marked the willingness of the leaders of our continents to move further towards harmonizing youth relations. This summit not only allowed us to thoroughly review our partnership, but also set our common priorities in the four strategic areas: peace and security, cooperation in the field of governance, mobility and migration, and economic prospects for young Africans and Europeans. Our cooperation with Europe on migration and mobility will be strengthened by focusing on tackling the root causes of irregular migration, namely development issues and trafficking in human beings. We welcome the adoption, at the Valletta Summit in November 2015, of the initial $1.800 billion Emergency Trust Fund to support our States' efforts to stabilize our young people on the African continent. In particular, we welcome the launch of the Marshall Plan by Mrs Merkel at our last meeting in Berlin, and are confident that the Marshall Plan will promote win-win cooperation. Of course, we have said that if there is a genuine Marshall plan, the European Union must devote a share of its GDP comparable to that which the United States once devoted to Europe. The European Union's new external investment plan, set up and adopted by the European Parliament in 2017 and with €44 billion mobilizable resources by 2020, will support our sustainable development efforts and the creation of new opportunities for youth. In the same vein, I welcome the European Union's contribution to the financing of the Integra programme in Guinea amounting to EUR 65 million through the resources of the Trust Fund to Combat the Root Causes of Irregular Migration. This programme will support the Guinean Government's efforts to integrate young people into the various economic sectors of Guinea through the creation of new employment opportunities. Excellencies, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cooperation between the European Union and the Republic of Guinea in recent years has accelerated and diversified in various fields, which has contributed to improving governance, the development of infrastructure and human capital, preserving the environment or improving the management of the fisheries sector. This assistance has already enabled us to meet the major challenges in terms of economic and social development and the strengthening of the rule of law, including reform of the justice sector and defence and security efforts, as well as the transformation of our administration to make it more efficient, modern and efficient. I cannot ignore the valuable assistance that the different States of the European Union have given us during the terrible ordeal we have had to go through with the Ebola epidemic. I would like to thank the European Parliament and all the Member States for this assistance. Through you, I would like to express to the European Union and its institutions our deep gratitude for the valuable and constant support given to our country. I remain convinced that the partnership between the European Union and Guinea will strengthen and diversify, particularly in favour of the implementation of the National Economic and Social Development Plan PNDES 2007-2020, which was presented to all our development partners last November in Paris at the consultative group meeting. The programme, which is the unique framework for our partners, is based on four pillars: promoting good governance for sustainable development, sustainable and inclusive economic transformation, inclusive human capital development, and sustainable management of natural capital. Despite the undeniable progress on the ground of democracy, my country remains a victim of the image of its past. We again count on the support of the European Union to enable us to achieve the objectives contained in our PNDES, which aims to put Guinea permanently on the path to sustainable development. Long live cooperation between Guinea and the European Union, long live cooperation between the African Union and the European Union, long live international cooperation! (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr. President, we thank you for your statement. I hope that today's meeting will allow us to enter into a new phase of cooperation, closer cooperation. For us, working with Africa is very important. In the next EU budget, we want to provide more money for cooperation between us and you. We try to read the African situation with African glasses and not with European glasses. We also count on this cooperation to address the challenges of climate change, terrorism and illegal immigration. We will only be able to achieve this goal if we are able to work together. That is why, Mr President, I thank you for your speech and for your presence here in Strasbourg, in the plenary of the European Parliament. (Applause)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my point of order is based on Rule 212 of it, concerning the composition of parliamentary delegations, and also on the Bureau resolution of 25 October 2015, which lays down the rules for them. It provides that when a delegation goes abroad to meet with our counterparts in foreign parliaments, special consideration must be given to participation in meetings of delegations. During May, the delegation for relations with Japan was composed of ten members. Of these ten members, three did not attend any of the eighteen meetings held since the beginning of the mandate, one attended one in eighteen meetings, and four attended less than one in two meetings. I do not intend to stigmatize these colleagues at all, but I say that the majority rule cannot cover parliamentary tourism in this House.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Gollnisch, your point is taken and we will look into it.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, on the 200th anniversary of the birth of Karl Marx, Jean-Claude Juncker held a festive speech… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleague, no, I will not accept that, it is not a point of order. Under Article 184, if I am not mistaken, Part A, on points of order this does not comply with our own Rules of Procedure. So I have to take the floor away from you. Unless there are other requests, we will now proceed with the votes.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: — Yes Mr President, it is a point of order on Rule 135. “Discussions on democracy and the rule of law”. We, colleagues, have dealt a lot of times with democracy and the rule of law, and it is true, all over the world. Then I think it's important to explain what happened in Italy. Where, what happened in Italy... (Protests in the House) (President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Corrao, please take your seat. This is a final request, take your seat, your micro is off ... (Uproar in the Chamber) We will now proceed with the extension of the term of office of the Special Committee on Terrorism. It’s a decision of the Conference of Presidents… (Disturbance continues)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Mr President, I call on Rule 59.3 to vote now on the amendments tabled in plenary before the compromise text is put to the vote. My group would like a roll-call vote on this request. The text of the North Sea Plan makes it possible to overfish and thus runs counter to the United Nations development goals. The plan is far too far from the mandate given by Parliament in September. International environmental organisations even call for a vote against this plan. Ladies and gentlemen, I ask your support to save this fishing plan and, above all, to save the species of the North Sea. Say no to overfishing.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: — Mr President, we are challenging the reports of the trialogue and we ask for a vote on all the amendments, please.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr President! As the last two dossier were given to us in a very complicated way, most MPs were confused when we voted on the final version of the Labour-Posting Directive. You didn't say what we were voting on, you just said we were voting. Please foreshadow clearly what we are voting on and I ask that we repeat this vote (...). (The President answered the speaker's voice)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Jazłowiecka, that is not correct. When I put it to the vote, I did say whose report it was. I think it was clear, we took a vote, and there was a vast majority.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the agenda, we have seen a show beginning of the session with very serious words about what is the situation of a country, an authoritative member of this Union European. I have respect for this House, so I think that inappropriate words cannot be said here. We've heard very serious claims. I want to reiterate here, Mr President, that my country is a country that has a Constitution, a President of the Republic that guaranteed respect by the Constitution in the face of attacks from those who wanted to put under your feet this Constitution. We are for the rule of law, and even these days Italy has turned out to be a country capable of defending the rule of law from unacceptable political attacks... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Toia, your point is taken. May I just remind you that I have taken the floor away. That was not a point of order so I have cut the microphone and whatever was on the microphone we might look into, but the microphone was cut off and unfortunately, with no interpretation, I could not get the meaning in Italian. But your point is taken, and that was considered to be a remark that was inadmissible, and that is why I have taken the floor away.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with her work, Mrs Aguilera García has welcomed many of the 5 Star Movement's instances here in Europe. When defending the interests of artisanal fisheries, in fact, optimization of the fish supply chain represents a crucial battle. The general concentration of the market and the rise of supermarkets, which are the most widely used distribution systems by consumers, have a negative impact on artisanal fishing which — let's remember — employs nearly 78 000 fishermen across Europe, more than half of them in Italy alone. Artisanal fishermen are increasingly victims of the appreciation of first-selling fish and the rising cost of fuel, but also not always uniform and regular fishing, in the face of fierce competition from foreign fish companies. Therefore, in order to fit into the new market segments, they need forms of aid and financial support. They need to speed up the time of the allocation process of funds: for example, if the fisheries operator is enabled to carry out the activity for the Member State, it should be automatically eligible to access funds without having to prove it every time. In addition, with this report we have called for upgrading direct selling and marketing channels such as zero-kilometre agricultural markets, community markets and school canteens. Finally, we proposed to increase network assistance, so as to create links between companies intervening at different times of the fair. Our vote was therefore in favour.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the world abounds with examples of countries that have managed to treat their fish stocks as renewable resources: Norway, Iceland, New Zealand or the Falkland Islands. All of them manage to combine sensible bilateral arrangements and licensing out to overseas vessels with a preservation of stocks based on a quota system that incentivises ownership. The outlier among developed countries is the European Union because of the tragedy of the commons: because of a fisheries policy that defines fish stocks as a common resource to which all members have equal access. After Brexit, the United Kingdom will resume control of its great renewable resource. And I hope we will have sensible bilateral arrangements with friendly countries, but on the basis of ownership, so that we can allow the recovery of what used to be a great natural resource.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of this report on the optimisation of the value chain in the fisheries sector because it seems to me that it is moving forward in recognizing the importance of artisanal and local fisheries within the framework of the European Union. I also think that the mention it makes to the need to guarantee decent quotas for the artisanal fleet is welcome and, in this regard, I would like to call on the Commission to put an end to the discrimination that is being made against artisanal fleets in the allocation of quotas. I also think it important to recognize the need for public establishments, such as schools and hospitals, to consume and purchase products from artisanal and local fisheries, and that marketing strategies tailored to local specificities include the possibility of direct selling. All this has inclined me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that the agriculture sector is plagued by an increasing and alarming ageing of the workforce: just 6% of the total of those who run companies agricultural in the European Union is under 35 years old, while more than 50% have exceeded 55 years old. It is necessary to encourage the generational transition within companies and facilitate the inclusion of young people from other family contexts in this area. One of the main problems is the availability and price of farmland: the concentration of property and land speculation are in fact making it increasingly difficult to access. Adequate financial instruments are needed, which are certainly useful measures: subsidised loans, higher co-financing rates, provided that it is very scrupulous that these aid goes to support active farmers. Financial support must also be accompanied by the training of new agricultural entrepreneurs. They must be trained in business management and funding skills, and modernization and use of digital technologies must also be facilitated.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Mr President, in Portugal, only 2.5% of farmers are under 35 years old and, on the other hand, more than 50% of our farmers are over 65 years old. This is the result of the common agricultural policy which has led to the abandonment of thousands and thousands of farmers in Portugal, worsening our agri-food deficit. We, of course, advocate greater support for young farmers, but let us stop hypocrisy, this discussion cannot be disconnected from the CAP, because we have a CAP that pays not to produce, which has completely liberalised agriculture, opening up global competition and crushing farmers' incomes. Therefore, if we want young people in agriculture, then we have to create a new CAP, based on the protection of small and medium agriculture and with public instruments to regulate production, which effectively enables young farmers to live off their activities and not from alms from the European Union.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Sur President, jekk irridu nitkellmu dwar futur gall-agrikoltura, ma jistax ikun li ma nagmlux enfasi dwar il-bdiewa żgażagu r-raala żgażag. F'pajjiżi membri li huma żgar, bal Malta, il-problema tal-art hi wada akbar. Jiena jkellmuni diversi bdiewa żgażagjew nies li jixtiequ jidlu fl-agrikoltura, u jitkellmu preiżament fuq dak li jindika r-rapport — li hemm studji li interpreter li l-akbar ostakolu gal min irid jid‑ol f'and husettur is-settur is-settur is-settur is-setur n-nuqqas ta' art; u f'pajjiż żgir in-nuqqas ta' art huwa anki akbar. Kien hemm filmat, and l-aar, dwar bidwi żagżugminn Gawdex li tkellem dwar kemm hu jixtieq li jkabbar aktar is-settur — it-trobbija tan-nagaf'dan il-każ — però gandu bżonn atar iktar fali, gli, gli), gli inkluż il-fondi Ewropej. Galhekk, jekk tassew irridu l-futur gal and is-settur, ejja nneu l-burokrazija, ejja nipprovdu iktar fondi, ejja norbtu l-futur kollu tal-agrikoltura maż-żgażagu nies odda f'and is-settur.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Mr President, European agriculture is on the brink of a crisis — demographic and generational. The “young farmer” measure is a tool in the right direction, but unfortunately the negative trends of leaving rural areas have not changed. More flexibility for both young and novice farmers is critical to keeping rural areas alive and active. If a more flexible and specific approach is not introduced, even more villages will disappear in the shortest possible time. The extremely difficult access to land, which remains concentrated in the hands of few producers, especially in countries like mine - Bulgaria, is one of the most serious reasons for the inability of young people to see potential livelihood and occupation in agriculture, especially in the disadvantaged regions like the mountainous ones. I call on national authorities to introduce an amplification factor of two, which takes into account the number of harvests per year or types of crops when determining aid for young producers in mountain regions, as we have called for by the vote on this report today.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: Mr President, in the next decade six out of ten Spanish farmers will enter retirement age. The generational shift is true that it is one of the main challenges of the sector. Many retired people are forced to continue to pay from the CAP because of their low incomes. Therefore, ensuring decent pensions is also essential to ensure relief. In addition, the CAP allocates only 2% of the national budget to the incorporation of young farmers. There will be no more support for young farmers if we are not able to secure more budgetary resources. Nor can we talk about price volatility simply to talk about financial instruments. We have to face the real debate. How are we going to protect young farmers from a global market that leaves whole crops to rot only so food prices rise? In 2007, when food began to be listed on the stock exchange, a crime against humanity was committed. The future of agriculture will paint black if the European Union does not abandon that road map in which it is blind to continuing with free trade agreements. We must bet on small-sized farms, bet on local production and short circuits. Only then are we going to defend our farmers and our food.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, if we truly wanted to help young farmers, we would amend the subsidy system that disincentivises land sales and raises barriers to entry – a subsidy system which, in any case, has been overtaken by events. When the CAP was launched in 1960, hunger was a recent memory and people believed that it was necessary to artificially have self-sufficiency of food in Europe. But we have moved from a world where hunger was common to a world where malnutrition has become rare, exceptional and now almost always caused by human action, precisely because countries have stopped trying to be self-sufficient and have realised that the route to actual food security is having a diversity of different points of supply: whenever there is a localised shortage somewhere, there will be abundance somewhere else. The best thing we could do is to remove the protectionist Common Agricultural Policy and integrate with the rest of the world economy.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, supporting young farmers is a key issue for preserving or restoring the population preservation power of the countryside. The report clearly sets out the biggest obstacles that need to be overcome. This includes land access, access to capital, and a key issue is reducing administrative burdens. More flexibility is needed in business plans so that young farmers can adapt to a changing market. I can agree with the firm action of the report that funding should be ensured within the CAP, but this is doubtful, given the desire to reduce agricultural funding by 15% in the next seven-year budget.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, support for young farmers is crucial for achieving the objectives of the CAP, but, in agreement with the recommendations of the report, we must emphasise that land path constitutes a serious obstacle to new entrants. At the same time, administrative barriers in many cases make access to aid unavailable for young producers, and young people's capital shortages also put larger producers in a more favourable position. In this area, the new Member States are in a worse position than the old ones, as these problems are more valid and constitute a much greater barrier to young people entering production. It is necessary to make the whole regulation more flexible, because in agriculture — only the role of weather, but also because of the rapid change in market conditions — a business plan cannot always be held from point to point for several years, the good farmer adapts to changes in nature and needs .

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this topic was discussed here in Parliament last night. And rightly so, because young people – be it in agriculture or any other walk of life – are the future of their sectors. Unfortunately, in farming the figures are alarming. According to Agriland, the number of young farmers declined from one million in 2005 to 600 000 in 2013. Access to land is a major issue, and I’m very pleased that Commissioner Hogan is giving this great emphasis in his proposals on the next CAP. But hand-in-hand with that must go an incentive for all farmers to be able to retire profitably and hand over the land to young people. The young farmers’ organisations, such as the European Council of Young Farmers (CEJA) in Europe and Macra na Feirme in my own country, are doing fantastic work in promoting the interests of young farmers and doing charitable and social work, and indeed widening the base of agriculture. I think their views on the next CAP must certainly be taken on board, and that will go a long way to solving this difficulty.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: — Mr President, on this subject, I would like to say that only 6% of all farmers operating in the European Union are under the age of 35. The state is alarming as it is the result of a downward trend in recent years. It is primarily the responsibility of national governments, and then the policies of the European Union, to take steps to improve this situation. After all, this is about our food production, our food self-sufficiency and even the competitiveness of our agro-sector. In particular, the access of young farmers to land needs to be improved, because this is really problematic. The ability to buy or rent land must be easier. Secondly, provide more profitable programs for the financing and purchase of agricultural machinery. Thirdly, to favour young farmers in drawing and mainly repaying loans, for example by postponing the repayment until after the first harvest. Last but not least, to revise the system of direct land payments, because they become too often, for example in Slovakia, a source of speculative business instead of supporting management. I supported this report because it is about promoting generational exchange and kick-start support for the segment.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, long live our Flemish fishermen. Tough men, strong characters too, but above all entrepreneurs who want to earn their living honestly. I was in Nieuwpoort last week, early in the morning, for a visit to the fish mine. Phenomenal, the fishing boats that sail early in the morning with a catch of fresh fish and of course our delicious grey shrimp. I spoke to Rudy Beuckels there. He is one of our strongest fishermen and you feel his love for the trade, the passion for the sea. At the same time you also feel concern. The fishermen are making great efforts. For example, if you look at Rudy on his boat, you can see that there is investment in more efficient engines, in custom nets, in the SumWing, in a tree trawl with rollers. For what purpose? To achieve more sustainable fishing. Our fishermen expect something to be in the opposite position, and rightly so. They deserve a clear future perspective. This North Sea plan is therefore important, but more is needed. Brexit, the pulse or, the landing obligation: all files that threaten our fishing industry. Let us also tackle them and cherish our small fisheries.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: — Mr President, we were promised that this new reform of the posted workers directive would settle everything. Balivernes, it's not! This directive will continue to organise in Europe the competition of workers with each other, social contributions will remain paid in the country of origin, the issue of subcontractors is not settled, a posting may last up to 18 months when the average in France is four months, housing and meal allowances will depend now rules of the country of origin, and mailbox companies still have good days ahead of them. Today, 29 May, the anniversary of the “no” to the Constitutional Treaty, if the vote of the peoples had been respected at the time, we would not be there and social harmonisation from above could have prevailed over social dumping.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: — Mr President, this new directive does not take advantage of the historic opportunity of the fight against dumping and anti-fraud. In fact, it sets the secondment limit at 18 months, while the current average in France is 47 days. Road transport and transport in general, the sectors most subject to secondment, are excluded from this directive and are even more vulnerable. This directive omits the protection of workers in order to retain only the freedom to provide services. She still omits the outsourcing chain. Finally, to date, travel and subsistence allowances and other expenses had been calculated on the basis of the legislation of the host country. It will now be on that of the country of origin, which means a race to the least so-called social for both. I voted against this directive and I regret it, unfortunately.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, I voted against this trialogue agreement and I believe that this is not a good deal, because instead of improving the movement of services in the internal market, we are building new barriers, a new administration and more bureaucracy. It is not good news even for employers who are complicating the provision of services in the internal market, but I believe that this is not good news for employees either. We want, of course, to increase the convergence of rewards, wages between East and West, to reduce the differences between social standards between East and West. But I believe that we need to do so without using protectionism and bureaucracy, so we should have improved the enforceability of existing rules and helped entrepreneurs to prove compete and increase its competitiveness, instead of administrative barriers and bureaucracy.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, I voted for these measures. When I came to this Parliament, I said that protecting the rights of workers would be one of my top priorities. I also said I would be honest and pragmatic in talking about some of the challenges the European Union faces. These measures adopted today do both of those things. In places and at times recently, because of the undercutting of local wages and the exploitation of posted workers, it has become difficult, if not impossible, to defend freedom of movement to those who have become sceptical and opposed to it. Now, these measures won’t go all the way to remedying that scepticism, but they will take us a long way to fairer labour markets, labour markets which have become too unfair in the eyes of many. The onus is now on Member States to adopt these measures, and today is a test for Theresa May and the Tory Government in Westminster. Brexit cannot be a race to the bottom for workers’ rights. Adopting these measures will be crucial to protecting workers across the European Union and in the UK. I urge the UK Government to do so.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr President! This whole idea of curtailing freedom of movement by curtailing the Posting Directive comes from a conviction held by the Social Democrats and some parties even from the right: that fewer Polish plumbers will cause extreme parties to decline in Western Europe. The problem is that it's wrong. You curtail opportunities for Polish plumbers to come, and they'll find someone else to get angry at. Beggar, you curtail beggars and truck drivers will come. You curtail truck drivers and there will be someone else. In this way: those who are angry, they will get angry. They will always find someone to get angry at. If we continue like this, we will have a both closed and isolated Europe that is harming itself, and these parties on the right will not diminish. It's sad that we've come here and I really can't vote for this.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I did not support this directive on the posting of workers, because I believe that this is a regulation that harms the principles of the internal market of the European Union, according to my opinion contrary to the principles of free movement of services. Problems of wage levels cannot, in my opinion, be eliminated by administrative restraint and administrative regulation. I am convinced that wages are meant to match the strength of individual economies. This regulation, adopted today, harms individual firms, burdens them with administration and may, in the future, lead to an increase in unemployment. This means we intervene in the liberal economy, we intervene in the free market, we interfere with the principles underlying European economic integration, the four freedoms of the internal market. I think the measure is very unfortunate and it is a manifestation of lobbying by those who are afraid of competitiveness and a cheaper and more efficient workforce.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Let's imagine that we sitting here in this room send our employee, an assistant from the office, to another state. Another state in Europe, another language, another labour law, another whole legal system. Little of that, in this other state with a different system of law and other language, we are dealing with collective labor agreements: national, regional and establishment. And now let's still imagine that such a collective bargaining agreement in the place where we send our employee has 700 pages in a foreign language relating not only to foreign labor law, but also to the alien of the entire system of law. I am confident that most of us sitting here will resign to sending their assistant briefly for this job overseas. The same will be done by all or most small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union. This directive kills the economy of the European Union and competition on our continent.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Mr President, I voted against this document because it actually suffocates and kills entrepreneurs in Central and Eastern Europe. This document is vivid evidence of a double standard and of hypocrisy. On the one hand our partners and neighbours from Western Europe say “We want a free market, we want to work in your markets, we want to be able to sell in your markets.”, on the other hand, they say “Your companies should not come to our markets because they will take the job of our workers.” This was shared today in this Chamber by fellow Members from France. There is no way to agree with such an idea when French companies work on Bulgarian territory. There's a difference. When you say “We want equal pay,” do Western firms in Eastern Europe pay the wages they pay in Western Europe? No, this whole idea is messed up. It kills the free market, it kills competition, it kills free initiative, it kills movement and divides the European Union in two. This idea is anti-European and eurosceptic, so I voted against it.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, here in that hall and specifically in this parliament, we hear a lot about how we should integrate more, that we need more Europe, that we need more of a single market, that we need to cooperate more, and in doing so, this proposal, this interim agreement goes against these principles. Because it abolishes the single market and its principles, creates protectionist barriers and is a product of the lobbyism of some states, which just didn't get used to even fifteen years that there was a enlargement to include Central and Eastern Europe. As can be seen, MEPs from Central and Eastern Europe are speaking out against this interim agreement because they feel that this threatens the free movement of labour from their countries. If the old Member States take these measures against us, please, but then let them get used to the fact that we will defend our national interests in an adequate manner, for example, in the case of quotas on redistribution of migrants. Thank you and of course I couldn't vote for it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, two years ago, when we had our first discussion here on this topic, I already expressed my doubts about whether the revision of this directive was really the solution to fighting abuses and fraud in the area of labour mobility that it was claimed to be. Today, after a great amount of political capital invested in this file from all sides, I am still not convinced. Labour mobility is a force for good. It allows a timely and effectively response to labour market needs, it stimulates innovation and development and is a vehicle for transferring and upgrading skills. To properly function it needs public support. This is why it is so important to address legitimate concerns and to tackle abuse, but this can also be done without falling into the trap of simplistic slogans, creating red tape, shocking cost competition and jeopardising the single market. We should bear in mind that the administrative burdens we create today will primarily affect SMEs that abide by the rules and leave bogus self—employment, social security fraud and undeclared work unaddressed.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr President! Those who produce something expensively and inefficiently and lose competition often try to forcefully alter game results and appeal to governments for help. And we have plenty of examples of how taxi drivers make a headstone on Uber, and expensive lines on Ryanair, or how machines used to be destroyed so they don't make people competition. So this is nothing more than simply lobbying expensive workers from western countries aimed at cheap workers from eastern countries. But on the other hand, it may be good that you, in view of the imminent break-up of the European Union, will take a shortcut, because thanks to such moves, polexit or the exit of other Eastern European countries from the European Union seems ever closer. And you guys fall for your Muslim immigrant countries and we'll see how you'll be cool living in an Islamic caliphate in a few years.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I very much welcome this report, which monitors the state of justice in each national state. Although justice policy, to me, rightly so, belongs within the scope of individual nation-states, after all, to create an internal market, advocating the value of the rule of law should lead to this that the European Commission and the European institutions should monitor how justice works in each Member State and we should make recommendations and, where appropriate, exchange of information between individual by nation states, so that we can gradually see that similar caucuses will be decided similarly in each Member State. It is the basis of legal certainty for citizens of the European Union to make individual judicial decisions, wherever they occur within the European Union, predictable. If this method of monitoring contributes to this, then I am only happy, but I think that this cannot be the only activity on the part of the European Commission. We should think in the future how to contribute more to making different justice systems work similarly in the European Union and make decisions similarly if we profess the principles of the rule of law.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in the Gaza Strip and the status of Jerusalem (2018/2719(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, these have been tragic weeks. Well over a hundred Palestinians have been killed since March, including several minors, several thousands have been injured, and hundreds will suffer life-long disabilities. Today, we have seen heavy mortar fire from Gaza that reached an Israeli kibbutz. No one can be indifferent to this tragedy. We need a political solution that stops the violence. Israel has the right to defend its legitimate security interests and its sovereignty. But every response should be proportionate and the High Representative has called on the Israelis to avoid the use of live fire against unarmed protesters unless there is a real and immediate threat to life. The Palestinians have the full right to protest peacefully. At the same time, we have also stressed that Hamas and those leading demonstrations in Gaza must ensure that they remain strictly non—violent, and they must not exploit the protests for other means. In five public statements we have urged all parties to refrain from actions that would lead to the loss of life. We have also engaged through our diplomatic channels. We heard different versions of the facts and different narratives about what was happening from Israelis and Palestinians. Our judgment should always be defined by facts, not emotions. That is why we have said since the beginning that an independent and transparent investigation is needed to shed light on events and possible violations by all parties. The priority right now is for all parties to avoid any action that could spark new violence and lead to further loss of life. The first step to reduce tensions is to mitigate the dire humanitarian situation in Gaza, where there is record unemployment and an economy on the brink of collapse. Gaza’s health system is under extreme pressure in treating the injured. Humanitarian access to Gaza and medical referrals to hospitals elsewhere must be allowed to save lives. The Commission has allocated an additional EUR 3 million for an emergency aid package for Gaza and the health, water and sanitation sectors. Second, we must speed up investments in infrastructure and job creation, as discussed in the two recent meetings of the ad hoc liaison committee. This is key to countering despair and frustration. There has not yet been the progress we had wanted and hoped to see in Gaza. Israel has to do its part. Real progress requires progress on movement and access and the possibility of trading. Removing Israeli restrictions would be more helpful than any increase in aid. The Paris Protocol agreed between the parties should be fully implemented, indeed updated. The Palestinian Authority must also play its part and fully live up to its responsibilities for the people in Gaza. This means working actively for reconciliation, under Egyptian auspices, to reunite Gaza and the West Bank under one legitimate Palestinian authority. The only realistic perspective for peace, security and growth in the region remains the two—state solution. and the two states can only be achieved through meaningful negotiations on the basis of the 1967 borders, with West Jerusalem as the capital of the state of Israel and East Jerusalem as the capital of the state of Palestine. No one can deny the historic ties of the Jewish people to Jerusalem, and the same is true for the ties of the Palestinian people to the city. Precisely because of Jerusalem’s unique history, its status can only be solved through negotiations between the parties. This is what we have repeated to our American counterparts since President Trump’s decision to move the US Embassy to Jerusalem. No one but the two parties can take Jerusalem off the table. We in the European Union have also said that we will continue to respect the international consensus on Jerusalem embodied in UN Security Council Resolution 478, including on the location of diplomatic representations, until the status of Jerusalem is agreed by the parties. What has happened near the Gaza fence and in Jerusalem in the past weeks reminds us that what we urgently need is to reopen a path that may eventually lead to peace and security for all people in the region. As Europeans we have a duty to play our part in this, however we can, and we will.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, I am somewhat uncomfortable with the title of our debate, which juxtaposes two separate issues. Indeed, the violence instigated by Hamas cannot be attributed to the decision of the United States to inaugurate its embassy in Jerusalem. In our resolution last month, we clearly recognised that the protests that started on 30 March were orchestrated by Hamas, a terrorist organisation recognised as such by Europe. Even today, thirty rockets have targeted Israel from Gaza, and it is still Hamas. Of the people who were killed in the protests two weeks ago, fifty were recognized by Hamas as its agents and rewards were offered for participation in these violent protests. In our resolution, however, we have clearly rejected terrorist acts and incitement to violence as incompatible with progress towards the two-State solution. On the question of Jerusalem, we should not seek clarity in the East of Europe, in Romania's position. We had, not one, but two different answers from the authorities. Consequently, the internal conflict over the location of our embassy has disappointed both Israelis and Palestinians. Romania — I recall — was one of the seven Member States to recognise the Palestinian State. There was an expectation for us to continue to look at Jerusalem as the capital of both states. We also disappointed the Israelis — with whom we have excellent bilateral relations — who expected to recognize Jerusalem, which has been their capital since 1949.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, the Israeli army had never done so much damage in Gaza. And, unfortunately and despite that damage, the European response has been very weak. One hundred and seventeen dead, including thirteen children, and thirteen thousand wounded. Not all of them were from Hamas, Mr. Preda. All injured by explosive ammunition, which destroys the bodies. Gaza is facing a human disaster of inhumane proportions, so we want an independent commission to investigate what has happened. And we affirm that Israel has the right to its security, of course. Israel is a friendly country, but the Netanyahu Government is clearly in breach of a part of Israel's agreement with the European Union. And what we want is for the European Commission to quote Israel and assess whether Israel is complying with the human rights clause and respect for international law contained in the Agreement. Because, if part of the Agreement is being violated, the European Union must raise its voice. Of course, we have to try to help Gaza. We must try to put a peace process back on the agenda. Because, ladies and gentlemen, President Trump's agenda coincides with President Netanyahu's agenda. And that is the great change that has taken place in the relationship between Israel and Palestine. We no longer have an ally in the United States to be able to conduct a peace process like the one we have always advocated. We do not even have an ally in the United States who will abide by United Nations Security Council Resolutions. And we need to take note of that as Europeans, because the political scene has changed radically since Trump is in the White House. The world is far more insecure, everything is much more dangerous; precisely because President Trump's agenda coincides with President Netanyahu's agenda. Israel had the right to its security and Palestinians also have the right to their security and dignity.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, we all lament the loss of young lives in Gaza. Israel, of course, has the right to defend its borders but, particularly in the face of deliberate provocation, it must show restraint. Apart from the loss of life involved, the international reputation of Israel has again been damaged. This, of course, was precisely the intention of those that set these tragic events in train. In 2007, two years after Israel had handed control of Gaza to the Palestine Authority, Hamas seized control of Gaza in a civil war between Palestinians in which over a hundred people died. Hamas is designated by the European Union as a terrorist organisation. It ruthlessly oppresses the people of Gaza. It murders its political opponents and abducts, tortures and kills those it defines as collaborators. The only media allowed is under Hamas control. It seeks to blame Israel for all the suffering of the people of Gaza and fills the minds of its people with hatred of Israel and the Jews. It does not believe in the right of Israel to exist, but in Gaza there is no democracy and no regard for human rights. The only demonstrations allowed are those under Hamas direction. The border areas are exclusion zones controlled by Hamas for their purposes, including the use as a base for rocket attacks on civilian communities in Israel. There is no democracy in Gaza. It was the Palestine Authority that imposed sanctions on Hamas-ruled Gaza in 2017, affecting salaries of civil servants, as well as medical and electricity supply. The Palestine Authority, Madame President, needs to take full control of Gaza and return to the negotiating table.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, the opening of the American Embassy in Jerusalem was yet another unilateral decision by President Trump. As we predicted, this meant nothing but oil on the fire. While on the one hand the champagne flowed abundantly at the opening, on the other hand hundreds were killed, including many children. It is good, Commissioner, that we are having this debate again here today. Last month we had an excellent debate with a good resolution. But I think that by having this debate today, we are sending a clear and strong signal that we are no longer tolerating it. How much blood has left to flow? How many more children have to die? I think it's clear what needs to be done. First and foremost — and I agree with what my colleague has said — we need an independent investigation. It must be made clear once and for all who are guilty there. Secondly, we should not underestimate the role of Hamas. We must also dare to condemn their actions vigorously. You said it yourself: the humanitarian situation in Gaza, in fact, we hardly dare to list the facts anymore. Month after month we repeat it here. Let us now ensure that humanitarian aid flows through to that point. Providing medical and humanitarian support. Finally, Commissioner, you have pointed out that we should no longer count on America to play an important role there. I think it is clear that Europe must play its role more clearly. You said that we must open the way to peace. Yeah, we should do that. But I think we need to step up our diplomatic efforts. I think we should say: this two-state solution, come to the table, [...] at the table. I think, Commissioner, that Europe should be the trigger, and that is why I am counting on you.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am a member of Parliament’s delegation to Palestine and have visited Gaza myself, and for that reason I’ll restrict the comments I am making to Gaza. I observed the living conditions of Gazans and the repressive nature of the Israeli blockades with their far-reaching effects on employment, infrastructure and any semblance of normal life. I met with Palestinian politicians who are losing faith with the two-state solution and Israel’s obvious lack of good faith in seeking that outcome. I talked to community groups and to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), who highlight illegal land grabs, and families who talk of their husbands, sons and children held in Israeli detention without charge. This – and so much more – is the reality of the repressive, disproportionate and illegal acts of the Israeli state when what we need is true equality for all the people of the Middle East.  But when I read Federica Mogherini’s newsletter, I saw the same old tired repetition of our positions and preferences, which have so far singularly failed to prompt Israeli government action of any sort. I would like to see our Vice-President flex our economic muscles and review the EU-Israel Association Agreement, because it is not unreasonable for us to expect the people that we trade with to act responsibly, proportionately and within the law.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, UN Resolution 181 makes it clear that all actions by the Israeli occupying force, which change the character and status of Jerusalem, are illegal and must be lifted. In this context, we also strongly condemn the US decision to recognise Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Their act is a flagrant violation of international law, serves to perpetuate occupation, circumvents efforts to reach a two-state solution, and, worse, sparks a new cycle of bloodshed against the Palestinian civilian people. Israeli state terrorism, with inhumane violence against peaceful demonstrators, murdered 117 and severely injured thousands of Palestinian civilians, including children. 128 states of the UN General Assembly have condemned the transfer of the US Embassy to Jerusalem and ask to be canceled. We believe that the European Union's statement, which rejected President Trump's decision, was positive. However, we stress that the European Union must cease its policy of equal distance and equating the perpetrator with the victim. It must put pressure on Israel to end the criminal blockade of Gaza, which has become an open prison with nearly two million people trapped in 365 km2 without sufficient access to electricity and water and with many shortages in pharmacies and food. As the GUE Group, we express our solidarity with the Palestinian people for a two-state solution and the recognition of an independent, sovereign, viable Palestinian state at the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you mentioned Resolution 181, the Partition Plan from November 1947. But do you remember that this Partition Plan was rejected by the Arab states? At the same time, as you know, after President Trump decided to move the Embassy, which was a decision of Congress from 1995, this does not preclude future negotiations between the two sides on the future status of Jerusalem. What is your opinion on this?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: answer to a blue-card question. — Dear colleague, first of all, we must say that we must respect the decisions of the UN and the General Assembly and the Security Council. We as the European Union must always defend international law and the decisions of the international organisation. It is within these frameworks that we must reject this Trump policy which, I repeat, perpetuates the occupation and ends the peace policy in pursuing a two-state solution. Peace in the Middle East and Palestine can only be achieved by two independent states living side by side.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tragedy of the Palestinian people is insisting on something terrible, namely the role of Hamas. Hamas sending to the front lines, near the Israeli border, with everything you can imagine, women and children even at an early age, with the very serious consequences we have seen. A great drama, on which we have the positive intervention of Egypt, which plays a role of moderator, but a bad and dangerous role of the usual Erdoğan, who stands to sobiller, to blow again on the fire. On behalf of a delegation that has always defended Israel's integrity, I do not, however, feel exempt from denouncing the seriousness of the humanitarian situation in Gaza, and the state of mind deeply shaken and humbled of a people who perceive themselves alone, helpless, with no way out, abandoned by all, without sovereignty. In Europe too, there is a risk that another people, thank God not in such a difficult situation, will feel humiliated and offended and without sovereignty, which is treated by the European Union as a country Colonial. I would not like to see a political intifada unleashed against those responsible for this coup, of this indecorous intervention by the European Union against a free people, who voted to have their government!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Could I suggest – and yes please, put on your headset – that if you have a vital point to make with respect to our time, please make it first so that you speak within your time.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, Donald Trump relocated the US Embassy to Jerusalem, indirectly recognizing it as one and indivisible capital of the Jewish state. This step has brought about a critical situation in the peace process, with a view to achieving a two-state solution in which East Jerusalem would be the capital of a potential Palestinian state. It is right that the High Representative condemned the American decision, with the majority of the Member States behind it, unfortunately, that united action has not been achieved. The US also had another decision which adversely affected the peace process, namely the termination of the nuclear agreement with Iran. It is right that the EU remains in favour of the treaty. Euro-Atlantic cooperation must not mean that the EU accepts America's dominant role. We need an autonomous European foreign policy.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, when the United States announced the transfer of its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, the High Representative, on behalf of the Twenty-eight, expressed concern about this decision. Today, a few months later, we have to see that this concern was a well-founded concern and we must also express our dismay at the high number of people killed and injured — including children — and call from this Parliament to prevent further casualties among the civilian population. The Commissioner referred to the request made by the European Union and one of its Member States to establish an investigative mechanism within the UN Human Rights Council. I would like, Madam President, to recall the terms of the resolution adopted on 19 April, in which this Parliament called for the avoidance of escalation in the region and for respect for human rights, including the right to peaceful demonstration, as well as Israel's right to live within secure borders; and it also pointed out the fact that the two parties to this conflict have legitimate aspirations that can be realized in a very clear manifestation, which is the formula of two States living in peace, coexist peacefully within secure borders. And to that end, it is important to resolve the status of Jerusalem, in the sense referred to by the Commissioner, on the basis of UN Resolution 478. I conclude, Madam President, by saying that, in these difficult times we have to live, it is important for the European Union and the international community to drive with courage and determination to achieve a just and lasting peace in Palestine.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 14 May last year was a black day: more than 60 dead and more than 2 000 wounded in the Gaza Strip, also due to the wrong choice of the Administration American to move the embassy to Jerusalem. The strong blame aroused, even at a diplomatic level, by the inauguration of the US embassy was dutiful, but it is reductive to relegate the Israeli-Palestinian issue to all this. In fact, the US move to Jerusalem is just one reason that has reignited the clashes. One cannot forget the effects of Israel's decade-long embargo to the Gaza Strip, but above all the desire for homecoming that Palestinians have been waiting for seventy years. Finally, it serves to frame the issue into a broader geopolitical exchequer. My impression is that Netanyahu, the Saudi king and Trump constitute a truly dangerous miscellany for that whole region. It is therefore important that the European Union stands firm in opposing these drifts, continuing to make its own pressure felt and exploit its relations, including economic ones, with Israel to push Netanyahu to embark on a path of peace. In this context, I also take this opportunity to forcefully ask the Israeli Supreme Court to review its ruling and not to proceed with the forcible transfer of the Bedouin village of Khan al-Ahmar and to demolition of the school of Gomme, realized by the Italian NGO “Vento di terra”, which has 160 children from 5 communities. The Commission also intervenes on this.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Madam President! The hypocrisy of this case, when it comes to the Israel/Palestine conflict, no end will take. It is quite remarkable that without any conditions for a peace agreement, the same parliament approved a Palestinian state—an act at least as aggressive in Israeli eyes as the embassy relocation of Americans seen with the eyes of others—and it did so with the premise that it just had to be accepted from the Israeli side. Now you then have the opposite situation where Americans have made a decision that we find it reasonable that we make ourselves moral chief judges of. Incidentally, it is related to the situation with Hamas, where Israel pulled out, and we are even seeing the consequences today. The consequences are that a terrorist organization has seized power. It exploits the local population, it carries out terrorist attacks against the state of Israel, and yet there are many in this hall who insist on going its errand by accepting that the violence it exerts is the fault of the victims. Let me be clear: Terror is one and alone the responsibility of individuals who commit it. Terror is never the victim's responsibility. Anymore, it's not.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: — Madam President, the mermaids sounded in Israel this morning around Sderot, just an hour from Tel Aviv. Thirty shells were fired from Gaza, one of them at a kindergarten. There were no children, fortunately, it was too early. This is actually the most serious attack since 2014. These images, we will not see them in the front page, that truth, we won't say it. Hamas is therefore pursuing its ultraviolence strategy. It is he who is the first to blame for the tragedy of the people of Gaza. For 12 years, this people have been living in economic, health and cultural deprivation. The population is caught up between the Israeli-Egyptian blockade and Hamas, which claims 50 of the 62 people who died on 14 May as combatants, which continues the bombing and announces a further step in the so-called return march on Tuesday, 5 June. Even though at this time negotiations should take place behind the scenes, sponsored by Qatar and Egypt, for a cold peace, a truce in which certain prerequisites, intangible so far, should be frozen, I hope, as the Commissioner said, that this hope will not turn into a further escalation.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, the terrible events in Gaza and the provocation of Jerusalem are nothing but the tragic, emerged part of an iceberg. In fact, contrary to what Mr Benyamin Netanyahu wants us to believe, the Israeli government is not a friend of the European Union, democracy and peace. He knows only repression and humiliation. It is a government that wants strength and it is a combat government. Mr Steinitz, a member of the Likud, who is now the majority party in the government, said on 23 May in Haaretz, about Mrs Mogherini and the European Union, that the European Union can go to hell. We don't talk to friends like that. The words are there, the debate is raised. The European Union must be strong and proud of its values, it must continue to work, as it does constantly, for peace. Finally, the European Union must punish those who at this stage despise with impunity for international law and the values of peace and human dignity that we defend.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: — Madam President, the same words repeatedly repeated here must cease to conceal the impunity enjoyed by the Israeli Government, which I recall is occupying another people. He has just shot down 117 women, men and children from Palestine like dogs and injured 13,000. These are crimes, and they fall under the jurisdiction of international tribunals. That is why, Commissioner, it is now time to produce clear acts based on international law. We can suspend our partnership agreements with Israel as long as Israel does not comply with international law. We can recognize the State of Palestine with East Jerusalem as its capital. Finally, it is time to engage in diplomatic work to secure international protection for the Palestinian people and to help significantly strengthen the health system in Gaza, because it is in great need, it is an urgent one.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Hamas calls for storming the Israeli border and killing Israelis. As a result, Israel shot 62 violent perpetrators on 14 May. 50 of them were certainly identified as terrorists. While Trump and Netanyahu act and create realities, repeat their phrases here on a quarterly basis. Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. There won't be a two-state solution — that's reality. And the sooner people understand that this is the reality, the sooner dying stops, the sooner it will cease that Hamas can stretch people in front of their carts for their purposes, in the spirit that you unfortunately have been here for decades. Ladies and gentlemen, acknowledge the realities — everything else is European open heroism, cheap for 50 years. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: a blue card question. — My colleague, I would like to ask two questions. If you would be so kind as to tell me if you see any benefit in resolving the issue there of the two states of the transfer of the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. Secondly, I would like to ask you, are you absolutely sure that Israel wants any solution?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I can tell you that, for example, the Federal Republic of Germany, when Germany was still a divided state, had the Permanent Representation in East Berlin. East Berlin was subject to four-power status — quite comparable to what we have in Jerusalem today. In this respect, Germany has always taken a very pragmatic position, at least on its own. I wish that for Israel too. And I believe that Israel is particularly keen to find a solution: Israel wants to live. The Palestinians, and I say Hamas in particular — as far as we have to limit this — wants to kill Israelis in particular.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the question: 'Why are you killing Palestinians? ', the answer: 'Why can't we put them all in jail'. This is not the delirium of some fanatical Israeli settlerman. It is an official statement by the representative of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. So, so, yes or no? Is Israel a killer state or not? Lately alone, he has murdered over 100 and young children, and injured over 10 000 unarmed demonstrators protesting the movement of the American embassy to Jerusalem. Announce 200 other settlements. It expands the wretched wall into the sea, turning Gaza into the largest concentration camp. The European Union and the governments that continue to expand relations with Israel, such as the Syriza-ANEL government in Greece, refusing to recognise the Palestinian state, calling for self-restraint perpetrators and victims by equalizing them, shedding crocodile tears over disproportionate violence, effectively legitimize Israeli barbarity. Seventy years of sacrifice have not brought the Palestinian people to their knees. It continues to fight for a new independent state with its capital in East Jerusalem and it is certain that the Palestinian people will win.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, all over the Middle East there is a tragic situation developing in a dangerous and an alarming way. Brutality, atrocities, warfare, the warfare of the Syrian regime versus its own people, the Iranians threatening to eliminate the only democracy in the region, Iran present in Lebanon and Syria, Daesh, Hezbollah, Hamas. All these forces of violence and hate are the main reason for all the conflicts we see in the Middle East and all the losses of life we’re seeing. It’s all the time, in every case, a tragedy. But let’s be very clear about one thing. Those who are advocating hate, those who are advocating terrorism, must always bear the responsibility for the acts of terrorism and hate. Hamas, Hezbollah, Daesh, the Syrian Government, Iran: they are responsible for the atrocities done in their name and in the name of the anti-Semitism we face. We have reasons to criticise Israel when they use military force in a disproportionate manner, but we must recognise their right to defend their borders and blame those who are advocating violence.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President! I think it is important that we stand by our stance on the part of the EU. The basic stance that a two-state solution is the only possible one, with Jerusalem as the capital of both Palestine and Israel, because Jerusalem belongs to Christians, Muslims and Jews and thus both Palestinians and Israelis. We can't step off from that grounding. In contrast, we need to start asking critical questions about what we can actually accomplish and what we can do. What difference can we make? For example, we have the EU's association agreement with Israel. It has been seen as saying it would be a step towards a just peace. Has it really been? Have we seen any of that? Has it perhaps even been just the opposite, that it has favored expansive settler policy? All EU association agreements are conditional for human rights to be respected. Have we really been able to claim that in a clear way? Chapter Two of the agreement with Israel clearly states that human rights must be respected. If that doesn't happen, the deal could be lifted by the EU. Maybe we'd get a little tougher, even if we don't let go of our grounding stance. The European Union is one of the largest aid donors to the Palestinians. We invest; Israel destroys these investments all the time. It can be about water supply, it can be about roads, it can be about anything possible.
