We need to start showing that we don't accept that our investments, our efforts, are actually crushed, are being destroyed by the United States. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (“blue card”) in accordance with Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: question (“blue card”). — Gaza is under Hamas rule. Hamas is a terrorist organization that also applies Sharia law, which is directly brutal and oppressive against dissent and which uses all different means of terrorism. Today we saw rockets being shot from Gaza towards Israel. We've seen tunnels being built for military attacks. We have seen aid money being used for terrorism. I wonder, how does Marita Ulvskog look at Hamas rule?

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: answer (“blue card”). — I think what fatteth organizations like Hamas is our passive act. It is the passive action of the outside world, that we do not look to what is the basis for this whole grim, horrible conflict, that the Palestinians can have their own land as well and that you can have shared responsibility for Jerusalem. Every single time we fail to support such an exit, such a development, Hamas is strengthened and violence prevails.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: — Madam President, the most extreme minister in the Israeli government — Liberman — announced that days the construction of hundreds of millions of euros of an expensive wall intended to virtually close Palestinians living in a walled enclave, a path to the sea. All this is expected to strengthen the security of the state of Israel and its residents. Meanwhile, with disproportionate violence, his soldiers reckon cruelly with young Palestinians protesting the nahujskani from Hamas or merely expressing their outrage and helplessness at the permissibility of their life in this space that best fits the notion of concentration camp. Israel appropriates Palestinian territories and arrogantly communicates to the world that it recognises only its interest and its truth. Even a new wall, whether built on land, at sea or in the air, will not provide peace to Israel. The path there leads only via a bridge that you build with understanding and respectful of your neighbors, international law and the right to live for young Palestinians.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Madam President, I remain horrified by what has happened in Gaza in recent months. The Israeli army has already killed more than 100 Palestinians and injured thousands of them. In the face of those crimes, which cannot go unpunished, in the face of Trump's irresponsible policy and the Israeli government's ongoing and illegal policy of colonization, the European Union needs to leave behind ambiguity: on the one hand, criticize the occupation, but on the other, tolerate it. Let us from here that Israel respect international law, end the blockade of Gaza, the occupation of Palestine and allow two viable States, with an arms embargo, of the sale of arms to Israel; with the suspension of our Association Agreement with Israel as long as human rights are not respected; with a policy of effective differentiation, prohibiting the import of products from the colonies. It is time to reset the Union's policy with Israel. Occupation, colonization and repression must have an economic and political cost.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, following the epic battle of the heroic Israeli troops to repel the unacceptable attack of thousands of hungry, barefoot, disabled, children and elderly Palestinians, residents of Gaza's powerful military force, I believe that the European The Union must not remain impathetic and neutral, but must take effective initiatives to prevent such an attack on defenseless Israel from happening! I very much welcome the progress of the work of the underwater wall — unique in the world as Lieberman said — but also the construction of the underground wall around the Gaza border, so that Israel is not threatened by either fish or mice coming from Gaza. and will certainly be members of the Hamas terrorist organization! I suggest that the European Union fund this project and that its initiators should be nominated for the Sakharov Prize! Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, our debate today is proving to be offensive ironic on the thousands of graves of civilian stateless Palestinians, and I call on you to remember all of us in this Chamber what occupation means and what resistance means.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, last plenary session we adopted a resolution on the situation in Gaza, and even though it was before the recent unrest, I believe we can lean on this resolution. The European Parliament stresses Israel's right to defend itself against attacks and appeals to it not to use disproportionate means for that purpose. Unfortunately, we consider the recent incident and Israel's recent response to be disproportionate. Of course, we pity the sixty residents of Gaza who perished. We regret these sacrifices, but we also see this as the result of Hamas provocation. So whoever provoked, he bears responsibility. And it must be said that Hamas is a terrorist organization. We cannot stand Israel for the one that provoked this attack. The 1947 resolution pre-empts the certain status of Jerusalem. We, of course, perceive the right of every country to determine which city will be its capital. For us Christians, Jerusalem is a holy city and we know that it is equally important to both Judaism and Islam. We wish this city to be a city of peace and spiritual contemplation, not conflict and wars.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Madam President, many people rightly consider that Gaza is not a strip of land, but an open pit prison. Crises happen in this open pit prison, and each new crisis brings not a sum of devastating effects, but a multiplication on the previous situation. Before the latest events, which have brought so many dead and injured, he was already suffering a food crisis caused by the Trump administration's funding cut to the United Nations Palestine Refugees Agency, to the point that on July 1 food supplies can be suspended to more than a million people, the 70 per cent of the population of Gaza, who are dependent on this aid. Now the crisis in the health system is adding: how to care for thirteen thousand wounded in a health system that has not been provided. We welcome the aid of three million from the Commission, but a greater effort must be made not only for aid, but also for the achievement of peace.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Madam President! Following the decision by the US president recognising Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and leaders of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Palestine, there were riots, people were killed. Undoubtedly, these were political decisions. However, Jerusalem is the holy city of three religions: Judaism, Christianity and Islam. So we need to take into account the positions of their highest representatives. Immediately after the US declaration, Pope Francis appealed for Jerusalem's unique status to be maintained and respected. The Catholic Church on this issue has not changed its position for decades. Popes appealed for it: Paul VI, as well as John Paul II, who repeatedly stressed the need to maintain the international and transreligious status of that city. All the popes appealed for peace in the Middle East. The European Union, which has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, should continue its commitment on the basis of aid and dialogue in order to find a solution accepted by the parties to the conflict.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, since 30 March, Israel has murdered one hundred and twenty-one Palestinians — sixty-one on the same day as the transfer of the US embassy. Zero Israelis are dead. I think it's enough to equate victims and executioners. Mrs Mogherini questioned in a communiqué that Israel is respecting the right to peaceful protest and the principle of proportionality in the use of force. The Israeli energy minister's answer is that Europeans go to hell a thousand times. That was his answer. Israel is the occupying force under the Geneva Convention. It does not respect the United Nations agreements, nor does it respect the peace agreements it signed at the time, for example, those in Oslo. Israel had an Agreement with the European Union and its States since 1994. Indeed, as has already been said, article 2 speaks precisely of respect for human rights. Otherwise, the Agreement falls. I do not know, gentlemen of the Council, how many more Palestinians have to be put on the table, how much more ethnic cleansing is necessary for you to start acting and not having the hypocrisy you are having.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President! Let's not talk around the bush: Gaza has been a prison — and has been for ten years — for two million people. The prison guards are Israel, Egypt and Hamas. How do people react now, especially when they feel innocent and oppressed? They're revolting, they're trying to break out. If they do that, they are shot at, then there are deaths — dozens, wounded — thousands. In Gaza were also women and children. Is there a way out? Tom Friedman, the famous New York Times columnist, has a proposal. What would it be like, he writes, if all two million inhabitants went to the border with laurel branches and shouted, “We want peace! “? Would Hamas want that? What would Israel do then? The current state of affairs is more in line with Prime Minister Netanyahu's concept: no progress in the peace process and all blame will shift to the Palestinians. But couldn't the EU maybe...? Well, we're waiting for that — hopefully not in vain.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, the Gaza population is in a miserable condition, which also means that we could not find a better environment for manipulation and the rise of extremism. I am sorry to say – probably some colleagues will be passionately opposed here – but it is the Palestinian Authority that has for years been consciously abusing the people of Gaza for their despicable political gain. The latest incident where almost 60 Palestinians died is another proof of that. The death of each one of them is a tragedy, of course, but it has to be said that Hamas planned the violent events way in advance. Most of the Palestinians killed during the violent riots on the Israel-Gaza borders were members of a terror organisation. A Hamas official, Salah Al—Bardawil, admitted in an interview to a local TV station that 50 out of the 62 Palestinians killed were Hamas terrorists. Also, Hamas orchestrated the violent riots with the purpose of breaching the Israel-Gaza border and threatening the communities located near the fence. This was published on YouTube, so I think it was prepared to create violence.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Last week I was in Israel visiting the Knesset and NGOs, among others. The escalation in and around Gaza, like settlement policy, is being viewed critically within Israel. A return march for Palestinians is understandable for some and a provocation for others. But in any case, it's no reason to use lethal ammunition against angry demonstrators and journalists. Netanyahu was to face an independent investigation into the escalation in the Gaza Strip. This would also make Hamas' responsibility public. The head of the joint list from Israel told me last week: internal Israeli conflicts are not resolved from the outside, and the Israeli opposition is needed for this. The US embassy relocation was counterproductive. It is moving farther and farther from the urgent two-state solution. So let us also strengthen the peaceful, critical and oppositional Israelis in order to give more opportunities to the guarantee of human rights in the region. It is not Israel that is our enemy, but the government of Netanyahu.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! The deaths of dozens of Palestinians and wounds sustained by thousands are undeniably a tragic event. We should express our regret and offer our sincere condolences to the families of the dead. By contrast, we should at the same time think carefully about the reasons and not make conclusions just based on media reports or facts like Washington's December decision. It is necessary to take into account internal factors — here I agree with a fellow ECR — that play a fundamental role in this conflict. I mean, above all, the political struggle between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority authorities, which has taken on strength in the last year. Ramallah's decision to stop paying Gaza's electricity, cut Gaza officials' salaries by 30%, intentionally withholding payouts in April, accuse Hamas of trying to kill Autonomy Prime Minister Rami Hamd Allah — without these facts, it is impossible to understand the entirety of the intentions of the grand organizers march of return and its violent course.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Mr President, I missed my time because I was in a shadow meeting on my EU-China report, so I am glad that you give me a little more time. I stand here with a heavy heart because of European policy in the Middle East: a policy which I reject rationally, but also morally totally. In particular, I rationally reject the European hunt for good relations with the Islamic Republic of Iran. See Tehran's destabilising military advance in the Middle East, see also Tehran's close links with terrorist organisations Hezbollah and Hamas. What happened in Gaza gets applause in Tehran. Do they sometimes serve European security interests in the region, as the High Representative says? Morally, I completely dissociate myself from the European policy that does not allow the international legitimacy of Israel's naked existence to be fully applied to the Ayatollah regime, which is not only rhetorically but by deeds the Jewish state and its citizens. On 20 June, the parents and brother of the Israeli soldier Hadar Goldin killed by Hamas came to Brussels. Their heart's wish: return of his body to Israel for a worthy burial. I am counting on European humanitarian aid.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, just this morning, militants fired rounds of heavy mortar from Gaza into southern Israel, alarming the Israeli air and land defences and, in the end, strongly jeopardising any chances of improving the situation in the region. The opening of the US Embassy in Jerusalem ignited the fire in the region and resulted only in clashes. Thousands were killed and thousands wounded.  After these weeks of protests at the Israeli border what, if anything, has been accomplished? Hamas has gained more publicity in the international press and Israel was condemned for disproportionate use of force against mostly unarmed protesters. If President Trump had the intention to mobilise and inflame Islamic fundamentalists and radicals, then he has achieved his goal.  Being a true friend of Israel, we, the European Union, should refrain from such political actions as moving embassies. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Madam President, Israel commits crimes against humanity by murdering men, women and children who in despair protest against continuing to vegetate in the oppression of the world's largest prison, Gaza. Israel helped create Hamas to legitimize Fatah and today collects the bitter pay not only on the 30 rockets delivered over its cities, but in the blockade of the two-state solution. A blockade that effectively threatens Israel's existence. Israel delegitimizes itself by violating the Geneva Conventions, UN resolutions, and by denying the conditions of a viable Palestinian state. And the European Union is working against itself, against its security, disrespect when it takes refuge in humanitarian palliatives and soft words in the face of everything that stirres the conflict in the Middle East, such as the transfer of the American embassy to Jerusalem, and refrains from acting to stop Israel from calling into question regional and global peace and security.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: — Mr President, the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians continues, largely because the peace process is based on unrealistic objectives. Israel is not going to evacuate half a million Jews from so-called occupied territory, and it is certainly not going to give up East Jerusalem. There are historical and psychological reasons for this, but also legitimate, safety-related reasons. The two-state model is utopian. As long as the international community sticks to these unrealistic demands, the peace process will remain in the stalemate it has been in for more than twenty years. Sure, the US decision to move the embassy to Jerusalem is partly Trump's domestic policy, but it is also a recognition of facts. So it's kind of a step forward.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, I would like to add a new picture to the debate. There is journalistic information this afternoon that a flotilla carrying Palestinians is leaving Gaza, according to journalistic information, towards Cyprus. I think, Mr Hahn, that we must immediately see whether this will cause new violence and new murders by Israel and what action the European Union can take to avoid further bloodshed. The second thing I have to say is that I understand that there is no one in here who is pro-terrorism, and I, much more than anyone else, want to raise my voice against terrorism. But I wonder what any of us would do if they were imprisoned in an open prison for so many years. We must also look at the causes of this violence sometime.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, between the last plenary and this plenary there were other demonstrations with 62 deaths and about 2 000 wounded. Among the casualties probably some Hamas militants, but surely also many civilians. At this very delicate moment, in addition to legitimate complaints against the disproportionate use of force by the Israeli army, there is also a need for a pars construcens. I therefore feel that I fully welcome the proposals of the UN Special Envoy for Peace in the Middle East, Nicolay Mladenov, who in reiterating as almost all major infrastructure in Gaza, in particular electrical, sanitary and water-related ones, are on the verge of collapse. He proposes a plan, and therefore the adoption of a rapid system, enabling the management and implementation of UN projects on the ground, strengthening and coordination between Palestinian authorities, Israel and Egypt for overcoming the aforementioned obstacles, the call of all parties involved to commit to a lasting ceasefire, as established in 2014, the identification of design priorities in Gaza for the next two years.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I have been to Lebanon in Lebanon for the past few weeks, I came back from Iran last week, and I see it as a scandal how terrorism is being discussed here and which is granted to individual organisations. Because terror always has a cause, and that cause is seventy years ago. Imagine that three generations of Palestinians live in the camps today, all of whom have been expelled from their homes, how bulldozers rolled their houses, how bulldozers rolled their houses, how Israeli settlements built there. They experienced that their fathers did not return from demonstrations, their mothers, their brothers, their sisters. And when they begin to fight back and fight a struggle for freedom for their people, they will be disqualified as terrorists here. With the same right, the attacks by the Israeli Air Force on peaceful settlements and camps can be described as terrorist attacks.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Madam Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, the south of Israel woke up this morning in the sound and smoke of the biggest rocket attack since 2014, with one of the rockets falling right next to the kindergarten moments before its opening. Hamas, which has governed the Gaza Strip for more than a decade, uninterrupted attacks on Israel day after day makes the lives of the inhabitants of southern Israel dangerous and unsafe by putting them incessantly at the center of a war zone. Hamas is a terrorist organisation that endangers civilian populations on both sides of the border with people living in fear every day. Security is thus becoming an increasing challenge in the Middle East. Israel is the only stable democracy in that space celebrating seventy years of independence this year. Jerusalem is not only the capital of Israel, but also a sacred place for believers of three great religions. His status has been a subject of debate throughout history. What is important is that security in the city and the freedom to practice all faiths have never been questioned, and it should remain that way.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the blockade of Gaza continues to create an unbearable situation for the people living there, and Europe’s indifference is both shameful and unacceptable. Meanwhile, President Trump’s disrespect for human dignity grows more and more appalling. His condoning of Israel’s policies towards the Palestinians is extremely worrying. I fear that the violence in Gaza will continue as long as the blockade exists. Palestinians will continue to protest their fundamental rights, and it is likely that the Israeli army will continue to use lethal violence against them.  The situation in the West Bank is also worrying, and I wish particularly to mention the situation of Khan al-Ahmar Bedouin school, which is facing imminent demolition against an international outcry. The only viable scenario for peace is for the EU to step in and take a strong leadership role in the Middle East. The High Representative and the Member States should condemn, in the strongest terms, Israel’s hostile policy towards the Palestinians alongside the condemnation of Hamas.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Fathi Harb is a boy in his 20s, he has no money or work, and his wife is expecting the first child. So, on the night of May 19 last year, Fathi attempted suicide by setting himself on fire. Fathi is just one of many young Palestinians in the Strip trapped in the rampant poverty of an open-air prison, a prison where the total lack of food and medicine adds up to one 45% unemployment. And so mass protests begin. And if on the one hand there are stones, bottles and Molotov bombs, on the other hand the live fire of the bullets of the Israeli armed forces ready to strike without hesitation. The toll tells us there were 60 deaths and 2 800 wounded. The only justification: the threatening shadow of Hamas. The right to defend itself does not legitimize the lawfulness of such a horrible bloodbath. We call on Israel to stick to the values of a democracy, exercise self-control and stop this needless loss of life. The High Representative brings everyone around a table to reason. The first enemy of peace is precisely this unacceptable status quo.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this European Parliament does not have the executive capacity to intervene in a conflict that lasts seventy years, but it does require the Commission to be consistent with the issues outlined in the resolutions we have adopted in this House. The first is that Israel had the right to its existence and security, but the Palestinian people also had the right to a State of its own in a two-State solution; the second, that a disproportionate use of force that has cost more than 100 killed in Gaza and thousands and thousands injured and therefore deserves condemnation; third, that the research promoted by the United Nations Human Rights Council must be supported; and the fourth, which clearly tells us that not only is the unilateral decision of the Trump Administration to transfer the embassy that has given rise to this terrible bloodbath, but it is also contrary to the law International — United Nations Resolution 478 — and that there is therefore no future or solution acceptable to the European Union which should not be in respect of international law and humanitarian law.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this has been a very useful, timely and necessary exchange, and I thank all of you for your interventions.  From this debate, I have concluded that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic power and EU instruments to their full potential in support of the Middle East peace process and with the objective of a negotiated two-state solution. Our priority at the moment is for all sides to avoid any actions that could lead to further violence or loss of life. Further escalation of an already tense and complex situation would only cause more suffering and will make the prospects for peace and security even more remote. It would be a gift to the extremists and to those who are not interested in peace and security and living together but are, in fact, opposed to it.  Ensuring humanitarian access to Gaza is also urgent in order to avoid the number of casualties rising further. Certainly, there is a need for an independent and transparent investigation into the incidents, not least focused on the use of live ammunition, so that we can understand what has happened and why.  Finally, it remains essential to restore a political horizon and hope for people on the ground. Wisdom and courage are needed in order to go back to the negotiations for a lasting political solution for the sake of both Israelis and Palestinians. Only the two-state solution will realistically allow both sides to fulfil their aspirations and put an end to the conflict. The Union is ready to play its role and fully supports the resumption of a meaningful peace process, together with regional and international partners.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. – We were all shocked by the news about clashes in Gaza, about the dead and injured people. Meanwhile, we know the power of images often re-writes the truth. Recordings of the injured, dead protesters overshadow the fact that the violent demonstrations didn’t explode on their own but were organised by Hamas, which the EU lists as terrorist organisation. Hamas encouraged protesters to break through the border fence and to carry weapons, including home-made explosive devices; Hamas sent women and children near the border fence and didn’t allow Israeli aid transport in Gaza on 11 May and on 16 May. Hamas didn’t do anything to keep the demonstrations peaceful but rather agitated for violence. So to place responsibility on Israel’s shoulders alone is more than an error, it is a serious political mistake. As all states, Israel has the right to defend its borders. If there were abuses or unjustified use of firearms, the military will investigate it, the same way they’ve been doing all this time. If we conduct a one-sided policy in judging the situation, it will not contribute to Middle Eastern peace. We need to stop one-sidedly condemning Israel and we need to stand firmly against Palestinian terrorism.

name: Kati PIRI
text: in writing. — A Brussels square full of empty shoes — 4 500 in total — symbolized the number of victims in the Gaza Strip since 2008 on Monday afternoon. The whole world is looking again at Israel and Palestine, including the European Foreign Ministers who met that day to talk about the flared tensions. That protests would break out in the run-up to the 70th anniversary of the State of Israel was in line with the expectation. And without prejudice to the long history and complexity of the problem, the disproportionate violence on the part of the Israeli side is unheard of. Shooting at protesters who do not pose an acute threat is unacceptable and, moreover, it further escalates. An independent investigation into the acts of violence is desirable. Both sides are obliged to their citizens to take their seats (back) at the negotiating table, because only a two-state solution can put an end to this decade of conflict. This means stopping settlement policy, causing violence and refraining from unilateral action.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. – The humanitarian situation in Gaza is unsustainable. The Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip is a form of collective punishment, like an open-air prison. The blockade is preventing the entry of building materials and spare parts that enable the rebuilding of Gaza's bombed hospitals, schools and infrastructure. It forces the Palestinians in Gaza to live without equal access to healthcare, medicine, food, water, electricity and education. I condemn the US government’s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. The EU has a clear, consolidated position on Jerusalem: the EU will continue to respect the international consensus on Jerusalem embodied in, inter alia, UN Security Council Resolution 478, including on the location of diplomatic representations until the final status of Jerusalem is resolved. On Tuesday, Gaza militants launched rockets across the border and Israel hit back with air strikes. The EU has to stop this escalating violence immediately. No more time for silent observers! Now is the moment for the EU to speed up the process towards the two-state solution, the only way to secure a peaceful and fair future for both people.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Nicaragua (2018/2711(RSP)). The Vice-President is replaced in the debate and will be represented by Commissioner Stylianides.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, above all, the violence in Nicaragua should stop immediately. What is needed to start again is a genuine dialogue: this is the only way to see peace and prosperity in this country. It has been over a month since the announced reform of the social security system, the first protests and the first violence against protesters. Tens of people have been killed since then, many of them students. Let me start by conveying again our sincere condolences to the families of the victims, and expressing hopes for a quick recovery to all those who were injured.  Immediately after the unrest began, we reacted publicly and condemned the violence. The people of Nicaragua have the full right to protest peacefully and to freely express their disagreement. It is vital that the police forces act with maximum restraint, that armed groups are reined in, and that all perpetuators of violence are brought to justice.  Over the last weekend, violence unfortunately escalated again: we have seen reports of more casualties among peaceful protesters, resulting from attacks by armed and organised mobs. Yesterday two universities were attacked, as well as a pro—government radio station. Participants in the national dialogue – be they students, private sector representatives or bishops – continue to endure threats and intimidation. These threats must immediately stop, as must violence in the country. The Nicaraguan authorities agreed to invite the Inter—American Commission on Human Rights to the country, and this was a really positive development. It is now essential that the 15 recommendations by the Commission are followed up. Yesterday’s meeting of the ‘three plus three’ mixed commission, with government and opposition representatives, has agreed to start implementing the first three recommendations: first, a halt to repression and arbitrary detentions; second, respect for the right to protest peacefully; and, third, an independent, international investigation into the violence to guarantee truth and justice. This is an important first step and we hope this decision will be implemented with no delay. We also consider it important that the government authorises a visit by the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights to the country. Meanwhile, all efforts must be made to push the national dialogue forward, and let me thank the Conference of Bishops for the important and crucial role it played in these very difficult circumstances.  After three sessions, last week the dialogue was unfortunately suspended due to a lack of progress. Yesterday’s meeting of the mixed commission has agreed to restart the dialogue later this week, and this is another positive sign and surely very positive news. We very much hope that dialogue will indeed restart as announced: it is the best hope to find a way out of the current crisis. To achieve this objective, several guarantees should be provided to build trust among participants in the dialogue. The first step should be to ensure the necessary security to all those who take part in this dialogue.  On another front, the European Union is also following very closely the dialogue between the Organisation of American States and Nicaragua on political and electoral reforms, which was initiated after the 2017 municipal elections. This process should take into account the demands presented by civil society at the national dialogue, as well as the latest recommendations issued by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights.  The people of Nicaragua are asking for greater social justice and increased political accountability, and they have the right to have their voice heard. On our side, as the European Union, we are ready to support a broad dialogue on democracy and justice between all sectors of society and the Government in Nicaragua. We care about Nicaragua and its people and we are already engaged in the country in support of human rights, education, economic growth and in the fight against climate change. Our Latin American friends know we are a partner for peace and for reconciliation, and we have already accompanied several peace dialogues in the continent. If our help is requested, we are ready to step up our engagement to help overcome the crisis. Let us help Nicaragua end this crisis through dialogue and mediation, before more blood is unfortunately spilt.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, allow me before starting my analysis to express my solidarity with the two Efe journalists who have just been assaulted and mistreated by the regime's repressive police. History, ladies and gentlemen, is repeated. The Sandinista revolution that legitimized its struggle against dictator Somoza has gradually become an authoritarian power. The model, Cuba. A dictator is removed and a new dictatorship is created. Nicaragua's current situation is causing a democratic crisis in the face of the country's dictatorial diversion. The correlation of forces created by the social revolt forced the regime to accept the possibility of dialogue and mediation by the Church, after 76 dead, 868 wounded, 438 detainees and countless wounded and missing. Sadly, the current Government refused to accept the conditions for dialogue, and even the bishops decided to suspend the negotiations indefinitely. The popular response was immediate. The problem of possible exit scenarios for the crisis is to be resolved and the type of exit is unclear. Ladies and gentlemen, the president is trying to stay in power, diverting or sending a message of force to silence popular pressure. This is unacceptable. The exit involves drawing up an itinerary and concrete measures to move towards the expression of the majority will. This implies, ladies and gentlemen, over. It means regime change. The European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, can and should take action and the motion for a resolution we support is reasonable and proportionate to the gravity of the facts.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the protests that have taken place in Nicaragua have shown social discontent, a very profound democratic crisis. This is not just a response to social security measures; what has become apparent is that there is a citizenry fed up, tired of a democratic system that is not, which does not work as such: concentration of media and economic power in a family clan — to put an example — a little constructed opposition; lack of a independent justice; corruption... There was a need to protest and the village has gone out into the streets. The truth is that the demonstrations have been responded with enormous repression, with repression that has led to more than 80 people dead and hundreds injured, a totalitarian repression considered typical of an almost dictatorial system. I wonder, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of what revolution can be met in this way to popular demands. I wonder, ladies and gentlemen, how is it possible to defend a proposal that abort freedoms and democracy in the name of socialism. I want to tell you — I am a socialist — that there is no socialism without freedom and without democracy. That is why tomorrow the European Parliament is going to ask for four things which I find fundamental: condemn the Government, because it has acted repressively and deserves condemnation; embrace the victims' families; demand that the Government cease repression — there can be no repression when there is a demonstration and demand for freedom like this; and that dialogue should continue, that the dialogue includes important political reforms, and that such reforms could incorporate a reform of the electoral law and probably elections that would enable the people to speak and decide.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the momentum behind the political unrest that has been on-going in Nicaragua for over a month now seems to be slowing, but nevertheless, what started out as a low-key protest about social welfare cuts has escalated into a vicious cycle of government brutal crack-downs, heightening anti-Government feelings. I too welcome the decision of the Government to invite the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights to observe the situation regarding human rights, as well as the setting up of a specific commission to look into the deaths of protesters. Freedom of expression and of assembly is an essential element of a democratic society. However, protests need to be conducted peacefully, and of course it is unacceptable to incite further violence. But the authoritarian Government of Nicaragua should also act with maximum restraint. Tragically, this does not seem to be the case recently, and I too would like to send my sincere condolences to all those mourning their loved ones who have been lost during this troubled month in Nicaragua’s rather painful history.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, a country that silences freedom of expression is not a democracy. Security forces that hurt their citizens are not the legitimate protectors of a nation. A president who violates the human rights of his people is not his representative. Any country that murders unarmed protesters is a dictatorship. While many abroad are surprised by the sudden turn of events in the brutal repression seen in the news, let us be clear: Nicaragua has not been a democracy for a long time. Repression in the past month is the culmination of years of authoritarianism, repression and fragmentation of democratic processes and institutions. The authorities must immediately cease any form of violence against demonstrators and release all prisoners arbitrarily detained. Negotiations must bring about real change; a change that all Nicaraguans yearn for; a change that will only be achieved through free and fair elections. What Nicaragua needs is the end of the current authoritarian regime and national reconciliation. The first step is to convene new free elections and to establish a balanced Truth Commission with independent members. The European Union must be prepared to help in any way possible.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, it is curious how violence is treated in this Parliament: if it is a government that is friendly to the majority, solidarity and condemnation; if it is not, we tolerate — until we often reach the encouragement — what we call elsewhere as street terrorism. Nicaragua today is experiencing a situation of violence that must stop, illegitimate. From the GUE/NGL Group, we have regretted and condemned the loss of human life, we have called for those responsible to be brought before the courts and that the Government investigate and prosecute any disproportionate use of force. What is positive is the launching of a national dialogue with the mediation of the Church that resumed yesterday, the incorporation of human rights recommendations or the launch of an international investigative mechanism. But this violence must cease. Yesterday, peaceful protesters burned a media outlet; today a young man and a policeman died. It cannot be tolerated that by violent means an attempt to overthrow an elected and legitimate Government. This Parliament and the European Union must accompany dialogue and condemn Nicaragua's violence and destabilization.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, I fully agree with my Socialist colleague Atondo that there could be no Socialism without democratic liberties. The crisis of democracy in Nicaragua has resulted in massive repressions by the Government, accompanied by attacks on civil liberties and silencing journalists. I would like especially to remember Ángel Gahona, an investigative journalist who was shot dead on 21 April. Tomorrow will mark six weeks of such brutal repressions, and that is really enough. I would suggest four priorities. First, we demand that the Nicaraguan Government immediately stop violence against their own citizens. Second, these violent acts need an independent international investigation to bring to accountability those responsible for the deaths of demonstrators. Third, the functioning of civil liberties and freedom of the press must be fully restored, and we call for an electoral reform which will provide for fair and credible elections under international standards. Early elections would be a sensible short- term compromise in such a dramatic standoff, offering both sides a democratic solution. People in Nicaragua are entitled to express their voice now, and it is really alarming that the Government has so far refused the solution, and we call on the European Commission and the Member States to exercise coordinated pressure on the Nicaraguan authorities to make them follow the priorities presented by the European Parliament.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Madam President, our role, indeed, is to call for an end to violence and repression and to maintain a path of dialogue — which began and has cooled — between the Ortega regime and the opposition, civil society and human rights organisations. Our role is to call for dialogue. Because history or psychology will be responsible for explaining how a commander of the revolution, who bravely freed his country from a bloody regime like Somoza's, has become someone who defends the interests of the oligarchy and represses its people. That is not for politics to explain it. But the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has made recommendations that Ortega must listen to; the Episcopal Conference, too; and civil society, gathered at that dialogue table, too. If Ortega listens, then it will probably be possible to open a new path in Nicaragua, and Nicaraguans will decide where he travels. Our role is to call for dialogue, an end to repression and for a new time to be resetted in Nicaragua.

name: Javier NART
text: Mr President, the honourable Sandinista movement has been betrayed by a corrupt regime, which is the regime of Daniel Ortega and his wife Doña Rosario, and which today reproduces the same repression for which the Sandinista people, the Nicaraguan people fought heroically in 1978. Today the Sandinista oligarchic regime, Daniel Ortega's oligarchic regime, is a shame to Nicaragua and the western world. And I'm not talking about something else: in June 1978 I had the honor of participating with the FSLN in the fight against the genocidal Somoza regime and was wounded on the southern front. And by the way, in that place and then, when we were fighting Somoza, there was no member of any of the political parties that now support Daniel Ortega.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, from the very beginning, as chairman of the Delegation for relations with the countries of Central America, I condemned the violence which resulted in the loss of human lives in Nicaragua. Violence is not a solution and in no way can it be accepted. Open and inclusive dialogue, with full respect for human rights, is the only solution for me. The Government of Nicaragua is obliged to do the self-evident, i.e. thorough scrutiny of the circumstances of the deaths and accountability of those responsible, and the Inter-American Human Rights Commission must make a catalyst for this. At the same time, however, we are obliged to condemn the attempts of those who, inside and outside the country, exploit these tragic events in order to destabilise the country on the altar of micro-political interests, and to press for the dialogue initiated by the government to continue to come up positively for the benefit of citizens. It is our duty, ladies and gentlemen, to contribute to a spirit of peace and consensus among all the citizens of the country. Any other unilateral agenda, I think, should find us against it.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, the events that have occurred in Nicaragua since 18 April are extremely serious. As of today, 84 people have died, some 860 have been injured and there are more than 400 detainees. The violent repression carried out by the security forces and by irregular armed groups was indeed unacceptable. Obviously, it was necessary that facts of this gravity be investigated and I am pleased that a delegation from the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights could visit the country. Yesterday, partial follow-up to the recommendations contained in the report of this committee began, but also yesterday it was regrettable that serious acts of violence occurred in the centre of Managua with one dead and dozens of wounded. Unfortunately also — as Luis de Grandes said — two journalists from the Spanish agency Efe were assaulted by the police. On the other hand, it is necessary to advance the so-called “national dialogue” which the Episcopal Conference has strongly promoted, which began on 16 May, but interrupted on the 22nd. I therefore welcome the fact that there was also a meeting of the Joint Committee for this dialogue yesterday: it is very important that it make progress on the so-called 'democratisation agenda'. And I'm done. We need to follow closely the developments in the situation. Nicaragua is a friendly country and partner of the European Union within the framework of the Association Agreement with the countries of Central America. But this Agreement is based on the so-called “democratic clause”, which obliges respect for the principles of the rule of law, democracy and human rights.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Mr President, a government, even if democratically elected, loses all legitimacy when it comes into conflict with the rule of law. Unfortunately, that is what has been going on in Nicaragua and, in fact, not just now. A clear repression of fundamental freedoms, an unacceptable concentration of all powers, a tendency towards corrupt practices. In other words, the current government of Nicaragua deserves and must, from the outset, deserve a profound and clear condemnation from the European Parliament. Secondly, of course, we must call for dialogue. Nevertheless, the doors are not closed so that, under the mediation of the Catholic Church, a dialogue between the various parties involved in this confrontation can be held and, in this perspective, we must not only appeal to this same dialogue, but also to express our willingness to participate in it, if perhaps it will prove useful in order to rebuild the conditions for Nicaragua to live a liberal democracy in its fullness.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are concerned about the incidents of violence that are taking place in Nicaragua and which have caused the deaths of at least 76 protesters, as well as numerous wounded people who opposed to Social Security reform. The Inter-American Human Rights Council, which paid a visit to the country, denounced the indiscriminate use of firearms by law enforcement agencies, as well as arbitrary arrests, mistreatment of detainees and intimidation against journalists, and there are numerous NGOs calling for the government of Nicaragua to immediately cease repressions and violence, promoting a serious dialogue national peace and have independent investigations to identify and process perpetrators of acts of violence. It is therefore necessary, Commissioner, for the European Union to intervene with the Nicaraguan authorities to ensure full respect for human rights and in particular freedom of expression and to manifest their ideas in a peaceful manner.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, as a human rights campaigner, I would like to express my solidarity with the protesters against Daniel Ortega’s oppressive regime. The Nicaraguan people’s struggle has been continuing for a long time, as they believed that the end of the Somoza rule would mean freedom in their country. The women, in particular, have been fighting for their rights on the ground, but have never been truly heard. For instance, abortion laws are extremely restrictive as they do not allow women to terminate pregnancy under any circumstances.  The European Union should be playing a much more active role in finding a solution to the crisis that the country is currently facing. An inclusive and transparent dialogue bringing an end to the violence, led by a strong European Union, offers a viable solution.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I should like to begin by congratulating you and those of course other Members who have done the same, for your reference to the fact that those who have executed innocent demonstrators must be sought and brought before the courts. Let me say, however, that I see a contradiction with regard to the previous debate on the executions of innocent Palestinians, where no such request was made by your colleague, Mr Hahn. I cannot understand this differentiation, not only on the part of the Commission but also on behalf of colleagues. Previously, they also found a way to justify the killings of the Palestinians, when they are now asking for responsibility - and I am right, I am also demanding - both in the case of the Palestinians and in the case of the Nicaraguan demonstrators. We are concerned by our political views, not by our faith in freedom and peace, and that does not make us effective.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there was a spark — the proposal for reform of the social system — to break out hell in Nicaragua. Since then 76 people have died in the clashes. The profound motives for the protest are many, but at the base there is an accusation by Ortega, in his third term, of attempting to create a dictatorship in the country. First students and then more and more people have therefore taken to the streets to protest, each with their own demands, each with their own history. The reaction was violent and was unacceptable: Law enforcement, as evidenced by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, responded with a disproportionate and indiscriminate use of force . I firmly believe that the only possible solution to every crisis is dialogue. The parties must return as soon as possible to the negotiating table of national dialogue and as a Union we must support the process and the strengthening of democracy in every way. But I have an invitation for President Ortega: if you really love your people, as I believe, stop violence towards your citizens, sit down, listen to them, talk to them, negotiate. Be prepared to step back if necessary. This is the right thing to do, the only one.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, it has been a very fruitful exchange, and I thank the honourable Members in the European Parliament for their interventions. From the discussion, I can conclude that we all have a common interest in promoting peace and dialogue for sustainable development for the benefit of, and in respect of, the will of all Nicaraguans. What is at stake is not only the stability of the country, but also the stability of the Central American region. As the European Union, we have historic ties with this region: not only political and economic ties, but also cultural ties. We will continue to follow the situation closely and make sure that our political capital and all available instruments – all available European instruments – can be used to support Nicaragua at this very difficult juncture for the Nicaraguan people. I would like to close this discussion by signalling once again my personal appreciation of the European Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda. As you already underlined, the only way is to focus on this issue and to prevent it from becoming a forgotten crisis.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: In accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions were taken. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, May 31, 2018. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. — What is happening in Nicaragua is regrettable. The repression and intimidation of peaceful publishers must be stopped immediately; the duty of Nicaraguan security forces is to protect citizens, not to leave or kill them without protection. A thorough investigation must also be carried out to identify the perpetrators of acts of violence and to prosecute them. To end the violence and resolve the crisis, it is necessary that both sides return to the negotiating table again. Unfortunately, lackling corruption in the country is seriously undermining the functioning of the country's institutions and restricting foreign investment. The constant extension of President Ortega's tenure, too, is inconsistent with the judiciary and illegal, clearly violating the right to democratic elections. The EU must seriously monitor the situation in Nicaragua and, if necessary, take appropriate action.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on US tariffs in the steel and aluminium industries and the EU response (2018/2697 (RSP)).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our trade and investment relationship with the US is becoming increasingly complex and it will require careful political management in the weeks ahead. We are very concerned from the Commission side about the US unilateral initiatives that are undermining the multilateral trading system. The temporary exemption for the EU from US measures on steel and aluminium runs until 31 May. In the absence of a new decision by the President of the United States, tariffs of 25% for steel and 10% for aluminium will apply to EU exports as from 1 June. That is on Friday.  I have stayed in regular contact with the US Secretary of Commerce, Secretary Ross. We have spoken numerous times over the phone and we will meet in Paris later this week – tomorrow, in fact – on the margins of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Ministerial Council Meeting. This will be an important moment, but it is clear that the final decision will be made by President Trump himself.  The Commission has continued to argue for a full, permanent and unconditional exemption from these tariffs while the US has sought to use the threat of trade restrictions as leverage to obtain not only a cap on future EU exports on steel and aluminium but also assurances on the content and goals of a future bilateral agenda to address market access irritants.  As you know, in their meeting in Sofia last week, EU leaders gave clear guidance saying that if there was an unlimited exemption for the EU from the US Section 232 measures on steel and aluminium, the Commission would be encouraged to explore a potential positive agenda with the US. Such an agenda would be based on four tracks: first, a deeper relationship on energy issues, notably in the field of trade in liquefied natural gas; second, voluntary regulatory cooperation between selected regulatory authorities on an ad hoc basis; third, joint work towards World Trade Organisation (WTO) reform to level the playing field and towards mutually acceptable solutions to lift the current blockage of the WTO upload body nomination; and fourth, discussions for reciprocal improvements in market access for industrial products, including cars and car parts, and liberalisation of goods in public procurement. This is the positive agenda that we are offering the United States.  Realistically, if the US decides to refrain from applying duties, I expect them, nonetheless, to want impose some sort of cap on EU exports. The question is whether that would be a hard cap, meaning volume limits above which no further EU exports would be possible, or a soft cap, under which further exports would be possible, but under duties. A soft cap of this nature would be less damaging than a strict hard cap. The volume of any tradable immigration quotas (TIQs) as well as their management and administration are also very important aspects to take into consideration.  Our future course of action will depend on the nature and the severity of the measures imposed on our exports by the United States and on the harm that they cause our industry. If the United States imposes restrictive quotas, the Commission will prepare a fresh implementing regulation that will include some immediate rebalancing on imports from the US, based on the list that you are familiar with it, but still at a level significantly lower than would be the case if they were to impose duties rather than quotas. We are also ready to launch a WTO settlement case.  The Commission is ready to take an appropriate safeguard action to protect our own steel market if it is shown to be justified by the investigation that is underway already. We have put in a prior surveillance system in place on aluminium so that we have a strong information basis in case action becomes called for in that section too.  I would like to thank the European Parliament for the strong support you have given to the Commission so far. The importance of your outreach vis—à—vis US counterparts through legislative dialogue is not to be underestimated. With midterm elections approaching, I wish to encourage you to continue to meet with and to convey our concerns on US trade policy to our US interlocutors. It is important at this moment that the European Union stands united and, I think, so far we have done so, and I’ll be looking forward to coming back and reporting to you the outcome of the coming days. Hopefully, it will be a positive agenda that we can see, with no tariffs or quotas but, realistically, I don’t think we can expect that.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner. In principle, the EPP supports the Commission's approach of insisting the EU on a permanent exemption from import restrictions on steel and aluminium before the EU may then take a second step towards possible trade talks at the negotiating table. At the same time, despite all the current political upheavals, it should be clear to everyone that the reduction of tariffs and other barriers to transatlantic trade must continue to be the overall objective of all negotiations. Donald Trump's protectionist strategy cannot work, because, as many years of experience shows, tariffs only help inefficient producers. They are de facto delaying and aggravating the problems, threatening jobs in their own country, as we have seen several times. The real problem in the international steel market is not de facto in Europe, but it is in Asia, whose overcapacity is destroying prices. It would be in the interests of both the US and the EU to agree on a common approach. For a time, the US side seemed ready to do so, rather than carrying expensive and useless trade skirmishes. Commissioner, we are on your side and look forward to further cooperation.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. What we are currently seeing is an attack on the rules-based trading system. This applies not only to the EU, but also to 163 other countries of the World Trade Organisation. Arbitrary foreclosure tariffs are used here to protect the domestic steel market. This is clearly contrary to WTO rules. In addition, Mr Trump relies on a 1963 Cold War law to discuss national security. It is quite clear that steel has nothing to do with national security in this context. There are also the first complaints in the United States against this action by the President. We must show a clear position of the European Union, and here we clearly support the Commissioner: no softening of the positioning. We can talk about reforms, but not under pressure. There won't be any dirty deals under pressure. It has nothing to do with national security, but rather the action of the American president endangers international security.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, three months after President Trump announced that he would impose tariffs on steel and aluminium, I regret that we are still debating the issue and the EU hasn’t got a permanent exclusion from these tariffs. I consider this to be a misguided action that will mostly affect strategic trading partners such as the UK and the EU, both long-standing and key security allies of the US and who are also affected by the same unfair practices. I have stressed before that the UK and the EU’s exports are not the cause of difficulties facing steel and aluminium producers in the US. The main pressures arise from overcapacity that is rooted in market distortive practices. Therefore it is not fair that our industries pay the price for something that they have not created, and it is important that the US recognises this and grants the EU a permanent exception. I reiterate that it is important to avoid a trade conflict, and the EU is prepared to exercise its rights within the framework of the WTO. We must use the multilateral trading system and dispute settlement as a vehicle to ensure third-country compliance with international commitments. We have heard about negotiations on trade concessions in order to secure a permanent exemption from these tariffs. As a free trade advocate, I would welcome any effort to liberalise trade, but it is important that it is done in a proportionate and transparent fashion. In case of an agreement, it is fundamental to clarify whether these concessions will be permanent or just temporary relief.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the ALDE Group. The customs dispute with the US is going to the next round. Friday is the next Trump deadline, and our Trade Commissioner's answer was and remains right: a willingness to talk with the US, but clear edge against harmful, ideologised protectionism. Of course, we want permanent derogations for the EU to continue. German Chancellor Merkel offers the US president all sorts of trade concessions behind the scenes, but without having a real plan. But this is what makes us blackmailable and, above all, dependent on Trump's whims. These concessions can lead to the beginning of the end of free trade. That is why we must stand together as the EU, as a trade and negotiating bloc. What we need now is a fresh start for a genuine new transatlantic agreement, including — but not only — trade issues and, above all, a joint fight with the US against subsidised overcapacity. Only in this way can we really lay the foundations for good trade relations in the future. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Christian EHLER
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — I would like to use the privileged knowledge of colleague Hirsch — in Germany, the FDP is in opposition — to learn again what deeper offers allegedly made by the Federal Government.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Green card response. — As you will undoubtedly know even better than we know, discussions have certainly been held here with both the Minister of Economic Affairs and the Chancellor herself in the US — including whether concessions on certain quotas and the like offer an opportunity, including, of course, the possibility of obtaining the to secure the German automotive market. But I believe that this would simply weaken our position as the European Union.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, with the strategy that we’ve seen from Trump, America First or something else, it does not only just attack the EU or China or whoever might be the ultimate target (there’s some speculation around that); what it’s actually doing – and it’s also not really about exemptions here – is that Trump is attacking the multilateral system. He’s attacking a rules-based system. That’s what it’s about and that’s what is really making the danger in this situation. I think this is what we as the EU need to fight to preserve. We need to preserve the multilateral system. It has imperfections, sure, and needs to be reformed, but it’s there and it needs to be safeguarded. That’s why we should bring this case to the WTO. It’s very laudable that we join China in the case, but we also need to be a bit more proactive on that matter. That doesn’t mean we need to sit idle while the WTO decides in a couple of years or longer about what to do. We can act now. But of course, trade measures are only part of the answer. The other thing that we need to look at is how we become more independent from the moods of a US president or the moods of someone else. For that, I think the question to ask is, why it is so threatening to our European economy – or should I rather say economies? Because that’s one of the problems: that we have 28, soon 27, different European economies that are trying to out-compete one another. That is part of the problem. We miss a strategy for economy and industry that goes beyond export, export, export. It cannot work like this. We are really, really independent. So we need to have a common European industrial policy that looks to protect our workers but that also supports a move to a low-carbon economy. Then we can also really outshine others. We also have to find answers to an unfair globalisation and make it fair and make it better for people in Europe – but also in the rest of the world – in order to defeat Trump and other like—minded people. For that, we also need to have a strong role in the European Parliament. It is very important that we are not shying away here from making statements as well in the Parliament.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Commissioner, I agree with you: yes, we need a very clear strategy towards President Trump, who is obviously making every effort to present itself as a strong president in the context of the forthcoming US Congressional elections — and he is predicted to predict bad forecasts — in line with the strategy” America First” We have to make it clear: “America First” must not mean that no one else will come after that. I also agree that the European Union must not play its game and can only beg for exceptions for itself. Trump is acting illegally, and we must now openly commit ourselves to the principle of equality before the law. This also means that punitive tariffs against India or China by the US must be rejected by us, because we cannot allow these steps to further erode the rules-based multilateral trading system. It is about overcapacity, it is about capacity, it is about the volume of production, about such issues that we have to address together, for example, in the G20 or OECD Steel Forum — Chinese, Americans, Europeans, steel-producing countries and aluminum-producing countries — to see how we can support the production of can organise today in such a way that jobs, sustainable development, environmental standards can be safeguarded — rich in prospects. That's up at the hour. I hope, Mrs Malmström, that we can count on an increased commitment by the Commission in this direction.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the duties that Americans want to impose on European steel and European aluminium are not only unmotivated, they are above all a subterfuge to get something else. Because all the concessions they have demanded of Europe to spare it from trade sanctions are the worst demands that were already present in TTIP. Reduced duties on certain products, but not only: increases in imported beef quotas, facilitated access to our public procurement, with no guarantee for our entrepreneurs in America, export of shale gas, regulatory cooperation on various sectors decided from time to time, that is to let our standards be challenged on sectors affecting large industries and to American lobbies. It seems that the US uses sanctions to arrive at a unilateral agreement even worse than TTIP. And that, frankly, is unacceptable. As if that wasn't enough, even if we find a deal, the Americans will still introduce a quota for raw materials, putting a limit on how much European steel and aluminium we can export from them. Madam Commissioner, I understand that it is not easy to find a way out and I understand that some concessions are not avoidable, but I would like to make it clear that we will not accept that TTIP comes back through the door on the back, and above all we will not accept compromises on the skin of European citizens and their health.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, since Donald Trump's election, there has been a wind of primary anti-Americanism on this Parliament. While I myself am reserved, and even criticism, about the US President's geopolitical choices, his domestic policy seems to me relevant and in line with his electoral commitments, particularly with regard to the fight against unfair competition. We are far from the European Union's half-measures, which will be approved tomorrow without a vote. If Trump's protectionism defrills you, we can take other examples. Fifteen years ago, Côte d'Ivoire imported most of its poultry, but in 2005 the country imposed customs barriers that allowed it to develop its own chain, with a tax of €1.50 on each kilogram of imported chicken. Ivorian chicken has again become competitive and even much cheaper. As a result, more than 50,000 jobs have been created, from livestock to slaughter, but also easier to carry out health controls and reduced greenhouse gas emissions, since one is in local production. Colleagues, from the United States to Côte d'Ivoire, we could mention many other countries, the future is short circuits in agriculture and industrial matters. Only intelligent protectionism can reconcile our economic imperatives... (The President withdrew the floor)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: — Mr President, the late President Mitterrand told a journalist at the end of his life that we were at war with the United States of America, in economic war, but at war to death. I am much more concerned about the unbearable claim to the universality of American sanctions against Iran than about protectionist measures in relation to steel or aluminum. On this first subject, indeed, the reaction of the Council and the Commission is quite inadequate. Total has already abandoned its plans to exploit the large South Pars gas deposit. The banks remember the EUR 7 billion that was stolen, extorted, from BNP Paribas. Airbus will have to give up an order of 100 planes. Air France suspends its flights between Paris and Tehran. Bouygues and Paris airport have renounced the management of Iranian airports. We need an otherwise stronger policy, and we must be prepared to sequestrate a quantity of American assets and funds equivalent to those we would be disposed of. That would be much more meaningful than our debates.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and other allies of the United States have been receiving threats over the imposition of duties for months. However absurd, the fate of millions of workers depends on a monthly deadline on Trump's tweets. The European Union, in its leading role, cannot subjugate itself to this perverse game. I would therefore like to thank the Commission for its efforts which have allowed Europe to be excluded from these trade tariffs to date. The result, however fragile and temporary, is yet another demonstration of how much the EU, if united, can protect its citizens. It is not enough: the Commission has done well to announce countermeasures and the activation of clauses against an increase in imports. Our workers must not be afraid, and the European institutions must be prepared to protect them at any cost. Today, Commissioner, there is a huge responsibility on your shoulders; we will do everything to help you complete it. To Trump I want to address this message: a relationship between partners is constructive only if it is based on dialogue. We will not accept the logic of threats, either now or in the future.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, in early June, we should learn from the President of the United States of America whether or not we can count on an unconditional exception from the imposition of a duty on steel and aluminium. Imposing tariffs themselves should not have significant consequences for the European economy when comparing imports of these commodities from other parts of the world — the surplus is huge. A much bigger problem could be the European Union's retaliatory measures against the United States of America. The European Union's top leaders should therefore seek to calm the situation and not take immediate dramatic measures. The aim should be a friendly, mutually sensible solution supporting transatlantic cooperation and establishing new business parameters. Rather than retaliation, Europe should concentrate on securing the European market in case the redirection of third-country steel originally intended for the American market, i.e. from those States, which ultimately did not agree with the United States of America. China's overproduction of steel alone is more than twice as large as the total annual output of the European Union.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, Commissioner and colleagues, at the moment we most need to strengthen rules-based trade in the multilateral system, our friends across the Atlantic are breaking with American and Transatlantic trends, making the US an unpredictable partner, and this plays into the hands of those who are seeking governance and trade models contrary to those of liberal democracies. So where we would ideally cooperate to address steel dumping onto the global market, the Trump administration has used the illegitimate argument of national security to slap tariffs on European steel and aluminium. It has pulled section 232 from the Cold War era at a time that no one should long to return to. Not only does the invoking of this section hurt our shared ability to solve problems, it also hurts the Transatlantic relation. I share the Commissioner’s assessment that these US measures are against WTO rules. We need to push for permanent exemption and support you in imposing rebalancing measures if the EU is forced to do so. What is certainly not appropriate is to pressure the EU into negotiations with the US on broader trade arrangements and to defrost TTIP under these circumstances. Sure there’s a lot we can talk about, but not with these tariffs hanging over our heads or with a metaphorically loaded gun pointed at us. This is the moment for strong, united European leadership – that means including all Member States – leadership towards trade that benefits all, and of course, this means standing against unfair trade practices, and I’m glad to hear some colleagues in this House who used to want to blow up the trade rules themselves now standing here to defend them. So there might be a little bit of a silver lining in all of this very, very troubling situation.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, the objective of Trump’s tariffs on steel is not primarily to support the US steel industry, but to launch a trade war and smash the multilateral system of trade negotiation. It would be a very serious mistake for the EU to respond by appeasing this global bully.  Trump’s reaction is ignorant and indiscriminate, but it offers us an opportunity to rethink our trade policy in a situation where the EU imports around 24% of its steel. If we import steel from countries that flout human rights and climate commitments, then we are destroying jobs at home while colluding in a race to the bottom. The Greens fought hard for the inclusion of social and environmental standards in the modernisation of the anti-dumping instruments, and we urge the Commission to make use of these instruments. To respond to Trump’s decision to pull the US out of the Paris Agreement, we need to make progress on the idea of an import tariff on climate-busting steel. This can ensure that taking action on the climate does not damage energy-intensive industries here, but it must be balanced by a meaningful and rising carbon price floor across the EU. Such a border adjustment mechanism would be acceptable to the WTO, since domestic and imported products would be treated alike.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question. You speak about imposing tariffs on imports from around the world, and particularly those you consider to be nations that manufacture in a way that damages the climate. Have you considered in this thought the fact – and I know this from having worked in steel stockholding myself for many years – that by doing this, you will drive up the prices all across the EU and the end-user price will go through the roof as well and effectively, there is a huge risk to employment and jobs across the EU by taking these measures rather than allowing people to buy competitively?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card answer. – In my view, if we want to maintain high standards in Europe, then we have to require other countries to keep those standards as well. If we don’t do that, we’re simply involved in a race to the bottom.
