So the ideal is that we set high standards here in Europe, we protect them when it is possible to do that by a tariff at our border, and therefore we enable the rest of the world to rise to our higher standards. For me, that’s what a constructive trade policy would look like in the case of steel, but for other products as well. If we’re going to have high standards in Europe, then we must require the rest of the world to rise to those standards.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, the most curious aspect of the EU’s trade dispute with the Trump administration is its enthusiasm for claiming the moral high ground, because the European Union is itself built on the ideology of barriers to trade. You are a customs union, so it is hardly logical to berate the United States of Europe for being one too. Indeed, it was recently admitted by the German think-tank, the IFO Centre for International Economics, that the EU has a significantly worse record on tariff barriers than does the US. The EU unweighted customs duty is on average 5.2%, while in the US it is just 3.5%. President Trump sees that America is running a USD 90 billion trade deficit with the EU and thinks he can force a better deal, so he is exerting leverage in the area of steel and aluminium, protecting his own producers. It will be interesting to see whether ultimately the EU takes a kinder stance towards him than it has so far taken towards Theresa May, who presides over a much larger UK trade deficit with the EU but who has bent over backwards to be accommodating in Brexit negotiations, not only begging for a frictionless trade deal in such circumstances, but she is also paying up 40 billion of UK taxpayers’ money to further sweeten things. She not only says she won’t have a hard border in Ireland, but she seems to be saying she must avoid doing anything that leads you to think you must impose a hard border in Ireland either, yet still you kick sand in her face. In such circumstances, can anyone blame Mr Trump for believing that the way to get a better deal for his country with the EU is to put the thumbscrews on you? I am sad to say I believe his tactics ultimately will bear a lot more fruit than Mrs May’s desperation to please has done thus far. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Christian EHLER
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr O'Flynn, I would just like to ask: you mentioned earlier that the European Union is based on the fact that it is a customs union. I believe that not only Brexit and your sometimes obscure reasoning is based on the error that the European Union was not closed to increase tariffs, but the most successful model is that a large number of Member States have completely eliminated tariffs. In this respect, it seems to me that you have been a little confused economically.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for that question. As far as I am aware, the United States of America is not yet a member of the European Union and nor are more than 100 other countries around the world, and they have to trade with the European Union on the basis of external tariff barriers. The point I am making is that it ill behoves the EU and everyone in this assembly to get on the moral high horse and berate other countries for imposing tariffs when the whole ideology that brought the forerunner of the EU into being was one of external tariff barriers.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Mr President, Mrs Malmström, you know the figures, at least I hope. The European Union has 120 billion surpluses compared to the United States and 170 billion deficit compared to China, and overall we have 30 billion surpluses. Unless you consider the economy to be predatory, impoverishing one another, or enriching one another, you should ask yourself every morning, when you get up: what should I do not impoverish the United States and what should I do to avoid enriching China? How do I put in place a policy to reduce my surpluses compared to the United States and how do I put in place a policy to reduce my deficits compared to China? You will not do this policy, because fundamentally the current policy serves finance and serves the debt.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Mrs Malmström reminded us, next Saturday the deadline for exoneration given by the President of the United States for steel and aluminium exports expires. Unfortunately, this policy has been practiced in other panels, such as the trade and investment agreement with the Union, the trans-pacific agreement, the agreement with Mexico and Canada, the Paris climate change agreement or the nuclear agreement with Iran, to which we have just referred. A moment ago, the European Union has been called for leadership in these times of protectionism. Well, I would like to say that Commissioner Malmström and the European Commission at very difficult times have shown vision, moved quickly and have initiated or concluded important trade agreements with Vietnam, Singapore, Canada, Japan and Mexico. And we hope, Commissioner, that the agreement with Mercosur will be quickly concluded. It is clear that you have conducted yourself in a prudent, measured manner. But it was recalled here that the President of the United States has given instructions to conduct a study, on the basis of section 232 of the 1962 Act, as to whether the import of cars could affect the safety of the United States. We call, Commissioner, that the European Union act on this positive and constructive agenda but, at the same time, act in accordance with its convictions, with determination, if the legitimate interests of the European Union are affected.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, we are living uncertain moments which might impact not only the future of the EU-US trade relations and the decades of governed global trade system, but also the future of the international rule-based multilateral system as a whole, in which the cornerstone of a peaceful and stable liberal order was represented, among others by the trade relations between our continent and the United States. Yes, President Trump’s demands are deepening policy differences between the transatlantic allies on issues ranging from trade to foreign policy. The requested tariffs on steel and aluminium could seriously harm the interests of both sides and can unleash retaliations in the reciprocal protectionism around the world. Without hesitation, I can only affirm today the most clear positioning of the Socialists and Democrats: we support and we wish to consolidate the multilateral system and work together with all our partners for ensuring free and fair trade. The worst we can have is an economic war (inaudible).

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, Commissioner. The Commission's strategy seems to be: 'Like you do to me, I like you'. If the Americans are nice, we are nice too, and if they are not nice, then we have the right answers. This is the beginning of every cycle into protectionism — this is what history has shown. If we continue like this, just repay bad and bad, so to speak, we will enter protectionism. Mr. Trump cannot be taught. He simply believes that he is on the stronger leverage, and he is also unable to be convinced by Mrs Quisthoudt-Rowohl's arguments that any protectionism leads to incompetitiveness — he does not make his country large, but rather small with it. That is why the proposal is now: the EU should launch a free trade initiative on its own initiative. The world is looking at the EU. We should be a free trade field, and if it is right for protectionism to harm a country, it is the case that free trade benefits a continent! (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Ask about the procedure of the “blue card”. — Mr. Starbatty! Do you agree that the European Commission is precisely not 'what you are doing to me, I use', but that the proposals that are on the table deliberately only take full advantage of just about half of what would be possible under WTO law? Secondly, do you agree that the party on whose list you were elected to this Parliament has expressly opposed free trade and against a trade agreement with the United States, and that is why your reasoning is somewhat ambiguous? Thirdly, agree with me that the Commissioner stands for a massive foreign trade strategy, which fortunately has successfully concluded many trade agreements, and now we in Parliament... (The President withdraws the speaker from the speaker).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mr Caspary. We have 30 seconds for a question and 30 seconds for an answer. With three questions, it's getting a little short of 30 seconds anyway.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. — Mr Caspary! I only hear what the Commissioner said and what is being said here in this House, and that is the beginning of a spiral of protectionism. And when you say: 'You have a different opinion than the party for which you have come to parlamour', I always take the opinion of an economist that free trade benefits everyone. No one's gonna stop me, not even you, Mr. Caspary.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I come at this debate from a somewhat different view to many colleagues here. It is one of the few debates since I’ve been here that I can speak from the perspective of pure personal experience. I was in the steel industry, stainless steel and aluminium, for twenty years. I worked in the service and stock-holding sector during that time. I started off with British Steel Stainless and then moved on to a variety of companies across Europe, Avesta and Thyssenkrupp being most notable amongst them. What I noticed during that time was the importance of the variety of areas you can import from to be able to service your customers correctly. Tariffs and a trade war with the United States would be absolutely devastating to this market sector. What we have to think about is that it would not just make it difficult to import – sometimes – qualities of steel that you can’t always get domestically or from within the EU, but also the situation is that domestic mills will grow in power and grow in size. Now you might think that that’s a good thing, but when competition is beaten away by a huge giant then you lose price competition, you lose quality competition, you lose many of the aspects that made steel stock-holding and service centres such an integral part of the manufacturing economy in the UK and across Europe. When you look at the tariff and counter-tariff argument, all the end result will be is an endless spiral of unemployment and of industry crashing down. I understand what President Trump is doing. There are cases of dumping on the market, most notably from China, which is tantamount to trade war. It’s an effort to destroy domestic production: wipe them out so that they can then control the market. It’s obvious. There must be measures against dumping, I think many of us would agree. But to take it on to a tariff war would be a catastrophic error. This is not just me speaking. This is coming from voices within the steel industry. We are concerned – many people – about the devastating and paralysing impact of these tariffs because all it would seem you’re hearing is the lobby voice of the big manufacturer, the big mill. Think about the service sector, the stock-holder, the medium-sized business who actually look after the end users, who are the people who have to provide the skill and the technological information that goes into it. We must be fighting hard for tariff-free trade across the world, and certainly with the USA. I hope an independent UK will be able to do a tariff-free trade deal with the United States of America. But also, for the sake of the world economy, I hope the EU can do the same because I don’t want to see people losing their jobs and their livelihoods anywhere. Let’s forget the political differences and focus on the reality of jobs and employment in our economies. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: question of 'blue card'. — Mr Etheridge, you have just pointed out the importance of being able to have a trade agreement — the United Kingdom with the United States — to prevent the trade war. I suppose you will recognize that Canada and Mexico have been equally threatened by the United States even though they have a free trade agreement and renegotiating another better free trade agreement, which has useless. In that regard, if the United States definitely imposes tariffs on the European Union, even though the European Union, the Commission is criticizing any trade war, how would it value it? What is the answer you ask?

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card answer. – I believe that one of the main roles of politicians – the Commission for the EU, the politicians for the UK, wherever you talk about – is to facilitate free trade so that we can all get wealthier. We want all to get wealthier. I understand what you are saying and understand that Mr Trump’s actions have sparked much of this. I don’t agree with tariffs; I want a world free of tariffs so that we can all trade freely and compete. In the short term, what we must do is speak to each other and stop this devastating trade war. It benefits nobody, and we must work together to stop this by organising free trade and having discussions.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Many times in recent years we have heard in this room, but also in the Member States, the voices of criticism about trade, service, investment agreements, for example, the TTIP agreement with the United States or the CETA trade agreement with Canada, which, after all, is only a hair only passed. The same people often, or the same environments now raise the voices of criticism against President Donald Trump and the United States' position on duties that bind trade between the European Union and the United States, among others. After all, this is a wonderful example of what such nationalism ends, chauvinism, closing their nations and states from others, restricting trade. So if trade was going to be open to the European Union — it's good if it was to be closed to us — then it's bad. What I want to say is that we're experiencing a good school for what the world should be. I want to commend the European Commission precisely for the position it presents, for its position, which is to act to open up and open up to other countries, to other economic areas of the world and this policy, we can also bring about a close to the conflict with the United States, and not vice versa.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Mr President, first of all I don’t understand the right wing of this Chamber arguing that when the US is imposing tariffs on steel and aluminium on Europe as a response to China, then we shouldn’t react. It’s okay to face China, who are actually violating the principles of WTO and doing unfair practices, but why is the US imposing tariffs on Europe? This is in violation of WTO rules and also the multilateral trade order. So we should be very strict here. People are talking about retaliation; no, it is a reaction. We need to use and protect our own workers our own industries against unfair trade practices vis-à-vis China or the US, as is the case now with Trump. Secondly, I just want to say we live in an integrated economy. So it is little absurd in 2018 to talk about this as if it would resolve any problems. And thirdly, I’m very preoccupied with how to defend the rights of workers in a time of globalisation. So we should start a dialogue with the US on how to implement ILO conventions, how to ensure collective bargaining and how to ensure that the things we get from trade agreements also benefit the people. That’s a real discussion.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, the United States is without any doubt our most important strategic partner. Together, we foster our strategic interest in mutual prosperity and security, but the international system is undergoing a transition period and everyone faces challenges. Even with the frozen TTIP negotiations, we have to use the momentum to harness globalisation together and to continue working together to fight excessive capacities in key sectors and tackle trade issues of mutual interest. Instead of acting against each other, we should search for solutions together. Therefore I consider imposing import tariffs on EU steel and aluminium as an inappropriate redress to cover the actual problems of over-capacity. Steel and aluminium imports from the EU should be permanently exempted from tariffs. US threats of punitive tariffs are jeopardising the transatlantic relations and the global trade and investment system under WTO rules. I strongly support the Commission in its engagement with the United States in order to avoid a trade war and to improve our trade relations. We all have to obey the rules and keep to the standards, otherwise we only produce chaos, and nobody can foresee which consequences this will have for the world.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: Mr President, Trump is endangering global stability. The European Union is a reliable ally of the United States that complies with the rules and, of course, cannot be exposed to permanent threats of tariffs by alluding to unjustified reasons of national security. It must therefore be definitely excluded from such measures and continue to lead the defence of global governance, because it is precisely within the framework of the WTO and in international forums that we must jointly face — the European Union and the United States — the challenges we share in the face of excessive industrial overcapacity, unfair competition and trade imbalances. That is why I also consider the blockade being made by the United States on the appointment of judges to the WTO Appellate Body is unacceptable. We need to redirect the situation and I support the strategy of the European Union, the Commissioner: intelligent, proportionate, based on coordination with our partners and within the Union. And I also ask you to help defend the interests of the Spanish table olive.

name: Christian EHLER
text: Mr President! First of all, I am pleased to have a wise, calm Commissioner at the head, that it is clear that the European response is value-based, that we are the voice of reason for free trade, for a WTO system. I am also pleased that Mrs Keller, who has caused an assault on the Greens and the Left against free trade and value-based trade agreements, is now returning to the Port of Reason. Although it briefly and somewhat confuses expressed its economic ideas, but nevertheless advocated a value-based and structured trading system. So, in times of crisis, Europeans come together. And it is also important to say to the Europeans — and I say this at home, with my steel workers, with the people who live here: in a situation of crisis where not America is our enemy, but a confused Trump administration is currently trying to set fire to the world trading system, Europe is the calm voice that responds where people are protected because we in the European Union have a voice together, are taken seriously and are able to take sensible measures to defuse the crisis on the one hand and not to make ourselves dependent on third parties on the other. I would also like to add again that this commonality does not exist between the majority of Parliament and the Commission in America. We are going to meet our colleagues from the US Congress this month, and I dare doubt that the US Congress will support this exotic policy of the President. It is basically un-American, and we also need to convey this to our colleagues in the US Congress.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, the only thing I agree on with the people on the right is that no sensible person wants a trade war, but the best way to avoid such a trade war is by strong action and strong words against the illegal measures that President Trump is proposing. Our response, as laid out by the Commissioner, is WTO compatible, it is lawful and it is the right course of action. If we can stick to this, if we can stay strong as the EU, we will be demonstrating to our trading partners beyond the United States that we are ready to stand up for the global system, we are ready to stand up for free and fair trade and we’re ready to stand up for a rules-based system. Only by demonstrating that we are ready to stand up for a rules-based system can we avoid a downward spiral in terms of open and free trade. If the EU stands firm, we will find allies across the globe and possibly in some strange places like China, which also depends on a globalised trading system. This is not about starting a trade war; this is defending the global free trade system.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner, we have been in the habit for some time here in Parliament to deal with duties and tariffs. I am not a lover of market protection systems, but I am strongly aware that it is legitimate, indeed dutiful, that those like us who respect the normal rules of the market decide at some point — and We have done this by changing the anti-dumping rules with Mr Cicu's report — he decides to protect himself from those who do not respect the market. Well, in this case we are in a totally different context. We have said this and you repeated it: the duties which the United States would impose on the European Union meet a totally different logic: even it is in the market that it proves to be their initial uselessness. One thinks — many of us know — that U.S. importers today have a very high US steel market price, to such a point that they wouldn't stop buying European steel even if increased by 25%, at a first stage. This shows that these are duties totally without justification, and they are duties that meet another logic. On that logic, rightly, you and the European Union decide to negotiate at a high level, which is a first and foremost political level, so that the United States agrees to continue to be our most important business partner.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President! President Trump is ruthless protectionism. Right now, Europe needs to be particularly strong for advanced and fair trade. Protectionism and nationalism — these are ghosts of the past and are not the right answers to the current challenges. If Trump accuses the EU of unfair trade practices, he simply did not understand that. We want to protect the internal market and European jobs from unfair competitive conditions. The EU must reach an unconditional exception with regard to the planned punitive tariffs. There is little to the national security argument for the European side. In reality, these are covert safeguards that are not WTO-compliant. In the event of punitive tariffs, we will respond with compensatory measures to restore balance. I expect Europe to use its strength and be united to Trump and the US.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I am pleased that we have taken a common position here in Parliament so far on the threatened tariffs of Americans, and I think, Commissioner, you also said it very clearly in its introduction: we want to defend the openness, but also the uniformity of the European internal market, because we want to defend the openness, but also the uniformity of the European internal market, because we believe that in the world, in the global world trading system, we need rules that everyone adheres to — including us. And because we believe that we want to develop these rules further — especially with the trading partners with whom we work closely — we also started talks on TTIP a few years ago, which were abandoned by none other than our current American counterpart, and that is why we should focus on ensure that we do not abandon our openness to develop international trade and keep the internal market open. Secondly, I share the assessment that has been made here that the punitive tariffs now unilaterally applied to us by the Americans are not compatible with the rules of the World Trade Organisation. If we want to defend the international rules, then we must also say here that we cannot accept the American approach at this point. I would like, Commissioner, to succeed in resolving this dispute constructively, and perhaps in the end, as George Bush did a few decades ago. Punitive tariffs were also threatened at that time, but in the end they did not bring what the American side promised. That would be a chance to start over with TTIP. World trade benefits everyone, even though residents of the US may not see this so closely at the moment.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that, as you have pointed out, the next few days will be important in deciding and establishing what new relationship between the European Union and the USA. I believe that we should share a lot of objectives, because we know that we are talking about overcapacity, we know that we are talking about rules within the WTO that must achieve a level of equal condition. We have worked so much with you within the European Union system, in compliance with these rules, especially as protecting these rules would result in an ability to defend our workers, our industry and our enterprise. But I also believe that Trump, as you have repeatedly noted, does a strategic recentralization reasoning of a dimension. Here, I am glad that there is unity and I am happy with its strategic work, which will certainly lead to important objectives.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, this is obviously a very unpleasant situation that we have not caused, but now we have the opportunity as the European Union to demonstrate that we are a truly positive global force and that protectionism must not be and will not be our tool. We, unless there is some agreement, will have to answer the American measures, but I would intercede very much to make those measures moderate, to be proportionate, to be limited in time and of course, to comply with the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO). We need to work there with other partners, such as Japan, which has already made it clear to us that it is willing to oppose the rationale that the US administration, especially in areas of national security, she used. But in that case, if we use arbitrage or apela to the World Trade Organization, we must prepare for the fact that it will be a very long process. But we have the opportunity to position ourselves in a positive way.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: It is very nice that Mr Zahradisl has fans in the gallery. I would nonetheless like to point out to you that it is not customary in parliamentary terms that there should be any statements of consent or abuse from the gallery. Spontaneous Speaking

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr President! The entry of the United States on the path of protectionism with regard to the steel and aluminum industries is undoubtedly information disturbing and sad. For history shows that such a policy never ends in a happy end, and Europe and the United States have always gained greater benefits working together. However, the decision of the United States forces the need to respond. In my view, it must be three-step. Firstly, we must negotiate with the States a permanent extension of the EU countries from the duties imposed until the end of June and to propose cooperation on a solution to the global problem of steel overproduction. If this cannot be achieved, the Union should complain to the World Trade Organisation and then take additional measures to safeguard the European industry.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the decision of the American Administration to grant, after the deadline of 1 May, another 30 days of exemption to the European Union from duties on steel and aluminium leaves alive hope that a global trade war can still be averted. We are at the beginning of a decisive week, in which it is still possible to treat. I very much appreciated Commissioner Malmström's position not to accept negotiations until the Union has received an unconditional extension of tariffs, so that decisions can be taken sufficiently weighted to avoid a trade conflict that would bring decompensation to everyone, Europeans and Americans. But on some things Europe can't turn back. In campaigning President Trump said that Europe has many other barriers to importing American products, including the quality standards of our food products and our own environmental legislation. The food security guarantees that we assure our citizens and the international commitments made with the Paris Agreement must not be at the negotiating table.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, we have repeatedly dealt with the problems facing the European steel industry and here, in this Chamber, we have called for measures to protect the European steel industry. Because it has a huge problem and, above all, it faces unfair competition from China. It's been so long! For two or three years we talked and we didn't see measures! At the same time, the United States is making decisive progress in formulating a protectionist strategy. Of course, the national security argument does not apply. It is drilled and cannot be said by Mr Trump towards the European Union, which supposedly most of its members are members of NATO and therefore have a main purpose. From then on, obviously, if the United States proceeds to take protectionist measures against the European steel industries, we too obviously have to react by taking appropriate measures.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, I think the debate is exhausted. I too think that there is no other way than to talk with the US Government and Mr Trump through the World Trade Organisation. I would remind you, however, that, apart from the discussions, it has given some countermeasures that it has put into trade with China, given that the country has countermeasures. So, apart from the debate or through the debate, it must be clearly seen what damage it can suffer from countermeasures of ours. However, I would like to conclude by saying that I think the United Kingdom may tend to want to exploit this difference to its advantage. Therefore, our discussions with the United Kingdom on Brexit must take into account the fact that the European Union wants and can be solid with the American Government on this issue.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, if the decision of the President of the United States to impose customs duties on European steel and aluminium exports is implemented, there will be consequences - in order to protect the American economy - not only on European industries but also on their respective industries. industries of many other countries. That is why the European Union must negotiate so that this decision does not apply. After all, the European Union is not responsible for the global increase in production of steel and aluminium products. Moreover, as an ally of the United States does not threaten their economy or interests. On the other hand, if these efforts and negotiations fail, then we are obliged to take measures to protect the steel and aluminium products produced in the European Union. If this attempt fails, then we will have a deterioration in the already existing economic war between India, China, the European Union and the United States, which will cause a political crisis.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President! Punitive tariffs, that is a word we have heard a lot today. We should be careful not to get on the glue of the Americans there. We are not talking about punitive tariffs here in fact, but we are talking here about illegal, unjustified protectionist tariffs that are being discussed in the United States, and that is exactly what we should call them in public. I am appalled when a number of colleagues have mentioned in the debate that we have higher average tariffs than the Americans. Yes, true, but Americans have much, much higher non-tariff barriers to trade for our products. We are struggling to enter the public procurement market. We have the Buy American Act in the United States, which is making our company's lives difficult. That is precisely why a large majority here in the European Parliament always wanted a comprehensive agreement to clarify these matters. Unfortunately, the Americans failed. The Americans are also not making their economies strong through the measures. Those who make steel more expensive will make American products more expensive. I'm curious to see what happens to all the cars that are currently being exported from America to the world markets, whether this is still possible in the future or whether unemployment in America will not rise through such a thing.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Colleague Zoană, could you please put on your earphones? Mrs Zoană! They just arrived. I am now giving you the floor on the procedure for spontaneous speeches. But I would like to draw your attention to the fact that written applications — we are good today today — will no longer be accepted for the procedure for spontaneous speeches. It's not like that. We assume that someone who speaks in the spontaneous speech procedure will also take part in the debate.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, I have already signed up. Europe is working to protect Member States against imports of dumped products and national subsidies into non-EU countries. The measures are necessary to ensure fair competition on the European Union market and to protect European companies from the effects of unfair competition practiced by some third country exporters. Romania is a producer, but also a steel processor and has made considerable efforts to maintain the steel industry, but also to meet environmental objectives. We must not lose sight of the fact that steel is not just any kind of commodity, but is a strategic product. Member States would become vulnerable if they closed down or significantly restrict steel production in Europe, thus becoming dependent on imports from third countries, especially in the context where the construction sector is still expanding. Given that no building can be built without steel, it would be wrong for the European Union to depend only on steel from third countries, and I believe that such dependencies do not bode well for the European economy.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mrs Zoană. That's exactly what I meant. This procedure is called “Catch the Eye” of the President, not “Catch the Postman” of the President. So, previous written registrations will no longer work, at least not when I chair. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there is a steel and aluminium problem in the world, notably an overcapacity in China due to heavily subsidising their own industry and thereby dumping the global market. But the EU is not the source of this. On the contrary, we have also suffered – our own, notably steel, but also aluminium, have suffered from this. We have put in place a lot of anti-dumping and anti-subsidy issues, we have reformed our trade defence instrument, and we should seek to address this problem globally with partners such as the US in the WTO, in the Global Forum on Steel and continuing the tri—party cooperation that we have started with Japan and the US. The EU and the United States are strategic allies and partners. We should work together to address this and other issues in the global trading system. But it has to be done within the rules. The WTO is not perfect, but it is the best system we have. The 164 members have set up global rules that have served us well – us and the United States. Today we offer a positive agenda to the United States: a positive agenda where we can discuss issues such as liquid gas; where we can discuss voluntary regulatory cooperation, where appropriate; where we can discuss issues related to WTO, including ending the blockage of the Appellate Body system; and where we could start to exploit and discuss a mutually-beneficial agreement addressing issues in industrial goods. It would have to be mutually beneficial and it would have to be explored – and, of course, were we to enter negotiations, it would have to be on a mandate given to the Commission by the Council. There are no secret negotiations going on on this. This would be a positive agenda, a mutually beneficial agenda. If this were rejected in the coming days, we would have no other choice than to go to the WTO to show that we must respect the global trading system and the rules we have set up together. We will take rebalancing measures in a proportionate way in full compliance with the WTO, and we will continue the safeguard actions on steel and aluminium, as we have already prepared. In the meantime, we will also continue to work for an open rule-based trade system in the world, together with allies, through free trade agreements and through the reform efforts that we are doing in the WTO. Thank you very much for the support and thank you for initiating this very timely debate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — It is regrettable that US tariffs affect European exports of steel and aluminum, but this sovereign decision is largely a response to China's unfair competition in the steel sector. The Commission introduced anti-dumping measures against China in 2017. In a communication dated 11 June 2013, it denounced the state's “predatory commercial behaviour”, which, with its overproduction of 400 million tonnes annually (2017), contributed to the loss of 80,000 European jobs in seven years — an industrial disaster that hit my native region of Lorraine hard. The decision to withdraw the Iranian nuclear agreement will, on the other hand, have considerable repercussions. Total, for example, would be squeezed out of a major gas contract, once again in favour of China. More so, Russian sanctions are seriously damaging our interests, the latest salute of US retaliation against certain European companies and jeopardizing the Nord Stream II project. On these points, the Commission does not provide any effective answer, worse, in the case of Russia, it persists in error, revealing at the same time the near-vassal relationship with the United States.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Pier Antonio Panzeri, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on Libya (2018/ 2017 (INI)) (A8-0159/2018).

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Rapporteur. — (IT) (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Libyan issue has come back strongly to the agenda in these hours, including today's meeting organised by French President Macron in Paris, with a plurality of Libyan and other countries and subjects and personalities, in which Mrs Mogherini, the High Representative, was also present. The willingness to pursue the objective of stabilizing the country I think can be a common objective, an ambitious objective, and I think that can be more achieved if you work within a framework unitary European, the only one that can ensure a successful success to the project. Because common sense is important, but alone it is not enough to solve the problems we have before. Unfortunately, the situation in Libya is still marked by factors of severe instability, not least because the continued influence of armed groups on politics and the economy is dangerous, and if it is not now opposed some endurance, it's likely to increase. Moreover, it should be clear to everyone that, without political and institutional stabilisation, many of the problems we would like to address will not be solved, starting with migratory ones. That is why I have no doubt, even if I know there is an open debate on the subject of election, whether we must have a constitutional basis first or if you can vote before the constitutional basis. I think that one of the key milestones in the project, of the action plan, is the organisation of the forthcoming electoral consultations, which can ensure the full and shared participation of all the Libyan components. It arose, this assumption, from the Paris summit on 10 December. This appointment constitutes an indispensable step to overcome the deadlock and to reach minimum conditions of governability and security of the country, setting the stage for a subsequent gradual stability. The recommendation we are proposing has these objectives. It is the result of a thorough discussion, not simple, not only because Libya calls upon itself a very high interest, but also because there are somewhat different views on the strategies to be adopted to provide a contribution to the stabilisation and democratisation of the country. In drawing up the recommendation, we followed some political criteria. First of all, to provide a coherence with the European foreign policy interpreted by the High Representative. The second is to support the UN action, represented by Salamé, which today appears, albeit among many difficulties, the only road to Libya. The third is to guarantee support for all those Libyan forces interested in finding a political solution for Libya, with an operation of genuine national conciliation. The fourth principle is to listen to the demands and exhortations coming from the Member States overlooking the Mediterranean — especially Italy — suffering from the consequences of a failure to stability of the country. And finally, to deal with realistic determination the issue of migrants, framing it in a broader strategy that is capable of involving multiple subjects and that allows us to respond to themes for we are very important, concerning people's rights and human rights. So, the objective of the recommendation seems quite clear: to put in place all the necessary initiatives so that the widest consensus is achieved around UN action for the purpose of the United Nations to ensure a future of stability for Libya in its political, institutional and constitutional arrangements.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: vicepresidente della Commissione/alto rappresentante dell'Unione per gli affari esteri e la politica di sicurezza. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli deputati, vorrei iniziare con un ringraziamento a Pier Antonio Panzeri, al vicepresidente Castaldo, alla presidente della delegazione per il Maghreb Ayala Sender e al presidente della commissione LIBE Claude Moraes per aver condotto questa importante visita a Tunisi e a Tripoli la scorsa settimana.  Per la prima volta da più di sei anni, il Parlamento europeo è tornato in Libia, e questo è un segno importantissimo dell'unità, di cui parlava l'onorevole Panzeri, dell'unità degli europei e delle istituzioni europee, innanzitutto nell'attenzione che prestiamo a ciò che succede in Libia e alla volontà di farlo, questo lavoro di sostegno e di attenzione alla Libia, innanzitutto con un ascolto a ciò che i nostri interlocutori libici stanno facendo e ci stanno dicendo e con una volontà di unire gli sforzi europei e dare un quadro unitario coerente dell'azione dell'Unione europea, dei propri Stati membri, delle proprie istituzioni a sostegno di un processo di transizione in Libia. C'è questa determinazione forte e io vengo proprio in questo momento da Parigi, dove ho partecipato alla conferenza internazionale ospitata dal Presidente Macron e dove ho potuto portare questo impegno, questa determinazione europea di tutti gli europei e di tutte le istituzioni europee ad accompagnare questo momento particolarmente importante per un paese così vicino a noi come la Libia. I believe both the recommendations and your visit are inspired by this attitude towards Libya, recognising that Libya is first of all, an important, vital, crucial country, not only for Africa and not only for the Mediterranean, but for Europe as well, and also that Libya is a rich country that would not need any help if it had not been transitioning for so long. It is a rich country not only in terms of national resources, but, first and foremost, of human capital. It is home to millions of smart, diverse people who have had enough of the current instability and of this endless transition. So we cannot make – and I am happy to say that we are not making – the mistake of looking at Libya and focusing on one issue only, be it migration or even security. Because the first duty we have – the first responsibility and even the first interest we have as Europeans – is to support Libya with Libyans and for the Libyans. Because there would be no other way to have a successful end to this instability in the country. Libya needs reconciliation, it needs a clear, legitimate framework and it needs inclusive dialogue. It also needs economic investments, nationwide, strong legitimate institutions and job opportunities for the people. This is the spirit of the work you are currently doing, looking at the broad spectrum of issues that are on the table, dealing with the country. And this has always been our approach to Libya. This was also the spirit of our meeting in Paris this morning. Hosted by President Macron, as I said, together with all the major Libyan players, for the first time gathered together we pledged, and they committed, to support a constitutional process leading to elections ideally during this year – you mentioned the date we agreed today of mid—December – and to unite Libya’s security forces, another aspect that is not at all irrelevant. So we need to contribute now, in a united manner – Europeans, Arabs, Africans and neighbouring countries, under the umbrella of the United Nations – to this process, helping Libya to come out of this long transition. This is what the Libyans want, it is what they are asking for and what they deserve. I would add that it is also the responsibility of the Libyan leaders to respond and to deliver on this demand from the Libyan people. The security situation in the country is improving slightly. The number of those killed in political violence has decreased sharply. There is a precarious, but real, calm in most of the country including Tripoli, even if in recent hours we have seen worrying events in Derna. Terrorism has not been defeated yet. Last week, a car bomb killed seven people and injured 20 in Benghazi and at the beginning of the month terrorists struck the High National Elections Commission in Tripoli, killing 13 people, and it was an attack against all the Libyans committed to the democratic process. We have to make sure that this does not become an attack on the democratic process itself. And here international European support is essential because we have been working with the Libyan authorities to prepare and to accompany this democratic process. We have been working with the Libyan authorities to help, first and foremost, to ensure that their security forces unite under civilian control and that they fully respect human rights. We have a long way to go, but I see the commitment there and I see some movement happening. Some militias will have to be integrated in the security forces through a proper vetting process. Others will have to lay down their weapons and Special Representative Salamé will soon present a strategy to this end to the UN Security Council. We, as the European Union, can and must continue to support the United Nations in this respect, including through our civilian border assistance mission – EUBAM – that is now permanently established in Tripoli so is best placed to work with the Libyans on law enforcement, criminal justice and border management. I heard today from our Libyan interlocutors – all of them – words of gratitude and praise for the work the European Union is doing in this sector and others. Uniting the security apparatus is not enough. Bolder action is also needed to enforce the UN arms and oil embargo and, as you know, Operation Sofia also plays an important role in this sector. The mandate of the operation is currently under review. By the end of this year we hope to reach a Council decision to extend and strengthen this mandate, where necessary. But security is only one part of the picture, and our cooperation with the Libyans goes beyond that. The political process is probably priority number one and is also what we discussed in more depth this morning in Paris. As the European Union, we are currently working with the High National Elections Commission to prepare the electoral process. It is thanks to the EU—UN partnership that the steps of preparing this process have been put in place so far and we intend to continue in this way. Technical preparations are ongoing. Voter registration has been completed with 2.5 million registered voters out of four, if I am not wrong, so it is a very encouraging starting point. Libyans want – and deserve – to exercise their fundamental rights and choose their country’s future, but there are two points I also raised very clearly today in Paris with our Libyan interlocutors, all of them. First of all, the Libyans have to know what they are voting for. The powers of all institutions will have to be clarified in time. A president elected in a legal vacuum could be dangerous, and also because it is the first time the Libyans will elect a president. So its powers and its relations with the other branches of the power, including and first of all, the executive branch, have to be defined. This is why adopting the Constitution before the elections is essential to give clarity to the electoral process. I know that in your visit to Tripoli you conveyed these messages to both the High Council of State and the House of Representatives and I know that you received assurances about the strong commitment. I have today heard encouraging voices in this respect. The other thing that I made very clear today – and I know this is also a reflection of your work – is that elections need to take place in an environment that ensures and guarantees that the day after the election all those involved recognise the result. Elections that might be contested or disputed the day after might be counterproductive or, in any case and the best case, not let the country to move forward. This is why today – this morning in Paris – I asked all four Libyan leaders present to commit and engage in an electoral process, but also taking the responsibility of accepting the electoral results the day afterwards. I believe that this is the basis for a transparent, open and credible electoral process. Libyans want an end to the transition. They made this very clear. They had more than 40 town hall meetings all over the country. We supported the organisation of these meetings. This is part of the work towards a national conference that should meet after the end of Ramadan. The initiative has come from the United Nations, the process is led on the ground by some NGOs, and the European Union is supporting – including financially – this process. For the first time since the revolution, Libyans from all walks of life, all backgrounds and all different parts of the country have the opportunity to discuss their aspirations and the future of their country. We also support mediation activities between the tribes at community level, for example to ease the return home. I know that your delegation met, for instance, with the Mayor of Tawergha, who expressed his gratitude to the European Union. As these processes move on, the economy is also slowing picking up, this was also confirmed by our Libyan interlocutors today. But conditions for ordinary people in Libya remain dire. Public services such as health care have been badly affected, and we have to make sure that the benefits of an economy that might restart, starting from the oil production, gets to the Libyan people on the ground. So, in parallel to the work on security and for reconciliation, we are also engaged on the ground to revive local economies and create good jobs. We are working with the World Bank in particular to improve public finance management and with Expertise France to create new business opportunities. We are also supporting 22 municipalities across the country – I believe municipalities are key in this process – to help them rebuild their infrastructure and deliver better services. A new and ambitious project with EUR 50 million dedicated to it is under preparation in coordination with the Italian Cooperation. We care about Libya, as you said, because we care about the people of Libya, but also because we know that caring about Libya is also the best investment in our own security and stability. I know that I taken too long, so I will probably stop here and leave other comments for the other parts of our debates. I thank you very much, but, first and foremost, thank you for the excellent work you have been doing together with other colleagues.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, Libya is a challenge. It is a test for maximum coordination of various European policy instruments. This includes development, security, migration policy, humanitarian aid or counter-terrorism. The European Union is the biggest donor in the area. For example, it is financially involved in all projects carried out by the UNHCR in the territory. But both the real influence and awareness of our efforts is small in ordinary Libyans and our citizens. This situation needs to be changed. One step that would help this is in the report recommended moving the European Union delegation towards Libya itself. The European Union should continue to support the efforts of the United Nations Special Representative Ghassan Salamé in his efforts to stabilize the country and the process of national reconciliation. However, the real dynamics in the country should be taken far more into account. For the stability of Libya, it is necessary to continue supporting the missions and operations of the common foreign and security policy. These help not only in the fight against smuggling, trafficking, in the monitoring of the United Nations arms embargo. The missions work with the Libyan side to develop a comprehensive border management strategy, both marine and southern ones. For the implementation of the enumerated policies, the European Union must allocate sufficient resources, including the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (DE) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. The EU must continue to strive to substantially improve — or make our contribution to the stability, economic development and security of the people on the ground. Above all, we need political stability in Libya. It is the basic prerequisite for economic development and better living conditions for local people. Political stability, however, can only be achieved if an inclusive reconciliation process is initiated. It is therefore important for us to fully support the UN Action Plan for Libya and to further deepen our diplomatic efforts. We all know — and this is one of them — the images of the refugee camps in Libya, the images of violence and poverty and destruction. We profoundly condemn these serious violations of human rights and we no longer want to accept these images. The wide-ranging efforts of the High Representative, together with the United Nations and the African Union, have already made it possible to dismantle some refugee camps in Libya and more than 15 000 migrants from Libya to return to their homes. We also want to continue this positive development with the help of the Libyan authorities.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, as we speak today, rival factions in Libya and their supporters are meeting in Paris for renewed talks at finding a road map for peace. One year on since President Macron also launched similar talks, we do hope on this occasion that there will be a more positive outcome. The Panzeri report underlines that jointly, the Libya Political Agreement and the UN action plan remain the only credible solution to this crisis. Elections by the end of this year lie at the heart of those plans, and I welcome that this will be the key point under discussion in Paris. Ensuring that these elections are accepted by all in advance will be vital to preventing a repeat of the 2012 elections, which resulted bizarrely in rival competing administrations. We need now to reach a point whereby an internationally recognised government reflects the situation on the ground, and not merely western aspirations. In this regard, we must take account of voter registration, which remains sadly at around only 50%, a figure that in my mind is insufficient to deliver a true legitimacy and credibility to any elected government. Providing a lateral support and assistance, therefore, is a practical EU measure that could be taken to ensure that the provisions are in place for any political solution that is eventually reached. Secondly, I also note that Saif al-Islam Gaddafi has made a stated intention now to run in any elections. Given the ICC’s renewed calls this month for his arrest, such a presidential bid could pose genuine problems for ending impunity for war crimes committed by his family.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Madam President, I believe that Libya is the perfect paradigm of Parliament and the European Union's irrelevance. We have spent years working on metaphysical ideality, the Government of Fayez al-Sarrach, which is unknown and does not recognize anyone in Libya, except in New York and Brussels, and ignoring the reality on the ground. I would recommend that any Member of this Parliament try to walk from the seat of presidency in Fayez al-Sarrach, for example, to al-Baladia Street in Tripoli: he will surely have the opportunity to be kidnapped ten times every hundred metres by any of the militias. I would also recommend, for example, that you travel at night, without guardian, without protection, between Tobruk and Benghazi, and you will find that there is no problem, because you can do it. I did it without problems, without difficulty. What have we done in the European Parliament? We have recognized those who do not know in Libya — who is Fayez al-Sarrach — and we have made him our only actor. And, of course, when you try to solve a serious problem — because it's dead — simply thinking that legality and metaphysics are what matters, reality is much more important than our own ideas. There is a phrase in Spanish that says: “If reality contradicts our ideas, so much worse for reality.” The problem is that the reality is dead. And when I hear that there is a Government in Libya, I say: and what happened to the Tauerga agreement, where the Libyan Africans who lived there could not return, despite the agreement of the Fayez al-Sarrach Government with their own militias, who say they obey him and, in fact, do not obey him — the Misrata militias — and that cannot be done. And what are they telling us about the battle of Sebha among the Aulad Suleiman tribes, supported by battalions of the Misrata militias, against the Tubús nothing ago, a few weeks ago? The Fayez al-Sarrach government is a fiction and the European Parliament has worked with fictions and the European Commission has worked with fictions and the Coast Guard are nothing more than local gangsters converted into the coast guard, because they are the same people who used to smuggle immigrants themselves. Let's work with reality and stop doing metapolitics.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. You, High Representative Mogherini, have just told us about the Paris conference. A common army is to be built, a constitutional referendum is to be established and preparations are being prepared for joint elections — probably in the autumn. Of course, I welcome these recent developments. However, due to the unstable situation in Libya, it is very difficult to make rapid changes or improvements. I am just thinking of these mafia militias in Tripoli, which have also gained access through the many weak state institutions. Will they be ready to abandon this easily? I hope so, but I have my doubts that it will be quick. It is also clear that the implementation of the Paris proposals can only succeed with the help of the UN. In our detention, too, the UN is very central to the Libyan peace process, and we stress this. However, we continue to call for an active role for the EU, particularly in promoting democracy and strengthening civil society. However, the resolution also contains positions on EU cooperation on migration and refugee issues, which we as Greens do not agree with. Cooperation with the Libyan coast guard will be strengthened. We must not forget that people brought back to Libya by the coast guard end up in camps, where they are demonstrably abused and tortured. There is even a complaint against Italy pending before the European Court of Human Rights for violating the obligation to protect against torture through cooperation with the Libyan coast guard.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, this Recommendation on the situation in Libya includes issues that we share, such as the fact that there is no military solution or that stabilization will come from an inclusive national and regional agreement. But one of the problems is the non-assumption of original sin, not understanding that the crisis in Libya is not a natural phenomenon, but is the result of a nefarious management following a criminal intervention by NATO. The result: a failed state where chaos reigns. From a donor country in Africa to a country whose population needs humanitarian aid; from a safe country to a labyrinth where terrorist groups expanding throughout the Sahel settle. We are totally opposed to the EUBAM mission, which involves arming a gang of pirates and criminals to prevent the arrival of refugees in Europe. The security approach will not solve anything until we address the political, social and regional problems that led to the Western intervention that destroyed the Libyan State.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, talking about Libya is both complicated and necessary. Necessary because in our neighbourhood there is a country that has been completely destabilized since 2011, that is a harbinger of threats that touch us directly. Complicated not only because of the dysfunctional institutional framework and the many internal and external actors present, but also because the context is constantly becoming. That is why I want to express my concerns about both the form and content of the Paris Summit, wanted by President Macron, a reinforced retort of the one held, with poor results, in July 2017. I firmly believe that no country, not even among the most geopolitically influential, can have the presumption and arrogate itself the right to impose a solution for a crisis through unilateral initiatives. Rather than new plans and proposals, I believe that a balanced and negotiated position is needed more than ever, a particularly European position, which gives impetus to a road map that already exists, namely that of United Nations. And this message, my colleagues and I gave it when we went to Tripoli. Forward leaks of individual countries are only likely to further complicate the situation by fragilizing the already precarious existing balances. Reintegrating, as far as possible, individual militiamen and not militias into a single army and unifying the executive is the priority, but on whether new elections are made by 2018, I agree with what is said by the Italian Ambassador to Libya and above all also repeated by many NGOs: before any consultation it is essential that there is the approval of a new electoral law and a shared Constitution, as well as better security conditions and legal certainty, if we do not want such elections to multiply tensions more than help the country. The stakes are sky-high: in the last month alone there have been two bombings, one in Tripoli and one in Benghazi. And as we speak, a new threat is emerging, that of the radical Salafist group of Madkhalists, increasingly powerful and transversely rooted in the territory. We must act, but we must do it together and without the usual subterfuge. What Libya is today and what happened in 2011 should be a clear warning not to repeat the mistakes of the past.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, the criminal intervention in Libya, launched at the initiative of Nicolas Sarkozy, has had a threefold consequence: the fall of the Gaddafi regime, the guarantor of Libyan unity, the emergence of groups close to Daesh, Al-Qaida or the Muslim Brotherhood, and the migration invasion of Europe, accompanied by its deaths in the Mediterranean . Sad record for action in the name of human rights! Western Chanceries have maintained this chaos by playing the map of the government of national accord, supported by mafia militias, against Marshal Haftar, yet recognized by the elected parliament of Tobruk. Following the talks just held in Paris, rather than making pious vows, the European authorities should step up the fight against illegal immigration without worrying about the minds of the UN and pro-migrant activists, with a clear objective: zero immigration. They should cooperate with the Libyan Coast Guard, severely punish NGOs complicit with smugglers and, finally, lift the arms embargo in order to empower the Libyan National Army to secure Libyan National Army, a prerequisite for the holding of elections.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen. Many of the previous speakers have already pointed to the catastrophic situation in Libya. There's nothing to add. But today we are talking about what we can do as the European Union. Two points are important to me. I would also like to take up what the High Representative said. Firstly, we, as the European Union, should continue to fully support the United Nations peace efforts. It is above all the action plan that points the way to political national reconciliation involving all the major players in the country. Secondly, we, as the European Union, should continue to honour our humanitarian obligations. In February of this year, we in the European Union adopted three new programmes to improve the situation of migrants, particularly in Libya. They have a budget of 150 million euros. This is an important step, albeit only a small step by many, to improve the lives of the people of Libya and to stabilise the country. Dear Federica Mogherini, I believe that all of us here are delighted with the results of the meeting today in Paris, the fact that the influential political forces in the country have agreed on the first necessary steps of reform, and above all on the parliamentary elections which, according to my information, took place on 10 December. should take place. Mrs Lochbihler spoke of September, I think it is 10 December — whatever. If these words are followed by action, today's agreement could be a decisive step towards reconciling the parties to the conflict. Finally, on behalf of the entire committee, thank you very much to our rapporteur, Mr Panzeri, for this comprehensive and, in my view, a successful report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Mogherini for her comments on the visits of myself, Ms Ayala Sender and Mr Castaldo to Libya. What this visit very much underlined is the central focus of my colleague Mr Panzeri’s report, which was, as we saw for ourselves, that the international community and the EU in particular must step up its efforts to support stabilisation in Libya. This is the central focus: it was what you said, it’s what Mr Panzeri is saying in his report. And this process is about peaceful elections and good governance. We heard repeatedly in our visit that people must accept the eventual outcome of those elections, and it really focuses on what everyone is saying and our colleagues from the Committee on Foreign Affairs have been working on – this holistic approach. Of course, the dominant media images and suffering that we saw in the Tariq al-Sika detention camps were very disturbing, but it is very, very obvious that there is a holistic approach required to solving many of these problems, and I wish everyone involved in this the very best. I want to say from my committee very quickly that the question of arbitrary detention and human rights abuses are very obvious and detention must end. The whole question of the Libyan coast guard was one that we investigated very thoroughly: the question of the ‘do not harm’ principles; the question of access to services for migrant women and children; the question of Libyan authorities facilitating the regularisation of migrants living and working in Libya. This dominant issue is not going away. Yes, security is improving – I agree with what the High Commissioner has said. But this is a long-term battle and this element must be absolutely central. I will say this finally: Libyans are suffering too and are leaving too, and this was a very sobering visit. Thank you all for the help, and I hope Mr Panzeri’s report is read most widely.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, I wish Libya all the best, although taking into account the complexity of its problems, I am not very optimistic. I would like to raise one issue: Libya is also a rich country in terms of its sovereign wealth, which was frozen in 2011. The obligation of the international community is to reinvest the interest and dividends in a proper way, enabling us to return them in proper shape when time allows.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: — Madam President, I largely share the analysis of the Panzeri report. Only an inclusive approach involving all actors, without forgetting local actors, can lead to a solution in Libya. It would be nice if European governments, some European governments, cease their untimely initiatives that could undermine the work of the United Nations. But support for the government alone of national agreement cannot lead to a solution. Which part of the territory does it control? Who does he represent, as well as the four main actors of the Libyan conflict gathered in Paris? Any measure through the few coastguards of that Government, which are only those in Tripoli, is doomed to failure and could lead to further human rights violations. It was seen on November 6, 2017, during a rescue operation led by Sea Watch. Twenty people reportedly died as a result of their intervention and the survivors, upon their return to Libya, were reportedly detained, tortured and sold. This case has been referred to the European Court of Human Rights. We must therefore freeze European funding in this area until no serious evaluation has been carried out, freeze the SAR project and refuse any refoulement to Libya, including, High Representative, from Niger, as has just been done for 145 Darfurians. I have tabled amendments to this effect and I thank my colleagues for supporting them.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Libya is the prime example of failed European foreign and migration policy. Since military intervention in 2011, Libya has plunged into chaos and became an African gateway to the EU. We have to close this gate. We need Fortress Europe. Firstly, we need to pull up our drawbridge, secondly, we need to return the migrants to Libya who reach the EU from there. Both tasks have failed the European Union. Italy itself has signed an agreement with Libya. Contribution of the EU: zero. This is also the case with repatriation to Libya — this does not actually take place. And the biggest failure: the EU still does not protect its borders itself. Border guards are outsourced to Libya and North African states. After years of crisis, those who make it out of the Mediterranean still have a free ticket to the EU Member States and their social systems. This is almost unbelievable!

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: — Madam President, High Representative, establishing a peaceful and stable situation in Libya is a matter of utmost importance both for Libya itself and for our own security. It is therefore essential that we continue to help stabilise the country by providing both economic and institutional assistance and, of course, to support the UN Action Plan for Libya. We need reconciliation between the different warring parties in the country. Today is a day of hope for Libya. The basis for holding these parliamentary and presidential elections, which according to the treaties of today must be on the 10th of December, should be a constitutional referendum and an electoral law, but the most important thing is to respect the agreements between the warring parties. It is important for us, of course, that the southern border of our European Union is also well guarded. Terrorism has no borders, so the fight against terrorism can also have no borders. The best instruments against terrorism, against violence, against extremism, these are reconciliation and economic prosperity for young people, especially in Africa and especially Libya. We must hope that what has been achieved today in Paris will not only be left on paper, but will also happen in reality. The European Union, and I am convinced, you will continue to work in this direction. I wish you success, I wish success for the statehood in Libya to be restored again and, of course, security for European citizens.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, thank you also for the information you have just given us, and I congratulate Mr Panzeri on his report. Libya is a very important country involved in a very serious political and security crisis which also affects the Mediterranean region, the Sahel — neighbouring the south — and the European Union itself. There are many different illicit trafficking in this huge territory, where efficient State structures are so scarce, and these traffics are then projected beyond Libya. The European Union must contribute as much as possible to find solutions. We must continue to support the efforts of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General, Mr Salamé. A political solution is necessary, there does not seem to be a military solution. But we must be realistic, have the realities on the ground, conduct an inclusive political process and put the structures of the State on the ground. I know that there is a process of political dialogue working from the grassroots in various parts of the country's geography within the framework of the so-called National Conference. There are also some successful local elections such as Zawiya, the fourth city in the country, which will be followed by consultations in other municipalities. But when I read the briefing that the Special Representative, Mr Salamé, made to the Security Council on 21 May on the situation in Libya, it became clear to me that there are still too many shadows, many unresolved problems, along with some lights. You return from Paris, Mrs Mogherini, from the Conference there with some optimism. It is true that the agreements of the meeting, especially what you have told us about the commitment to presidential and legislative elections in December — three months earlier, I think, there will be an electoral law — allow some hope. The truth is that we all have to contribute to finding a solution for this country, including the other Arab countries involved in this crisis.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: — The Honored Chairman, Libya and its geostrategic position is crucial for the stability of the whole of North Africa and the Mediterranean. It's not just its borders to the Mediterranean but also its borders to countries with institutions in disintegration that are the source of migrant waves. In this regard, in order to resolve the crisis, we seek stronger engagement by the European Union with a more efficient mobilisation of external funding funds to help rebuild institutions, infrastructure and civil society and address the key causes of migration reaching Europe through that country. Europe must ensure unreserved support in the implementation of the UN Action Plan for Libya with the aim of achieving national reconciliation. The priority is to establish a functioning government with police and the military to protect their borders. Europe is kept not only on the borders of Schengen, but also on the borders of Libya. We must strengthen the fight against smuggling groups and slave traffickers as key solutions to reduce migrant pressures on Europe. Eliminating the causes of irregular migration and future instability in Europe begin in stable Libya, as well as in the stable Balkans through which, we see these days, a new migrant route to Europe opens. We are the biggest contractors of development aid, both in the world and in Libya and Syria. We need to be a more ambitious protagonist in making solutions for the stability of these countries, from which instability towards Europe is exported. It is time to articulate more clearly and take a stand on this issue on the international stage to make it clearer for our citizens what appears on their behalf as well.

name: Emil RADEV
text: — Madam President, High Representative, nearly eight years after the start of the revolution in Libya, the country is still divided and its citizens give daily sacrifices because of attacks by the warring factions. It is time for the European Union to have a clear, coherent and, above all, proactive policy towards Libya, providing unreserved support to the UN-recognised Fayez al-Saraj government in order to restore statehood in the country. The government must be provided with continued technical and financial assistance in the fight against ISIS, as well as against human traffickers. To this end, the European Union and the Member States should increase their actions to ensure the security of Libyan borders, especially maritime ones, by providing the necessary equipment and training programmes for Libyan border guards. It is essential that the mandate of the European mission EUBAM in Libya is extended beyond 31 December 2018 and, at the earliest opportunity, that the mission be relocated back to Libya in order to be more effective. Ladies and gentlemen, it is necessary to harness all the resources available to the European Union to help the official government return Libya to the peaceful countries.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I would like to first of all thank Mr Panzeri, our colleague, for his report, which is truly comprehensive and very well describes the current state and developments in Libya. Madam High Representative, I also want to thank you for the current report from the Paris meeting. Of course we need Libya to be a stable partner and have a democratic government.
