Libya is crucial to detaining migrants. It is important that refugees in this country are treated humanly and that new refugees do not arise, that people traffickers are fought here. So, in an uncluttered situation, it is important to support the 2017 United Nations Action Plan for Libya. As you said yourself, Libya is a rich country and therefore the need to involve young people in the reconstruction of this society, to prevent them being manipulated into being involved in crime and terrorism. It is in everyone's interest to support the reestablishment of this country and democratic elections.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate and to Mrs Mogherini's performance. Thank you for that message we got today about current developments in Paris. However, it must be said here that so far the situation in Libya is not unfolding very well. The promise of an early election is great, but to the election itself is very far away, the actors will need to be supported so that the process of preparing the election is carried out objectively, so that the elections are conducted independently and mainly, as You have already said yourself, Mrs Mogherini, for individual actors to recognise the election result. So today's action is a good promise, but please, let us now be very active in the whole process to free elections in Libya and let us not only leave it to individual civil actors war in Libya. I have to say, as I perceive the atmosphere in the Czech Republic, many citizens of the Czech Republic, Europeans, feel that the European Union may be more active in the situation in Libya and we could have done more to do this, to resolve the atmosphere and situation in this country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the military intervention of the West in 2011 in Libya literally disbanded that country. There is now civil war, there are slavers, we have an area where huge migratory flows begin, human rights violations, slave trade, the dissolution of any peaceful process. I consider the initiatives of both the UN and the European Union and, of course, the Paris Conference to formulate a solution to Libya issues to be important. There should be national reconciliation, there should be a message that the country's resources will be exploited by the people of the country themselves, that there will be inclusive dialogue, investment, jobs for the younger generation and, of course, institution restoration, parliament, central bank and all the institutions necessary for the functioning of a democratic regime and, of course, free elections.

name: Patricia LALONDE
text: — Madam President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Panzeri's report is timely, at the very moment when the French President brings together today the two strong men of the country, Fayez Al-Sarraj and Marshal Khalifa Haftar, the country's main political forces and, of course, the United Nations. This initiative is welcome, as it is time to find a way out of the crisis in Libya to end the chaos that has prevailed since 2011, and Europe must be the driving force. A road map engaging the parties in Libya on the organization of free and credible general elections should be signed. There are encouraging signs concerning, inter alia, the process of registration on the electoral lists, despite the recent attacks. The timetable for elections should not be constrained by the end of the year, because the priority is to ensure that elections are held in a safe and secure manner, that they are transparent and that everyone accepts their results. There must be a high turnout, that an electoral commission set the rules, and above all that a constitution be adopted by referendum, so that it can be in place at least for presidential elections. It must be done quickly and well, because the Libyan population is impoverished and the whole of Libya is plagued by an increase in militias or groups working for international crime.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Madam President, the disaster in Libya has no end in sight as long as the European Union insists on a mystifying policy, funding alleged Libyan coast guards, who are nothing more than armed militias, the same people who traffic and torture migrants and oppress the population. There are no coastal guards, no security forces under the control of a government that does not govern or by a criminal like Haftar. European security and defence and alleviating the suffering of the Libyan people are investing in what we have hitherto neglected: the reform of the security sector, which involves demobilisation and disarmament of militias. Without this, there will be no governance, no transition strategy leading to elections in Libya, nor will we stop terrorists from Daesh and al-Qaeda or the Madkhali Salafists increasingly entrenched in Libya. It is essential to open controlled, safe, legal migration channels, so that we do not continue to feed the business of drug mafias. The UN, UNHCR and AOM need to reinforce their intervention in Libya, with the support of military forces that have to integrate European and African contributions.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Madam President, I too would like to thank Mr Panzeri for his great and important work. Dear Mrs Mogherini, I do not know what else you can add to your knowledge. I think, unfortunately, you know a lot more and you've seen a lot more about Libya than all of us here together. However, I would like to add a couple of ideas that may have been heard to some extent. If it wants and can help, the European Union is with its presence there. Not just the visits. Persistent presence in the direction of education, in the direction of bringing together warring factions, political and military, towards investment. If the economy does not reactivate, if very different views within the country do not come together, I think, and you know it yourself, it will still take a long time. Insisting on the issue of reconciliation within the country, investment and education.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: — Madam President, the wrong way in which the French Government of President Sarkozy first intervened militarily in Libya and then other European Union countries, such as England, Germany and the United States, was the main reason for this chaos. situation at the moment in the country. Libya was and still is a wealthy country, which was trying to negotiate with the European Union. However, it has now become the main entry of illegal immigrants from the African continent into the European Union. At the same time, the inability to cooperate with each other by the many armed groups that exist, the conflict between the races, the inability to combat terrorism, and the current situation leave no room for improving things. It is utopian to believe that we will be able to solve the Libyan problem. It is good to intervene by the UN and the European Union, and let it continue at least so as not to make the situation worse.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I think that for once Mr Panzeri has performed a sort of miracle in uniting the chamber around not only his report, but also the common work with Libya, for Libya. I will touch upon a few specific points that were raised either in comments or questions, and specify, maybe in a better way than I’ve done previously, the sequencing and the meaning of the Paris meeting in relation to the overall work we are doing in the international community. First of all, the specific points that were raised: transfer of the EU delegation to Tripoli. We have been working on that constantly over the last months and I would hope and expect, to be able to give you good news in the coming weeks. In the meantime, some of you asked for EUBAM to be present in Libya. As I said in my opening remarks, EUBAM is present in Libya, and has been operating now from Tripoli for several weeks. This is a major asset we have, because day-to-day work, especially with the border management agency and the criminal justice sector, is much more effective on the ground than from Tunis. Second, some of you referred to the role of the militias. As I said, but I want to underline this, it is clear to all that some of the members of the militias will need to be disarmed. This is an effort that is always complicated at the end of a transition of a conflict. It is also an aspect in which the European Union and the Member States have relevant know-how and competence. We have been working on this with several different conflict areas and crisis areas in the world. Tomorrow this chamber will be listening to President Santos, and he might tell us something interesting about how a disarmament process can be conducted, and we have also supported and helped there, so there is a way of doing this. It is not easy. It is never easy. On top of that, we are talking about Libya, which I hope everybody understands is different to talking about Norway. It is a different kind of country. Some of the militia members will need to be integrated in one security force under civilian responsibility. This is also what has been discussed in Paris and this is mainly what the UN Special Representative is working on with our active accompanying role and support because, as I said, we have a specific competence and know-how in this. The third point that was mentioned and that I intentionally didn’t touch upon in my opening remarks is the issue of migration. I didn’t touch upon this because we have discussed several times the situation of migrants inside Libya, and I believe that for once Libya deserved a discussion on Libya and Libyans, and not purely focused on the situation of migrants in the country. Even if we know very well that solving the Libyan crisis would also be the best possible way to fight the traffickers’ networks, to save lives, and to guarantee a sustainable, manageable, humane approach to this. But as many of you said, we have now established, for the first time ever, a good pattern of work. Thanks to the task force we – the European Union, the African Union and, the United Nations – established last November, the three of us have managed in a few months, working on the ground, to help save 26 000 people from the detention centres. They have been able to return to their home countries voluntarily in an accompanied manner through the IOM, with European Union support. And another 1 600 people who were in the detention centres and who have been assessed as in need of international protection, with the status of refugees, through the UNHCR, have been evacuated with a view to their resettlement. And as you know, we have also been providing resettlement opportunities inside the European Union and helping the UNHCR to find other resettlement opportunities around the world. It is the first time ever that work like this has accomplished, and this has been possible over the last few months thanks to an unprecedented partnership between the European Union, the United Nations and the African Union. And just last week in Brussels, when we had the college-to-college meeting between the European Commission and the African Union Commission, we decided to extend the work of this task force, so we will continue working together on the ground in Libya. And this is something we also discussed today with our Libyan interlocutors in Paris. Last but not least, two points, one on the elections. It is clear, first of all, as Mr Castaldo mentioned, that elections need to take place in the context of a constitution and constitutional clarity under electoral law. I made it very clear not only in Paris, but also in my opening remarks here. And the EU is now already providing supporting for the elections. It is the European Union that is supporting the UN’s work on the ground to prepare this road. As you know better than anyone else, we have a certain experience in accompanying countries in difficult situations to build up their way to credible elections. We have also committed to increasing our support for the organisation of the elections and, eventually, if the conditions are in place, we will contribute by sending an electoral observation mission to Libya. The last point but not the least, the most important one. Some of you referred to a Paris agenda: let me be very clear on this. The reason for the meeting this morning in Paris – very clearly specified and laid down by President Macron – is to support the UN work and to support the UN road map. There is no competition between agendas here. It’s a matter of uniting forces for a coherent, regional and international accompanying work to the UN, because we realised that if the regional organisations, the neighbouring countries, starting from the European Union, the African Union, the Arab League, all the neighbouring countries in Africa but also in Europe, do not join forces to accompany every single step of the work done by the UN and by the Libyans, the entire agenda of the UN road map risks slowing down. And Libyan partners risk referring to one interlocutor or the other to take a slightly different path. So the unity of the international forces and the unity of the regional actors – starting from the European Union, the Arab League and the African Union – is essential to support the work of Salamé of and of the United Nations. This is the sense of the meeting that I had this morning and this road map leading to elections hopefully – inshallah as we would say – on 10 December, can work only if there is: commitment and responsibility by the Libyans and their country’s various institutions and leaders; unity of international and regional actors to accompany and support this work; and all of this converging under the UN umbrella and leadership. If we have these three conditions in place, I believe that commitments can turn into concrete steps that would help lift the country out of the crisis. In all of this, the role of the European Parliament will continue to be essential, so the praise for the excellent report and recommendations of Mr Panzeri should turn into a plea to continue the work actively supporting this process, especially as Libya heads, hopefully, towards elections. The role of the European Parliament in accompanying this process will continue to be key, it will actually become even more essential, so we count on you.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the High Representative Federica Mogherini and I completely agree with his conclusions. I stop only briefly on three considerations. I confess that I always find suggestive the narratives of Mr Nart and this his recall to reality on the field I always consider it important and to share, but I think he agrees with me that this is precisely this reality requires us to accelerate the process of reconciliation and quickly set up a road map capable of facilitating a stabilization of the country, and that is what we indicate in some way in this recommendation. Second consideration on the election, I tell Castaldo, let's not get lost around whether the egg or hen was born first. I agree that absolutely an electoral law is needed without which it is difficult to have a basis, but on the Constitution we can also work to have only a first general reading and then have a confirmation later. Voting and acknowledging the outcome is, as far as I am concerned, essential to ensuring minimum conditions of governability for Libya. Finally, the migration issue is a very serious problem which has also been ascertained by the visit of the European Parliament delegation, and I know that there is this debate around the Coast Guard and the European Union mission, among other things there is a strategic review commitment within the year of the EUBAM and Sophia mission, and there we will actually discuss what needs to be updated and changed. Some amendments have been accepted on immigration, although, and I say this very seriously, we cannot charge Libya and the Mediterranean countries, especially Italy, the absence of a Common European immigration policy, which I hope the next Council of 28 and 29 will be adequately addressed. Ultimately, I am convinced that we have all the conditions, as the High Representative said, with this recommendation to bring our contribution, the European Parliament's contribution to the process of stabilization of Libya.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Wednesday 30 May 2018. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. — Madam President/Mr, In relation to Libya, I support the UN-led settlement process, the activities and plans of Special Envoy Salamé. I agree that assistance should be given to the Libyan Government in establishing political consensus and guaranteeing security. I believe it is important that the report emphasises the intensification of diplomatic efforts with regional actors and neighbouring countries to ensure that they contribute to a positive resolution to the Libyan crisis. I also agree with the examination of the Libyan crisis in the wider, regional and Pan-African context, bearing in mind the key role of Libya in terms of stability in North Africa, the Sahel and the Mediterranean. Hungary is hopeful about Libya's political settlement, and nothing shows this better than that last year we reopened our Embassy in Tripoli. The embassies of the majority of EU Member States have not returned to the region for years. In addition, Hungary believes that the protection of Libya's southern borders should be given considerable attention. However, as regards migration, I consider it a crucial point that the report sees the long-term solution to irregular migration through and from Libya in that the Council, the Commission and Mrs Mogherini define the international migration processes based on direct resettlement legal basis. In my opinion, in future, the relocation of asylum seekers from outside the EU will continue to take place only on a voluntary basis. For this reason, among other things, I do not find the report acceptable.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. — The political and socio-economic situation in Libya is very difficult and complicated. Therefore, the European Parliament, in accordance with this recommendation, intends to provide guidance to the European External Action Service, the European Commission and the European Council on how to proceed with this topic. The European Union helps in Libya's political transition towards the creation of a stable and well-working state and provides assistance to restore effective state governance and improve socio-economic conditions. Thanks to partners in the area above, such as the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the EU regularly increases humanitarian aid to meet migration challenges in Libya. Consequently, on the sidelines of the European Union and African Union summit in November 2017, the EU, together with the AU and the United Nations, formed a joint task force to advance both the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) programme on assisted voluntary returns as well as the emergency transit mechanism of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). The EU has allocated EUR 182 million from its budget for migration projects, EUR 162 million under the EU Trust Fund for Africa (EUTF) and EUR 20 million in bilateral aid.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: — The next item is the report by Carlos Coelho, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the annual report on the functioning of the Schengen Area (2017/2256 (INI)) (A8-0160/2018).

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Rapporteur. — (PT) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 1990, in a small town in Luxembourg that would remain in history, the Convention implementing the Schengen Agreement was signed. Later President of the European Parliament, Pieter Dankert, asked who forty years ago could have imagined that France, Germany, almost reunified, and the Benelux would sign an agreement here in Schengen. Allow me to adapt these historic words to the present day. Who would have thought twenty years ago that the area of free movement would include twenty-six countries, four hundred million people and fifty thousand kilometres of external borders? Who would have thought that the European Parliament would be debating its report on Schengen for the first time today? In 1990, Pieter Dankert answered his question with a resolute 'We did it'. Today, however, we know that Schengen is never completed, nor guaranteed. The full entry of Bulgaria and Romania remains unfulfilled. It is unacceptable that, seven years after meeting all the requirements to benefit from freedom of movement, Bulgarians and Romanians continue to be treated by the Council as second-rate citizens. I hope that tomorrow the European Parliament will reaffirm once again that Bulgaria and Romania should be full members of Schengen. Ladies and gentlemen, Schengen is never completed or guaranteed, in fact, and thirty-three years after the signing of the Schengen Agreement we face new dangers and challenges. The last three years have been dramatic. An apparent new normality has emerged. Internal border controls have once again been part of the daily lives of millions of Europeans. National governments, along with the most populist fringes of our political spectrum, have turned Schengen into the scapegoat for the shortcomings in security policies and the weaknesses of the common European asylum system. They put Schengen in a coma, carrying evils that aren't their own. In order to spy on guilt and win elections, Member States are using the Schengen atomic bomb lightly and are doing so illegally. The maximum period agreed by the Member States themselves has been far exceeded and the vague and contradictory reasons are not reflected in reality. If Schengen perishes, the economic impact could reach EUR 50 billion, but above all, the greatest expression of a citizens' Europe disappears. Mr President, the Schengen Information System is the largest European system in combating crime and controlling our borders. However, there are Member States that continue to disregard the rules on their use. The United Kingdom, being not the only one, is particularly serious in this area. Already after the adoption of this Commission report, the Schengen Working Group over which I chair was informed of the serious problems in the United Kingdom's use of SIS. The access of this State is temporary because it is not a member of Schengen and is therefore independent of its withdrawal process. This evaluation is no longer the first with serious results. However, it is of particular concern at the moment, because the United Kingdom is in the process of leaving but wants to maintain a relationship with the Union also in the area of security. Here too, the Council and the Commission must work with Parliament to find a solution. Mr Avramapoulos, we need to give Schengen back to the citizens. The Commission cannot fear using all the instruments at its disposal and can count on the support of this Parliament. With this report, we take a significant step in the exercise of democratic scrutiny in Schengen, we increase transparency and, with this, a more serious discussion and, ladies and gentlemen, the problem of combating terrorism is not resolved with more frontiers, it is solved with more cooperation. If national governments do not have the courage to rescue Schengen, let us have the courage to save the freedom of European citizens.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I don’t need to repeat how important economically, politically and, in particular, symbolically Schengen is. We all know. I would like to express my thanks to the Members of the Schengen Working Group for their continuous work and in particular the European Parliament’s ‘Mr Schengen’, Mr Carlos Coelho. Thank you for your report and this very timely debate. It comes at the moment where we are reflecting a lot on the future of our common external border management but also on how to enhance our internal security and free movement in the Schengen Area. The thing is, we need to be pragmatic but without ever forsaking our values and fundamental principles. This is why one of our concerns is how to better make use of the existing tools at our disposal to fully implement the legislative measures we have recently adopted and to conclude pending legislation. But we also look to the future. How do we see the future as regards borders management but also as regards the free movement of European citizens in an area without border controls? My answer to this is clear and simple. We need to take joint responsibility for the management of our common external borders but also ensure mutual trust among Member States and everything that is implied by this. During the last three years, as we all know, we have been working together intensively in order to safeguard Schengen. During the last three years Schengen has been confronted with the most important challenges since its conception. Several Member States have reintroduced temporary internal border controls to address irregular migration flows and secondary movements and also in reaction to the multiple terrorist attacks. But temporary internal border controls cannot and should not become permanent ones. That is why it is so important to preserve the right balance between ensuring mobility, on the one hand, whilst guaranteeing security on the other hand. It is important to use, but also to improve, all the tools we have at our disposal to ensure high standards of security. It is precisely to maintain this balance that the Commission has proposed, among others, to amend the Schengen Borders Code, which is also one of our priorities. Member States retain the main responsibility when it comes to security. The temporary reintroduction of border controls is a legitimate measure available to Member States confronted with a serious threat to internal security or public policy in exceptional cases. We should never forget this essential point: that internal border controls are, and should indeed remain, exceptional. Our proposal does not intend to make controls at internal borders easier or permanent. On the contrary, we have proposed reinforcing the procedural safeguards. The reintroduction of border controls should only be a measure of last resort, with the Council having the last word. And the views of the other Member States affected by such decisions must be duly taken into account. Alternative solutions, such as police checks and cross-border cooperation must always take priority. I would also like to stress the Schengen Borders Code amendment, which aims to adapt the rules for the reintroduction of temporary internal border controls to the current needs to respond to evolving and persistent serious threats to public policy or internal security. In the meantime, the Commission is in contact with the Member States concerned on lifting internal border controls as soon as possible, allowing them to maintain the same level of security by using other tools, such as reinforced police checks and increased cross-border cooperation. We all agree that we should return to the full, normal functioning of the Schengen Area as soon as possible. I made this very clear in all my recent contacts with the countries that have done it. Mobility inside our Schengen Area requires secure external borders. This is exactly why since 2015 we have made significant progress in our external borders management. A key element has been the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, bringing together the national border guard authorities of the Member State and the European Borders and Coast Guard Agency, which now operates along the European borders. As part of our proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework which we put forward on 2 May 2018, we proposed to almost triple the expenditure for external borders management, migration and asylum, which could fund 10 000 border guards by 2027 for the European Borders and Coast Guard Agency. The EU budget for the management of external borders, migration and asylum would reach more than EUR 34.9 billion overall, compared to EUR 13 billion for the period 2014-2020. A new integrated border management fund will help to guarantee a high level of security in the European Union by ensuring strong and effective border management, while safeguarding the free movement of persons. If adopted, it will reinforce financial and operational support given to Member States in securing the European Union’s common external borders. We equally need to know who is crossing our borders and be able to stop those who pose a threat whilst ensuring mobility for bona fide travellers. We have already made substantial progress. The development of the entry/exit system is starting. We have also reached a political agreement on the European travel information and authorisation system (ETIAS). I would like to thank you for your work on this file too. We also have proposals on the table to strengthen existing systems, such as the Schengen Information System where negotiations are about to close, and the European Criminal Records Information System in respect to third country nationals convicted in the European Union by creating this centralised system on third-country nationals. Again, we need to reach swift agreements on these files. We also aim to improve the exchange of information and to make our systems interoperable to help us counter terrorism and serious crime and secure our borders, with full respect for data protection. Our proposal on interoperability will be a game-changer in this respect, and we need to complete the work on it by the end of this year. As you can see, we have many building blocks in place to strengthen our external borders, but we need to make yet further efforts to preserve Schengen, to make it even stronger and more resilient. Finally, let me repeat: the absence of internal border controls constitutes the very essence of Schengen, but in a common area without border controls, security concerns are common too. This is why we must do everything to preserve the careful balance between free movement and mobility, on the one hand, and security on the other. This is also what our citizens expect from us, and we can only achieve this through a coordinated and united Schengen framework, which brings me to my last point. Schengen should include Romania and Bulgaria too, because a more inclusive Schengen is a more secure Schengen. We call on the Council to finally decide on Bulgaria and Romania to join the Schengen family and Croatia too, once all criteria are met.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, I congratulate Mr Coelho on his work and on his commitment. The Schengen area and the free movement of persons are under threat. The restoration of internal borders by some Member States has undermined the principles of solidarity, cooperation and mutual trust. Restoring internal border controls has proved to be easier than removing them. New controls to regulate the movements of nationals have been the response of some States to the arrival of asylum-seekers and refugees and terrorism. The causes do not refer to the essence of Schengen, but to related areas such as the deficiencies of the SECA. It is therefore very necessary to continue working on the migration and asylum package presented in 2016. We must make full use of existing systems and continue to promote police and judicial cooperation between States and with Europol, Eurojust and Frontex. The ongoing reform of SIS II is also essential. In addition, SIS and VIS systems must always be operational at border crossings. New legislative proposals on database interoperability are necessary to optimize EU-LISA's role with the Input and Output System. Political will, solidarity with first-entry countries, strengthening existing systems and interoperability are essential tools for strengthening the Schengen area. And yes, I also say 'Bulgaria and Romania, inside'.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Madam President, the Schengen area of free movement is one of the greatest advances in the European Union. This phrase, which testifies to the pride of the progress made, also resonates as a banality to which one would almost have become accustomed to. But we must land and pinch ourselves to believe that this is still true and that it is still the strength of the European Union in the world. Yet it all started so well when, in 1995, European citizens from 22 Member States, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland were given the opportunity to move freely from one country to another, which greatly improved social, cultural and economic exchanges. To guarantee this, our predecessors have adopted a common rule, finally quite simple in its elaboration: harmonised controls at external borders in exchange for freedom of movement within the space thus created. I speak in the present, but a lot has changed in the last few years. It is because we do not resign ourselves to this slow deterioration that the European Parliament affirms in this first annual report its commitment to the Schengen area and to free movement. It highlights the shortcomings in the implementation of Schengen policies and makes recommendations. The most important of them is shared by the vast majority of Parliament. While several Member States have re-established controls at their national borders, sometimes for more than two years, and although these controls are authorised by the rules of the Schengen Border Code, they are contrary to the spirit of free movement. They must therefore be limited in time and justified, for example, because of security risks. However, while legislation to strengthen security at our external borders — Frontex reform, systematic verification of Europeans and third-country nationals, new databases — are being stacked, the Schengen counterpart no longer exists and several Member States continue to carry out these controls at their national borders, sometimes in contravention of the rules. We denounce this non-compliance with the common rules. As shadow rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats on this text, I also wanted to insist that other recommendations be included in it, because the Schengen area interacts with other common policies, including the management of migration flows. I must cite only two examples. Welcoming people who try to join the Schengen area. Too many migrants have lost their lives in the Mediterranean. At sea search and rescue operations must be increased with Frontex, which is obliged to participate fully in these operations, and Member States can agree on a strong European asylum system, legal access routes to the Union and solidarity and shared reception of asylum seekers between Member States. At a time when asylum negotiations are blocked in the Council, we want a courageous and progressive policy to help strengthen the management of reception at the external borders and the stability of the Schengen area.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, The whole Schengen project has greatly lost the confidence of Europeans, and it is for good reason, because the Schengen project has failed in all that which is the essence of a border. It has failed over the fight against organised crime, it has failed in keeping uncontrollable migration out of Europe, and it has failed in combating terrorism. The biggest tragedy in the fallacious history of the Schengen system has been the implementation of a European prestige project once again without having the underlying structures in place. It simply removed internal borders without having a sufficiently robust and complete system of external border controls in order, and this has been shown to have absolutely fatal consequences for the security of citizens in European countries. That is why it is clear that we must do two things: first, the external border must be much more robust, much more secure and much more impervious to people trying to get to Europe. Secondly, we must say that as long as there is no completely fundamental control of external borders, external security in the European Union, it is the prerogative of every Member State to maintain internal border controls and ensure that the citizens of our Member States are as safe as possible. That is why we are far from the objective as far as Schengen cooperation is concerned, and therefore internal border controls must be allowed to continue until this is achieved.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, One of the first, greatest and most important successes of EU cooperation is the right for us citizens of Europe to move freely across national borders, but since 2015 this right has unfortunately been restricted in country after country. Several member countries, including Sweden, have reintroduced border controls that would be temporary but unfortunately appear to have been permanent more or less. Today, the refugee situation within the EU is under control. The outer border is strengthened. Many measures have been taken to ensure safety. Border controls have played out their part, but they today strike very, very hard on the economy and prosperity of us citizens. Moreover, they are neither proportionate nor necessary and should have been abolished long ago. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Carlos Coelho, for a well-balanced, very important report which is necessary because it turns out that all Member States do not meet the basic requirements that are being made. Two years ago, the Commission presented a roadmap to return to a full and firm Schengen. Two years later, it's a distant dream. Extended border controls impose a strain on the single market and it is not a national issue. It is a question that needs to get a European and international answer. I think it is very important that we now return to a full Schengen, and I think, like the Commissioner, the rapporteur and many colleagues here, that it is high time for Romania and Bulgaria to be involved in a fully functional Schengen cooperation.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, Schengen cooperation is probably what many citizens appreciate most in EU cooperation, and it has provided significant benefits to EU citizens as well as business. This is something we all want to safeguard, but it has been put to a hard test in recent years and particularly in the context of the refugee situation in 2015 when several Member States reintroduced border controls. Although the situation looks different today, member countries continue to extend controls, citing threats of terrorism and security. I would suggest that it is the perceived sense of intimidation of the Member States rather than the actual existence of threats that govern in this case. The answer that we in Europe usually give to the sense of insecurity is that we should strengthen our external borders and prevent people from coming here, both migrants and potential terrorists, despite the latter being raised in the vast majority of cases in our countries. I think it is a shame that today's report too much gets into this line of thought, but I will be talking about what is most important to me in the report, that is, Parliament's strong criticism that Member States continue to impose internal controls, in particular because several of them are not in line with the existing rules in terms of scope, need and proportionality. So, according to Parliament, they are not legal. We in Parliament also believe that there is no proportion between measures adopted to strengthen external borders and measures to abolish the internal ones. We believe that there are other and better methods to prevent, among other things, cross-border crime than ID controls at internal borders.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, the Schengen area is, or was, one of the main achievements of European integration for European citizens. It was the symbol of free movement. However, it has become a symbol of the failure of European governments to show solidarity. The more tools are put in place to combat organised crime, trafficking of all kinds, money laundering, the fight against terrorism, the more certain states are questioning Schengen to mask their shortcomings and their lack of willingness to share information on their sovereign competences. Obsession is the fight against so-called irregular immigration. There is a growing number of numbers, confusing “border control” and “police objectives”, we forget the principles of necessity and proportionality, while the balance between security and fundamental rights is broken. France is at the forefront of these major failures and, worse, it dared to use the fight against terrorism to put in place facies controls on the Franco-Italian border. It's a mistake of the Schengen rules. I would like to conclude by thanking Mr Coelho for his work, for his willingness to have an inclusive approach to this report. I share his concern about what is happening in the United Kingdom and I support his amendment on this point, as I support Bulgaria and Romania's inclusive accession to the Schengen area.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Schengen Agreements are a pillar of the European project. We are talking about the free movement of citizens without internal border controls, but also of strengthening the fight against organised crime, with controls at external borders. Well, the operation of Schengen is closely linked to basic points, namely mutual trust between the Member States, cooperation, the exchange of information, all of which have been put in place hard to test the huge migration flows of recent years, with the consequence, on the one hand, of reaching the unhealthy combination between migration and terrorism and, on the other, of seeing countries alone and in difficulty border, also put under indictment. The weaknesses of the Schengen area are then the weaknesses of the whole of the European Union and it is vital to find a political will among all the Member States to strengthen the European project, in such a way to achieve real cooperation between all the Member States and above all to achieve a fair sharing of responsibilities, protecting the freedom of citizens, on the one hand, security, on the other, and do not suspend Schengen to avoid secondary movements of migrants.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, in the report on Schengen, the European Parliament opts for open borders and therefore against security. Like the European Commission, Parliament does not want to hear criticism of illegal border crossing and is blind to its criminal consequences. Even the 1200 assaults in one evening Parliament has not opened its eyes. The arrival of huge numbers of illegal migrants has led to the reintroduction of border controls, including in Germany, and rightly so. Even Mrs Merkel — the multiculti acela — seems to be shocked by rape and crime, and border controls have not been abolished again. If even Merkel wants fewer illegal immigrants, how is it that this European Parliament is blind to the misery that the open borders have brought about and does not show any compassion for the women affected?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, when the Schengen area was first created, many thought it was one of the greatest achievements of the European Union. It is true that the free movement of people, means and materials between the countries of the European Union is a very attractive and desirable development by all. However, the security of external borders is a basic prerequisite for the Schengen Convention to enter into force. The sages of the European Union did not take into account this basic condition, they removed the competence of border security from the countries of the external borders and entrusted this delicate task to a completely incompetent, worthless and, as has been shown in practice, dangerous organization, which hears in the name Frontex. The fatal consequence of Frontex's weakness was that Italy and, above all, Greece were flooded with illegal immigrants. Moreover, Greece has now turned into a camp for the concentration of unhappy and impoverished souls. If, therefore, the European Union wants to rescue the Schengen Convention, it will have to do two things: firstly, to force Turkey not to send illegal immigrants to Greece and, secondly, to entrust the security of the external borders to the competent countries again.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, European citizens today consider freedom of movement without internal border controls as the greatest achievement of the Union. If we want the Union to remain important for our citizens, then preserving the Schengen system must be a priority. However, it is now clear that internal border relief requires full control of external borders, that all Member States with external borders fully comply with the existing Schengen legislation, as Hungary does. This energy and cost at the external border must be declared part of solidarity, and therefore the resources of those Member States which protect the Schengen external borders and thus the security of the Union as a whole must be increased. A successful migration policy can only be implemented with the full protection of external borders. Unfortunately, the European Union's bad response to the migration crisis, based on a mandatory resettlement quota, and the consequences of this, many Member States have restored border control at the EU's internal borders. This practically threatens the functioning of the Schengen area. These temporary border controls must be lifted without delay, because a Europe without internal borders is a tangible Union for citizens, and it is time that it has come to the inhabitants of Romania and Bulgaria.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, Mr Coelho's report, I think it is an accurate, apt and responsible view of the current state of the Schengen area, and I would like to thank the rapporteur in particular. Contrary to the populist arguments in certain Member States, it is important to emphasise that, as part of the measures taken to protect the Schengen area, the protection of the external borders of the European Union has been strengthened and the introduction of checks based on appropriate databases . At the same time, it is pointless in itself to maintain internal border controls. I fully agree with the rapporteur that the amendment of the Schengen Code should not constitute an additional opportunity to maintain internal border controls. There is a need to respond to new challenges, but this reaction should not lead to restrictions on free movement within the Schengen area, and even less to extremist plans such as closing or threatening the borders of a country. I also agree with the rapporteur that the Schengen system, the current system of the Schengen area, is not due to problems relating to the structure and rules of the region, but mainly to the shortcomings of the Common European Asylum System. Therefore, instead of further isolation, legal roads must be created for refugees and immigrants, and the Council must be determined to start negotiations on the Dublin Regulation and finally approve the new European Asylum Agency.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, within the Schengen area we can travel freely without passport control. But this mutual trust between countries cannot be without strong joint protection of the EU's external borders. Unfortunately, these external borders are still porous, as European judges prohibit pushbacks. Boats are still being transferred to Europe, to rescue rather than to the last safe transit country. It therefore seems perfectly justifiable for Member States to be able to temporarily re-introduce internal border controls. However, this report condemns that approach. It is also critical of the systematic control of EU nationals coming from outside the EU, including returning Syrian fighters, for example at Zaventem airport. We think that criticism is very misplaced from a safety point of view. The reintroduction of border controls within the EU does indeed entail economic costs. But it is precisely because the EU is not doing enough to strengthen these external borders that Member States want to know who goes in and out. Border controls, like targeted police actions, are sometimes necessary.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: —Mr President, the report on the functioning of the Schengen area again found that Bulgaria and Romania had already met the criteria for admission seven years ago. Readiness for accession has been repeatedly confirmed by both the European Parliament and the President of the Commission and the Council conclusions. I fully support the report's view that 'full implementation of Schengen law in the Member States that have met the criteria is essential for a coordinated and reliable framework for legal security'. If internal borders are removed, interoperability of border schemes will be improved. Schengen would indeed be stronger if Bulgaria and Romania were part of it, as Commissioner Avramopoulos said before. The arguments against are entirely and only political. That is why I support this report, but I also urge the Council to adopt the long needed actions to accept Bulgaria and Romania into Schengen.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President! All empires fall sooner or later. The first badge to fall for the EU was when Brexit started. Now the next badge may be about to fall because it no longer serves its purpose. I am, of course, talking about Schengen cooperation. The idea of Schengen was fundamentally good; it would facilitate EU citizens to be able to move freely and smoothly within Europe. This left many, at least in my country Sweden, choosing to vote for EU membership. Think how smooth to be able to go around Europe without having to pass passport or border checks. In order for this to work and be possible, it was provided that the EU's external border protection would work. After all, we know that it does not, even if we have bribed Turkey with 60 billion to stop the migrants from making their way across the Mediterranean. More recently, we have also assisted Libya with help to stop migrant flows to Italy. During this time, we have also threefold appropriations for Frontex to monitor and secure our external borders. The result is, on the whole, a larger mission for them to search and rescue people offshore that they then transport to Greece and Italy. Approximately 80 percent of their operations consist of this mission. With facit in hand, and with the change we see today, it no longer holds. We've seen an illegal migration without its like. Weapons and drugs have also basically had freedom of movement, let alone terrorists, how they organised themselves and committed acts of terror in our Member States.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in these minutes I am really calling and writing a lot of Italian citizens, asking me to defend them inside these buildings and ask to be defended against them palaces and this must make us think, it is crazy to think that we have transformed the European palaces into the first front of defense of Italian citizens. Today there is an Italian citizen, he sees a European flag, he does not see the future, he sees no hope, he sees no opportunity. Unfortunately today if an Italian citizen sees this Europe sees the European war “4.0" and about this I am extremely concerned, a political war, a war of financial speculation, as we witness in these hours. This Europe has taken away from the Italian people monetary sovereignty, removed the sovereignty of border control, brought as the cause of this European war 4.0 poverty, hiding, unemployment, insecurity, fewer births and therefore death. And then we ask this Europe not to enter the Italian vote, we ask this Europe to let the Italian people free in choosing ministers, choosing programmes, choosing hope and our country. The League and many Italian citizens today ask in a strong and clear way to remain free from this Europe, otherwise it will become a Europe that will suck to Italy.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: — Mr President, I congratulate Mr Quelyu on this objective report, which gives a real assessment of the state of the Schengen area today, stresses the pros and cons and the actions to be taken. The Schengen area has been under great strain in recent years, and it is precisely such periods that require the European Parliament to play a role more seriously in preserving this area. The European Parliament has a duty to protect citizens' rights by actively fighting for the protection of the Schengen area. Unfortunately, however, it cannot be said that the functioning of Schengen today gives optimal results. The reintroduction of border controls seriously undermines citizens' confidence in European integration. It is therefore necessary to take measures to restore benefits to citizens so that the basic idea of free movement does not suffer. The European Union has new challenges — threats of attacks and terrorism. All these threats require better exchange of information, better coordination, closer cooperation and more European solidarity. The effective functioning of the Schengen area depends on how much the countries will be united and in solidarity with each other. It is this solidarity that requires Bulgaria and Romania to be admitted immediately into Schengen. Acceptance of Bulgaria and Romania into Schengen will contribute to more security and stability in the European Union. The Union must immediately decide on the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the Schengen area, because the two countries reliably protect the external borders and must therefore be full members of this area.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President! The Schengen area is an essential condition for the internal market. Those who shake this foundation are jeopardising our prosperity and are putting the European future at risk. That is why it is important to regularly and self-critically check what can be improved. The annual progress report presented today by Carlos Coelho is a good opportunity to do so. Above all, he shows that Schengen is a success story, despite all dulk calls. The reintroduction of border controls would cause immense damage. Therefore, vulnerabilities can be relentlessly identified. I see three areas: the insufficient protection of external borders, which is also due to the inexertion of some Member States on their national sovereignty, and in particular the Dublin regime, which did not function from the outset, have contributed much to the crisis of credibility. There are clear ideas about both of our house. Indeed, more Europe could improve the security situation. A serious problem is also the symbolically motivated permanent border controls. We experience this every time we travel to the plenary session at Strasbourg airport. What is the security gain? Or if the motorway crossings are checked in the Austrian-Bavarian border area, but the other border crossings are not. One cannot help the impression that many things are motivated domestically.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: — Mr President, many people are concerned about the collapse of the Schengen system. The real problem, however, is not that some of the Member States have returned control to internal borders. The real problem is that the lack of border control has allowed illegal migration and asylum hopping. If this problem is not solved, we will lose free movement. A strict external border and asylum policy is the best and only way to defend the Schengen system. Member States must have the opportunity to restore control to internal borders in a flexible manner and for as long as the situation requires. This opportunity encourages the external border countries and the European Union to take care of the external border. We can choose between leaking external borders or free movement in the Schengen area, but we cannot choose both.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, in the age of ISIS and mass migratory waves, the Schengen area is pie—in—the—sky utopian student politics. It is a concept that is out of time. If an external border is porous – as it has been with the EU for many years – then the absence of internal borders becomes still more critical. When Ms Merkel invited everyone in who claimed to be displaced by wars in the Middle East, she invited them in not just on behalf of Germany, but on behalf of 25 other Schengen members and, to a large extent, on behalf of the EU’s six non—Schengen members too. So no wonder internal border checks are creeping back within Schengen – in the case of France, for wholly understandable security reasons, and for some other countries, to cope with the sheer volume of Merkel migrants. Social and cultural cohesion is a precious and fragile thing. When it exists, it enhances the life of almost everyone in a community, but allow the pace of population change to run too fast or be careless as to the character of people moving from one country to another and you will ignite the indignation of indigenous populations. Italians want to control their own borders; Hungarians wants control their own borders; one of the big reasons for Brexit was the desire of the British to control their own borders again. The European political class is insulated from the downsides of uncontrolled mass migration. Instead of empathising with European populations who feel overrun, far too many European politicians show contempt for their electorates – even branding them as racist just for wanting a degree of social stability. If you were wise you would make the Schengen area the second item thrown into the dustbin of history – hard on the heels of the eurozone – but we know you won’t do that, and so the confrontation between Europe’s citizens and its elites is set to intensify.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question raised by raising the blue card. — Mr colleague, you mentioned here that the Member States want to take responsibility for guarding the border, you appointed Hungary, you appointed Italy. So I'd like to ask you, why hasn't Italy already taken that responsibility?

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card answer. – I think I said – or I certainly meant to say – Italians and Hungarians and the British. It’s the people who want to take back control of the borders. To some degree the governments of some countries do as well, but they are forbidden from doing so by the rules of the European Union, as you must well know. I am simply pointing out that the European elite and its rules are on a collision course with the popular will in many countries which are members of this Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Mr. Chairman, the question arises as to how to increase internal security while protecting our external borders. As is known, in the area of free movement, external borders become common, so we share more than 50,000 kilometers of common borders, which means that a security problem in one country or on its external border can affect everyone. But there is a acquis on which mutual trust is based, from which the area of freedom, security and justice should be developed. It is a pity that as often as possible Member States erect walls at external and internal borders as a measure of deterrence from entering the European Union. Imagine the fact that European countries have built more than 1,200 kilometers of walls and borders, on which they spent around 500 million euros. And all this is against the spirit of Schengen. Therefore, I hope that things will change, that Bulgaria and Romania that you all mentioned here very soon will enter schengen, and I thank you Mr. Avramopoulos who mentioned Croatia as Croatia is on the best track, spent about 117 million euros to establish technical conditions from the envelope. Hopefully, in 2019, we will be ready. We know that Croatia itself joined the European Union in 2013, so I hope that it will enter the Schengen area itself. I just want to say another information that the Schengen Information System in Croatia showed all the justification of application — in seven months 168 million views were recorded from 8,000 identified cars or people who were interesting from the safety point of view. Therefore, I am firmly convinced that the Schengen space is part of the solution, not the problem. If he ceases to exist, and I hope it doesn't, it would happen with the citizens Europe we live in today.

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Mr President, I thank the rapporteur Carlos Coelho and I support everything he has stressed here, including the use of SIS by the United Kingdom and the inclusion of Romania and Bulgaria. In this report we show that the main problems in the functioning of the Schengen system result from political narrowness, selfishness and lack of solidarity between Member States in responding to transnational security challenges, especially terrorism, which call for more Europe and more Europe passes through Schengen. The European Commission too, Mr Avramopoulos, cannot continue to whistle in the air, ignoring Schengen violations which undermine the integrity of the system and jeopardize collective security. From gold visas in which several Member States perversely compete, including my country, Portugal, to Malta, where there are alarming testimonies of organised schemes for the massive sale of Schengen visas to Libyans and Algerians, not to mention the shame that is the illegal dirty deal made by the European Union with Turkey. When will the European Union comply with Schengen and no longer let the trafficking mafias manage migratory flows, as UN Secretary-General António Guterres denounced? When will the Council unblock the revision of the Common European Asylum System and open legal and controlled, secure ways so that asylum seekers and refugees do not have to put their lives at the mercy of the traffickers who are actually fuelled by the lack of European management?

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, allow me to thank and congratulate Mr Coelho for his excellent work. I must say that I have heard many times quote Italy today and therefore allow myself to make a focused reflection on Italy and the Schengen area. And then the reflection is this: hearing the citizens, hearing the artisans, feeling the traders, feeling the base and therefore the Italians, you see Schengen is a great achievement, surely it must be handled well, should be handled at best, but I ask one question: with what do you control? Would Italy be fine or would it go bad? Would Italy get more or get less? According to an analysis, first, it would get more problems and so we already have enough. On immigration: Ventimiglia case. At the time France expanded the controls we kept them all in the house. We have an external border problem, we have to carry out blockades there, not internal borders. Second: Brenner case. Well, Austria decided to increase the controls and we had 70 kilometers of queue, because in this case we damaged the import and export trade of Italians. And then you see, I think that it is the external borders to be controlled, the ones that are difficult to build walls like the sea, and the Commissioner knows that well, given his origin, and also other colleagues in the Mediterranean. And let me, this is asking Italian citizens to stay in Europe, but in a different Europe. Not to exit either the euro or Europe.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, this first annual report by the European Parliament on the functioning of the Schengen area sets a precedent for the years to come, and therefore it is essential to ensure that the rights and freedoms of our citizens are respected. The Schengen area does not work as long as some countries maintain control at internal borders. Thus, six Schengen Member States have been illegalized since November 2017. Moreover, instead of sanctioning them, the European Commission is trying to legalise their practices. All this time, since 2011, Romania has been applying the provisions of the Schengen acquis and acts as a de facto member by managing more than 2 000 kilometres of the European Union's external border, without benefiting from the benefits of free movement. That is why we called for the widening of the Schengen area in this report, thus receiving Romania and Bulgaria. Every day outside this space represents a clear discrimination against Romanian and Bulgarian citizens, but also a defeat and a shame for the European project. Thank you, fellow Members, Commissioner, for supporting this, and I hope that tomorrow a clear majority will vote for this accession, which is too late.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: — Mr President, at a time when France, a few years ago, for good reasons at the time, decided to reintroduce border controls, I remember that the 100,000 French citizens who had a job in Luxembourg, because there were none at home — and who, despite everything, voted Front National because it must be good for border protection — spent three to four hours each morning and every night in their cars to work. Those were healed of this stupid and stupid wish to see the borders restored for the good of all of us. I heard the English-speaking colleague earlier. It seems to me that the British Government is not at all in favour of the reintroduction of a hard border in Ireland, between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, because that would mean disaster, the economic breakdown for Ireland and for the people living on both sides of that border. It is lamentable, Mr President, and I say that in weighing my words, it is lamentable that strictly internal political motives in Austria, Bavaria, France and elsewhere justify maintaining something that should be abolished for decades and abolished for good. I am glad that opposite Schengen — it is a village in Luxembourg for those who do not remember it — there is the German Land of Saarland, because the Saarans are still reasonable enough not to reintroduce borders. If it were Bavaria, we would soon have a regional border protection troupe for the purposes of a campaign by a politician who wants to be re-elected in September. This is not normal. We can no longer continue to make the proper functioning of one of the very great achievements of the European Union of political lubies depend on some who believe that, with security, any bad policy that can be imagined is justified. This is wrong and it must stop.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, it is evident in this debate as in so many previous debates that if anti-Europeans and Europhobes, who are increasingly numerous in this House, hate Schengen is exactly because Schengen is the most precious asset of European citizenship, what European citizens identify more and better with the best in the history of Europe as we have built it. That is exactly why, when Schengen enters into crisis, as a result of what was called the migration crisis, the pressure on the external borders, and Schengen's effectiveness was suspended for almost three years, the European Parliament, through the Committee on Civil Liberties, did the right thing by establishing a working group, informing in order to assess how we can be more effective and guarantors of fair cooperation and solidarity in the management of external borders while maintaining the free movement of persons within the Union. That is why we support this report. That is why we want Schengen to return to normal as soon as possible and the movement of people within the European Union be fully restored. And our objection to this report has to do with the security bias which Schengen intends to impose a marchamo on biometric controls and interoperability, as well as a return policy that has nothing to do with free movement between borders. (He agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Marek JUREK
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. — Do you not think, however, that it is not the political parties that express fear of uncontrolled immigration, but it is the policy of the European Union authorities that encourage illegal immigration, which has led to this the most serious crisis of the Schengen area? Isn't that mastering this phenomenon the best method for her to have confidence and work well? Meanwhile, in our report, there are again the demands of legalising illegal immigration. Is this really the way to guarantee the good functioning of our external borders?

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: answer from 'blue card'. — With all due respect, dear Mr Jurek, you have not raised a question, but your opinion. And the first thing I did when I came to the European Parliament was to read to me the Treaty of Lisbon, which precisely instructs the European Union to build together, in a solidarity and cooperative manner, a policy of free movement of persons, at the same time as an integrated management of the Union's external borders. And it must be made as soon as possible more European, so that we have more and better Europe, including Bulgaria and Romania in the area for the free movement of persons. That is the goal promised by the Treaty of Lisbon and, to the extent that we have contradiction against this asset, which was the most precious in the European Union, the European Union will continue to fail its promise.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report. I think the document is based on a very good basis. I think that next to the fact that he's describing the situation there, he's proposing some ideas for improving the system. It has been sounded many times here, we are not happy with how it works. Every time we go to France, there's a rather embarrassing passport check here in Strasbourg. I think that anyone who goes through it needs to tap their head because that's not a way to prevent an attack or increase the security of citizens. I don't think anyone thinks that this control will prevent any terrorist from reaching Strasbourg. I think that within the Schengen area we lack enforceability of law, and that is what is described in the report. To ensure that all Member States really adhere to what they have, and not to really circumvent it, whether in the form of the mentioned golden visas or in the form of various passports given to third citizens countries. This is what leads to skepticism over the functioning of the Schengen area. Schengen space itself is an excellent idea and believe me, as a student of the Pontifical University I experienced what it means to be out of Schengen, and have experienced those controls at the border and already I would never want to see those controls rolled back into Europe.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Grazzi President, Kummissarju, nibda billi nirringrazzja lir-rapporteur ta' dan ir-rapport u llum qegdin nisimgu to the maat afna varjanzi, b'mod partikolari jiena ngid ertu anki estremiżmu żejed. Qegdin nitkellmu dwar immigrazzjon bla control ta' xejn, meta fir-realtà, illum il-enurnata, aktar minn qatt qabel, qegdin nadmu biex verament ikollna bilan. Jiena nirreferi gähal dak li gamilna matul din is-sena, flimkien Mal-mep Coelho, fejn qegdin fuq ir-riforma tal-kummissjoni Ewropea dwar is-sistema ta' Informazzjon ta' Schengen. Ghengaliex din hija riforma li permezz tagЂha rridu niżguraw kooperazzjon akbar bejn L-itated membri biex, iva, nassiguraw is-sigurtà Tal-unjoni Ewropea kollha kemm hi. U hemmhekk ninsabu fl-aar stadji biex nikkonkludu leiżlazzjon mmirata biex tiżgura l-iskambju ta' informazzjon dwar theddid li jista' jkun hemm. Ima, u din hija xi envelabali rapporiet enfasizzata anki fir-rapport, biex din il-leiżlazzjon tadem, ne- tie- li L-Istat Membri jimplimentaw kif suppost l-acquis ta' Schengen. Ghengaliex, wara kollox, i-ittadini tagna jridu jkunu chicory però jridu wkoll ikunu to the ielsa. GЂ‹вЂ‹andna pjan, gЂandna r-regoli u s-sistemi konkreti li, jekk implimentati sew, iva jistgЂu jadmu u gandna l-gandna l-godod neessarji biex lithe -

name: Emil RADEV
text: — Mr President, in recent years, the Schengen area has faced a number of tests — the migration crisis and the terrorist threat. And we have witnessed the introduction of internal border controls between countries that have had no border between countries for a quarter of a century. This is a dangerous trend because, in reality, the European Union would function very hard without Schengen. We can even say that Schengen and the European Union are indivisible. It is therefore important for all Member States to be part of the common area without borders once they have fulfilled the necessary statutory criteria. Bulgaria and Romania have done this seven years ago. We are actively using the Schengen Information System, and I hope the Council will decide on 100% access to the system for both countries very soon. We are part of the European border and coast guard, we use the Single Calculator of the new entry-exit system, we have access to the visa information system, we implement the Schengen legislation entirely, we protect the most difficult and busiest external border — the one with Turkey, both from criminals , as well as from illegal migrants. Bulgaria is actually part of Schengen. It is time to reflect this also through a political decision to lift internal border controls and to join Schengen. Bulgaria in Schengen means a safer European Union.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the Schengen Working Group established by the LIBE Commission and the rapporteur, Mr Coelho, for working on this report and the comprehensive vision of the functioning of Schengen. The report shows very clearly what the priority actions of the European institutions and Member States should be to strengthen the safety, security and integrity of the free movement of people, goods, services and capital within the Schengen area. We clearly need closer cooperation between countries in reforming and improving the Schengen information system, as well as strengthening cross-border cooperation between police authorities, judiciary, customs and visa authorities. Schengen Member States should implement the recommendations on the vulnerability assessment of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency. I support the recommendation in the report which condemns the continuous reintroduction of internal border controls. Systematic checks must be transformed into punctual checks. Unfortunately, in some non-Schengen countries, as is my country, some non-proportionate border control measures have been introduced over the last 2 years, which make the movement of people unduly difficult. In particular, I welcome the reiteration of support for Bulgaria and Romania's immediate accession to the Schengen area. Romania is fully prepared from the technical point of view and border security, and only reasons related to domestic policy and some easy, populist speeches, in some Member States have opposed Romania and Bulgaria's accession and have made this impossible so far.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Mr President, the Schengen Area is one of the greatest achievements of the European Union. It is a vital part of the European integration project. The Schengen area has come under pressure in recent years and its basic rules and conventions are ceasing to operate. I am referring to the introduction of recontrols at the internal borders of the European Union or the building of border fences within the European Union. For the first time Article 29 of the Schengen Code was activated, new border controls are emerging. That's very dangerous. If the Schengen area dies down, the European Union will disappear as we know it today. The preservation of the Schengen area remains a key tool for the expansion of economic and social benefit, the free movement of people, goods and capital. And not just conservation. Let us strive, ladies and gentlemen, to expand the Schengen area. Romania and Bulgaria, for example, are professionally aiming to enter the Schengen area. They try to protect their borders in order to justify their entry into the space. I recently visited the Bulgarian-Turkish land border, where Bulgarians have built an estimated 300km-long fence. They have made it virtually clear that they can protect the external borders of the European Union. They contributed to efforts to prevent internal borders in the European Union. Thanks for that Bulgaria!

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, the LIBE Committee approved the first report on the functioning of the Schengen area in which it was very clear reiterated that Romania and Bulgaria are ready for an immediate entry into Schengen. As Romania's representative to the European Parliament, he appreciates the fair and fair assessment of the LIBE Committee as well as the rapporteur, and I believe that we are prepared in all respects for this. Thus, if this is also recognised by the European Commission and the European Parliament, it is time for certain Member States to recognise this fact and support Romania's accession to Schengen. At the same time, I would like to point out that the Schengen area was created on the basis of a technical approach, which was not a political agreement. I remind all colleagues once again that Romania fully meets all the criteria for becoming part of this space since 2011. It is unacceptable that until now Romania is not part of the Schengen area and I am firmly convinced that any delay in this respect is not justifiable, representing a genuine discrimination against a considerable number of European citizens. From my point of view, any concerns on this subject are strictly political positions and it is time to admit at European level that Romania's place is in the Schengen area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Avramopoulos, it is obvious that the functioning of Schengen has a number of problems. On the outside field, Frontex is not working properly. Currently, according to current data, 16 627 people are located in the Aegean Islands, 3 274 of them in Samos. There is Frontex on all islands and it is obvious that it cannot ensure that borders are guarded. You will say that the maritime border has problems. I agree. In Evros, which is the land border, we have a huge increase in inputs. There must therefore be very specific measures. Secondly, there is reintroduction at internal borders. What about the checks here at Strasbourg airport? There's been three years. Passport control for all MEPs. Will this situation continue? It is also an unacceptable situation: German and Belgian quarantine against Greek passengers arriving at Germany's airports and Brussels. Will this situation continue? It's unacceptable.
