name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, Mr Avramopoulos, you have heard everything and I do not even need to repeat how positive the free movement of people is. You know better than me how many difficulties there are in its implementation, so that it works the way we want. I only have one question and, please, see how you can answer it for me. When Member States, under the pretext of temporarily introducing measures, essentially violate the Treaty, and the European Union cannot say anything to them, then the rules go to the ground. What do you intend or what can we do, or what can you do, so that if the violation of signed rules is repeated in the future, you can deal with it in an effective way? Otherwise, we prove that we are just saying words.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: — Mr President, the Schengen area has essentially been broken down and only a formal finding is pending, while the gates of entry and protector countries such as Greece are overwhelmed by the massive influx of illegal immigrants despite the scandalous satisfaction of the absurd Turkey by the Union. But basic concepts are confused. Freedom of movement concerns the right conferred on citizens. Border control falls within the competence of the States, constituting an obligation for the state to achieve and maintain security and security within its territory. Carrying out thorough and systematic checks, therefore, does not impair the freedom of passage. On the contrary, rules are needed to ensure that persons in transit have the corresponding right. It therefore requires a border line resistant to any external imposition or intrusion, a reform of the databases and an adjustment to their use, a strong institutional framework and a rapid return of those who have entered illegally.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, thank you for understanding and granting the word. I do not agree with the criticism of the temporary restoration of control at internal borders by some Member States. That criticism gets sounded quite often here. At the time of the outbreak of the refugee crisis, it became clear that the European Union was not yet able to secure its external borders, and so, of course, such measures were legitimate and, I think, on the ground. Conditions have changed and the European Union has set up a European coast and border guard and taken a number of other measures to secure the external border. It is therefore time for a version of the Schengen Border Code to be adopted, which sets out more objective conditions for the restoration of internal borders and to avoid excessive use of this measure. At the same time, however, we must not relieve our efforts to protect our external borders even further.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: — Mr. Chairman, I thank the rapporteur for the good report and acceptance of all the amendments I have submitted; especially the one where the European Parliament confirms support for Croatia's admission to schengen as soon as it meets the necessary criteria. However, we must not ignore the external and internal challenges of Schengen as a single system of free movement of people and goods between as many as 26 countries. The lack of political will and a better legal framework to jointly address security threats and migrant crises have led to the reintroduction of border controls among some members of the Schengen area. I come from a member country that has almost met the criteria to enter the schengen, successfully controls the external border, but is still fenced off by barbed wire from the rest of the European Union. Schengen, as a great achievement of European integration must not be a collateral victim of the deficit of our security policies. Solutions are not raising fences and closing borders among members, as well as political blockades. We can only upgrade Schengen through joint action and appreciation of the members who, by fulfilling all the criteria, deserve to be part of it.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, there have indeed been serious abnormalities in the functioning of the Schengen system in recent years and unfortunately we must see that we are only taking very slow steps towards a solution. This is also a serious problem because the existence of a zone without internal border control is one of the most serious European achievements, and citizens have clearly seen it as one of the most tangible positive aspects of the European Union. However, we must acknowledge that until there is adequate protection at the external borders of the zone, unfortunately, the concern of the Member States and the maintenance of internal border controls can not only be imagined on a temporary basis. I come from a Member State which the other Member States did not consider fit to become a member of the Schengen area, while several Schengen States are unable to maintain the protection of their own borders, which is also the Schengen border. Romanian and Bulgarian citizens, who are EU citizens, see that even today they cannot be part of the Schengen area, while hundreds of thousands of immigrants arrive in these two countries uncontrollably and illegally.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I want to thank you for reminding once again that Romania and Bulgaria must be in Schengen. I want to thank my colleague Coelho, who also made an excellent report to all colleagues who stressed the importance of the Schengen area and the need for Romania and Bulgaria to be there. Commissioner, after the Single Market, the Schengen area is the most important. How can we have competitiveness? There are additional costs. How can we have borders within the European Union? What is the purpose of the European Union? Please, Commissioner, try to insist on the Council that Romania and Bulgaria enter Schengen, and as the rapporteur said and as it is contained in the report, that all Member States respect the Schengen area and, without borders, we will be able together, with solidarity and communication, to we better defend the border of the European Union, a single border.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Mr Chairman, the Schengen area is rightly regarded as one of the greatest achievements of the European Union since it enables freedom of movement within its single territory. The Republic of Croatia, as the youngest member of the European family, aspires to become part of this single space without internal border controls. I thank fellow rapporteur Coelh for his expressed support for Croatia's accession to the Schengen area. As a Croatian MEP, I believe that the technical conditions that must be met will be met by the end of this year and that Croatia, which is soon celebrating its fifth anniversary of its accession to the Union, will also join the Schengen area for the mandate of this Commission. This is not only important for the Republic of Croatia, it is important for the security of the whole region and the European Union as a whole. Since the Croatian border is in most of the Union's external borders, the entry into Schengen will strengthen the external border surveillance, which is especially important in these times when, on the one hand, we face security threats, and on the other hand, migration.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this interesting debate. I can assure you that I have taken note of all your remarks. The first thing I would like to say is that almost all of us are on the same side. We share the will to return to a fully-fledged Schengen area, but also a unified one, including all the Member States from the moment they are, or will be, technically ready. We should continue turning the crisis of the last three years into opportunities for stronger and more effective cooperation. We should keep on learning from our experiences, fully follow up on our joint evaluations and use the tools at our disposal to the maximum. As I said, I took good note of all your interventions that are feeding the current reflection about the future of our border management, and I am sure that we will soon have more opportunities to follow up on this debate. We have to continue working together on all parts of our comprehensive approach on migration, security and border management, in a spirit of solidarity, joint responsibility and trust. Yes, Schengen is the greatest achievement of all times, and we have to uphold and defend it. And this is what we share in this room today. Together we have to strengthen and preserve this great achievement as the core symbol of our unity. Europe can only exist if it is united: united politically, economically, socially and geographically. And Schengen is the guarantee and also the symbol of a geographically united Europe, ensuring the unity of our nations and of all European citizens. Let me now reply in Greek to the question raised by Mr Hadjigeorgiou. Όσον αφορά στους εσωτερικούς ελέγχους που αυτή τη στιγμή έξι κράτη μέλη συνεχίζουν, τόνισα και το επαναλαμβάνω ότι πρέπει σύντομα να λήξουν και να προτιμηθούν – και είμαστε σε θέση να προτείνουμε – εναλλακτικές λύσεις και μέτρα αστυνομικής συνεργασίας που θα εξασφαλίζουν ένα υψηλό επίπεδο ασφάλειας. Αυτό το έχω επαναλάβει τον τελευταίο καιρό σε όλες τις συναντήσεις που είχα με τους Υπουργούς Εσωτερικών των έξι αυτών χωρών. Θα πρέπει να σας πω ότι σε γενικές γραμμές όλοι συμφωνούν μαζί μας ότι πρέπει να επανέλθουμε σε μία ομαλή λειτουργία της ζώνης του Σένγκεν. Η Επιτροπή είναι πάντα πρόθυμη και έτοιμη να συνεισφέρει με τις προτάσεις της σε αυτήν την κατεύθυνση.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: rapporteur. — (PT) Mr President, I would like to say, firstly, to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have helped build this report and all those who have worked in the Schengen Working Group throughout this time; secondly, to remind you that what we have to protect is freedom of movement and that the internal borders, and that internal border controls, are a return to the past. To destroy Schengen is to demolish the people's Europe. We therefore all have an obligation to save Schengen and I believe that tomorrow it will become clear that there is a clear majority in this House to defend this heritage. Mr Avramopoulos, we all have a responsibility, but so does the Commission. It must exercise its powers and do not doubt the support of this Parliament for this purpose, because it is difficult to make the Council understand what this is about. Today the Council's absence from this debate has been sensitive. We have not been able to hear your views and have not been able to pass on our messages to you, but as I rightly said, the Council is essential because there are responsibilities of the Member States not only with regard to borders, but for the confusion in which we are all involved. Commissioner, all of us, the Commission, Parliament and the Council, have the same obligation: the obligation to return Schengen to European citizens.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 30 May 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — With this report, the European Parliament reiterated its support for Bulgaria and Romania's immediate accession to the Schengen area, because they fulfilled their conditions and no longer be considered second-rate countries. The European Commission also calls on the Council to take a decision on Bulgaria and Romania, with the Schengen area becoming safer with the inclusion of these two countries. The European Parliament must support the democratic control of the Schengen area. Some Member States have put in place temporary internal border controls, which must not become permanent. National governments often tend to transfer some responsibilities to the Schengen agreement, thus blaming it for what is happening at the borders. Therefore, a balance must be found between internal security and the movement of citizens. It is necessary to amend the Schengen Code, as proposed by the Commission, by readapting internal border controls to a current level in order to respond to security requests and support the area.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Coelho, for his diligent work on the report and his dedication throughout the years of defending the principles and merits of Schengen as one of EU’s brightest achievements. I consider Schengen indeed to be a space of not only security and open borders, but also a space of solidarity and recognition of the trust between our economies and societies. In that relation I highly value the acknowledgements of the rapporteur for the role of countries like Bulgaria and Romania, who are at the forefront in protecting our common borders and ensuring high-levels of control by allocating the necessary financial, technical and human resources to those tasks. I would like to reiterate the rapporteur’s conviction that Bulgaria and Romania should be granted immediate accession to the Schengen area as fully-fledged members, as this has already been announced in the European Parliaments resolution from June 2011. Those conclusions in the report are based on proven facts that both countries comply and fulfil all criteria for conclusion of their Schengen accession. This will reinforce citizen’s trust in the credibility of European institutions and will foster further cohesion including the full benefits related to the freedom of movement.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: in writing. – I would like to stress out that Turkey violates the EU's external borders and the question of the Schengen zone and the security of the external borders, which is the core subject of the Annual Report on the functioning of the Schengen area, is not just about the implementation of Schengen under normal circumstances, and even in countries with no land borders such as Cyprus and Malta, but also about the unacceptable situation in a Member State which is under occupation, such as the Republic of Cyprus. Cyprus does not belong to the Schengen zone because, due to the occupation, it cannot exercise effective control over its occupied part. This issue is not only our problem but also the EU's one, whose borders are being violated by Turkey, while security issues are being raised for which Ankara has sole responsibility.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: in writing. — Last week, another step was taken to allow Romania to be accepted as a member of the Schengen area. In the LIBE Committee I voted for a report to implement the remaining unapplied provisions of the Schengen acquis relating to the Schengen Information System (SIS) in Romania and Bulgaria. As an MEP, I note that things are moving extremely slowly, and the fact that a member country of the European Union is deprived of access to the Schengen Area in 2018, although all official documents enshrink that we have fulfilled the conditions imposed since 2011, denotes not only underneath and internal political calculations of opposing countries, but also distancing themselves from the principles of equality between members of the European Union. On 9 June 2011, the Council concluded that Romania fulfilled all conditions in the areas of the Schengen acquis relating to air, sea, land borders, police cooperation, data protection, Schengen Information System and visas. Romania deserves and needs to be received NOW in the Schengen area! Don't delay any more, dear fellow Europeans. The Council, by postponing Romania's accession to the Schengen area, only fuels anti-European feelings such as those that have already begun to escalate in some Member States.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Angelika Mlinar on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the implementation of Directive 2012/29/EU establishing minimum standards for the rights, support and protection of victims of crime (2016/2328 (INI)) (A8-0168/2018).

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I take advantage of this debate on victims to extend my deepest sympathy to the families of those killed today in Liège. I want to tell you that we are not just giving the words here, I want to give you facts too, because this directive defends all the victims and also the victims of terrorism. I would also like to thank the co-rapporteur, Mrs Mlinar, for her work, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs and the Secretariat who have worked with us. Since I came to this Parliament, I found the lack of laws on victims and encouraged the Commission to present a directive on support, law and protection of victims of crime. Today, seven years later, I am here again to discuss how we can improve that directive, because what we have now is not enough. The 2011 Directive paved the way for harmonisation of victims' rights, but not all Member States have done their duties well: some countries have not implemented it well. That is why we are making recommendations in this new report to States to comply with what we said in 2012. In addition, we introduced new guidelines to improve the lives of victims. Some relevant issues are the role of victims during criminal proceedings, particularly witnesses, because they often suffer secondary victimization. We have also stressed the importance of the Istanbul Convention in the fight against gender-based violence. For example, it is important to harmonize the crime of harassment because there are still many countries that do not have harassment. We also wanted to point out that, regardless of the State where the crime is committed, the victim is guaranteed his rights. Another important part of this report is the protection of children. In most cases, children are victims of gender-based violence and are the most vulnerable. One of the main failures we have seen in the implementation of this directive is that neither professionals, nor judges nor policemen have received sufficient training and training to explain to victims that they had these rights. We have also included in the report the importance of awareness-raising campaigns to inform victims and society on how to enjoy these rights. Perhaps the most significant achievement of the Directive, for which I was rapporteur in 2012, was what was called the 'individual assessment' and, unfortunately, not all Member States have been able to carry it out: an individual assessment is essential to know the specific needs of a victim. The lack of implementation of article 22 has created many problems, for example, for victims of terrorism. That is why I worked to ensure that they were represented, because they were not represented in the 2012 Directive — there was only a small reference. The latest attacks by Europe — Paris, Brussels, Nice, Berlin, Barcelona, Liège — have caused many casualties. Those victims have not received the rights and aid mentioned in the 2012 Directive. At various hearings we have organised in this Parliament, they complained about how they were dealt with, and in this report we pointed out the needs that these victims of terrorism have told us during these months. We should guarantee them not only their economic rights, but also their right to memory, justice and dignity. This report also urges States to establish legal mechanisms to criminalize the glorification of an act of terrorism if this humiliates victims, because it may cause a second victimization. And finally, I end up, Mr President, by calling for a regulation or directive for the victims of terrorism.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking my co-rapporteur, Ms Jiménez-Becerril Barrio, and all the shadow rapporteurs for an excellent cooperation on this report. By assessing the implementation of the Victims’ Directive, we focused on the many areas that still needs to be improved in order to fully protect and support victims of crime. By strengthening these areas, we want to make sure that any victim, no matter where in the European Union, receives the same level of rights, support and access to justice. We should leave no one behind. We welcome that some Member States have successfully implemented certain actions, but much more needs to be done. We must give visibility to the victims. The justice systems in the Member States must give priority to those who suffered, give them a voice and provide them with the support in order for them to rebuild their lives, such as access to shelters and to justice. We must build trust and help victims to report the crime. Too many crimes go unreported, and this is very much linked to fear, embarrassment and social stigma. This is, of course, especially in cases of crimes related to domestic and gender-based violence, trafficking and forced labour. This report is one step forward in our commitment to fight gender-based violence. Therefore, I call on the Member States to set up specific support programmes targeting, in particular, some of the most vulnerable victims of gender-based violence, such as refugees and migrants, people with disabilities, Roma, persons belonging to national ethnic or religious minorities, LGBTQI, elderly women and homeless women. We all know that we have to do much more to respond to the cries for justice of women who have suffered violence. We have to do much more to end these horrible abuses and the impunity that allows these human rights violations to continue. The effects of violence can remain with women and girls for a lifetime and can pass from one generation to the next. This violence against women has tremendous costs to communities, nations and societies for public wellbeing, health and safety, law enforcement and public programmes and budgets. For an effective response to these crimes, a holistic approach is necessary. All of society has to join forces and work together. Police officers, lawyers, medical practitioners and social workers must be trained to address the needs of victims in an adequate manner. We must remember that these professionals are often the first point of contact for vulnerable victims. Finally, this speech could not be held without stressing the importance of the Istanbul Convention, as already mentioned by my co-rapporteur. A crucial tool to prevent and to combat violence against women: a wave of opposition to the so-called gender ideology has emerged, and I urge the remaining ten Member States who have not yet ratified the Convention to do so. This is your chance to stand on the right side of history.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my condolences to the families of the victims of today’s attack in the city of Liège in Belgium, as well as to the injured officers. We stand by them, the city, and the Belgian police that lost two policewomen on duty. The Commission welcomes this discussion on the correct implementation of the Victims’ Rights Directive. I would therefore like to thank you for putting this point on the agenda of the plenary today. The Victims’ Rights Directive is the core EU instrument for our policy on victims’ rights across the board, ranging from women who are victims of violence, to victims of terrorism, to victims of hate crime, and children suffering sexual abuse. We all have a duty to do more to protect their rights. Where specific EU rules are in place in these policy areas, the Victims’ Rights Directive applies in tandem and complements them. Where no specific EU rules apply, it is this directive that fills the gap. It is this directive that ensures that all victims of crime in Europe, regardless of nationality and their family members, must receive proper support, protection and access to justice. First and foremost, they must be treated with dignity and respect. This directive is also about how we strengthen victims’ procedural rights in criminal proceedings and about how we ensure that EU countries provide training on victims’ needs to officials that come into contact with them. It is therefore crucial that Member States transpose and apply this instrument fully and correctly. As you know, we have already initiated infringement proceedings against those Member States which have not notified the transposition of this important instrument, and next year we will publish a report assessing whether the Member States have taken the necessary measures in order to comply with the Victims’ Rights Directive. We are continuing to raise awareness of the Victims’ Rights Directive through a constructive dialogue with our Member States. Cooperation among our Member States is facilitated by our funding for the European Network of Victims’ Rights. This is an area in which we will, of course, continue to work with Parliament, and I look forward to listening to your views.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (ES) Mr President, as the rest of the honourable Members and the Commissioner have done, in condolences to the families of the victims of the terrorist act that took place today in Liège. Of course, this Parliament always has to be on the side of the victims and families who are currently suffering a really difficult situation to sustain. I therefore join those condolences, and also in a debate like the one we have now on the implementation of the 2012 Victim Protection Directive. I think it is important, first of all, to put on the table the importance of the directive itself and the impetus given to the fact that in Europe we need to be aware that citizens need to establish such a legal framework for victim protection throughout the European Union. And I would also like to point out that, at the time this Parliament discussed the content of this directive, it did very important work to mainstream a gender perspective and to incorporate victims of gender-based violence within victims. This is a fundamental issue, because we are arguably talking about the greatest scourge that exists at the moment in Europe and in the world. And therefore, the gender perspective could not be forgotten. We also need to take into account now how this directive is being implemented and implemented through judicial transposition in each of the States. And indeed, six years later, it is worrying to see how not all countries, not all Member States have legally transposed this directive. And therefore, we cannot say that today in Europe protection for victims is being guaranteed in each and every territory of the European Union. It is an issue on which you have to act on. There has also been talk here about the importance — and the report refers to it — of the Istanbul Convention, where this reference is also made to victims of gender-based violence; to victims and their sons and daughters, whom we cannot forget. And therefore, I think it is essential to bear in mind that this report refers to how the current situation can be improved and this report refers to the need to support judicial systems with more means so that they can advance work on raising awareness of victims of gender-based violence. We are talking about this report on the directive, but this same week, Mrs Guteland's report on the indicators of justice, also refers to this: the need for justice to have sufficient resources to advance this gender perspective, which is essential in the training of judges and which is fundamental to ensure that women victims of violence feel protected. We must therefore continue to work, we must continue to insist and this Parliament will continue to defend the victims of gender-based violence and to defend the need to end the greatest social scourge that Europe is currently having. (She agreed to answer a question under the blue card procedure (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: blue-card question. — To tell the truth, I wanted to put the question to the rapporteurs, but I think that every MEP and Mrs Pérez can answer. Recently in Cyprus a Turkish Cypriot, 84 years old today, proudly said on television that he killed dozens of Greek Cypriots unarmed and civilians and even said that he was “burning” for the fact that some had escaped him! I have a specific question: are we entitled and obliged to bring to justice people who have so brutally violated the human right to life, even though 44 years have passed? I also maintain that this also applies to Greek Cypriot criminals. The question remains to the rapporteurs, therefore, whether after so many years we are entitled and obliged to bring them before the court.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: answer from 'blue card'. — Mr Hadjigeorgiou, it seems to me that the question was not addressed both to me and the rapporteurs. But in any case, I would reply to you that this Parliament has to be sensitive to all the victims. In each of the circumstances, which will be difficult, we will have to look at situations, but in any case I invite you to read this report and to join forces to work for the protection of victims' rights.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to express my condolences to the victims of the attack in Liège today, as well as to their families. This resolution contains many interesting ideas which are useful to my report in the Special Committee on Terrorism. Victims of terrorism or their family members signed for life must go through a complicated, painful and slow process to claim their rights. All too often, they end up in an administrative mallemill of insurance papers, where they have to tell their traumatic story over and over again, faced with all sorts of high costs. So, twice victim. However, I cannot agree with the provisions on pro bono assistance. The resolution seems to want to extend the system and places the emphasis on financial assistance and legal assistance to illegal immigrants. For information, the total cost of the pro bono system in Belgium amounted to EUR 73 million in 2016. Up to a third of all pro-bono procedures involved Aliens cases, or 21 million, to assist people who are illegally residing in the country. At national level, my government dealt with the abuse of asylum applications. Successive asylum applications were made more difficult and a new point system was introduced for pro-bono lawyers. This new pro-reward system aligns compensation better with actual performance and must combat recklessly litigation. To get rid of lucrative asylum and migration business, including through the pro-bono system, should also be a top European priority. I cannot get rid of the impression that this report calls for the contrary.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I too would like to express my full support, solidarity and saddened condolences to the families of the victims of this new attack today in Liège, which of course affects all Belgians, but which affects us all as Europeans. While there are still many battles to be fought, the fight on victims' rights must really be at the centre of the criminal justice and cooperation system in Europe. I would like to congratulate and thank Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Angelika Mlinar for the tremendous work they have done and devote my time to the most vulnerable victims of children. In the “Rights of the Child” intergroup, we fight to protect children as much as possible in all European texts, because — reports show this every day — violence against children is pervasive in our democratic society, often on the Internet, very often at school and extremely often also in their places. family and their place of life. That is why we must fight, in all Member States, to ensure that children have access to specific measures, to specific follow-up, to a genuine system of aid and, as colleagues have said, to an individual assessment and to understandable information, in short, a genuine system of support for the children: social and psychological assistance, trained persons and actors, for example for children who witness domestic violence. It is also important to pay particular attention, as Mr Caterina Chinnici proposed and adopted in the report on procedural safeguards in the directive, to the risk of double victimization. Children are our future. Let us protect them in the light of our European values.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (ES) Mr President, I would first like to express my condolences and condolences to the families of the victims in Liège. In the European Union, one in three women suffer violence at some point in their lives. Thousands of women have taken to the streets in European cities, calling for more action against sexist violence. And this also has to be made a reality, also for all people who are victims of crime outside the country of origin, whether they are workers, students, tourists, legal migrants and, too, undocumented. We therefore call for an expansion of victim support services and greater training for professionals, with special attention to victims of gender-based violence, women and girls and also LGBTI persons. We need more shelters available 24 hours a day, with judicial advice for women victims of sexist violence and their children. It is our obligation to ensure that every woman within the European Union can feel safe in denouncing sexist violence and to end what, for us and us, is a real social scourge.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, This report has a broad appropriation, but I would like to dedicate my intervention to making visible all those firesouls, heroines, tigrines even, who work to make our world and our existence free of gender-based violence. I think of all of you who work tirelessly at women's hotlines and on call phones and of you making sure women and children have somewhere to go when needed. You don't just take care of women who are exposed — you build expertise and knowledge for prevention. Without you, we wouldn't have gotten anywhere in combating violence against women and girls. In this text, we have got through demands to support your work. We say that the EU and the Member States need to extend the number, and accessibility to, women's hotlines around the EU. We say that the EU and the Member States need to fund your business. These are important recommendations from Parliament. I would also like to lift the Istanbul Convention as a tool for combating violence against women. What a shame it is that not all Member States have ratified it and that they are also blocking in the Council so that the EU cannot join. I wonder what the Commission will do about this? Other key recommendations included in our joint report, for example, are support for victims of crime who are undocumented, to migrants and asylum seekers, support for LGBTQ people who are also subject to hate crimes and for gender-based violence, support for minorities. Overall: there's a lot left to do. It's got to be workshop now!

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, I would also like to extend my full support to the families of the victims of this new attack in Liège today. When you read the title of your report, European citizens could legitimately, if not perhaps naively, expect recommendations full of common sense from you, but by continuing to read them, they would quickly dischant. Once again and as always, you are asking for the ratification by the Member States of the Istanbul Convention, which is openly promoter of gender ideology, and you ask that all personnel dealing with victims be trained in this ideology. You propose to criminalize the glorification of terrorist acts but, to read you, only if there is humiliation of the victims. Finally, you refer to the horrific situation in which migrants live in Europe, who are more likely to be victims of crime or crime than the rest of the population. I leave the citizens to judge your comments. Finally, with this text, you serve those you claim to defend, namely the victims. Criminals do not differentiate between sexual orientation, skin colour, immigrant or refugee status. First of all, they attack innocent people, and we must think of them, they are the ones we must defend.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank our rapporteur. Yet again she, as always, is a strong voice for all victims across the European Union. The report makes it clear that the different definitions of a victim are a barrier to support. In Northern Ireland, the perverse definition of a victim of terrorism places the bomber and the gunman on a par with those whose lives they’ve claimed or changed unalterably. Our work in this Chamber should benefit the victim, and not the victim—maker.  The border dimension is also important, and today I am calling on the Irish Government to properly address the case of Ian Sproule, a young man gunned down 26 years ago, where there is suspicion that rogue garda officers leaked information on him to IRA members. We hear much in this Chamber about the Irish border, yet nothing about the victims of terrorism in border communities in Northern Ireland. Every Democrat in this Chamber should be outraged.

name: Lara COMI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the closeness and condolences which have already been expressed by my colleagues to the victims of Liège. And the best response to terrorism is precisely the work that has been done by colleagues Teresa and Angelica and the approval of this which will happen, precisely because the need to recognize the legitimate interest of the victims and making their voices and interests heard is very important, precisely because we have the injustice that people are already victims of a crime and, secondly, victims of a system because of inadequate and non-existent protection. This is itself a form of secondary victimization. You see, the reparation of damage caused to victims of crime must be immediate, integral and effective, respecting personal dignity and psychological integrity, which does not only consider harm to health, but also the pain and suffering suffered. Sufferings and discomfort of the victims, which in some ways some states still struggle to recognize in their criminal codes, we also discussed this just a few days ago, as regards the issue of stalking, an offence which is not recognised in all Member States within the Union. And just within the theme of stalking, the problem of cyber-security and those that are cyber-crime is more and more emphasized. So we are always ready for innovation, but we also want 360-degree protection of our rights and duties.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President! Europe is not only a single market, it is also a common area of security and justice. In addition to the prevention of crime and the prosecution of perpetrators, the main focus should be on the protection of victims. Both the European Commission on Human Rights and the Charter of Fundamental Rights provide for special vulnerability. More than five years ago, we were very proud to have been able to adopt a victim protection directive here in this House that sets European minimum standards. No one at the time believed that some Member States simply did not take this important measure seriously. This is scandalous, and it is incomprehensible at all if political leaders have no choice for the problems and plight of innocent people. The Commission's efforts to remove this eyesore are welcome and therefore deserve our full support.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Enhancing EU integration and, consequently, increasing freedom of movement have created the need to take care of the rights of victims of crime and provide them with their due support at European Union level. The directive we are discussing today laid down important legislation such as the right to be heard, the right to complain and access to support services. It is primarily intended to counter mistreatment and disregard for victims. The scope of the directive also covers victims of trafficking, which is third after arms and drug trafficking, the most lucrative form of crime. His victims are used for prostitution, forced labor and begging. Poland implemented this directive and has done very much to protect victims of violence. However, I cannot entirely agree with the contents of the report. Traditionally, the European Parliament has been adding many controversial elements, that is sexual, reproductive rights or powers for sexual minorities, which causes the report to go beyond its scope.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Mr President, I believe that the provision of timely and clear information and sensitive treatment is necessary to better protect victims. The fact that several Member States still have not implemented the Directive complains its evaluation, but the report nevertheless highlights the main pitfalls in the implementation of the Directive. I am pleased to say that the Czech Republic is now among the States fully transposing the directive, since the adoption of the amendment, which took effect in 2017. But there is still, of course, something to work on and, above all, to improve individual access to victims. I can identify with some of the report's recommendations. Therefore, in order to ensure that the protection of victims is as effective and as far as possible uniform within the European Union, Member States should coordinate the definition of the term 'victim' and other central terms. I support the need for helplines, but I take the view that more efficient is the existence of one universal line, within which connectivity between experts can occur. It's better than setting up new specialised lines that will see information fragmented. So I appreciate some of the new proposals on victims of terrorism, such as setting up special websites. But I don't think there's a need to adopt a new specific directive. It is possible to ensure this amendment by adding provisions to the existing Directive.

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Mr President! I strongly regret the fact that victims are finding it difficult to access support and that in some Member States there is a lack of support for victims. This should be a right for all citizens of the European Union and that is why this legislation is so important and good. The most vulnerable victims of crime — children, people without education, people with disabilities, the elderly and victims of trafficking — often find it difficult to understand the information provided by authorities. That is why I am delighted to see writings that an expert should be on site to assist victims. It is extra important that there is access to protected accommodation and women's hotlines. Women who have survived violence should never be denied space in a protected accommodation. Member countries must also strengthen the rights of victims of hate crimes. Offences against LGBTQ people and crimes with racist motive must also be given a greater focus by member countries. Most important, however, is to recall the very vulnerable situation that children who are victims of crime are in, especially children who fall victim to trafficking, sexual exposure as well as gender violence. No child should have to be subjected to violence, nothing, but those who do should always be given priority.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, I think it is necessary to say at the beginning that the rights of victims of crime have been significantly transformed, improved and intensified is also a credit to the European Union. The aim of this report is to implement secondary legislation and, as we know, the state of this legislation is not ideal in the European Union. Still victims are seen only as a fount of evidence and are treated in a similar way. Few take into account that a victim of a crime has often lived through a very traumatic situation, and it is not always enshrined in our legal systems in which way we have on these sensitive persons approach. Ladies and gentlemen, here it is very important to know that there are a number of victims of crime who do not have the capacity to be interviewed in a normal way. It is therefore necessary for us to devote ourselves to these persons and to improve the access of these persons to, as mentioned by my pre-speaker, to have their rights adequately explained and also to know how in a way they may exercise these rights. From my point of view, the very concept of “victim” is the most problematic. I think we still have something to catch up there as the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, this debate is enlightening about the situation of protection of crime victims in the European Union, because this Parliament adopted legislation in 2012 to strengthen that protection and, six years later, breaches are as clamorous as it is painful. The European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights highlights the growth of victims of sexual crimes, violence against women, discrimination and hatred, illicit trafficking in persons, as well as terrorist crimes. And that is why today we must condemn that terrorist act in Liège and express full solidarity with its victims. At the same time, however, the Commission must be required to make this report a tool to correct the shortcomings of coordination, information, adequate funding, awareness-raising, coordination of measures between Member States in order to avoid gaps and differences between Member States penal laws members continue to give rise to this growth of victims, of crimes. That is the task of the Commission and that is the lesson drawn from this report, which must be welcomed so favorably.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I express my solidarity with the family members of the victims of today's attack in Liège, but I express my regret to see that several states in the European Union Members have not yet transposed, or in any case, fully implemented, to the Victims Directive. Although it sets minimum standards, the directive stresses the importance of a social response to the suffering of victims, and calls Member States to do much more to support victims of crime, operating an individual assessment of their needs according to the type and circumstances of the crime suffered, adequately training the personnel called to assist them in the different stages, both procedural and otherwise, and assuring all rights in court. Awareness campaigns are also needed to promote a real cultural change in public opinion, in order to avoid situations of secondary victimization, mistrust, reproach, against victims of specific crimes, such as gender-related or sexual offences, which create particular suffering in victims, especially if young or very young.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too subscribe to everyone who has spoken before me, giving my condolences to the families of the victims of Liège. Failure to transpose a directive into national law is not only a blatant violation of Community law, but also implies that nationals of the Member States defaulting will be discriminated against when it comes to defending their rights as European citizens. Victims of crime must be able to enjoy the same rights, support and protection throughout the European Union, regardless of their residency status. It is unacceptable that victims without regular documents cannot report insecurity and situations of violence without risking penalties related to their migrant status. We are talking about women, men, often minors, victims of forced labour, trafficking, gender-based violence, who cannot enjoy the rights, support and protection offered by this directive. Member States' failure to comply with cannot and should not create hateful forms of discrimination. Victims of crime, all victims of crime, must be at the heart of the criminal justice system.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too subscribe to the closeness and condolence to Belgium and of course to the families of those affected by yet another vile attack. I believe that it is our job — colleagues have already said, but I want to reiterate it here — to prevent victims of crime from feeling even more lonely, and I think the work we are doing tonight, colleagues, somehow goes in this direction, because being a victim of crime is a difficult experience to overcome, an often traumatic experience, which naturally accompanies the victim for many years. And then I believe that the directive we are discussing is a valid instrument, as has already been said, to do this, to accompany these people, to prevent them feeling even more lonely, but it has It needs to be applied in a better way, it needs above all, as was said a moment ago, to be transposed by all those states that still dramatically — I want to say — have not done so. And I believe — let me say, President — that in particular on the issue of protecting women who are victims of gender-based violence, we must continue our battle for ratification, both at the level of Member States that at European level, of the Istanbul Convention, because unfortunately it remains a battle still to be done, which is indispensable for all women who are victims of violence.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, at the start I also want to join my colleagues who offer their condolences to the victims of today's terrorist attack. Now allow the text of the directive itself. I remember a time when I negotiated the text of this legislation for the Czech Republic more than nine years ago. There was great support back then for the minimum legal standard for victims of crime in Europe to be corrected. It is shocking and incomprehensible to me that after more than eight years there are Member States that have not yet transferred these rules to their national legislation. Unfortunately, this shows the problem of European law, where we can find it hard to explain to our citizens why the European Union does not always regulate and operate effectively when Member States are unwilling to fulfil their liabilities. So I beg you, Commissioner, put maximum pressure on the Member States to fulfil the commitments they made eight years ago and to help the fact that victims of crime will have throughout Europe the same legal standards.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, first of all, my warmest congratulations to the two rapporteurs, Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio and Angelika Mlinar. This is a report that I consider to be a battle for the rights of victims of crime, and especially the most vulnerable, who have already been mentioned: underage children, untrained, disabled people, elderly people, victims of trafficking in human beings, migrant workers, and so on. But I will concentrate on one point. Addressing the victims by judicial proceedings can, in itself, be a victimisation of the victims themselves for the second time. Therefore, the administration of justice, unfortunately, is decisively influenced by whether the victim has the determination to uphold his right to punish the guilty party until the end. Unfortunately, however, in the case of Cyprus, I will only say one word: the missing persons since 1974, with the signs of their cold-blooded execution, are handed over to the relatives without recording the cause of death.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, this report highlights progress made by Member States in the field of victims’ rights. The Victims’ Rights Directive is an important tool in order to provide for better assistance for victims, and particularly for women’s access to justice. Many women’s groups in my country, such as Women for Europe, are currently campaigning to keep Britain in the EU. They know that women’s rights are threatened by Brexit, and I stand in solidarity with them.  I am happy to see that the report also recommends the reinforcement of the rights of victims of hate crimes, including racist crimes and crimes against LGBTIQ+ people. This is crucial, especially since the UK’s EU referendum, which triggered a huge rise in hate crimes. The Victims’ Rights Directive is a crucial piece of EU law which establishes minimum standards on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime and ensures that people who have fallen victim to crime are recognised and treated with respect. We need this kind of safeguard after Brexit.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the directive on victims' rights is an important institutional achievement, because there is protection of the rights of the victims themselves, there are special rules and, of course, specific procedural rights, such as access to justice. At the same time, however, I believe that there is also a need for severe punishment for the guilty, because that is also a fundamental right for the victims. In this context, therefore, as described in the directive and in the suggestions made, concrete measures must be taken to protect victims of trafficking in human beings. There must be protection for minors and harsh penalties must be imposed on the various slavers. At the same time, to protect victims of gender violence, especially victims of domestic violence, and in this context the Istanbul Convention can provide concrete answers. Exemplary punishment of the guilty parties is therefore the key element that must emerge in the implementation of the directive.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, I should like to begin by expressing my solidarity with the victims of the Liège attack and my support for the Belgian authorities. I would also like to thank Angelika Mlinar and Teresa Jimenez—Becerril for the working climate created around this report, which will make it possible to improve assistance to victims of crime throughout Europe. The amendments tabled and accepted have made it possible to define procedures, mechanisms and remedies to solve two of the fundamental problems faced by victims, especially in the face of indiscriminate and massive attacks such as those often involved in terrorism: the lack of accurate and practical information to find help and the need to access it through a single instance, avoiding a long and complex pilgrimage through different services and levels of the Administration. After years of dialogue and direct work with victims, my amendments — most of them accepted — reflected these repeated and shared demands. Attending to these policies requires the recognition of knowledge and effort and integrating into the planning of these policies the local and regional government that provides most of the services that assist victims.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this was indeed an interesting situation: Commissioner Avramopoulos listened on behalf of Commissioner Jourová, who should have been here, but sometimes agendas clash. So, of course, on behalf of the whole of the Commission we want to thank the co-rapporteurs for this very important debate and very important report indeed, and we will also share all the comments with the responsible Commissioner, Ms Jourová.  The rights of victims are, of course – as you point out – the cornerstone of many of the EU’s policies, and we will continue to ensure that they are fully protected in our Member States.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I have listened to all the comments and we are all going to be able to continue to insist, because our work is not finished here, the work of defending victims does not finish; this is another step we are taking, but we have a long way to go. This was an instrument that was created for all victims, so that they would have the same level of protection throughout the European Union. We talk about 75 million victims of crimes per year — serious crime/petty crime—we talk about victims of human trafficking, organized crime, children, persons with disabilities, victims of terrorism, victims of gender-based violence. All this has been heard here. And I do not think that this report — as has also been heard — goes beyond its powers. No. If we have to defend a victim who is transsexual, a victim of hate crimes, we do it. We don't have to have ideology when talking about victims; all victims are joined by a common thread that is what we are defending here. And yes, Mrs Dodds, I agree with you when you talked about Ireland: it is disgusting that a victim of terrorism is treated just like your executioner. We have to suffer that in the Basque Country, where whoever murdered my brother and his wife receives tribute for having left three children aged 4, 7 and 8 orphaned. But it is, unfortunately. I would like to thank the Commissioner — who is already gone, but, Commissioner Malmström, let him know. I am reassured to know that there are sanctions and that there will be legal proceedings against anyone who does not comply with this directive. I ask you to be real and insist on it. And I just have to say, except to thank everyone who has taken us here and helped us in our work.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all those colleagues who expressed their views. I think from this debate it became clear that there is a real need for a common standard and a protection for victims of crime all over the European Union. I think we all expressed a plea to the Member States to implement the directive and our recommendations. I would like to express my big hope that we will have a good result tomorrow at the vote; I count on your support, and thank you all very much in advance.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 30 May 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. — In most cases, the existence of minimum standards on the rights of victims of crime is not the existence of the provisions in question, but the correct application of the relevant provisions. In many cases, states do not comply with the provisions of the Directive in relation to their own nationals and do not regard the provision of certain rights for victims of other nationalities, such as the right to information or access to interpretation. One of the aims of the directive is to ensure that EU citizens in any EU Member State enjoy the same rights when they become victims of a crime. Given that the law enforcement systems and police practices in each Member State vary widely, much needs to be done today to ensure that this is achieved and that citizens can enjoy at least approximately the same rights in this respect, any be victims of criminal offences in the Member States.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. — Every day in Europe many of our fellow citizens are victims of serious criminal acts, but only a small number of such crimes, with the exception of minor offences, are reported to the police. The proper implementation of the European Directive, which sets out the binding obligations of Member States for victims of violence, terrorism, hate crimes, sexual abuse and trafficking in human beings, is only the minimum necessary response of any democratic society to shield the rights not only of the victims themselves but also of their families. Furthermore, the protection of the rights of victims of crime must not be limited only to the strict time-limits of criminal proceedings but must be provided for life. A universal approach is therefore needed throughout the European Union so that victims of such inhuman acts are placed at the heart of the criminal justice system and strengthen their rights, enjoying the same level of protection regardless of the place where the offence was committed. We need to build trust and help victims report crime, while both criminal justice systems and society actors need to work together to provide support to victims in order to get their lives back together.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the recommendation for second reading from the  Committee on International Trade on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union and Regulation (EU) 2016/1037 on protection against subsidised imports from countries not members of the European Union (05700/1/2018 – C8—0168/2018 – 2013/0103(COD)) (Rapporteur: Christofer Fjellner (A8-0182/2018))

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I must say that this is a rather special moment for me: I have been living with European trade defence legislation for rather a long time now. Back in 2006, when Peter Mandelson first presented his green paper, I started writing my first report on behalf of this House on how to reform the trade defence instrument. That wasn’t really a success, either for me or for Peter Mandelson, I must say. But here we are now, just about to vote on the ghost proposal that we have been working on and waiting for a vote on for more than five years now. This is actually the first major reform of European trade defence instruments in 25 years. A lot has changed in the world during those 25 years – global supply chains, the rise of China – so this is long overdue, and it feels good to be able to close the books on this thing. I would like to start by thanking all my shadows, who have worked on this for all this time, and I’d like to thank the Commission and both the Maltese and Estonian presidencies in the Council for their hard work finding a compromise, because this is truly a compromise. This is what needs to be a compromise, in what might be one of the most controversial areas of trade policy, where different interests so clearly stand against each other: European producers on the one hand, who want tariff protection from what they see as unfair trading practices; on the other hand, importers and consumers who, in the end, have to bear the cost of these tariffs. For every job protected by anti-dumping duties, we always run the risk of potentially threatening some job in another part of the economy. But we have to recognise that these instruments are the second best option when we don’t have international rules for competition. They should be a safety valve for us, giving us the possibility to push for further trade liberalisation, and not – as the US is using these tools today – as a tool for protectionism to stop liberalisation.  The three important things that we have done in this report involve trying to give something to all stakeholders. The first is to see to it that it’s possible to have higher tariffs under certain circumstances – something I know that producers appreciate. We also added predictability as the second point: we guarantee that you get prior notice three weeks before tariffs are introduced, so that anybody that imports something knows it won’t be more expensive when it arrives compared to when they bought it, and that’s important for importers. Third – something that’s important for all stakeholders – is that the investigation periods are shorter, because the mere threat of tariffs will affect trade and cost money.  Now we leave this in the hands of the Commission, and you will have to implement this. I will just make some pleas: first, obey the WTO rules in every detail when implementing this, because we cannot, at a time when others don’t respect the WTO, follow that example. We have to play by the rules. Second, don’t target the environment with these tools: too many duties today are targeted at environmentally friendly goods such as biodiesel, ethanol, solar panels and, soon, electrical bicycles. Third, don’t target value-added goods produced in Europe. Think about the global value chains. Sometimes we might earn more with ‘designed in Europe’ than with ‘made in Europe’. Last but not least, think about the overall interests of the European economy: it might be more important to do a good Union interests test to see that everyone wins than to do just one thing. Finally, I have never met anybody that has claimed to be a protectionist in this process, but I have met a lot of people that want to protect XYZ. Be careful: don’t listen to the sirens; never use these tools for protectionism.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank Mr Fjellner very much for his kind advice. Thank you also, Mr Fjellner, for the work that you have done together with the shadow rapporteurs on this very important piece of legislation. As you alluded to, there have been long and numerous negotiations. The co—legislators have now finally found a way to deal on the modernisation of trade defence instruments that far exceeds expectations. I think it is a good outcome. There have been many contributions, and these will now be part of our new legislation.  The Council has also, together with the European Parliament, played an important part. You thanked the Estonian Presidency and the Maltese Presidency. I would like to add the Slovak Presidency, which actually did some work there as well, to bring us all together.  This modernisation is a success. We have managed to find concrete improvements for all stakeholders – producing industry, importers and downstream users of imported merchandise alike. Also, thanks to the European Parliament, workers can now be represented by their trade unions in investigations and the position of SMEs has been strengthened. I see three key messages in this modernisation. First, it will be more economically effective. The primary purpose of TDI measures is to remove the injury that the EU industry encounters due to unfair trade. The new rules enable us to do that better because we can factor in elements such as necessary investment, research and development. Moreover, there will be a minimum target profit of 6% and this ensures that the calculations reflect economic reality. The EU will take a more assertive stance against trade distortive measures by our trading partners. If they maintain raw material distortions or provide subsidies that go against the WTO, we can respond with higher duties – and I fully agree that the European Union has a specific responsibility always to follow WTO rules, not least in times like now. The EU industry should have access to trade defence instruments without fear of retaliation in other markets. In such special circumstances, with a threat of retaliation, the Commission can start an investigation on its own initiative. However, according to the new rules, the industry is then requested to cooperate with the proceeding.  Secondly, this is good for EU business. The modernisation has significantly increased transparency and predictability. From now on, the Commission will announce duties three weeks before they enter into force. This gives the markets time to adapt to the new situation, and at the same time the law ensures that this possibility to adapt cannot be abused for stockpiling. The new anti—dumping investigations will indeed, as the rapporteur said, be faster. Provisional measures will normally apply seven months after initiation, and that is two months earlier than today. We will facilitate the access of SMEs in the form of a TDI helpdesk that provides information but also addresses language barriers and we will reimburse importers where they have paid duties during an expiry review that results in terminating the measures. Third, thanks to the modernisation, we have strengthened our EU values in our trade defence. We are committed, as you know, to an open rule—based trading system. Trade has to be fair; the role of TDI is to ensure this. Trade defence measures are not a punishment, but they should re—establish fair competition. At the same time, such measures should be balanced and proportionate. I think this has all been strengthened in our proposal. We have in the European Union high environmental and social standards and we are committed to further improvement. The TDI modernisation ensures that the potential higher costs which EU business incurs by applying these high standards are fully taken into account, and this includes future costs that will occur during the lifetime of measures such as the one resulting from our strengthened emission trading system. The Commission will consider third countries’ action on multilateral environmental agreements and core ILO Conventions before accepting undertakings by exporting producers. Unfair trade is threatening jobs in the European Union. Trade unions representing these workers now have full access to the investigation as interested parties and can prepare complaints jointly with our industry.  All these elements are concrete improvements of our current TDI system. Together with the new calculation methodology, we have done our homework. We stand united to defend our common interests at all levels in the light of external challenges, and we can do so thanks very much to the work that you have done.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Christofer Fjellner for his work on this extremely important subject. International competition has evolved dramatically over the past 20 years without adapting our trade defence instruments. It was therefore more than urgent to strengthen the arsenal of our companies to defend fair and fair competition. The modernization we have achieved is a step forward and will contribute to the development of stronger, faster and more accessible trade defence instruments, especially so that our SMEs can use them. I would also like to welcome the inclusion of environmental and social criteria in the use of the new instruments. On the other hand, I regret that, despite our request, the lesser right rule is maintained in general. Only certain exceptions will allow for higher taxes to be imposed in the event of dumping. We now look forward to the early entry into force of this reform and will be attentive to its implementation. This agreement comes at a timely time. It will accompany the new anti-dumping method we adopted a few months ago.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, my congratulations to the rapporteur for this report. The Union's trade defence system is based on WTO rules, which enable its members to respond to unfair practices of exporting countries, restoring the level playing field and avoiding market distortions they produce. But the world — indeed — has changed a lot and time has shown that current rules are insufficient and ineffective. After years of blockade by the Council, the truth is that it is excellent news that the European Union modernizes its trade defence instruments, although honestly, we Socialists would have liked to go further. But it is true, it was never so necessary to have effective instruments to deal with unfair commercial practices that threaten our industry and cause significant job losses that are not justified by less competitiveness, but by unfair practices that exist — let us not forget — because they are consented. And politics is there to change things. That is why the reform that we will adopt tomorrow is so important and which will enable us to have more effective instruments, by imposing higher anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties, incorporating the minimum profit margin of 6% — which I think is a very important element — and streamlining procedures, although I think this should be get further progress. What the Commissioner said is also important: to strengthen transparency and predictability. And I very welcome the fact that, thanks to the position we have advocated in our Group and which has been supported by all and defended by the Commission, the higher social, environmental and labour costs borne by our companies — or which we fortunately have in them — are incorporated into the new regulations and that they are taken into account time of calculating dumping. And I also find it very important that trade unions become interested parties and be able to apply for the initiative. Instead of trade wars, fair and loyal rules to avoid competition.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, we are seeing new, innovative products being developed at a rapid pace. In the European Union, we are sometimes too confident about this. We sometimes feel invulnerable, as if everything is being invented in Europe. That, of course, is not right. That's not so. Moreover, we can see that the pace can be even higher. That is certainly the case. In a number of authoritarianically controlled regimes with expansion, you see that the pace of production can still be increased artificially. So it's really naive to think that everyone respects the rules of the game. That is why we need to arm ourselves against these global challenges. And how, then, is the question. I see two ways. One, by recovering foreign direct investment in sensitive sectors. We voted on this yesterday in the Committee on International Trade. Two, because of what we are discussing here tonight: by modernising our trade defence instruments. This is really necessary in order to protect our European industry from unfair commercial practices and from heavy job losses and prosperity. Let us not fall into flat protectionism, but take up the challenge.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after dramatic changes in global developments as well as trade flows, it is high time our trade defence instruments are reformed to be fit for purpose. As Christofer Fjellner said, it has been a long time coming. We, in Europe, remain open for business and committed to rules-based trade without being naive or defenceless vis—a—vis blatant violations that cheat our citizens. We need one method to assess substantial market distortions, whoever may be suspected of engaging in such unfair practices. Of course, we must be WTO compliant and lead by example in the trade measures that we apply ourselves, and I’m glad we have positioned the EU properly by this modernisation. This house has focused on the transparency, predictability and efficiency of the new rules, and has zoomed in on the particular needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. Yes, we have considered importers and exporters and not just listened to the voices that shouted the loudest. It’s essential that Europe leads in promoting rules-based trade globally, ensuring that trade rules and trade flows benefit everyone – again, without being naive. This package fits well with the discussion about screening foreign direct investments; it’s really the other side of trade defence instruments. We need protection without protectionism, and I think we show how it can be done.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, even a few years ago, it seemed impossible that the EU would use trading measures to penalise those who are damaging the environment and exploiting workers. Today, we are delighted to say that the EU will include social and environmental standards within its anti-dumping measures. This is a huge win for the Greens and our supporters after years of campaigning and a historic step by the EU as the first member of the WTO to do this. This will now mean that goods produced with low labour standards or those that are harmful to the environment, such as the mining industry, will face investigation of their environmental impacts. If they have cut standards to cut costs, this will affect their ability to export. The next step is for the Commission to adopt a clear and transparent method for measuring these impacts so that the anti-dumping policy can come into effect. While the EU is making progress on trade policy, Brexit Britain looks weaker and more isolated than ever. As we saw with the Trump steel tariffs fiasco, two visits by Trade Minister Fox to the US left him empty handed. The US and other trading giants would laugh in the face of a lone United Kingdom that tries to protect its industry from tariffs or dumping. We need to stay part of a strong and democratic trading bloc if we are to have any hope of using trade as a tool to protect our workers and the natural world around us.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you, Christofer! I believe that with our anti-dumping instruments we have really achieved an important new breakthrough in EU legislation. The European Union is now the first major player in the world to take into account social and environmental costs when setting a fair price level by international standards. Certainly a compromise, not everything worked out, but a decisive step has been taken. This means that social dumping and environmental dumping can finally be tackled. Originally, this was a key requirement of the left and trade unionists. In today's globalized economy, however, this has also become the number one demand in the corporate world — I think it is an important experience. Now, as the European Union, we need to actively and vigorously approach our international partners to successfully bring this issue to the multilateral fora. The task remains to develop the regulatory framework in world trade to prevent labour exploitation and depletion of nature and our climate. This also requires the transparency and predictability of positions and international rules that we have already mentioned. To this end, Commissioner, I hope that, with the experience of EU legislation, it will now also work together to modernise WTO law accordingly and raise it to the level of the requirements of the twenty-first century.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of aggressive trade policies, particularly on the part of China, to which we have just mentioned, in a world where globalised ultraliberalism takes precedence over any form of reasoned protectionism, the need for an anti-dumping procedure was of course essential on the part of the Europe. On this point, I believe that the United States has clearly demonstrated to us that trade defence must be determined, without fear of crumpling its competitors. This is not the message conveyed by these measures. The lack of firmness with respect to potential offenders will have no deterrent effect. No country would be so benevolent to us in the opposite situation. Finally, this text, as you have said, is backed by WTO rules that nobody outside Brussels seems to want to respect anymore, whether it be the United States, whether it is China or even India. In order to assert herself on the international scene, for a genuine policy in favour of the sovereignty of national economies, in the face of the growing commercial aggressiveness of certain countries, the best of defences remains the path that Mrs Malmström describes as easy, is the courageous path of protectionism.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union's trade protectionist measures are tools to ensure advantages for the monopoly groups it represents in its confrontation with their competitors, in particular the United States, China and Russia. Trade liberalisation and protectionism coexist. They are used alternately, sometimes as a weapon against competitors, never as a vehicle for penetration into the markets, their resources, their transport routes.
