Recent incidents of this competition include tariffs from the USA to China and vice versa, new sanctions against Russia, United States tariffs, Brexit and negotiations, the agreement with Iran and the European Union countermeasures. As the economic war intensifies, the risk of continuing on military battlefields increases. Great losers are the peoples who pay with harsh exploitation and bloodshed for imperialist competitions for profits. Their interest is not to choose an imperialist, it is to overthrow capitalist barbarism in order to take the economy and power into their own hands.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner and the rapporteur. Five years have passed since the Commission's proposal, and I say that we have finally come to a conclusion with tomorrow's vote. A dossier which finally sees the light and that is because it was strongly wanted by Parliament, by the Commission itself, and given precisely the vetoes which have been laid above all by the Council, I believe that is a central and important achievement. Especially in the context in which we live, the difficulties of a global international system, but above all by pointing out that the European Union stands as a reference, as a model that implements the rules that are compliant within the World Trade Organisation and which carry out extraordinarily relevant aspects. Protection yes, defence yes, but in a process of liberalization, but also, above all, dedicated to an interest, that of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, that of small industry, easier access, reduced time, the application of the minimum duty even in some cases, there is a percentage of 6% that is realized compared to the application of the costs that are achieved. In short, an overall extraordinary and effective framework, so I thank the work of the rapporteur and the Commission.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: — Mr President, this evening is not a “protectionism against free trade” debate, but rather a discussion on the fair or unfair nature of international competition and how we Europeans are respected in trade, because that is what we are talking about: to be respected in trade. trade. So far, particularly with the 1995 legislation and the shy and fearful lesser right rule, this was not entirely the case, to the point that we suggested that we were prepared to make reasonable accommodation with partners who did not hesitate to resort to very harsh sanctions in the face of abusive practices. The current text improves the lesser duty rule, because it is either discarding it or reviewing the calculation method or its base. It also improves the situation because it incorporates international social and environmental commitments into our legislation. Finally, as the rapporteur has said, the text improves the conditions in place, particularly the time limits within which the Commission can initiate an anti-dumping investigation. This text is therefore a modest progress, but still progress, which we take as such.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: — Mr President, the review of the anti-dumping and subsidy regulations under discussion today can become the beginning of a qualitative transformation of the European Union's external policies. Finally, we have legislation requiring social and environmental standards to be assessed when calculating anti-dumping duties. It's no secret that some third countries can offer cheaper products solely because they pay behavioural wages, while production waste pollutes our common homes — land. Not only the environment or workers who do not receive fair salaries in third countries suffer from this, and we Europeans suffer from this, both because of the deteriorating environment, including climate change, as well as the increasingly retracting European industry and the land that does not ripen out of the permanent crisis Farm. I am convinced that if these rules are adopted and implemented properly, we will take a fundamental step towards a qualitatively better, cleaner and fairer global economy.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, declaring the imposition of new duties three weeks in advance is an excessive advantage because it violates competition. This uncourageous reform is also out of historical context. Today, the United States of America, with Trump, gives us a concrete and real vision: to combat those who implement unfair competition need severe sanctions. This Europe bent to the lobbies of large multinationals has shown once again that it fears democracy. This alarm comes from those who suffer competition from those who exploit the work, not being subject to our taxation or our strict and costly environmental and social standards. This is one of the great failures of the Union. The choice you have taken is clear: give preference to large operators who choose to produce far away, firing at our home, over those who give work and development to our territories. I would also have expected that our respectable President of the Republic, with a gesture of pride, had raised his head rather than prone to this hanging Europe. The Italian people will no longer accept the disloyalty of this Europe, and with democracy they will repay you for these injustices.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr President! This battle of dumping is a redundant fight against an apparent problem. If someone wants to sell us something below cost, which is at a loss, and we sell them at a profit, it's just us that way getting rich and he works for us for free. This is pure profit for us. If someone keeps doing that for a long time, they just won't make it. In the long term, the balance of international trade must go to zero, because in order to sell something to someone, you have to buy more or less from them. Otherwise, such international trade would quickly end. So if someone also wants to destroy their environment in order to give us cheap goods, then we should be happy about it, because we don't have to destroy our environment. We are the parliament of Europe, not the whole world, and we should take care of our environment first and foremost. This is as much of an unwise idea as denying yourself a free dinner just so you can protect your workplace in the kitchen.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, the European Union was slightly ahead of global developments with respect to trade tensions between liberals and protectionists. The debate we had dealt with the very same tensions – how to accommodate the two competing forces and interests – but I think we struck the right balance. In exchange for a number of importer—friendly provisions, we also strengthened protection against dumped imports. The key provision in this package is mainly the removal of the lesser duty rule in the event of structural raw material distortions. The European Union needs to do more to combat dual pricing, regulated prices and subsidisation on third markets. Removing the lesser duty rule in such a situation is the first step in a more muscular policy. There are a number of on-going proceedings that involve such distortions, and I do hope that the European Commission will seek to use these rules for making sure that our policies are properly implemented.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President! It is high time that the European side responded adequately to the threat to dumped products. It is gratifying that, after years of discussions, the Council has finally been able to reach an agreement. We adopted a position on this in the European Parliament back in 2014. The fact that environmental and labour law standards as well as free wage negotiations and ILO core labour standards will also be taken into account in the future when calculating dumping is mainly due to pressure from the Socialists and Democrats. Our task is to guarantee the best protection for European industry and the European labour market, as we are talking about 200 000 jobs for steel workers in Europe, threatened by dumped imports from China. We need to put an end to low-cost imports that are distorting competition quickly. With this legislation, this is now possible. Congrats to the negotiating team!

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: — Mr President, the European Union, which was presented as a shield to defend our commercial interests, is powerless in this task. As evidenced by this text, which provides only a minimalist solution to protect oneself from unfair competition, the only novelty is the possibility of applying customs duties to compensate for the injury suffered, and still, only on raw materials, and only if the distortion leads to a difference in the cost of production of more than 17%. It should be said that this is totally ineffective in correcting the damage of the wild globalization that you have imposed on us. How can you say you want to fight against social dumping if, at the same time, you open Europe's doors wide to massive imports through CETA or the free trade agreement with Mercosur? To combat unfair competition, you must immediately stop negotiations with Mercosur, and above all you must give nations the freedom to set their customs duties and import quotas sovereignly.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, this is a bittersweet moment for me. Finally, tomorrow we will vote on this all-important reform of EU trade defence instruments that will help protect thousands of jobs all across Europe. Bittersweet, because we had to wait five years to get here, because my home Member State did everything that it could to block the reform. Bittersweet, because Tory ministers stood on the beach in Redcar wringing their hands and claiming that they were blocked by EU rules from protecting our steelworkers from dumped under-priced steal, while they blocked this legislation which could have helped. Bittersweet, because the EU was blamed in the referendum, leading to high leave votes from all our steel communities. Bittersweet, because now we have a job to get anything near as good in our UK trade remedies legislation post-Brexit. This is a bittersweet moment for Labour MEPs in the European Parliament.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I just wanted to say that this is a very timely report, given the global debate and tensions we have on trade issues. Having effective trade defence instruments (TDIs) is imperative because not only do we have an aggressive approach from China, which appears to be playing a global monopoly game in acquiring infrastructure and energy plants at strategic locations, but we also have an unpredictable President in the White House who changes global trade rules on a whim.  For me, the TDIs should have been more ambitious, but I recognise that they are a first step that factors in social and environmental standards when determining trade dumping. This is exactly what industry in my region, the West Midlands, wants.  The second want is that the EU duties should be higher because, at the moment, they have said that they’re not high enough to be a deterrent when it comes to dumping steel or ceramics. Therefore, it’s regrettable that the UK Government voted against this deal in the Council and the vote goes against what UK industry has been lobbying for.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I will be on time this time. Congratulations to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs. We must not forget that this is a compromise text, but the objective has been ambitious from the outset: a strong trading system based on rules promoting fair trade and for the European Union to speak with one voice. After all, as written in the text, the common commercial policy, as proposed by the 'Trade for All' strategy, is a value-based policy. So far too well. Unfortunately, however, the application of international trade rules through judicial mechanisms of the World Trade Organisation has not always been impartial or effective. For example, Turkey continues to violate international trade rules against a particular Member State of the European Union, and you know that, Commissioner, very well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, at last the European Union has decided to wake up from its slumber, it has decided to activate trade defence tools. Because at the moment there is, of course, a distortion of competition. There are certain countries — China, India, Turkey — that literally distort competition, follow unfair practices, follow dumping practices. Of course, there are also a great many countries which do not comply with the specific criteria relating to environmental protection, the application of labour legislation and the application of the protection of workers' health and safety. In addition, there must be measures to prevent foreign investment in areas of strategic importance within the European Union. If all this is really implemented, then we can hope that something will happen.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this debate. I think it is a reflection of the very constructive approach that the rapporteur and all the shadows have had in this very long journey. I have listened very carefully and I hope that we will continue to engage on this, for instance, in our exchange on the annual Trade Defence Instrument (TDI) report with the International Trade (INTA) Committee. The debate has pointed out many of the improvements to our trade defence instruments, and if you vote yes tomorrow – which I sincerely hope you will – this will now enter into force on 8 June, and we will thereby be much better equipped for future challenges.  The European Union pursues a free and fair trade agenda. We want to have open markets at home and abroad. This work is reflected in the work we do in our free trade agreements and also in our work to try to strengthen and to reform the World Trade Organization (WTO). That is why we need these tools: to make sure that we can compete on a fair basis. We stand committed, as I said, to a rule-based system and we will continue to pursue an update of the WTO rulebooks in order to ensure that continued effectiveness of the WTO rules against fair trade – notably in the area of subsidies – is addressed as well. So thank you very much for this debate.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Malmström and my colleagues for their kind words. I hope that colleagues who know where I come from politically on this question can appreciate that I have tried to be an honest broker in this process. I don’t like tariffs – any tariffs at all – and let me just personally leave you with a scenario to ponder upon, because it might be 25 years until the next time we discuss this here, so we will have the time to ponder upon a response. Imagine that the Chinese leave us with 500 million tons of steel at the European border for free, just for us to pick up. What is the rational European reaction to that? Is it to say, ‘Wow, great, let’s build cheap cars for our citizens and maybe even export them at a profit to China’? Or is it the Russian reaction, which is to get angry, send it back and say, ‘If you try to sell us more steel, we will charge ourselves even more for that steel’? I know what my response would have been if I were a European steel producer. I would have gone for the first option, but if the responsibility had been jobs and wealth in Europe, I am not so sure. Until the next time we discuss this topic, I hope everybody has thought carefully about what would be best for Europe in that case.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 30 May 2018.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Tokia Saïfi, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the Annual report on the implementation of the Common Commercial Policy (2017/2070(INI)) (A8-0166/2018).

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs for our good cooperation on this issue, as well as you, Commissioner, for the regular exchanges you have with the European Parliament. International trade contributes to growth and job creation. In this sense, European trade policy is central, and we must work to improve it. This report provides a mid-term review of the implementation of the European Union's trade strategy, which dates back to 2015. The international trade context continues to evolve. The Asian continent continues to rise. Donald Trump's irresponsibility, even aggressiveness, creates uncertainty, even towards his allies. Online commerce is growing at a very fast pace and the British voted for Brexit without having a clear vision of their future. These are examples that demonstrate that it is fundamental for the Union to show responsiveness and firmness on its principles. We advocate fair, balanced and rules-based trade. That is why negotiations must be conducted in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit, that European standards cannot be changed, that the sensitivity of certain products, in particular agricultural products, must be taken into account and public services must be excluded. In parallel with these negotiations, we support the multilateral system and are concerned about the failure of Buenos Aires and the United States blocking the renewal of the Appellate Body. Beyond negotiating principles, concrete implementation of agreements and legislation must be an integral part of our trade strategy. European companies use only 70% of the trade preferences available in trade agreements, while companies in partner countries do so by 90%. It is therefore necessary to identify the causes of this imbalance as quickly as possible and remedy them so that our companies benefit fully from these agreements. As for SMEs, public procurement and geographical indications, these are priorities for our trade policy. The Union must continue to negotiate specific provisions for our SMEs, which account for 90% of jobs in Europe. With regard to public procurement, the Commission estimates that more than half of world markets are currently closed due to protectionist measures, while European public procurement is open. Greater reciprocity must be required. At the same time, a real communication strategy is needed: we need to make more use of digital tools. I would also like to highlight a more technical but no less important point: the current rules of origin are too complex. The Union must modernize them in order to make them easier to use. With regard to trade and the promotion of European values, tools exist, such as the GSP systems and the chapters on sustainable development in the agreements. We must continue to work with business and civil society, including responsible management of global value chains. Finally, we call for more transparency. It is this transparency that will contribute to the development of a public debate that provides concrete answers to citizens, takes into account their concerns and does not only feed their fears. In this context, we recall our request for the publication of negotiating mandates.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me thank the rapporteur for the very important work that you have done on the implementation of the Common Commercial Policy. We welcome the very detailed look that the European Parliament has taken at the Trade for All Communication and the implementation of our Free Trade Agreement (FTA) reports. I appreciate in particular, Madam Rapporteur, the way that you also highlighted the fact that you share our assessment of the quick-changing environment for EU trade policy, protectionism, changing positions on the US and China, on what open, free and fair global trade based on WTO obligations actually means in practice, as well as the growing economic political weight of Asia, the digital economy and Brexit.  The report highlights the importance of revitalising the multilateral trading system, boosting trade in services, protecting and promoting EU values and standards, and the need for transparency in our negotiations. In this regard, the report recognises the Commission’s efforts to ensure that our trade policy meets our overarching economic and political objectives, as was seen in the package of proposals aiming for a balanced and progressive EU trade policy that we presented here in 2017.  We would like to underline the importance of implementing free trade agreements. All the institutions, business, stakeholders and the Member States need to work together to make sure that EU operators and consumers can fully benefit from the opportunities offered by our trade agreements. Parliament’s orientation will be important here when it comes to guiding the work on the Enhanced Partnership on Implementation. This is, as I said, a shared responsibility. We are working with Member States and all stakeholders to forge a strong network of implementation to improve the coordination of outreach activities and the information flows. This is crucial. The Enhanced Partnership will also allow us to represent the EU’s interests more effectively, to spot problems at an early stage and to identify possible solutions.  We are working on several items mentioned in the report to make sure that our free trade agreements deliver benefits. For instance, we are conducting comprehensive implementation studies on partner countries’ legal and administrative frameworks to ensure that the FTAs function properly. We are also working together with the External Action Service to deploy EU economic diplomacy that aims at improving the way we promote our economic interests abroad with regard to trade agreements, in cooperation with our Member States’ embassies and business organisations.  We are also working to extend the Market Access Database and looking to create tools to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to benefit more from our trade agreements. In the latest agreements with Japan and Mexico, there is a specific chapter for SMEs to help them to take advantage of the agreement. As suggested in the report, we are also working to improve data availability. We take note of the requests to place figures in context and provide additional explanations to help Parliament to assess the impact of our FTAs. The implementation of the trade and sustainable development chapters is one of our top priorities. We will be working on the 15-point action plan and, here, stepping up the support to civil society groups and reinforcing cooperation with international bodies such as the International Labour Organisation (ILO), the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and other civil societies.  Thank you very much to Madam Rapporteur, Ms Saïfi, and the different shadow rapporteurs for this very important report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as the report points out, since the publication of the strategy entitled 'Trade for All', the international context has been marked by the emergence of new challenges and, in the face of the resurgence of protectionist practices, must strengthen our support for an open, fair, balanced, sustainable trading system based on values that offer economic opportunities for the citizens of the European Union and our trading partners. As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development, I would like to reiterate the role of trade as a major driver of development and growth. It should be emphasized that trade is not an end in itself, but that a mutually supportive and equitable trade policy, pursued in accordance with the goals of sustainable development and the promotion of human rights, plays a key role in eradicating poverty. Therefore, it is essential to remain committed to engaging partner countries in a process of cooperation and to include comprehensive provisions in trade agreements, including social, labour and environmental standards.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, I would first like to thank Mr Saïfi for a very good and balanced report which gives an honest evaluation of the Commission's policy, but if I were to give my own personal perspective on the Commission's strategy on free trade policy, I would really like to say that the most important thing in The Commission's strategy may not be what we do but what we do not. That at a time when more and more people are turning towards protectionism, we are not following that path; that Europe stands firm on free trade and stands firm to play in accordance with international trade rules. We don't challenge, we don't break, as for example the US does. We probably need to use this vacuum in the world — which the United States leaves behind when they withdraw from global trade — and fill it with valuable European content. Then I have four things that I want to point to. The first is that it takes too long with our free trade agreements. The free trade agreements with Canada and Singapore have taken eight years! That's how we can't have it in the future. Secondly, we need to have a trade policy for the new economy, for the digital economy, and then we have to have trade agreements with data flows, not without. Thirdly, global value chains must be a central part of our trade policy, to enable them, and then we cannot have crass rules of origin but we must have flexible rules of origin that allow our companies to use globalisation. And last but not least: investment policy. We need protection for European investment and need to restore European investment policy. I think that is the most important thing the Commission can make clear.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I’d like to thank Ms Saïfi, the rapporteur, and the other shadows on the good work that we did on this report. In recent years EU trade policy has been challenged like never before, and I think that we are united in this House in the objective to rebuild public trust. This means that we need to be honest about what’s working and what isn’t, and I welcome, in this spirit, the publication of the Commission’s first implementation report on the EU’s common commercial policy. Now it’s our turn as Parliament to do our job and hold the Commission to account. There are many things missing from the Commission’s report, but most importantly, an honest analysis of what our trade policy does for our people and planet. I suspect the answer is actually not very much so far. Although now the tone is changing around EU trade policy, with recognition of the negative consequences of globalisation and the need for a values-based trade policy, there’s still little interest in concrete measures to address the shortcomings. The toolbox to address these consequences is inadequate, and the Commission’s implementation report offered little analysis of how those limited tools have been used in practice. The Commission simply can’t go on without giving us a detailed assessment of the impact of labour and environmental provisions in EU trade deals in particular. I’d like to emphasise the importance of enforcement in terms of labour and environmental protections. Rightly, we’re critical of the unilateral closure of the Commission’s consultation on the use of sanctions to enforce these provisions. In other Parliament reports, notably on the EU-Korea Agreement, Parliament’s shown in detail why the current approach is inadequate. The Commission has closed down debate far too early, and it reminds me of the debate about investment protection just a few years ago, in which the Commission resisted change until the public opposition to the EU’s approach threatened whole Free Trade Agreements (FTAs). I would encourage the Commission to heed this criticism in this report and engage on enforcement of trade and sustainable development chapters in a more constructive manner. We also need to take an honest look at what our free trade deals deliver concretely on the ground. The Commission report is full of success stories, but what about the losers – the regions and the sectors? One thing is clear from the report: our companies, unlike our partners, do not take the most advantage of EU trade deals, and we need to know why this is. I suspect that one of the reasons may be austerity policies and cuts in national trade promotion budgets, which have played a big part in that. That’s why I think that a values-based trade policy cannot only be about talk. We also need to walk the walk. And that means we need to do much more on implementation.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I cannot help but imagine how different this report would have been if we were discussing it three years ago. Just think of how much has changed in global trade since the Trade for All strategy was published. I am happy that, despite setbacks to global trade today, the EU is moving forward and not letting itself be tempted by protectionist tendencies in the world. But we still need to deliver: we need to speed up the processes of negotiating quality agreements and make sure they work in practice. We need to make sure that European businesses – in particular our SMEs and consumers – can take full advantage of the benefits from these agreements. We need an EU that takes delight in cementing a free and rules-based system on a global level. Effective implementation and monitoring of trade agreements is key to achieving all of this: it is key to making sure that all European actors have the information and assistance they need to thrive via our trade relations, and it is key to identifying areas where we have potential, and we should focus on these areas. As I mentioned at the beginning, a lot has changed in three years. Now is the perfect time to reflect on these changes, and not just how we should adapt to them – but how we can lead and drive these changes.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Parliament's report on the EU's trade policy is rightly very critical. I welcome him and would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Saïfi, warmly for her good cooperation. Nonetheless, a few comments have been made: the public debate has shown that the so-called modern trade agreements restrict our democratic rights. Worse still, however, human rights play less and less important. For example, the so-called Mercosur Agreement, which is currently being negotiated, is intended to stimulate the import of chicken meat. This chicken meat is produced with the help of 160 000 slaves — I repeat, you have not interrogated: with the help of 160 000 slaves. Is this compatible with human rights? Another example: Morocco occupies the economically interesting part of Western Sahara. The European Court of Justice has therefore ruled that trade agreements with Morocco must not relate to products in these areas. The European Commission has frankly stated that it wants to circumvent this ruling. Human rights are also being violated here. So we can see that a lot of improvement is needed in our trade agreements and our policy.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I would like to express my appreciation to the rapporteur, Tokia Saïfi. Your report is a critical annual report that highlights the complexity of current trade challenges in the implementation of the EU trade strategy for all the year ahead of the European elections, clearly identifies actors, content, contradictions and the need for transparency. It is particularly important to me, Mrs Saïfi, the agreement to call on the EU and the Member States a stronger commitment to the discussions within the framework of the United Nations on a binding corporate responsibility treaty on human rights and business. On other issues on which there are fundamental divergences in the political perspective, but we have dealt fairly with each other in the negotiations, we will table a number of amendments to the vote. I hope that my fellow Members will be able to join them. Finally, on this occasion, I would like to ask the Commission, Mrs Malmström, to commission a sustainability assessment of contractual options for future trade relations with the UK.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder what we are doing here when we talk about reports. As the opposition grows and the Council expressed its ambition last week to conclude trade agreements without the agreement or the validation of national and regional parliaments, you are not raising this issue at any time. Yet this is a serious and important subject. Does the Commission have the ambition to govern without the peoples? Human rights, you say? Well, I remember Mr Juncker in 2015, who said, “There is no democratic choice against trade treaties”. Today, when Italy has chosen a new policy, Brussels, through its European Budget Commissioner, said: “Markets will teach Italians to vote fairly”. It is a direct threat to Italians, it is a direct threat to democracy. The Commission is clearly choosing to govern this Europe against the peoples, for the benefit of the financial powers which now lead us. We have made another choice, that of defending and respecting the will of the peoples.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for this report, Mrs Saïfi, on her excellent contribution in analysing the assessment and impact of the European Union's trade policy. As the Commissioner and other Members have stressed, obviously the circumstances under which the Trade for All strategy was adopted differ substantially from those present both in the internal dimension — with the UK's decision to abandon our project, which will have significant commercial implications — and in the external projection — due to the withdrawal of the United States and the rise of other powers. More than in this analysis, I am interested in focusing on the rapporteur's proposal for the future and, in that regard, I think that the important thing — as we have done in the debate on the protection measures adopted by the United States — is to encourage the Commission to deepen the network of trade agreements, to stop itself from demagogies and defend the interests of companies and our citizens. I think we must place the emphasis on principles — as the report clearly points out — on trade that is fair, fair and principle-based. I also think it is important to underline one of the data in the report, and that is the fact that our companies benefit to a much lesser extent than our partners' companies. We must put an end to this situation and also emphasize the principles which must really be an instrument, which should serve our trade policy. Times are important and, as Mr Fjellner has observed, in the digital age we cannot move slowly.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We know that the implementation of trade agreements is not working satisfactorily. Particularly after the conclusion of the agreements, we need to monitor more closely whether the provisions are complied with and the impact of the respective agreement on the economy and on society. We need to identify the issues that come with the implementation and find solutions. Strong monitoring is therefore needed after the entry into force of the Treaties. In this context, it is also essential to strengthen and enhance the development of civil society and Domestic Advisory Groups in the implementation of trade agreements and to better allocate their resources. Likewise, a mandatory and enforceable sustainability chapter with the possibility of sanctions for infringements, as well as a binding duty of care in the supply chain and corporate social responsibility must finally become a reality. If we are serious about 'trade for all', then sustainability, the protection of workers and the protection of environmental standards must be given the same importance as, for example, the liberalisation of tariffs. In any case, more transparency is also needed. In particular, I would like to highlight the publication of the negotiating mandate here. If we do not act now, the inequality will only increase and never everyone will benefit equally.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, the EU is a front runner in the world for free and fair trade, and trade liberalisation. Trade within the global value chains opens markets, creates growth and jobs and strengthens our relations with third countries, illustrated by various of our Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) and Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) worldwide. However, we want to have a values— and principles—based trade policy. That is why we need more than TDAs, in order to prevent unfair trading practices in our markets and an increase in transparency within the processes of global value chain instruments. For example, bilateral investment agreements (BIAs) are very effective instruments to protect our investors against unfair practices. That is why I am calling on the Commission to complete the preparatory work and to start negotiations with Taiwan on an EU—Taiwan BIA, including an impact assessment. Taiwan could serve as an ideal springboard to the Chinese market as we, of course, want a level playing field with China, which still imposes unjustified non—tariff measures and technical barriers.  Furthermore, one should not overlook our economic relationships and the positive advances that have been made with FTAs conducted by the EU so far, and should speed up progress in the ongoing negotiations, especially our economic cooperation under the European Neighbourhood policy. Our DCFTAs under implementation help to create a stable, democratic and prosperous EU neighbourhood.  Finally, we should actively reach out to our partners, pursuing an ambitious trade agenda in a global context, especially keeping up the framework of the WTO for free and fair trade on a global basis and in compliance with all WTO obligations.  Finally, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Ms Saïfi, for her work.

name: Aleksander GABELIC
text: - Mr President! I begin by thanking everyone who has contributed to this report. Trade policy is a root bolt in our economy. Along with good policies, it creates growth, jobs and increased prosperity. It is therefore extra important that we follow up on the policies pursued and see what can be done better. Actually, a pre-negotiated agreement is just the beginning. We need to get better at ensuring that our companies can take note of the benefits that the agreements actually offer. We need to get better at increasing the participation of civil society and the social partners. To achieve the UN agenda in 2030, we must also be even better at promoting fundamental values such as human rights in trade policy. The implementation of the sustainability chapter is important, and also not to stop evaluating how this is best done. We disagree with each other on everything, which makes it valuable and important that we can compromise. I think we should always have as a starting point to push for progressive and fair trade agreements and remember that a negotiated agreement is just the beginning.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, the world – including European trade policy – is changing, and we need to adapt. Brexit, China’s market economy status (MES) or even, as we discussed a couple of hours ago, the US trade tariffs in the steel and aluminium sector are examples of challenges to be addressed. Public debate about international trade has also become more vivid, and we need to supply clear and precise answers in order to demonstrate that EU commercial policy brings benefits to companies and citizens. This report on the common commercial policy is therefore badly needed. Challenges are also opportunities for the EU worldwide, and we should be able to take advantage of these new opportunities. Madam Rapporteur, you did a very good job. It wasn’t an easy job, but you managed to accommodate different positions and find compromises on such sensitive issues as trade and sustainable development (TSD) chapters, global value chains and corporate social responsibility. Congratulations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, international trade can contribute to growth and employment when it is fair, when it is based on mutual benefit and when unfair practices are not followed. With the multilateral agreements, free trade agreements that the European Union has signed, in practice, what we have seen is the European Union's agricultural economy being dismantled, there is no protection for the products of designation of origin and geographical indications. At the same time, the future of public enterprises must be at stake. In addition, we have seen various countries seeking to shape trade policy without complying with environmental standards and, at the same time, their obligations under legislation to protect workers themselves. We have also seen an attempt to get the mutants into the European Union. You understand that trade policy cannot proceed under these conditions.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the world is changing rapidly and so is our trade policy. We have in recent years focused very much on trying to bring trade policy into line with these changes age by making it much more efficient, making sure that it responds to the demands of our consumers, of our companies, and making sure that it includes digital trade services, that it is efficient and that it is implemented.  We have increased transparency considerably; you can now find information on all on—going and concluded trade negotiations and detailed – sometimes regional – examples of how it works in practice. There really is a lot of information on our website. It has become even more value—based, emphasising the values of the European Union when it comes to labour rights, the environment and human rights, but also to the value of open rule—based trade. We are doing this through our trade agreements, which are mutually beneficial, sustainable and fully in line with multilateral global rules. It is true that they sometimes take time – and there are some examples that have been absolutely too lengthy – but we are trying to do our best. The Mexican agreement was concluded in two years. I think that is quite an achievement. But also, all the time, we have to take substance into account vis—à—vis speed, and you and many other stakeholders are putting increasing demands on what should be in a modern trade agreement and that of course also makes it take a lot of time, as we have listened carefully to these as well. Implementation is key. We need to do much more there. We have focused on working with Member States, on working with business associations, on working with civil society, on working with Chambers of Commerce and what have you, and on trying to reach out and to explain the benefits of a trade agreement, but it is simply not good enough yet, and we need to do much more to reach out to SMEs. Lots has been done, but we can do more here as well.  The same goes for evaluation and for enforcement, especially on the sustainable development chapters where we have this 15—point action programme where we will focus on much stronger enforcement and cooperation with the different stakeholders.  We will be discussing with you this year’s edition of the annual FTA implementation report. We will try to cover important developments, both when it comes to hard data and qualitative assessment, and also give analysis of our major FTAs, our deep and comprehensive trade agreements and our economic partnership agreements, and take a closer look at some of the areas and sectors you are raising. Free trade agreements cannot solve all the problems of the world, that is important to underline, but they are a very important tool, not only to contribute to growth, jobs and investment, but also as a way to promote our values and to connect with our partners – on a personal level as well – building bridges and not walls. Thank you very much, Mrs Saïfi, for your report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, everyone's speeches show the importance of the subject and the need now to strengthen the monitoring of the common commercial policy and ensure its proper implementation. As the world's largest trading power, the European Union must continue to affirm its position, defend its interests and enforce the trade commitments that have been made. As you said, Commissioner, it is important that all economic players, particularly SMEs, have access to better information and know the trade preferences they can subscribe to. Better use of our regulations and trade agreements is now a priority. In the report, we also call for the creation of a specific service within the Commission, responsible for monitoring trade policy, and we recall that the Union delegations play a crucial role and are at the forefront of contacting our partners. Finally, I would like to stress once again the importance and necessity of developing a public debate on European trade policy, which includes all actors, whether it be businesses, citizens, civil society and public authorities. As such, the establishment of an advisory group on trade negotiations is good news, and we will follow this initiative carefully. I hope that the European Parliament will be able to send a strong message on international trade in the vote tomorrow, and I thank all my colleagues once again.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 30 May 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - The withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union, changes in the practices of world superpowers in the field of international trade and policy, and strengthening the trade impact of Asia require the Union to focus more on the conditions for implementing and monitoring its trade policy. Consistent analytical activities must be an aid to European producers and traders and must be a permanent part of the Union's trade strategy. At the same time, its results can provide a good basis for reviewing existing bilateral and multilateral agreements and for flexible implementation of new rules and procedures that take account of the Union's needs and opportunities in the field of international trade.
